The Disability Advisory Services at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus is strongly committed to equality of opportunity and providing support for students with disabilities.
The Disability Advisory Services focus on reasonable adjustments of accessible services to help students complete their courses as independently as possible.
Disability is defined as seen disability (physical, visual, or hearing impairment) and unseen disability (mental health challenges or long-term medical conditions).
To be eligible for Disability Advisory Services, students need to be registered university students with a long-term disability (12 months or more) and provide the latest medical evidence.

The Disability Advisory Services assist students with disabilities in admissions, registration, academic adjustments, assessment arrangements, library services, IT accessibility, and accommodation arrangements.
The contact information for the Disability Advisory Services at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus is through email, phone, or in-person visits.

A group of four MEng students; Jason Lee Jun Wei, Lim Dao Kun, Lim Jian Ching and Wong Ee Chew from the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering (M3) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) has emerged as the national runners-up in the James Dyson Award Malaysia 2019 on 19 September 2019.
The winning entry of the students was a floating sea bin, titled “Litterid”, which was designed with the concept of a drone in the water to capture and drag plastic back to the shore.
The prototype designed by the students had the capacity to carry up to 46 litres of plastic and a manoeuvring speed of 0.5 m/s.
The James Dyson Award is an international design award that celebrates, encourages, and inspires the next generation of design engineers.

The project titled 'Urban growth monitoring with multi-scale remote sensing approach' aims at investigating the suitability of existing remote sensing data for monitoring different growing patterns of HoChiMinh City, Vietnam and developing a multi-scale remote sensing mapping framework for urban growth.
The Pump & Priming grant from Faculty of Science was awarded to Dr. Tuong-Thuy Vu to develop this initiative.

The project outcomes will be further incorporated with environmental and socio-economic data to answer the question 'Does the current urbanisation process significantly contribute to the negative environmental impact induced by the on-going climate change?'.

The Luminophonics project in the School of Computer Science at the University of Nottingham Malaysia has received a Faculty of Science Pump Priming grant for the amount of RM4,500.
The aim of the Luminophonics project is to develop novel solutions for the conversion of visual to auditory information.

The project focuses on the representation of shape and colour, the production of sounds with different timbres, and the maximisation of both the quantity and interpretability of converted information.
The project will focus on incorporating depth information and improving the quality of the generated soundscapes.

The Setting and Achieving Goals workshop was held on 18 January 2020 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Teaching Centre in Kuala Lumpur.
The workshop was designed to help alumni clearly define their goals and to set their purpose and direction of life.
Participants were provided with a handout and several maps including the Personal Ecology Map, Life Categories Map and the Wheel of Life.
The workshop used a range of learning tools and methods, including instructor-led training, role-play activities, props and open learning.
The workshop included four sessions that required participants to write their goals, break them down into details, simplify them and develop action plans.
By the end of the workshop, participants learned a SMART way to define their goals using GPS.
Participants took part in the Yee Sang tossing ceremony, in-conjunction with the Chinese New Year celebration.
The alumni found this workshop informative, worthwhile and a good start for the new year.
The University of Nottingham is a global community of over 290,000 graduates.
The workshop was the first event organized by the Alumni and Donor Relations Office for 2020.

The study was led by Professor John Terborgh from the University of Florida, Gainesville.
The study conducted by experts from the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus focused on the foraging impacts of Asian elephants.
The density and diversity of tree saplings were higher in Krau where elephants are absent compared to Belum where elephants are present.
Asian elephants have an important impact on forest dynamics, but their impacts differ from African forest elephants.
Asian elephants show a preference for monocot plants such as palms, grasses, and bamboo.
Elephants in Malaysia may not be modifying the forest in the same way as African elephants.
Human-elephant conflict in Malaysia is influenced by the fact that elephants love to eat palms, a preferred food source.

Effective from Sunday, 22nd Jan 2017, Level A (Ground floor) of The Library will be closed for approximately 10 working days to facilitate the installation of an electrically-driven, high-density mobile shelving system.
Books from classmark A to K will not be accessible for browsing to all library users.
A Library-Item-Fetching (LIF) system will be used to retrieve these books.

Library users need to use an online form accessible at https://share.nottingham.edu.my/sites/bizapps/LIF/SolutionPages/Default.aspx to request for these books. (This eform is best viewed in Internet Explorer).
Users can also request for the relocated books in person by using a printed LIF form available at the Customer Services counter at Level B of The Library.
There will also be no booking allowed for PG Individual Study Rooms and Meeting Rooms no. 1 and 2 during the closure.
Normal library services and operating hours will not be affected, but the noise level will be high on some days.
Library Services apologises for any inconvenience caused.

Nottingham University Business School has been awarded renewal of a major independent accreditation, EQUIS, for the maximum length of five years.
EQUIS is one of the three prestigious accreditation schemes for leading institutions in business education, granted and run by EFMD, the European Foundation for Management Development.

Nottingham’s EQUIS accreditation applies to all Business School operations on campuses in the UK, China, and Malaysia, making it the only UK business school to hold EQUIS accreditation in three locations.
Nottingham University Business School is the only business school in the world accredited for its operations in three countries simultaneously.
EQUIS is a mission-based accreditation with an international focus, covering the entire School and all its activities.
Nottingham University Business School holds both EQUIS and AMBA accreditations in Malaysia, meeting stringent standards for business education.
EQUIS accreditation is one of the most coveted international business school accreditations due to its stringent standards towards the quality of institution activities being accredited.
Since 1993, Nottingham University Business School has held accreditation from AMBA for the quality of its MBA courses.

Nottingham University Business School Malaysia has gained accreditation from professional bodies for individual programs, including 8 Credits for Prior Learning from ICAEW for the BSc/BA (Hons) Finance, Accounting and Management program.
EQUIS has accredited 161 institutions across 40 countries worldwide, raising the standard of management education globally.

University of Nottingham Malaysia Library is working on migrating the EZproxy authentication system to a cloud-based solution. This will change the URL of direct links to any eResources and you may need to update any links you have previously saved or shared.

EZproxy enables off-campus access to the library’s licensed eResources through specially constructed URLs that pass the user through EZproxy. This shows resource providers that the user is coming from a University of Nottingham Malaysia IP address so that access is granted to the resource.
Currently, our URLs are prefixed by https://ezproxy.nottingham.edu.my/login?url= and this will change to https://unm-ezproxy.idm.oclc.org/login?url= when the new service goes live.

Library staff have updated links in existing reading lists, and will continue to do regular checks. However, any links that you have previously saved within the Talis Aspire online reading list system under 'My Bookmarks' (i.e., not necessarily added to a specific list) may no longer work. You can either check and change the URL as outlined above, or simply delete the item and bookmark it again to get the corrected link.

Any other direct links to resources such as those added as favorites on your PC browser, to a document or slides, or embedded on your Moodle page, will no longer work if they contain ezproxy.nottingham.edu.my

The team from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus won third place in the final round of the CIMB Online Trading Competition.
The CIMB Online Trading Competition provides university students with the experience of buying and selling stocks in a fully simulated and virtual environment of the Malaysian stock market.
The competition was first introduced by the CIMB Group last year and is aimed at providing a holistic and structured learning program in trading and investment for tertiary students.
Eighty-three teams from four countries took part in the competition, and only five teams with the highest total credit participated in the final round.
The team from Nottingham University Business School won a cash prize of RM4,000.
This is the second consecutive year that the NUBS undergraduates have been successful in being in the top three spots of this competition.

The competition took place from 26 to 29 October, where participating teams were given a RM500,000 'fund' as initial capital and instructed to choose the best investment strategy to maximize the value of the fund.

The BSc (Hons) Finance, Accounting and Management at the University of Nottingham Malaysia integrates finance, accounting, and business management, providing a comprehensive three-year program.
The degree is accredited by EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), AACSB, and AMBA, ensuring exemptions from professional examinations.
The program includes modules in business finance, business law, computers in business, economic principles, financial and management accounting, organisational behaviour, and quantitative methods.

Entry requirements for the program include A Level qualifications with specific grades, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior High School Diploma (China), and other equivalent qualifications.

In addition to academic qualifications, applicants must also meet English language requirements, such as IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, MUET, UEC, and other English proficiency tests.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM undergraduate degrees.
The program offers various career opportunities such as auditor, accountant, business or tax consultant, finance executive, and data or risk analyst.
Graduates of the Finance, Accounting and Management BSc (Hons) degree can pursue careers in accounting, banking, investment, and management consulting.

The degree is suitable for students interested in finance, accounting, and management, preparing them for roles like financial analyst, investment banker, management consultant, tax accountant, and more.
The BSc Finance, Accounting and Management program at UNM takes 3 years to complete on a full-time basis.
International students are welcome to enroll in UNM's BSc in Finance, Accounting, and Management.

The Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Psychology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) provides a dynamic understanding of human thought, emotion, and behaviour.
In the first two years, students engage in foundational modules such as cognitive psychology, individual differences, and developmental psychology.
Quality Assured Education: Earn a degree accredited by the British Psychological Society (BPS), ensuring rigorous curriculum standards and excellence in the field.

Comprehensive Curriculum: Build a strong foundation in core areas like cognitive psychology, individual differences, and developmental psychology, with opportunities to explore specialist topics such as neuropsychology, clinical psychology, and forensic psychology.

Versatile Career Pathways: Gain transferable skills in communication, problem-solving, and data analysis, opening doors to careers in mental health, education, human resources, user experience, and more.
State-of-the-Art Facilities: Benefit from access to cutting-edge laboratory equipment, including eye-tracking, transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), and electroencephalogram (EEG) technology.
Supportive Learning Environment: Experience student-centred learning in a collaborative and encouraging academic setting.
Entry requirements: A Level - BCC in either arts or science subjects, excluding Critical Thinking and General Studies. Psychology A Level is not required.
Entry requirements: IB Diploma - 24 points overall.
Entry requirements: STPM - BC+C+, excluding Pengajian Am.
Entry requirements: UEC - 3 B3s and 2 B4s (excluding Bahasa Malaysia and Chinese Language).
Entry requirements: Australian Year 12 - ATAR 78, with consideration for relevant subjects.
Entry requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) - 75% average across 6 subjects.

Entry requirements: Gaokao (NCEE) and Senior High School Diploma (China) - 68% average in the Gaokao, and a minimum of 70% overall in the Senior High School Diploma, including 80% in Mathematics and at least 70% in one of the science subjects.
Entry requirements: Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE) / Indian School Certificate (CISCE) - Class XII - 75% average from the best 4 subjects.
Language requirements: IELTS (Academic) - 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element).
Language requirements: TOEFL (iBT) - 90 (minimum 19 in Writing and Listening, 20 in Reading and 22 in Speaking).
Language requirements: PTE (Academic) - 71 (with no less than 65 in each element).

Dr Chan Yi Jing, Associate Professor in the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, is working towards making palm oil production cleaner and greener.

Dr Chan has been involved in developing a novel integrated anaerobic aerobic bioreactor, winning a Biotechnology Award at the IChemE Global Awards 2018.

Dr Chan's work aims to guide the industry towards innovative and sustainable solutions for the palm oil sector.

Founded in 1925, the School of Pharmacy at the University of Nottingham has a rich academic excellence and innovation history.
The School of Pharmacy is one of the largest pharmacy schools in the UK with a vibrant presence in both the UK and Malaysia.
In 2005, the School of Pharmacy at the University of Nottingham launched the Master of Pharmacy (MPharm) programme in Malaysia, the first UK-accredited pharmacy degree offered outside of Europe.
The Master of Pharmacy (MPharm) programme grants graduates direct access to the UK pharmacist job market and is the longest-running and only fully accredited MPharm programme in Malaysia.
In 2010, the School introduced the BSc (Hons) Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences programme.
The School of Pharmacy established the School of Biomedical Sciences, offering the BSc (Hons) Biomedical Science programme.
The School of Pharmacy welcomed its first cohort of Bachelor of Pharmacy (BPharm) students in 2023, providing a comprehensive pathway to a pharmacy career in Malaysia.

Tim Gocher, Founder and CEO of Dolma Impact Fund and Honorary Professor of Sustainable Business at Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia will be giving a talk on ‘The ESG Investment Tune - How Business Organisations should move to this Beat’.
This webinar is jointly organised by NUBS Malaysia and UN Global Compact Malaysia (GCMY) and will be held on 7 May 2020 at 8.30am (UK time) and 3.30pm Malaysia/Singapore time.
During the session, Gocher will discuss the spectrum of impact investment and the types, and drivers of impact capital.
Gocher will cite examples from his experience in managing Dolma Impact Fund, international private equity and infrastructure capital from European institutional investors and family offices.

The Malaysian national team comprising University of Nottingham (UNM) Year One, BSc (Hons) Economics student Loh Nicole along with Raja Rajeswary from International University of Malaya-Wales and Winfrey Kong from University of San Diego, emerged as global champions at the Unilever Future Leaders League (UFLL) 2021.
The winning team, the all-women team will be attending the One Young World Summit that will be held in Tokyo, Japan, once travel restrictions ease, with the Unilever delegation in May 2022.

Having first emerged champions in the national level round of the competition on 26 February 2021, Nicole and her team members then went on to compete in the global competition where they emerged champions as well.

The aim of the competition was to bring together university students from across the globe and have them showcase their business leadership skills as they took part in a challenge centred around a case study of Unilever’s brands.
This year’s finals were held online due to the COVID-19 pandemic and received a total of 54,000 applications.
“We competed against 78 finalists, who were split amongst 26 teams. This was the first time in Unilever history that Team Malaysia had emerged as the global champions for the UFLL,” Nicole said.
The team was under the mentorship of UNM alumnus Dinesh Jayabalan (BA English Language and Literature, 2019), who is currently a trainee in the Unilever Future Leaders Programme.

Dr Sergio Camacho is the Director of Performing Arts of the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
He proposed the establishment of a Performing Arts strategy for the Development of Performing Arts at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
He devised, produced, and directed 'The Mikado: a COMIC opera', the first inclusive pan-University of Nottingham Malaysia musical theatre production.
He contributed to the establishment of several artistic collectives at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, including Uni Per Arts, the UNM Performing Arts Platform.
Dr Camacho is one of the leading voices in advocating for the Spanish operatic genre, zarzuela, as a valid platform for contemporary practitioners.
He has contributed to the development of the study and practice of Chinese Orchestra works in Malaysia.
Before joining UNM, Dr Camacho worked as the Associate Course Leader for the International College of Music, ICOM, in Kuala Lumpur and as a Lecturer at various universities in the UK.
Dr Camacho is currently leading the development of educational opportunities for FASS students in the field of Music and Performing Arts.
He designed and delivered modules such as Global Music Studies and Music in Film as part of the International Communications Studies pathway at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
In the academic year 2019/2020, he designed a full Performing Arts itinerary for the Nottingham Advantage Award programme.
In the academic year 2020/2021, he led the opening of the first degree option at the UNM in the field; International Communication Studies with Performing Arts.
Dr Camacho contributes to several modules of the School of Media, Languages and Cultures at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Faculty of Science and Engineering and Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences recently delivered a masterclass on STEAM, with over 500 high school students from 100 schools across Malaysia participating, both physically and virtually.

STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Mathematics) education encourages learners to think outside the box, changing the way they perceive and navigate the world, and helping to nurture individuals better prepared to address complex global concerns.

STEAM education can equip learners for some of 2022's most in-demand jobs in Malaysia, such as information technology (IT), software development, digital marketing, finance, business development, medicine, and education.

University of Nottingham Malaysia is organising the Malaysian Poetry Writing Competition with the aim of promoting Malaysian literature.
Associate Professor Jason Pandya-Wood, Dean of Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, mentioned that creative writing in English is a focus in the School of English at UNM.
The competition is open to all Malaysian writers, regardless of age.
Participants can submit their entries until the deadline on 15 July 2021.
All submissions must be original, unpublished work, and each participant can submit a maximum of three poems not exceeding 40 lines each.
The announcement of the competition winners will be made in November 2021.
Submission guidelines include making entries online through email, specific formatting requirements for each poem, and using Word document format for submissions.
The competition will longlist 20 poems and shortlist 10. Winners will be announced at a prize-giving ceremony on 28 October 2021.
Cash prizes for the first, second, and third winners are RM1,000, RM750, and RM500 respectively. Shortlisted and longlisted winners will also receive cash prizes.
Selected poems will be published by Maya Press after the competition.
Media enquiries regarding the competition can be directed to Josephine Dionisappu, PR and Communications Manager at University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Accredited by the Association for Nutrition (AfN), this three-year programme equips students with the knowledge and skills needed to address global nutritional challenges, focusing on areas such as metabolism, public health nutrition, and clinical nutrition.
This degree empowers students to make meaningful contributions to improving health and well-being worldwide.

The entrance requirements include qualifications such as A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao (NCEE), Senior High School Diploma (China), Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE) / Indian School Certificate (CISCE) - Class XII, Advance Placement (AP), Diploma - Local Institutions, Foundation - Local Institutions, and Nottingham's Foundation Programme.
Applicants must also meet specific grade standards in subjects such as Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, and Physics based on the qualification they hold.
English language requirements include qualifications like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, and others, with specific score requirements mentioned.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a range of scholarships and financial assistance options for eligible students.

The Semenyih Campus is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just 45 minutes’ drive from the famous city centre with its iconic Petronas Twin Towers. The campus provides facilities like a sports centre, library, and student accommodation.

Career opportunities for graduates of the Nutrition programme include roles like Public Health/Clinical Nutritionist, Nutrition Consultant, Food Scientist/Analyst, Public Health Policy Maker, and Food Product Developer.

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Malaysia’s Graduate Students’ Internship Programme (GSIP) provides opportunities for graduate students to gain insight into the work of UNDP and the development programs in Malaysia.
The internship requires the successful candidate to work from the UNDP's Office in Kuala Lumpur.
The internship period at UNDP is a minimum of 2 months and a maximum of 6 months, and it can begin at any period in the year.

Eligibility for the UNDP internship includes enrollment in a graduate-level degree program in a development-related field such as economics, public or business administration, or environmental studies.
Only students who will return to their studies upon completion of the internship assignments are eligible for the UNDP internship.
UNDP does not provide financial assistance for internships, and the costs associated must be covered by the nominating institution, related institution, government, or the student themselves.
The application process for the UNDP internship requires the completed Application form and Curriculum Vitae to be sent to registry.my@undp.org.
The Application form for UNDP internships can be downloaded in MS Word or PDF format.

Malchin Testament: Malaysian Poems edited by Professor Malachi Edwin Vethamani from the School of English, of The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) brings together poems of established and emerging Malaysian poets writing in the English language.

The book covers a period of six decades of Malaysian poetry in English with works from more than 50 poets, including early poets like Ee Tiang Hong, Wong Phui Nam, Muhammad Haji Salleh, and recent spoken word poets like Melizarani T. Selva and Jamal Raslan.
The School of English at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) has expertise in areas of arts, theatre, literary, and poetry, responsible for burgeoning theatre productions on campus.
The Malchin Testament: Malaysian Poems was initially introduced at the George Town Literary Festival in November.
Malchin Testament: Malaysian Poems is a landmark publication gathering Malaysian poets writing in the English Language, reflecting how Malaysians have used English for creative expression.
The launch event of Malchin Testament: Malaysian Poems witnessed renowned poets like Wong Phui Nam, Jamal Raslan, Muhammad Haji Salleh, and academics from UNMC reciting their poems.
Malchin Testament: Malaysian Poems is available at Gerakbudaya Bookshop, Petaling Jaya, Silverfish Bookshop, Bangsar, Dubooks Publishers Bookshop, Bangi, and Gerakbudaya Bookshop, Penang.

The NetCon (Network and Connect) with Alumni event was organised by the Education Network 21/22 on 8 and 9 March 2022 in conjunction with the Education Week 2022. It was done virtually via Microsoft Teams.

Thirteen successful alumni were invited as guest speakers for the two-day event. The speakers were all from diverse backgrounds and industries, who shared their experiences and provided participants with guidance and advice.

The first day of the event gathered alumni from the Faculty of Science and Engineering (FOSE). They were Choo Tzer Maan, Chief Executive Officer of ELMLAB Sdn Bhd; Carmen Lee, Clinical Physiologist at WeCare Allied Health Center; Chin Ren Yi, Co-founder and Managing Director at myBurgerLab; Mathialagan Magendran, Board of Director at Global Compact Network Malaysia; Sahl Abdus Salam, Managing Consultant at Baringa, UK; Teh Yong Lin, Chief Executive Officer of Kravve.Co and Yvonne Teoh, Organization & Employee Experience Designer at FedEx Express.
The event attracted more than 200 participants, and responses and feedback from participants were positive and well received.

The Great KL Challenge Competition is a competition presented by Sweden-Malaysia aiming to close ties between the countries and invite students to drive innovation by submitting ideas and solutions to existing and future city challenges.

Winners of The Great KL Challenge Competition will have the opportunity to complete an internship at SAAB in Malaysia, participate in innovation programs, or go on a study trip to Sweden in summer 2013.

Important dates: 21 April 2013 23.59 MYT is the competition deadline. 24 April 2013, top two applicants per award will be selected and notified. Late April or early May 2013, the first prize winners will be announced during the prize ceremony held at the embassy opening in Kuala Lumpur.

Eligibility criteria: Applicants must be enrolled in their Bachelor's or Master's studies in Malaysia or be a Malaysian student currently on exchange or pursuing their Bachelor's or Master's studies abroad.

Chan Bi Xuan, first year Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia student of University of Nottingham Malaysia has won the Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Award Essay Writing Competition titled: How Best to Promote Malaysia’s National Interest in the Changing Global Environment. This is the first time a student from the University of Nottingham has won this competition, which has been held annually since 2014.

According to University of Nottingham Malaysia Provost and CEO Professor Graham Kendall: “Our students are high achievers in their own field and many are already creating an impact outside of their fields, especially in the arts world.”

At the prize giving competition Chan Bi Xuan shared: "This competition has inspired me to become a more proactive citizen of Malaysia. I have learnt so much about Malaysia's economic and political landscape through this competition but I feel like there is a need for me to do more than that. I am now motivated to put myself out there to create greater impact on society. This competition gave me the chance to realise this and for that I'm thankful."

Winners for this year’s competition were announced on 15 September 2018. The event was graced by Ministry of Education Malaysia Deputy Director General of Higher Education Dr. Mohd Nor Azman Bin Hassan.

Other champions include second prize winner; Methodist College Vydehgi Pillay Kumaraguru and third prize winner; University of Nottingham Malaysia School of Economics student Muadzzam Abdullah, winning RM 1,500 and RM 1,000 respectively.

The award is named in honour of the Founding member of the United Nations Association of Malaysia (UNAM), YM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen bin Tengku Ismail who served as minister in several portfolios, including Foreign Minister in the Malaysian Government.

The YM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Award Essay Writing Competition is jointly organised by the University of Nottingham Malaysia and the United Nations Association of Malaysia (UNAM); to honour Tengku for his many contributions to the Malaysia. This is the 4th year that the University of Nottingham has jointly organised this competition with UNAM.

Several types of bookable rooms are available for use: Meeting rooms, Postgraduate individual study rooms, Multimedia room.

Postgraduate individual study rooms are meant for postgraduate students only, who can make online bookings for up to three hours per session.

Online bookings for bookable rooms can be made up to 24 hours in advance, and penalties are imposed for late returns or lost keys/access cards.
Valid University ID card is required for booking rooms, collecting keys or access cards, and cancellations should be notified to library staff.
Food and drinks are not allowed in bookable rooms, users must keep the rooms clean, and materials should not be left unchecked.
The library is not responsible for any lost property, and any damage or disorder should be reported immediately.
Do not move furniture in or out of bookable rooms, and ensure the room is clean, lights off, and door locked before leaving.

YM Tengku Tan Sri Dato' Seri Ahmad Rithauddeen Bin Tengku Ismail was an instrumental figure in the establishment of the Nottingham campus and led the historic ground breaking in January 2002 for the new purpose-built campus at Semenyih.
Tengku Rithauddeen was the first Chairman of the University of Nottingham Malaysia and held the position for 19 years.
YM Tengku Tan Sri Dato' Seri Ahmad Rithauddeen Bin Tengku Ismail was appointed Chairman on 27 January 1999 and retired on 31 July 2018.
He was conferred Doctor of Laws honoris causa at the Malaysia campus inaugural graduation ceremony in 2002 and in 2013 received a University Alumni Laureate Lifetime Achievement Award.
Professor Sarah Metcalfe, the Interim Provost/CEO of the Malaysia Campus, mentioned Tengku was working to establish the Malaysia Campus for many years.
Professor Shearer West, President and Vice-Chancellor of the University of Nottingham, expressed gratitude for Tengku Rithauddeen's significant contribution to the Malaysia Campus.

The Master of Science in Biotechnology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is a comprehensive one-year programme that prepares students to address real-world challenges using advanced biotechnology solutions.

The programme provides an in-depth understanding of antimicrobial drug resistance, plant and crop improvements, genetic engineering techniques, bioprocessing, synthetic biology, and bioinformatics, with applications across three specialisations: Agricultural, Industrial, and Medical and Pharmaceutical Biotechnology.

The optional modules offered in the MSc in Biotechnology program include Advanced Industrial and Environmental Biotechnology, Postharvest Technology, Genetics and Advanced Breeding in Crop Plants, Medical and Pharmaceutical Biotechnology, Postharvest Preservation and Technology, Advanced Biochemical Engineering, Therapeutic Immunology, Cancer and Clinical Genetics, Epidemiology, Public Health and Health Informatics.

All candidates are considered on an individual basis and a second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent in Biotechnology, Agricultural Sciences, Microbial Sciences, Medical Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Genetics, Microbiology, or related life sciences subjects is required.
Applicants must hold a degree from a recognized university and certain programs may require prior qualifications in related fields.
English language requirements for the program include minimum scores in IELTS, TOEFL (iBT), PTE (Academic), and MUET.
IELTS, TOEFL iBT, and PTE (Academic) test results must be less than two years old, and IELTS One Skill Retake is accepted.

The learning and assessment methods for the program include lectures, seminars, tutorials, practical classes, supervision, field trips, lab sessions, and e-learning, with modules being assessed through a combination of exams and coursework.
The fees for Malaysian students in the MSc in Biotechnology program are RM50,000 per program, while international students pay RM55,000 per program.

The GEP Conference on Globalisation Trends and Cycles: The Asian Experience was hosted at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
The conference took place on January 12-13, 2011, at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, Kuala Lumpur Teaching Centre.
The conference included public lectures by David Smith and Professor Wing Thye Woo.
David Smith's lecture was titled 'Shifting Sands: The Global Financial Crisis and the Changing Balance of the World Economy.'
Professor Wing Thye Woo's lecture was sponsored by Wiley-Blackwell and focused on 'Understanding the Middle Income Trap in Economic Development.'
The detailed conference programme and other GEP events at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus are available on the GEP website.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia will celebrate graduation through a virtual celebration on 24 February due to current physical distancing restrictions under the Malaysian Movement Control Order.
The February graduation will witness the graduation of 178 students from undergraduate and postgraduate levels from the Faculties of Arts and Social Sciences and Science and Engineering.

The virtual celebration will include video messages from The University of Nottingham Chancellor Baroness Young of Hornsey OBE and Vice-Chancellor Professor Shearer West, as well as a speech by UNM’s Interim Provost and CEO Professor Sam Kingman.

In conjunction with the graduation, the University presents the Lord Dearing Award to staff, Vice Chancellor’s Medal for staff and student recipients, Nottingham Advantage Award for students, and Alumni Laureate Awards 2020 to alumni.
The Lord Dearing Award is awarded to staff who have shown high levels of dedication towards enhancing the student learning experience.
The Vice-Chancellor’s Medal recognizes exceptional achievements or contributions to the University community by staff and students.
The Nottingham Advantage Award is a module offered to all University of Nottingham undergraduate students to enhance their employability skills.

Jason Pandya-Wood joined the University of Nottingham Malaysia as the Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences in June 2020.

Jason is responsible for the strategic and operational leadership of six schools: Business, Economics, Education, English, Media, Languages & Cultures, Politics, History & International Relations, one division (Organisational & Applied Psychology), one centre (English Language and Foundation Education), and one department (General Studies).
Jason's recent publications include 'An Independent Review into Youth Diversion in Nottinghamshire' and 'Small Steps, Big Changes: First Annual Evaluation Report 2019'.

Jason is completing a project investigating the impact of broad-based community organizing across ten areas within the UK and developing proposals to investigate the institutional design of 'compassion' in social welfare.

The Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Mathematics and Data Science at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is an interdisciplinary degree combining computer science, statistics, and scientific methods.
The curriculum of the Mathematics and Data Science program includes core mathematics, probability, statistics, programming, machine learning, and artificial intelligence methods.
The program is designed to prepare graduates for roles in big data, artificial intelligence, and analytics.
The Mathematics and Data Science degree offers practical learning opportunities such as group projects, programming tasks, and industrial training.

Entry requirements for the Mathematics and Data Science program include specific qualifications like A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Gaokao, Senior School Certificate Examination, Advance Placement, Diploma from Local Institutions, and Foundation from Local Institutions.
English language requirements for the Mathematics and Data Science program include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, and IB English.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM’s undergraduate degrees.
Malaysian students for the Mathematics and Data Science program are required to pay RM52,000 per year, while international students pay RM58,000 per year.
The Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport.

The careers available for Mathematics and Data Science degree holders include Data Scientist, Data Science System Developer, Data Analyst, Statistical Analyst, Machine Learning Engineer, and Data Engineer.
UNM offers scholarships and financial aid to deserving students enrolled in the Mathematics and Data Science degree.

This procedure is applicable to study within the 2023/2024 academic session and beyond.
Decisions regarding non-attendance are made by Schools/Departments.
Attendance monitoring for students should begin at the start of Week 4 (after the Add/Drop period).
The Attendance Intervention Meeting (AIM) is to ascertain the reason(s) for a student’s absence, provide advice, and document the steps taken to avoid absence.
An Absence Request form must be completed and submitted to the Faculty Office if a student knows they will be absent from the University for any period of time.
Evidence presented for both planned and unplanned absences must meet acceptable standards set under the guidance on Acceptable Circumstances and Evidence in the university EC regulation.
Schools/Departments should arrange for an attendance case handler to process absence requests and inform the student of the outcome of AIM.
From Week 10 until Week 12, any students overall attendance below 80% students will need to interrupt their study.
For students in April Semester / 3rd Semester of FDN 3 semesters, in Week 3, students whose overall attendance rate is under 80% will receive an invitation for AIM meeting.

Requests related to personal data access or correction must be made in writing, and there may be a prescribed processing fee for access requests.
Personal data should be kept up-to-date, and individuals should notify the university of any changes to their personal data.
The university may update the Data Protection Notice periodically to comply with changes in the law, and the latest version is available upon request or on the university's website.
In case of any inconsistency between the English and Bahasa Malaysia versions of the notice, the English version prevails.

Authors of the study believe that another species previously recorded from the region may have already become extinct in the country.
Sungai Pahang and Sungai Perak, two of the longest rivers in Peninsular Malaysia, are of particular importance to the conservation of very rare mussel species.

Omar Ashraf Elfar from the University of Nottingham Malaysia’s School of Pharmacy together with Dr Show Pau Loke, Chang Chih-Kai, Leong Hui Yi, Angela Paul Peter and Chew Kit Wayne recently published a paper on Elsevier entitled Prospects of Industry 5.0 in algae: Customisation of production and new advance technology for clean bioenergy generation, in Energy Conversion and Management, Elsevier.

There is a high demand for clean, affordable and sustainable source of energy due to the limitation in fossil fuel supplies. The algae industrial revolutions have proven to be a significant step in realising the growing need for energy and achieving the sustainable development goals (SDGs).
Prospects of Industry 5.0 in algae: Customisation of production and new advance technology for clean bioenergy generation was well-delineated in the paper.
Numerous aspects in the algae industry have been discussed, including economic and environmental analysis of algae bioenergy production, customisation of the algae-derived bioenergy.

To keep your offer open, we must receive a response from you within the deadline. This is typically a 4-week deadline, but we may set an earlier deadline for late applications, such as when the registration date or visa application deadline is approaching.
You are required to pay a non-refundable course deposit at the point of accepting your offer.

Refund requests must be strictly submitted online on or before 30 October in the calendar year in which your offer was made to be considered.
Deferrals are not automatically granted and you may need to meet certain conditions or requirements before we can approve your request.
You can ask to defer up to one calendar year. Decisions are usually confirmed once offer details for the following year are available.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia alerts vendors to an active email ordering scam involving requests for quotations, purchase orders, which purport to originate from the University but are fraudulent.
The University encourages vendors to verify the accuracy of all orders to prevent falling victim to such scams.
Fraudulent emails may have poorly written content, inauthentic website links, and email addresses in different formats, such as purchasing@nottingham-edu-my.com or finance@nottingham-edu-my.com.
Fraudulent emails may include attachments designed to look like official requests for quote or purchase orders, with logos or watermarks copied from the university's website.
Vendors can contact the university at 603-89248638 or procurement@nottingham.edu.my to verify the legitimacy of purchase orders or report suspected fraud.
The Central Procurement team at the University of Nottingham Malaysia values its partnership with vendors and their role in providing goods and services to the university community.

Swinburne Sarawak Creative Writing Community participated in reciting poems from Professor Edwin’s collections.
Christina Yin, a current PhD student of Professor Edwin, recited his first published poem at the event.
Professor Edwin recited several poems from his collection and a short story 'Drowning' during the event.
There was a 'Conversation' session where Edwin answered questions from the audience.
The 2019 School of Education Awards Ceremony was held at the Marriott Hotel, Putrajaya on 13 December 2019.
The event brought the curtains down on another successful and eventful year for the School of Education and its students.
The night aimed to bring together lecturers, current students, faculty administration staff, and alumni to celebrate and honour the outstanding work done by the members of the school.
It was heartening to see so many alumni participating in the event and sharing how their lives and careers have been propelled by the learning and experience at UNM.
The evening was filled with glamour and pageantry, exciting activities including student and staff performances and video montages.
The standout staff performances included Dr. Alberto Luis August’s saxophone duet with his daughter, and Nabila Shariff Al-Baiti’s rendition of Thank You by Dido.
The presentation of more than 50 awards to staff, undergraduate, masters, PhD, and alumni was the highlight of the evening.
The Undergraduate Student of the Year award went to Anushka Sajani Karunaweera, while Postgraduate Student of the Year was won by Chai Xun Yu.
Twelve awards were presented to faculty members for various contributions to the school.
The Head of School Professor Ganakumaran Subramaniam received two awards namely the Most Creative Award and Best Postgraduate Lecturer Award.
The Lecturer of the Year award went to Dr. Alberto Luis August.
To add fun to the evening, personality awards were given to students in six categories - friendliest, funniest, most inspiring, most creative, most chill, and most driven.
Sixteen undergraduate students and four postgraduate students received personality awards.

The School of Education Awards Night is designed to embody the school’s philosophy of humanistic, transformational, holistic and inclusive education aimed at achieving high standards and improving the lives of individuals and communities.

The International Symposium on Environmental DNA for Conservation and Biomonitoring in Southeast Asia 2023 is held in conjunction with the 4th International Workshop for Mangrove Biodiversity Studies by eDNA Metabarcoding 2023 from 11-19 Mar 2023.
The symposium will take place on 14 March 2023 at The University of Nottingham Teaching Centre Level 2, Chulan Tower, No.3 Jalan Conlay, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

Registration for the symposium opens on 06 February 2023 and closes for Extended Abstracts on 24 February 2023. The program will be finalized by 28 February 2023, and registration will close on 10 March 2023 with no walk-ins allowed.
The registration fees are RM200 for Delegates (non-student) and RM100 for Students, with a 6% sales and service tax added during payment.
Contact for Registration and Enquiry: edna.symposium2023@nottingham.edu.my

The symposium program includes sessions such as Arrival & registration, Welcome speech, Challenges to Understand Global Mangrove Biodiversity, Developing Cost- and Time-efficient eDNA Protocols, Next-generation Biodiversity Monitoring, Lightning talks (poster session), Group photo, Lunch, Oral presentations, Afternoon break, Poster viewing session, and Closing remarks.
The Symposium Chair is Dr Alison Wee Kim Shan from the School of Environmental Geographical Sciences, University of Nottingham Malaysia.

To register, participants need to fill up the form on the Registration form link provided on the website. An individual invoice will be sent via email after submitting the form, and payment can be made through Bank Transfer or Online Payment methods.

Students can borrow laptops for part of the day from the Customer Services Counter or student adviser’s desk at Learning@The Core.
A valid University ID card is required to borrow and use a laptop and its accessories.

Professor Andy Chan, Dean of the Faculty of Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, was invited as a guest speaker at the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) in the UK.

The European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) is an independent intergovernmental organisation in the UK that produces and disseminates numerical weather predictions to its 34 Member States.
The ECMWF operates one of the largest supercomputer complexes in Europe and is the world's largest archive of numerical weather prediction data.
Professor Andy Chan's presentation at ECMWF was titled 'Computational studies of 2013 Biomass-burning haze event in South Southeast Asia'.

Dr Lim and his team have isolated a new class of natural compounds from a local fig plant species that induce vasodilation in aorta tissue.
Preliminary data suggest that the new compounds might be eliciting their activity via an important pathway (TRP channel pathway) that may be key to treating resistant hypertension.
Over 10kg of dried fig leaves were needed to produce enough compounds for biological testing.
The compounds were found to induce significant vasodilation effects when tested on rat aorta tissue.

Dr Mamunur Rashid, Assistant Professor of Finance at Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia, presented a paper on financial inclusion in Bangladesh and the role played by the Islamic microfinance sector at a regional seminar co-organised by the World Bank in Islamabad, Pakistan.
Dr Mamunur discussed the challenges facing microfinance institutions (MFIs) in Bangladesh and emphasized that Islamic microfinance programs alone cannot alleviate poverty.
Bangladesh has over 600 MFIs contributing to government financial inclusion strategies and engaging in digital inclusion, women entrepreneurship, and micro-entrepreneurship.
Rural Development Schemes (RDS) hold 50% of the global Islamic MFI share, aiming for vertical and horizontal inclusion among the Muslim population in rural Bangladesh.
Efforts of MFIs should be aligned with Islamic socio-economic development tools such as Zakat, charity, and waqf to support Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations and the World Bank.

The regional seminar on Financial Inclusion Strategies in South Asia took place from 28-29 March 2017 in Islamabad, Pakistan, to promote financial inclusion awareness and study best practices in microfinance and micro Takaful in the South Asia region.

Bee Yean Low is the BPharm Programme Director and an Associate Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Kang-Nee Ting is a Professor and Head of School of Pharmacy at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Kang-Nee Ting obtained their BPharm (Hons), PhD, and PG Certificate in Higher Education from the University of Nottingham.
Kang-Nee Ting is a trained pharmacist and holds professional memberships with the UK General Pharmaceutical Council, Malaysia Pharmacy Board, and Singapore Pharmacy Council.
Kang-Nee Ting received several prizes and awards for their work in community outreach and fundraising activities.

Kang-Nee Ting received awards such as the Best Poster Award from the International Biotechnology Society & The Pharmaceutical Society of Korea, University of Nottingham's Alumni Laureate Award - Special Excellence, Vice Chancellor's Achievement Award, Pharmaceutical Association of Malaysia (PhAMA) President's Community Impact & Awareness Award, among others.
Kang-Nee Ting is involved in teaching Physiology and Pharmacology modules for students in various programs like Pharmacy, Biomedical Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, and Biosciences.
Some recent publications by Kang-Nee Ting include studies on riverborne microplastic, Chinese Caterpillar Mushroom, effects of Schwarzinicine A, and more.

Dr Mohan Avvari, NUBS Malaysia's Associate Professor of Strategic Management, was a Judge in the inaugural Asia Sustainability Reporting Awards 2015, organised by CSRWorks International Singapore and supported by the British High Commission in Singapore, which winners were announced on 28 February 2016, at an event held at the British High Commisioner to Singapore's residence.

The winner of the 2015 Awards was Hong Kong real estate developer Hang Lung Properties, which was awarded 'Asia's Sustainability Report of the Year (Judges Choice)' and 'Asia's Best Sustainability Report'. The Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Psychology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) provides a dynamic understanding of human thought, emotion, and behaviour.
In the first two years, students engage in foundational modules such as cognitive psychology, individual differences, and developmental psychology.
Students benefit from expert-led teaching, practical workshops, and access to advanced facilities, ensuring they are ready to make a meaningful impact in the rapidly evolving field of psychology.

The entrance requirements for the Psychology BSc (Hons) program include specific qualifications like A Levels, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Gaokao, Senior High School Diploma (China), Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE), Advance Placement (AP), and other recognized diplomas and foundation programs.
English language requirements include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, and IB English proficiency tests.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a 1-year pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM’s undergraduate degrees.
The Malaysia Campus, Semenyih Campus, is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just 45 minutes’ drive from the city center with its iconic Petronas Twin Towers.
Public transport is plentiful with free shuttle services operating on some routes, and taxi/Grab services are widely used by the student community.

Career opportunities for graduates of the Psychology BSc (Hons) program include roles such as Clinical Psychologist, Behavioural Therapist, Special Education Needs Teacher, University Lecturer, Human Resources Specialist, Business Development Consultant, and Public Service Personnel.

The School of Economics and the School of Politics, History and International Relations jointly organised a career talk titled 'Charting Your Career Path as an Economics and/or Political Science Graduate' with speaker YB Dr. Ong Kian Ming, the Deputy Minister of International Trade and Industry, Malaysia on 29 November 2019.
The career talk aimed to provide information about potential career paths and internship opportunities to Economics and International Relations students.
According to Dr. Ong Kian Ming, career paths for economics graduates include roles in banking, business, financial consulting, and the public sector.
There are growing employment opportunities for economics graduates in think tanks and private equity firms in Malaysia.

Dr. Ong Kian Ming mentioned the need for more good quality economists for better business, economics, and policy advisory services, suggesting that more female economists should be hired for inclusivity.

Dr. Ong Kian Ming highlighted career opportunities for political science graduates, including political risk analysis for investment, corporate relations or government relations officers, and working for government representatives or international organizations such as UNESCO and the World Bank.

University policy and minimum age requirements allow for waivers on an individual basis with written agreement from parents or legal guardians.
If a student is at least 16 years old at the time of registration, the Head of Admissions can waive the minimum age requirement upon receipt of a signed Under 18 consent form.
For international applicants who are 15 years old, they need to provide details of a guardian based in Malaysia to act in Loco Parentis.
The University cannot waive the minimum age requirement for applicants below 15 years of age.
Acceptance to the University does not guarantee the ability to obtain a visa to study in Malaysia for international applicants.
Upon receiving the signed 'Under 18 Consent Form', the Head of Admissions will waive the minimum age requirement and send an offer to successful applicants.
One month before registration, the Admissions office will inform relevant departments of under 18 students joining the university.
The Accommodation office will inform hall wardens about under 18 students who will be staying in their residence halls.

MEME aims to fit 50 elephants (3% of the Malaysian elephant population) with GPS-satellite tracking devices to monitor how they are responding to changes in habitat and conservation measures.

The study 'You Look Familiar: How Malaysian Chinese Recognise Faces' was led by Chrystalle B.Y. Tan, a PhD student at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
The results of the study have been published online in the prestigious scientific journal PloS One.

The study by the School of Psychology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus used specialised eye tracking technology to investigate the visual strategies used to recognise photographs of faces.
They recruited 22 Malaysian Chinese student volunteers from across Nottingham’s Malaysia campus for the study.
The study was supervised by Dr Ian Stephen, an expert on face processing, and Dr Elizabeth Sheppard, an expert in eye tracking.
More information is available from Chrystalle B. Y. Tan, on +603 89248350, bihyuan.tan@nottingham.edu.my.

Dr. Lau is an Associate Professor of Accounting in the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus specializing in International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) for corporate reporting.
Dr. Lau holds a Doctorate of Philosophy (PhD) in Accounting, a Master of Business Administration (MBA), and a Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA), all specializing in Finance.
Dr. Lau is a Fellow member of the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (FCCA) and a Chartered Accountant of the Malaysian Institute of Accountants (CA).
Dr. Lau's past working experiences include 8 years of industrial exposures with a reputable banking group and 12 years of teaching and academic administrative experiences with a private university.

Dr. Lau teaches modules and courses in financial accounting, corporate reporting, and corporate financing at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus for both undergraduate and postgraduate students.
Modules Dr. Lau teaches include Advanced Financial Reporting, Financial Analysis, Accounting and Finance, Corporate Reporting, and others for various academic programs and professional examinations.
Dr. Lau also provides corporate training courses on topics like International Financial Reporting Standards, Financial reporting for financial instruments, and Sustainability Reporting.

Selected publications by Dr. Lau include works on financial reporting, debt covenants, economic consequences of IFRS adoption, sustainability reporting, and stakeholder perceptions on business sustainability practices.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) football team won the MASISWA Zone Selangor Qualifying Round Football Championship 2015 held recently at Universiti Tenaga Nasional (UNITEN).

As the champions for central district of Selangor which covers Semenyih, Bangi, Gombak, Sepang, Sabak Bernam, Hulu Langat, Hulu Selangor, Klang, Kuala Langat, Kuala Selangor, and Petaling Jaya, UNMC’s team now qualifies to compete against 8 teams from universities around Malaysia for the national title which will take place from May 19 to 24 2016 at Universiti Teknologi Mara, (UiTM) Perak.
The team received medal, certificates, and a trophy.
The UNMC football team comprises of students from foundation, undergraduate, and postgraduate across Faculty of Arts & Social Sciences, Engineering, and Science.

Professor Ir Dr Dominic Foo was interviewed by Ai FM, a national Chinese radio station operated by Radio Televisyen Malaysia (RTM), on 9 October 2020 to discuss the topic of “Climate Change and CO2 emissions”.

Professor Foo spoke about the extreme weather in different parts of the world, including Malaysia, such as sudden floods in Kuala Lumpur in September and prolonged drought season and floods in the east coast in 2014.
Professor Foo mentioned that CO2 concentration exceeded 400 ppm in 2014 and reached the highest recorded level of 417 ppm in May 2020.
Malaysia has pledged to cut its emission intensity per unit of GDP by 45% by 2030 compared to 2005 levels.
Renewable energy is seen as a potential long-term solution for reducing the use of fossil fuels with solar power and hydropower mentioned as examples, each with its own limitations.

The Alumni E-Mentoring Programme is a collaboration between the university's Careers Advisory Service (CAS) and the Alumni and Donor Relations Office (ADRO) for UNM Alumni.
The mentoring programme allows UNM alumni to mentor and guide current students online during the month of July 2024.
Mentors are required to be good listeners and possess the desire to help student mentees realize their potential and strengthen their communication skills.
The e-mentoring programme allows mentors and mentees to communicate online, negating distance, time, or schedule constraints.
Alumni mentors can refine their one-to-one mentoring skills, widen their professional network, and contribute to maintaining good partnerships with the university and their organizations.
The mentoring relationship is facilitated by CAS, is governed by an explicit agreement, and provides flexibility for both parties to withdraw if necessary.
Alumni and current students can sign up for the UNM Alumni Network to offer or receive mentoring services.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus offers a protocol for absence from examinations due to religious observance.
Students are required to complete a Religious Observance Form authorized by their personal tutor and submit it to the School Examinations Officer.

Completed Religious Observance forms should be submitted by specific deadlines: 18 November 2022 for January 2023 Examinations, 17 February 2023 for May 2023 Examinations, and 23 June 2023 for Reassessment/Summer 2023 Examinations.
In cases where alternative arrangements are needed, the School may set alternative examination papers, permit alternative assessment times with a chaperone, or set alternative forms of assessment.
Students may be offered a deferral of their examination until the August/September resit period under the University's Extenuating Circumstances Policy.

The 15th International Conference on Atmospheric Sciences and Applications to Air Quality (ASAAQ15) was hosted by The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) at Corus Hotel, Kuala Lumpur from 28 to 30 October 2019.
The conference was co-organised with Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM) and National University of Malaysia (UKM).
The conference received support from Malaysia Convention & Exhibition Bureau (MyCEB) and Atmosphere 360.
A journal special issue entitled “Atmosphere, Air Quality and Health” by Springer was secured as part of the conference.
The International Conference on Atmospheric Sciences and Applications to Air Quality (ASAAQ) has been held in various cities including Tokyo, Shanghai, Seoul, Seattle, and more.
The opening ceremony of ASAAQ15 was conducted by Professor Andy Chan, Professor Graham Kendall, and Dr Nagulendran Kangayatkarasu.
The conference was attended by 130 participants from around 30 countries.
Plenary talks were given by several distinguished guests including Professor Chak K. Chan, Professor Roy Harrison, Dr Mian Chin, and more.
A total of 11 sessions were conducted during the conference, with a specialized session for the discussion on 7 South East Asian Studies (7-SEAS).
A gala dinner for networking was organized at the KL Tower Atmosphere 360 Revolving Restaurant.
The conference ended with an interdisciplinary discussion session and 7-SEAS workshop.
The conference aims to foster scientific discussion and exchange of information on atmospheric science and air quality.
Professor Andy Chan expressed the importance of the ASAAQ conference for discussing ways to improve global air quality.

The module 'Introduction to securities and investment' at The University of Nottingham Malaysia consists of three important aspects of financial markets: the introduction to financial services industry, the economic environment, and the management of financial assets. Key financial assets include equities, bonds, derivatives, investment funds, and other financial products.

Students who complete the module may opt to take the Chartered Institute for Securities and Investment (CISI’s) ‘International Introduction to Securities and Investment’ examination, which is a CISI Foundation Level qualification that contributes towards the CISI Level 3 Certificate in International Introduction to Securities and Investment.
The module aims to develop a comprehensive understanding of financial market and institutions with an overview of international regulation.

Level A of the library is a silent study zone which is an area for individual study only. Silence must be maintained at all times.
Levels C and D are quiet study zones where library users will be able to pursue quiet, individual study and low-level conversation.
Level B is where group study and discussions are allowed. Level B is also the location of the circulation desk and a learning hub.
No food and drinks are allowed in the library except for bottled water.
Mobile phones must be set to either silent or vibration mode in the library.
If you need to talk on your phone, please leave the study zone first to avoid disturbing others.
Phone conversations should take place at the phone zones (lift foyers) found on each level of the library.
When leaving the library, please clear your rubbish away into a bin so that someone else can use the space.

The Master of Science (Hons) in Environmental Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is designed to tackle global environmental challenges through innovative engineering solutions.
Core areas of study include water treatment, carbon capture, nanotechnology, and environmental assessment.
The MSc in Environmental Engineering offers options across departments, catering to diverse career goals in renewable energy, environmental consultancy, and sustainability.
Graduates benefit from state-of-the-art facilities, expert faculty, and a global alumni network.
The program ensures that students are equipped to drive sustainable change worldwide.
The entrance requirements for the program include a second-class honors degree (2:2) or its international equivalent in engineering or a related field.
Applicants must hold a degree from a recognized university.
English language proficiency requirements include a minimum score of 6.0 in IELTS (with no less than 5.5 in each element).
TOEFL (iBT) minimum score is 80, PTE (Academic) minimum score is 65, and MUET Band 4.
Fees for Malaysian students are RM50,000 per program, and for international students, it is RM55,000 per program.

Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia has entered into a partnership with the Chartered Institute for Securities and Investment (CISI) to promote knowledge and understanding of financial markets and institutions amongst students at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

The module is open to the University’s undergraduate students who are enrolled on any course in any School, and is part of the Nottingham Advantage Award (NAA), the University of Nottingham’s employability award that provides students the chance to be involved in extra-curricular and co-curricular modules designed to enhance employability, personal and professional development.

Students who complete the module may then opt to take the CISI’s ‘International Introduction to Securities and Investment’ examination, which is a CISI Foundation Level qualification that contributes towards the CISI Level 3 Certificate in International Introduction to Securities and Investment.

The CISI’s mission is to help members attain, maintain and develop their knowledge and skills and to promote the highest standards of ethics and integrity in the securities and investment profession.
The CISI works in close cooperation with regulators, firms and other professional bodies worldwide and over 40,000 examinations were sat in 80 countries in the last twelve months.

With 45,000 members in 104 countries the CISI is the professional body which sets examinations and offers qualifications for those working in or looking to establish a career in the financial planning, wealth management and capital markets profession.

For the second year running, Nottingham University Business School has improved its position in the latest international league table of full-time Master of Business Administration programs.

Only 15 UK business schools appear in The Economist ranking this year and Nottingham is one of only four UK business schools to improve on its position in the 2013 ranking.

To qualify for inclusion in The Economist ranking, the schools with full-time MBA programs that responded to the survey had to meet various thresholds of data provision, as well as attaining a minimum number of responses to a survey gauging the opinion of current MBA students and alumni who graduated within the last three years.

The programme is funded by the Higher Education Innovation Fund (HEIF) and activities supported by these awards must deliver against University of Nottingham HEIF targets.
The first call for the fellowship will be issued on 15th September 2011.

Take heed that some of the career choices you are considering today may change after you graduate. Your degree discipline is only a piece of who you are and what you can offer to the employer.

It is also your life experience and knowledge gained outside the classroom that would equip you with a set of transferable skills that can be used in a variety of careers which may not be related to your degree subjects at all.

In fact, the degree discipline you choose does not limit you to a handful of careers. It is likely to offer you many incredible options not listed here. Exploring those options across a number of job sectors may provide you with an understanding of your own unique abilities, weaknesses and career interests.

The Bachelor of Arts with Honours in English with Creative Writing at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is an immersive programme that combines literary studies with creative writing.
The programme offers a dynamic curriculum, starting with foundational modules such as Studying Literature, Introduction to Linguistics, and Beginning Creative Writing.
The course culminates in a creative writing dissertation.
Graduates will be well-prepared for careers in media, publishing, education, and the arts.

The course modules include Academic Community, Beginning Creative Writing, Introduction to Linguistics, Studying Literature, The Influence of English, The Survey of English Literature and Drama, Discourse and Society, Literary Linguistics, Modern and Contemporary Literature, Writing for Performance, Prose and Poetry Writing, Victorian and Fin de Siecle Literature, and World Literatures in English.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers various entry requirements for the BA (Hons) in English with Creative Writing, such as A Levels, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior High School Diploma, Advance Placement, Diploma from Local Institutions, Foundation from Local Institutions, Nottingham's Foundation Programme, and language proficiency tests like IELTS, TOEFL, and PTE.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia campus is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just a 45-minute drive from the city center.
Campus facilities include schools of business, education, science, and engineering, a sports center, library, student accommodation, and access to green jungle surroundings.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers career opportunities such as Editorial Assistant, Advertising Executive, Copywriter, Creative Content Specialist, and Social Media Manager for graduates of the English with Creative Writing program.
The university provides scholarships and financial aid for deserving students.
Students can engage in literary events, creative writing showcases, and potentially submit their work for publication.
The program prepares students for careers in various roles and industries related to writing, media, and communication.
UNM organizes guest lectures, author talks, and writing workshops for creative writing students to interact with established writers or authors.

Nottingham University Business School Malaysia is launching a Masterclass Series, a program of talks with thought leaders on contemporary topics in business and management.
The Masterclass Series is organized by the Executive Education arm of NUBS Malaysia and aims to connect the Business School and University community, alumni, and industry partners.

The Masterclasses are complimentary and open to alumni and invited guests, taking place on weekday evenings at the University of Nottingham Malaysia’s Kuala Lumpur Teaching Centre at Chulan Tower, Jalan Conlay, Kuala Lumpur.

The inaugural Masterclass will be held on Tuesday 16 April 2019, 7pm, covering the application of big data analytics and artificial intelligence in business, presented by Professor Alain Chong, Dean of the Graduate School at the University of Nottingham Ningbo China.

Dr. Lau Chee Kwong, Dean of NUBS Malaysia, will deliver a Masterclass on MFRS 16 Leases on Tuesday 18 June 2019, discussing the challenges and impacts of the new Malaysian Financial Reporting Standard.
Deadlines for RSVP: For the 16 April Masterclass - RSVP before 14 April 2019; for the 18 June Masterclass - RSVP before 10 June 2019.

The Grand Finals of the Inaugural Christine Ennew Business Challenge Trophy 2016, sponsored by Ken-Rich Corporation, was held on 29 February 2016 at the Great Hall, The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

The competition was organised in conjunction with the 15th Anniversary of The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) with the aim of offering UNMC students a professional experience and an opportunity to participate in a real-life business project.

Contestants were required to develop a business plan on the theme 'Male Toiletries for Daily Personal Care', to be pitched to Ken-Rich Corporation, an established manufacturer of household, industrial and personal care products.

The Panel of Judges for the Grand Finals consisted of Dato' Hooi Lai Lin, CEO/Director of Ken-Rich Corporation, who was also the Chief Judge; Professor Christine Ennew, Provost of UNMC; Dr Nishanth Chemmangattuvalappil, Associate Professor, Faculty of Engineering, UNMC; Professor Claire O'Malley, Dean of the Faculty of Science, UNMC; and Professor Ong Fon Sim, Dean, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, UNMC.

The Champion, and recipient of the inaugural Christine Ennew Business Challenge Trophy, was Team EDGE, consisting of Business School students Fabiolla Netto, Evonne Chen May Yie and John Wong Yoong Wern, won themselves an all-expenses paid trip to The University of Nottingham, UK.

During the announcement of the winners by Professor Lee Chew Ging, Dean of Nottingham University Business School Malaysia, Chief Judge Dato' Hooi Lai Lin also announced a 'surprise' Second Prize - a cash prize of RM3,000 sponsored by Ken-Rich Corporation. The recipient of the Second Prize was Team J&J - Liau Haw Yuan, Natalie Liew Jia Yi and Tang Yingjie.

Professor Christine Ennew mentioned that business challenge competitions present students with a great opportunity for experiential learning; such events are an opportunity to work collaboratively, think innovatively, and develop creative solutions to business problems.

In her closing remarks, the Chief Judge, Dato' Hooi, commended the quality of the performance of all the finalist teams and their innovative product ideas, remarking that in the practice of marketing and communications, it is important to note that 'attitude drives altitude'.
UNMC expresses deep gratitude to Dato’ Hooi Lai Lin and Ken-Rich Corporation for sponsoring the competition and providing students with an opportunity to learn about real business challenges.

Arushad Ahmed (BSc in Computer Science, 2016), is the Director and Chief Technology Officer (CTO) of Javaabu, a software development firm based in the Maldives.
Arushad spent four years learning business aspects like management, human resources, administration, and finances to run his software development firm.

Arushad had opportunities to work on national-level software projects, including developing an online job center for the Economic Ministry used to disperse income support benefits during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Arushad's first job after graduation was as an Application Development Architect at a telecommunications company.
Arushad plans to expand Javaabu to the international market, introduce their software products, and pursue master's and doctorate degrees in Computer Science.
Arushad attributes the foundation of his software development career to studying at the University of Nottingham in Malaysia and the opportunities for international project collaborations.
Arushad advises aspiring entrepreneurs to develop skills through self-learning, build a portfolio by volunteering or freelancing, and seek references for future job or business endeavors.
The School of Economics, University of Nottingham Malaysia campus, is organising an Economics essay competition.

Ts Dr Wong Jing Ying is a Professional Technologist under Malaysian Board of Technologist (MBOT) and a fellow of the Higher Education Academy UK.

Dr. Wong obtained her Degree of Bachelor of Engineering (Civil) with First Class Honours and Vice Chancellor's Award as well as Degree of Doctor of Philosophy (Civil Engineering) with Best Student Award from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia.

Dr. Wong received the 2018 Lord Dearing Award 'Virtual Reality for Building Information Modelling (BIM) in Engineering Education' in recognition of outstanding contribution to enhancing the student learning experience at University of Nottingham.

Dr. Wong has published in International Journal of Interactive Mobile Technologies, International Journal of Innovative Technology and Exploring Engineering, European Journal of Environmental and Civil Engineering, Jurnal Teknologi, and Procedia CIRP.

Dr. Wong's current teaching modules include CIVE 3062 Building Information Modelling (BIM) Group Design Project, CIVE 2047 Portfolio of Civil Engineering Studies II, and CIVE 1022 Structural Analysis.
Dr. Wong's past teaching modules include H23BIM Building Information Modelling, H23MCP Construction Practice, H23MPM Applied Construction Project Management, and others.

Some of Dr. Wong's recent publications include papers on Dynamic response of scaled structure with one liquid tuned mass damper, Performance of Cantilever Structure Inspired by Tree Patterns, and BIM-VR Framework for Building Information Modelling in Engineering Education.

The Bachelor of Science with Honours in Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a comprehensive three-year degree that equips students with interdisciplinary expertise across pharmaceutical sciences.
