Since 2011, graduates of the program have excelled globally in the pharmaceutical and chemistry industries.

The admission requirements for the Bachelor of Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences program include specific grades in science subjects like Chemistry, Biology, Mathematics, or Physics depending on the qualification.
English language requirement for entry into the program includes a minimum score in tests like IELTS, TOEFL, or equivalent.
The program typically takes 3 years to complete for full-time students at UNM.
The language of instruction for the program is English.

Graduates of the Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences BSc (Hons) program may find employment in roles such as Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Manager, Formulation Scientist, Analytical Chemist, Quality Control Management, and Product Specialist.

The Centre for Independent Journalism (CIJ) Malaysia conducted a 2-week media monitoring study on mainstream Malaysian press coverage of the Bersih 3.0 rally.

CIJ partnered with the Centre for the Study of Communications and Culture (CSCC) to undertake a large-scale media monitoring project of the upcoming media coverage of the 13th Malaysian General Election.
The results of the Bersih-coverage study showed a significant decrease in print media coverage compared to the previous year's event.
The coverage by Utusan Malaysia and the New Straits Times was largely negative, while The Star and theSun had more neutral articles.
The Centre for Independent Journalism (CIJ) calls for a complete repeal of the Printing Presses and Publications Act (PPPA) and a review of the ownership of the print media by political parties.

A new technique to dry cocoa beans, fruits, herbs and edible birds nests is helping to improve quality and increase the shelf life of food.
Drying lemon myrtle at the lower temperature of 20ºC enabled the retention of color and bioactive ingredient 'citral' significantly more than conventional drying methods at 60ºC.
Low-temperature drying is effective in retaining bioactive ingredients and key nutrients in processed products.
Professor of Chemical and Process Engineering, Dr Chung-Lim Law, is leading the study on low-temperature drying techniques for food preservation.
The technique uses a heat pump system and heat transfer module to dehydrate bio-origin products in a low-temperature, low-humidity environment.
The technology is important for tropical countries like Malaysia due to its high humidity throughout the year.
The low-temperature drying process eliminates or minimizes undesirable chemical reactions, retains product color, quality, and extends shelf life.
Interested parties can contact Dr Chung-Lim Law at Chung-Lim.Law@nottingham.edu.my or Josephine Dionisappu for more information.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia has achieved the Competitive (Berdaya Saing) rating in the latest SETARA 2022, which is the highest rating in the assessment.
The SETARA 2022 ratings are based on evaluations of 2021 data by MOHE-elected auditors on 104 higher education institutions in Malaysia.
SETARA 2022 has two categories: Competitive (Berdaya Saing) and Viable (Berdaya Maju) for the assessment of higher education institutions in Malaysia.
UNM was previously rated 5-star 'Excellent' in SETARA 2018/2019, and the new 'Competitive' rating in SETARA 2022 sets a new benchmark for the university.
The SETARA rating was initiated in 2007 by MOHE to ensure quality and standards of higher education institutions in Malaysia.
The SETARA assessment is mandatory for all HEIs in Malaysia that meet the basic requirements.
In previous years, the SETARA rating used a scale of 1 to 6 stars to assess the level and performance of higher education institutions.

The sports that are discussed include; athletics, baseball, cricket, cycling, football, hockey, tennis and rugby.
Many of the rule changes highlighted in this paper are aimed at making the sporting event more exciting.
These are the rules that often lead to an unexpected occurrence which was not foreseen, even if it has the desired effect for the vast majority of the time.

We hope that one consequence of this paper is that the scientific community and the sports industry can work more closely together in order to study the effects of potential rule changes before they are implemented, or implemented in such a way that they can be studied before wider adoption.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus is hosting a conference on 'Decolonisation, Leadership and Knowledge Democracy in the 21st Century.'

The conference is a collaboration between the Ministry of Education, Malaysia, Academy for Higher Education Leadership, Universiti Sains Islam Malaysia, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, and the Multiversity.
The Ministry of Education's Higher Education Department Director-General, Professor Dato' Dr Asma Ismail, launched the conference.

Professor Christine Ennew, The Pro-Vice Chancellor of the University of Nottingham and Provost for UNMC, highlighted the responsibility of educational institutions to develop existing knowledge and encourage the exchange of knowledge.
The concept of 'learned, values-driven talent' is emphasized in the Higher Education blueprint and strategic development of the Malaysian Education system.
Decolonisation in higher education involves moving beyond traditional conventions and forms of organizing universities.
Malaysia was represented by members of the AKEPT Leadership programme and senior figures from the Higher Education field at the conference.
Experts at the conference discussed revising and reassessing traditional ways of organizing and leading universities.
Eminent academicians such as C.K. Raju, Tan Sri Prof Dzulkilfli Abdul Razak, and Babuuzibwa Luutu presented their work at the conference.

The University processes personal data provided voluntarily by individuals and related parties for various purposes as outlined in the Data Protection Notice.
Personal data includes information such as names, addresses, contact numbers, identification numbers, academic qualifications, employment details, financial information, and health records.
The University may disclose personal data within and outside Malaysia to parties such as employees, consultants, government agencies, academic institutions, embassies, and sponsors.

Individuals have the right to access, correct, or limit the processing of their personal data, and can address any queries or complaints to the Data Protection Officer at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Changes to personal data should be promptly communicated to ensure accuracy and relevance of the information.
The University periodically reviews and updates the Data Protection Notice based on changes in regulations, and the latest version can be requested or accessed on the University's website.
In case of any inconsistencies between the English and Malay versions of the Notice, the English version prevails.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) is the first private higher education institution in Asia offering the multi-organisational Global Business Services (GBS) course.

The first British University in Malaysia, UNMC launched its multi-organisational GBS course in collaboration with Talent Corporation Malaysia (TalentCorp), the Ministry of Higher Education (MOHE), Malaysia Digital Economy Corporation (MDEC) and UKM.

The GBS course at UNMC started in September 2016 and has five industry partners: Emerio, Sime Darby Global Services Centre Malaysia, Xerox Business Services Malaysia, IBM Global Delivery Centre Malaysia, and Sellbytel Group Malaysia.
UNMC CEO and Provost Professor Graham Kendall stated that UNMC graduates are about 90% employable in Malaysia.

GBS is a fast-growing industry in Malaysia and is a priority in the country’s Economic Transformation Plan and the National Key Economic Areas (NKEA) towards its transformation into a high-income, knowledge-based economy by 2020.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus recently organised a study tour to Beijing, China for its Master of Business Administration (MBA) students.

A group of fourteen students from Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia and the University’s partner institution PSB Academy Singapore gained first-hand experience on global business culture through visits to multinational corporations in China.
The MBA students visited companies like Huawei Technology, Tencent Corporation, Lenovo, BDO China, and China Galaxy Securities during their study tour in China.
The MBA Programme Director, Professor Khong Kok Wei, regularly invites business leaders and industry experts into the classroom to expose students to various ideas, trends, and viewpoints.

"Through NUBS Malaysia's business connections, we gained exclusive access to major industry players such as BDO China, Lenovo, and Tencent, whose executives provided us with invaluable insights on doing business in China," said Ethan Siew, an MBA student who participated in the study tour.

The MBA students had the opportunity to visit Beijing Foreign Studies University, where academics shared insights on business opportunities in China and socio-cultural nuances of effective business practices in the country.

Nottingham University Business School Malaysia's MBA international business study tours offer a unique business and cultural program for students, including meetings with executives, company visits, and cultural excursions.
The next intake of the MBA program is in September 2017 for full-time and part-time students.

Professor Asgar Ali from School of Bioscience at the University of Nottingham Malaysia was recently invited to be a guest speaker on a webinar at Bihar Agricultural University in India.
The webinar on Recent Trends in Processing Technologies for Food Quality and Safety will be held via Zoom on 20 July 2020.

Thematic areas to be discussed during the webinar include challenges and opportunities of the food industry during the pandemic, cold plasma processing for food quality and safety, role of pulsed electric field processing technology in food preservation, innovative post-harvest technologies to improve shelf life of fresh produce, and nanotechnology application for food processing.

Other speakers invited to the webinar include Dr Sanu Jacob, Food and Safety Standards Authority of India; Dr Vasundha Bansai, Punjab University; Dr N.N. Misra, Dalhousie University; and Dr Khalid Gul, Shanghai Jiao Tong University.

The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Chemical Engineering with Environmental Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) delivers a comprehensive education that integrates advanced chemical engineering principles with a strong focus on environmental sustainability.

The four-year programme is accredited by the Institution of Chemical Engineers (IChemE) and the Board of Engineers Malaysia (BEM), preparing students to become Chartered or Professional Engineers equipped to address global challenges in energy, water, and environmental management.

Students benefit from an industry-focused curriculum, starting with core engineering and environmental modules and advancing to specialized topics such as water treatment, air pollution, and sustainable process design.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Semenyih Campus is located 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and 45 minutes' drive from the city center, surrounded by a green jungle backdrop with a campus lake and facilities such as a sports center, library, and student accommodation.
The campus houses the business, education, science, and engineering schools, providing students with a modern learning environment while being centrally located in Asia for easy travel opportunities.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia reserves the right to withdraw your scholarship if you are subsequently found to be ineligible or if these terms and conditions are not adhered to. The University also reserves the right to amend its scholarship provision without notice. All our scholarships are applicable for tuition fee reduction only, no allowance or stipend are provided.
Please read the following carefully and ensure that you understand the conditions of the scholarship you have applied for or been offered to.

Your Obligations:
1. Accept the scholarship offer by the given deadline – the University reserves the right to withdraw the offer of a scholarship if it is not accepted by the deadline given.
2. To hold only one scholarship during the duration of your course. In the event that you are offered more than one scholarship, you must choose only one. You are advised to choose the scholarship with the higher quantum unless you choose otherwise.
3. Join your academic course at the given start date and before the registration deadline.
4. Inform the Sponsorship Unit of any other scholarships or sponsorships currently held, or awarded at a later date. The scholarship shall be withdrawn if other sources of funding have been awarded.
5. Seek permission and obtain consent from the Sponsorship Unit before making any changes to your courses – this includes course transfers, suspending studies, withdrawal etc. Please note that approval is not guaranteed. Where changes are made without prior approval, the scholarship will be withdrawn and you may be required to repay the scholarship in full.
6. Pay all outstanding tuition fees by University deadlines if you have not been awarded a full scholarship.
7. Meet the scholarship requirements (if any) or satisfactory progress for you to be able to continue the scholarship in the next academic years. The scholarship will be withdrawn if you do not meet the requirements.
8. Agree to act in an ambassadorial capacity, to provide student profiles or testimonials if requested, and to attend scholarship or recruitment events as required by the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
9. Agree to the University of Nottingham Malaysia contacting you during the period approximately three years after your graduation for an update on how the scholarship has influenced your career. Your data will also be passed to our Alumni and Donor Relations Office who retain data in support of your lifelong relationship with the University.
10. Where a scholarship is co-funded with an external organization or donor, we will pass on the details to the external organization for the purpose of selection and reporting.

While scholarships are usually provided based on merit and academic excellence to deserving students, financial aid is provided to support worthy candidates to pursue their studies. Scholarships are sponsored internally by UNM, whereas financial aid is provided in the form of allowances, grants and more to support eligible candidates.

The MyMentor initiative was launched by the Ministry of Education II in Malaysia on April 13, 2015, at the Royale Chulan Hotel, Kuala Lumpur.
MyMentor is a collaboration between The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, University of Southampton Malaysia Campus, and Monash University Malaysia.
MyMentor's entry requirements are competitive, and in the inaugural year, only ten mentor/mentee pairings will be accepted.
MyMentor pairings will increase in subsequent years to 25, 50, 70, and 75, totaling 230 pairings over two years.
The MyMentor logo was designed by Nour Salah Mohieldin Elwassimy from Monash University Malaysia.
MyMentor can be followed on Twitter at @MyMentor15.

Key attendees at the launch of MyMentor included representatives from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, Monash University Malaysia, University of Southampton Malaysia Campus, and other leading universities in Malaysia.
The MyMentor project is a collaboration between three international universities: The University of Nottingham, University of Southampton, and Monash University, all with branch campuses in Malaysia.
The mentoring program under MyMentor pairs a mentor from Nottingham, Southampton, or Monash with a mentee from a public university in Malaysia for 24 months.
For more information on MyMentor, contact Professor Graham Kendall at graham.kendall@nottingham.edu.my or Josephine Dionisappu at josephine.dionisappu@nottingham.edu.my, +6 (03) 8924 8746.

The MA in Media, Communications and Culture at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers an interdisciplinary approach, blending theoretical and practical skills to help students thrive in the dynamic media landscape.

The key feature of the Master’s programme is a fully funded, optional 1-week Digital Storytelling and Production module at CNN Academy in Abu Dhabi, where students gain hands-on content creation experience with CNN experts.

The programme offers flexible pathways, allowing students to specialise in media, cultural policy, or combine both. With access to cutting-edge facilities, including a Digital Media Lab, this course will prepare students for careers in media, journalism, marketing, public relations, and more.

The full-time MA Media, Communications and Culture course lasts 12 months and is divided into two semesters and a summer period, and you will take three modules per semester. You will then complete a dissertation over the summer to be submitted in September. If you are studying the course part-time, you can complete this within 24 or 36 months, depending on your circumstances.
Entry requirements include a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent. Non-UK qualifications will be assessed against this standard.

English language requirements include IELTS (Academic) 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element), TOEFL (iBT) 90 (minimum 19 in Writing and Listening, 20 in Reading and 22 in Speaking), PTE (Academic) 71 (with no less than 65 in each element), and MUET Band 4.5.
IELTS (Academic), TOEFL iBT, and PTE (Academic) test results must be less than two years old. MUET results are valid for five years from the release date.
Fees for Malaysian students are RM58,000 per programme and for international students are RM65,000 per programme.
Career opportunities after completing the programme include Public Relations Manager, Media Consultant, Brand Strategist, Corporate Communications Manager, and Marketing Communications Director.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia hosted a workshop on the topic of 'Biosensing with DNA Nanotechnology: From Design to Application' on 25th September 2024.
The workshop focused on recent advancements in DNA nanotechnology for biosensing applications, covering topics such as DNA circuit design and the development of aptamers.
The workshop organizers were Associate Professor Dr New Siu Yee, Associate Professor Dr Michelle Tan, and Professor Dr Sandy Loh from the School of Pharmacy at University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Distinguished speakers at the workshop included experts from the National University of Singapore and Biogenes Technology, who provided insights into designing DNA circuits and applications of aptamers.

The workshop aligns with the University of Nottingham Malaysia's dedication to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, focusing on promoting good health and well-being, fostering innovation, and encouraging responsible consumption.

The project will involve collaborators from the School of Geography at the University of Nottingham (in UK and Malaysia), British Geological Survey, and the Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology (VAST) in Hanoi.
The project will investigate water quality issues in the Red River Delta in the north of Vietnam, which supports 20 million inhabitants and includes a major rice-growing region and the city of Hanoi.

The project includes a team of 10 collaborators from the University of Nottingham (Suzanne McGowan, Virginia Panizzo, Tuong Thuy Vu), British Geological Survey (Melanie Leng, Chris Vane), VAST (Do Thu Nga, Anh Duc Trinh, Thi Nguyet Minh Luu, Thi Phuong Quynh Le), and Vietnam Academy of Agricultural Sciences (Minh Tien Tran).
A workshop in July will be launched to ensure that the findings can be applied to improve water management in the region.

The project will develop the installation of Microtox® techniques for water quality analysis in Vietnam and employ material flow analysis modeling to understand future water management scenarios in the delta region.

The Politics, history development and international relations PhD program offered at the University of Nottingham Malaysia can be taken full-time for 3-4 years or part-time for 6-8 years with start dates in February, April, June, and September 2025.

The entry requirements for the Politics, history development and international relations PhD program include a good master’s degree plus at least a second-class honours degree or a first-class honours degree in a relevant discipline.
English language requirements for the program include IELTS score of 7.0, TOEFL score of 100, PTE score of 76, or MUET Band 5.

Abdillah Noh is an Associate Professor at the School of Politics and International Relations.
Abdillah received his DPhil (Politics) from St. Antony's College, University of Oxford.

Abdillah is the author of two books: 'Issues in Public Policy and Administration in Malaysia: An Institutional Analysis' and 'Malaysia's State Formation: Small Steps and Large Outcomes of a Contested Leviathan.'
Abdillah is currently working on his third book on Political Change in Southeast Asia.
Abdillah has published articles in journals like Contemporary Politics, Electoral Politics, and the Journal of Policy History.
Abdillah has written opinion pieces in the Straits Times (Singapore), South China Morning Post (Hong Kong), New Straits Times (Malaysia), and Today (Singapore).

Abdillah's expertise lies in the quality of institutions, institutional change, state formation, democratisation, political change, public policy, economic diversification efforts, and international relations.

Abdillah has taught courses at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels including international studies, public policy and administration, introduction to politics, political economy of development, and more.
Abdillah applies institutional analysis to understand state formation, political transition, international relations, governance, public participation, and policy design and implementation.
Abdillah is working on a book project on political change in Southeast Asia and is interested in the shifting international order and its impact on Southeast Asia.

The AIESEC Global Volunteer program offers youth the opportunity to develop Leadership Qualities through cross-cultural volunteer experiences on social impact projects that contribute to the Sustainable Development Goals.

The Global Volunteer program was put on hold due to travel restrictions caused by the COVID-19 outbreak, resulting in the adaptation to Virtual Volunteer experiences during the Movement Control Order (MCO) period.

Virtual Volunteer has been rebranded as Malaysian Youth Volunteer, allowing for various volunteer modes (virtual, hybrid, physical) and engaging youth of all nationalities in contributing to social issues.

Eligibility criteria for the Global Volunteer program include being a youth with tertiary education status or a recent graduate within 2 years, aged between 18 and 30 years old, interested in world issues and social responsibility, and possessing leadership qualities such as being adventurous and a challenge taker.

Requirements for NAA members participating in the Global Volunteer program include attending a Preparation Seminar and Debrief Session, sharing volunteering experiences, and participating in AIESEC campaigns organized in Malaysia.
To apply for the Global Volunteer program as an NAA module, students need to register via Moodle and fill in the interest form for the Malaysian Youth Volunteer (MYV) four-week journey.

Feedback from past exchange participants highlights the valuable experiences gained during their volunteering projects, such as personal growth, cross-cultural interactions, and contributions to social causes.

Malachi Edwin Vethamani is a professor of modern English literature at the School of English, University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Malachi compiled an 'A to Z' of Covid-19 words titled 'My Coronavirus Lexicon'.
Malachi's lexicon includes definitions like 'Anti-social stockpiling' for hoarding and 'Panic Buying: toilet-roll craze' to highlight social behaviors during the pandemic.
Malachi also defined 'Front-liners: first line of susceptibility' to highlight the risks faced by those dealing with infected individuals.
Malachi adapted to the Covid-19 situation by engaging in online lectures and communication with students.

The main wireless network for staff, associates, and students at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is eduroam.
Instructions for connecting to eduroam include entering University username followed by @nottingham.edu.my and University password.
Additional instructions for setting up eduroam on Android, Apple iOS, Apple OS X, BlackBerry, Linux, Microsoft Windows, Windows Phone, and other devices are provided.
Users are advised to ensure their device security by checking the server common name, certificate issuer, validity dates, and installing the certificate provided.

The UNMC Mobile Tutors Project was initiated by engineering staff and students to provide free tuition to Rohingya refugee children from Myanmar.
The project is run by the Institute of Engineering Malaysia Student Section, IChemE Student Chapter, and IMechE Student chapter of UNMC and supported by UNMC’s Faculty of Engineering.
Since May 2016, the mobile tutor group in partnership with UNHCR-Tzu Chi Education Centre have provided a tutoring program for refugee children based in the Ampang and Selayang areas.
Almost 30 volunteers have contributed their skills and time at these centres every Saturday.
Ng Mei Xiang, a final year PhD student in Chemical and Environmental Engineering, volunteers to make a difference to the children in the project.

Sachini S. J. Gedarawatta, a second year undergraduate in Chemical and Environmental Engineering, and Abhay Menon, a final year PhD student in Chemical and Environmental Engineering, highlight the importance of education for the underprivileged in the project.

Tim Brailsford's application for a Dearing Award has been successful. The panel judged a large number of submissions of a very high standard, and chose his to be among the winners. Tim Brailsford is the first person on the Malaysia campus to have won two Dearing awards.

Tim Gocher is Hon. Professor of Sustainable Business in the Business School at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Tim's background is in private equity, energy, and technology.
Tim is the founder and CEO of Dolma Fund Management, the first international private equity fund manager for Nepal.
In the 2022/23 fiscal year, Dolma's funds were the largest FDI investor in Nepal, generating over 10,000 jobs in renewable energy, healthcare, and technology industries.
Tim was awarded the OBE in the 2022 Queen's Birthday Honours List for services to British investment and economic development in Nepal.
Tim lectures at Nottingham University Business School Malaysia Campus in the areas of sustainable/climate finance and impact investment.
Tim also lectures at London Business School on infrastructure climate finance and entrepreneurship in Emerging Markets.
Tim has an interest in university Intellectual Property (IP) commercialization and how it contributes to national competitiveness.

Nottingham University Business School Malaysia's Industry Advisory Board met on Saturday June 6 at the offices of the University's overseas partner institution in Singapore, PSB Academy.

The Board includes distinguished leaders from private and public sector organisations that help to develop strong links with businesses and policymakers to ensure the continuing relevance of the School's activities.

The meeting coincided with two panel sessions organised in Singapore by NUBS Malaysia, involving the Advisory Board members and MBA students from NUBS Malaysia's Malaysia and UK campuses as well as MBA students based in PSB Academy.

The sessions, moderated by NUBS Malaysia academicians, tackled current issues of the role of 'big data' and analytics in business and the changes in skillsets necessary in a changing financial services sector.

A 2019 alumna of the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, Heng Yen Fern has emerged as the top 7 winner after beating 10 other finalists in the second round of the 3rd Tan Sri Ir Yusoff Ibrahim Final Year Project (FYP) Competition 2019 on 18th April 2020.
The competition is organized annually by the Institution of Engineers, Malaysia (IEM) to award outstanding undergraduate final year projects across Malaysia.

Yen Fern's winning entry is a report of her individual FYP, where she investigated the effects of flow conditions including Reynolds number, Swirl number and densities of two fluids as well as the geometrical parameters on the mixing of the fluids in a combustor, using the computational fluid dynamics approach.
Yen Fern passed through the first round, where her report was evaluated by a scientific committee, and then presented her work in the second round of the competition.
A prize includes a certificate for recognition and a monetary reward of RM400.00 in the form of cheque.
Originally, a prize-giving ceremony was to be held during the IEM Annual Dinner in April 2020 but was halted due to the Movement Control Order (MCO).

The University of Nottingham Malaysia opened in September 2000 to become the first campus of a British University in Malaysia and one of the first anywhere in the world.

'Global Citizen' is a module aimed at encouraging students to interact with and learn in-depth information about different cultures that they haven’t encountered before.
Each student enrolled in this module will select one person belonging to a different country and will interact with them to learn about their culture.

A detailed template will be provided to each student that explains what kind of information they are expected to learn, including geography, climate, population, festivals, food, religion, clothing, arts, language, political system, division of states, current affairs, and economy.
Students will be required to present what they have learnt and include their personal experience learning about this culture.
Grading will be based on how much information is covered and how well it has been presented.
Assessment: Coursework and Presentation
To register for this module, students need to go to the Nottingham Moodle page starting at 9:00 am on 13 Feb 2025.
Contact for further information: naa@nottingham.edu.my

During the library renovation project, Levels A and B of the library will be CLOSED to all library users, and access to the library will be through the external emergency staircase.
Library services, including the Circulation Desk, Reference Desk & User Education, and High-Demand Collection, will be temporarily relocated to different levels during the renovation project.
A 'library-item-fetching system' will be used to retrieve items for library users from Levels A and B since users are not allowed access to those levels during the renovation.
The self-check machine will not be in use or relocated during the renovation project, and all borrowing and returning of library items must be done at the Circulation Desk relocated on Level D.
Meeting rooms on Level C will be opened for free seating to provide more seating capacity, and the opening hours for Learning@The Core and Learning@Vetro will be extended until 12 midnight daily.
The Library regrets any inconvenience caused during the renovation period and encourages users to contact Library Services with any inquiries.

The university's Disability Advisory Services assist students registered with the services to arrange alternate examination and timetabling with negotiable provisions to accommodate individual needs.

Students with seen or unseen disability such as physical/mobility disability, visual/hearing impairment, mental health challenges, or long-term medical condition (12 months or more) can request for an alternate examination by making an appointment with the Disability Advisory Services before the published deadline.

Autumn Semester Examinations: Students to have been assessed by 8 November 2024. Spring Semester Examinations: Students to have been assessed by 7 March 2025. Resit Examinations: Students to have been assessed by 26 June 2025.

All requests should be supported by the latest medical evidence from a medical specialist, psychologist, or psychiatrist, and adjustments are based on the letter of recommendation by the medical experts.

All students requiring alternative arrangements should go through the Disability Advisory services, especially for students with physical or mobility disability, to ensure all students receive an independent and accessible teaching and learning experience.

Staff members should inform the Disability Advisory services in advance if they know any student who will need timetabling arrangement. The Disability Advisory services will contact the student to discuss and will pass the recommendations to the timetabling office.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a collaborative management development programme for senior government officers in partnership with the British Malaysian Chamber of Commerce and the Malaysian Public Services Department.

The training programme conducted by NUBS Malaysia Executive Education included sessions on strategic mindsets, empowerment, mentoring, customer experience, open innovation, and sustainability and leadership for transformation.

The panel discussion during the training programme was moderated by Professor Christine Ennew, CEO/Provost of The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, and included speakers from various professional backgrounds.

The Postgraduate Diploma in Education requires candidates to complete four taught modules with a total value of 120 credits.
The 30-credit module Practice Based Inquiry is compulsory for this qualification.

For the remainder of the credits, you can choose from any of the School of Education’s other postgraduate taught modules, including any Educational Leadership and Management (ELM) module, any Special and Inclusive Education (SIE) module and any TESOL module.
Students will explore a wide range of topics, including curriculum, pedagogy, leadership, and technology, providing a comprehensive understanding of the diverse dimensions of education.
The MA and PG Diploma include designated core modules, the PG Certificate offers flexibility, allowing students to select from a range of modules.
The PG Certificate, PG Diploma, and MA in Education do not confer Qualified Teacher Status (QTS).
The programme equips students with the expertise to drive meaningful change in education, positioning themselves for leadership roles in schools, policy-making, or consultancy.
Malaysian applicants, expatriates, and their families residing in Malaysia without the standard entry requirements but with substantial and relevant work experience may be considered for entry.
IELTS (Academic): 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element)
TOEFL (iBT): 90 (minimum 19 in Writing and Listening, 20 in Reading and 22 in Speaking)
PTE (Academic): 71 (with no less than 65 in each element)
MUET: Band 4.5
MUET results are valid for five years from the release date.
Each module is run with the aim of providing the best learning experience for students and module objectives are achieved by devising the most appropriate delivery and assessment methods.
Modules are assessed by a combination of exams and coursework at the end of the relevant semester.

Steve Stewart Williams is a Professor of Psychology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Before joining the University of Nottingham Malaysia, Steve Stewart Williams was a Senior Lecturer at Swansea University and a postdoctoral fellow at McMaster University in Canada.
Steve Stewart Williams did his Ph.D. in psychology and philosophy at Massey University in New Zealand.
Steve Stewart Williams teaches courses in Evolutionary Psychology, Behaviour Genetics, and Philosophy of Mind at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Some of the courses Steve Stewart Williams currently teaches include PSGY2015: Conceptual and Historical Issues in Psychology, PSGY2017: Personality and Individual Differences, and PSGY3024: Evolutionary Psychology.

Selected publications by Steve Stewart Williams include 'The ape that understood the universe: How the mind and culture evolve', and 'The Ape That Thought It Was a Peacock: Does Evolutionary Psychology Exaggerate Human Sex Differences?'.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus won the 7th Nottingham Tri Campus Games hosted by the University of Nottingham, UK from June 21 to June 26, 2015.

The Tri Campus Games included competitions in football, basketball, volleyball, badminton, squash, tennis, table tennis, and Frisbee with nearly 200 students from over 20 different nations competing in three international campus based teams.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia Team won gold medals in men and women’s tennis, men and women’s squash, men’s badminton, men’s football, women’s squash, and the mixed volleyball match.
The team was led by Maheswaran Ganesan, Team Manager and Sports Officer at UNMC, Intan Liyana Idris, Assistant Team Manager, and Mavis Tsang, Director of Student Experience of UNMC.

UNMC hosted the Tri Campus Games in 2010 and 2013 and will be hosting the next games next year. The games are hosted on a rotation basis between the University Nottingham campuses in Malaysia, the UK, and China.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus was set up as UK's first full-fledged international campus in Malaysia and 2015 marks the 15th year since its establishment.
The Korean language course at UNM covers listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, as well as understanding current Korean popular culture.
Learning Korean at UNM includes exploring Korean drama, variety shows, movies, and K-pop to enhance language learning.
UNM offers an exchange program with partner universities that allows students to study in Korea during the Korean language course.
Students at UNM learning Korean are encouraged to take the TOPIK (Test of Proficiency in Korean) which is available in over 70 countries worldwide.
Individuals with Korean language qualifications have job opportunities in business, technology, tourism, media, entertainment, film, and journalism.

The University of Nottingham features among the best in the world in a new ranking of individual subjects.
In this year’s ‘QS World University Rankings by Subject’, The University of Nottingham sits among the world’s most elite institutions in 33 of the 42 subjects surveyed.
The new rankings also feature 21 Nottingham subjects in the top 100, and six in the top 50.
The University was placed particularly highly in Pharmacy & Pharmacology (6th), Education (28th), Veterinary Science (35th), Geography (39th), Law (41st) and Agriculture & Forestry (42nd).
More than 4,226 universities worldwide were evaluated as part of the survey, with 945 institutions ranked in total.
The QS World University Rankings by subject series takes into account the opinion of academics and employers via a global survey.
The latest report showed that the University had come second for the second time in a row in the list of universities targeted by the largest number of top employers in 2015-16.
It has been voted the world’s greenest campus for three years running, according to Greenmetrics Ranking of World Universities.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers an Executive Master of Business Administration (EMBA) program designed for professionals seeking to advance their careers in business and management.
The EMBA program is accredited by the prestigious triple crown—EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), AACSB, and AMBA.

The EMBA curriculum provides education in leadership, strategy, and decision-making within a global context, including expertise in finance, marketing, operations management, and strategic leadership.

Students can choose elective modules from options such as Corporate Finance, Portfolio Management and Investment Analysis, Business and Commercial Law, Business Intelligence in the Digital Economy, and other specialized areas.

Students are required to have at least three years of full-time management or supervisory work experience, a second-class honors degree or equivalent professional qualification, and meet English language requirements (e.g., IELTS score of 6.5 with specific scores in each element).
The EMBA program fees are RM66,000 per program for Malaysian students and RM68,365 per program for international students.

The Malaysia campus of the University of Nottingham is located in Semenyih, which is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with access to various facilities such as schools, sports center, library, and student accommodation.

Upon graduation, EMBA students can pursue various career opportunities such as CEO, Management Consultant, Marketing Director, Financial Controller, Project Manager, IT Professional, and other managerial positions.
The University provides career support services including resume writing assistance and interview preparation for students preparing to enter the job market.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a variety of academic programs, including English literature and poetry.
Dr. Malachi Edwin Vethamani, a professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, has embarked on a book tour to raise awareness on English literature and encourage students to write.

Dr. Vethamani visited 11 higher-learning institutions nationwide, including Universiti Putra Malaysia, Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak, and Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman, as part of his literary journey.
Some of Dr. Vethamani's books have been incorporated into the syllabus of universities he visited, such as Coitus Interruptus and Other Stories.
University of Nottingham Malaysia's School of English dean, Professor Danton Remoto, expressed happiness with Dr. Vethamani's effort to inspire students and promote Malaysian English literature.
To become a writer, Dr. Vethamani advises aspiring writers to read a lot and attend writing courses or literary festivals like the George Town Literary Festival.

Am Muammar Abdul Aziz, a third-year student from the School of Economics at University of Nottingham Malaysia, was offered a position in this year’s Perdana Fellow Programme.
Candidates for the programme had to write an essay on how the youth can better prepare themselves for Industrial Revolution 4.0 as part of the preliminary screening.
Candidates who advanced were subjected to an online interview conducted by high-ranking government officials, focusing on global events, current government initiatives, and the political climate.
Only 82 candidates were selected out of the thousands who applied for the Perdana Fellow Programme this year.
Am will be stationed at the Ministry of Finance in Putrajaya for a six-month period as a fellow to Malaysia’s Finance Minister, YB Dato’ Senator Dato’ Sri Tengku Zafrul Tengku Abdul Aziz.
The CEO and Provost of University of Nottingham Malaysia, Professor Graham Kendall, congratulated Am for being accepted to the Perdana Fellow Programme.

NUBS Malaysia hosted the 2019 edition of the 'Nottingham In the City' Alumni Reception for alumni and invited guests of Nottingham University Business School Malaysia, held on 6 July 2019 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia's Teaching Centre in Kuala Lumpur.
The reception brought together alumni of the School, industry professionals, and faculty members in a casual setting aimed at expanding networks and sharing expertise.
The event was attended by students and alumni of the School, and members of the Nottingham Graduates Association Malaysia.

Guest speaker Robert Boxwell, Director of International Management and Professional Development Consultancy Opera Advisors, spoke on salient issues regarding the US-China Trade War and ways of strategizing amid possible changes in the global economic environment.
Alumni had the opportunity to broaden their network towards developing their professional and personal connections with former classmates and other MBA graduates, as well as with faculty members.
MBA Finance alumnus Haw Hui Mun mentioned the value of the Nottingham MBA beyond graduation in unlocking career opportunities and making social gatherings interesting.
Alumnus Sameeta Kaur of Virtual Health Angels found the event a good opportunity to network and connect with other graduates, expressing a desire for more such meetings.
President of the Nottingham Graduates Association Malaysia, Goh Hoon Huar, expressed enthusiasm for the event and looked forward to more such events.

Dean of Nottingham University Business School Malaysia Dr Lau Chee Kwong expressed delight in bringing together alumni for an evening of reunion and reminiscence, forging connections for future engagement opportunities.
The University of Nottingham has a global community of over 290,000 graduates.

Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia provides international quality teaching and scholarship in various areas of business, management, and finance, accredited by the European Quality Improvement System (EQUIS) and Association of MBAs (AMBA).

Zhi Xiang Ng is an Associate Professor in the School of Biosciences at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Zhi Xiang Ng obtained his PhD in Molecular Biochemistry from the University of Malaya and PGCHE from the University of Nottingham.
Zhi Xiang Ng is a Medical Laboratory Scientist registered under the Malaysian Allied Health Professions Council, Ministry of Health Malaysia.

Zhi Xiang Ng is a Fellow of Advanced Higher Education (UK) and a member of various scientific associations such as Malaysian Scientific Association and Malaysian Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
Zhi Xiang Ng is currently an editor board member of Scientific Reports and has been involved in peer reviewing for over 80 international science indexed journals.
Zhi Xiang Ng is teaching modules such as Food Materials and Ingredients, Genetic and Nutrition, and Statistical Skills For Bioscientists, among others.
Zhi Xiang Ng has been involved in studies related to the role of RAGE gene polymorphism and oxidative-glycation process in the development of retinopathy in type 2 diabetic patients.
Zhi Xiang Ng's expertise includes antioxidant, metabolic diseases risk factors and biomarkers, food sciences, and molecular nutrition.
Zhi Xiang Ng's publications include works on the anti-inflammatory activity of Peperomia pellucida extract and the potential of medicinal plants in diabetes management.
The Malaysian Aerospace Mission 2013 took place at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus from 18 to 22 March 2013.
The event aimed to foster collaboration between the University of Nottingham and the aerospace industry in Malaysia.
The event included technical discussions with industry players like BAE Systems, Spirit Aerosystems, and others.
The event received positive feedback, and both groups are exploring future collaboration opportunities.
Among the speakers at the conference were Professor Choy Kwang-Leong, Professor Graham Kendall, and Professor Andrew Chan.
For further information, contact Professor Andrew Chan at andy.chan@nottingham.edu.my or visit www.nottingham.ac.uk/aerospace.
Dr Ian Stephen has been awarded a Faculty of Science Pump Priming grant to investigate the effects of exercise on physical appearance.
In this project, we will use 3D imaging to model the changes that occur in the face and body when we exercise.
The technology that we will develop will also have the potential to demonstrate to individuals the effects that they can expect from undertaking exercise or other healthy behaviours.

Nadeera K. Vasu is an alumna of BSc (Hons) Psychology at The University of Nottingham Malaysia and a former recipient of a scholarship from Yayasan Sime Darby (YSD) under the Bursary Fund for Students with Special Needs.

Nadeera was born with Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI), otherwise known as ‘brittle bones’, and as a result of this, suffers from respiratory challenges and severe scoliosis, among other things.
Nadeera first made waves at Malaysia Fashion Week Runway in 2018 when she took the stage as a differently abled model.
Nadeera also encouraged others to dream big and to never give up despite their physical and mental health challenges and to also always seek professional help when needed.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) and The National Tech Association of Malaysia (PIKOM) announced the renewal and expansion of their Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to further develop industry-academia collaboration that aims to enhance Malaysia’s technology ecosystem.

The MoU was first signed in 2020 for Global Business Services (GBS), and this MoU renewal will see both parties extend their partnership to collaborate on several initiatives covering the entire ICT industry represented by PIKOM.

Dr Hazel Melanie Ramos, Vice Provost for Teaching and Learning at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, expressed excitement to continue the partnership with PIKOM to promote industry-academia collaboration.

Mr. Ong Chin Seong, Chairman of PIKOM, shared PIKOM’s vision to support the government’s goal of Digital Economy contributing 25.5% to the nation's GDP by 2025 and acknowledged the importance of collaboration with higher institutions like University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Dr Mandy Sim, Associate Professor in Services at UNM, was appointed as an Advisor on PIKOM’s Talent Gap Committee to bridge the talent gap for the industry and oversee intern placements from universities.

PIKOM represents the ICT industry in Malaysia and consists of chapters focused on global business services, cybersecurity, chief information officer, e-commerce, venture investment, women in technology, and SpaceTech Malaysia, with over 1,000 active members.
The talk on Risk Management in the Financial Industry was conducted by Mr. Jase Chen Ko Mun, Assistant General Manager, Group Risk Management, CIMB Investment.
The talk took place on Tuesday, 13 April 2010, from 4.00pm to 5.30pm at Room F3A04, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (Semenyih Campus).

The University of Nottingham celebrated the graduation of 27 students on its Master of Business Administration (MBA) program in Singapore on 13 January 2017.
The MBA program is offered in the UK, Malaysia, and at the University\u2019s partner institution in Singapore, PSB Academy.
The Nottingham MBA program in Singapore had 19 students graduate with an MBA and eight students with an MBA in Finance.
The Nottingham MBA is accredited by the European Quality Improvement System (EQUIS) and the Association of MBAs (AMBA), with global recognition.
The graduation was attended by key personnel from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC), PSB Academy, and Nottingham University Business School Malaysia.
PSB Academy is situated at two campuses in Singapore: PSB Academy Delta and PSB Academy City Campus at Marina Square.
PSB Academy was awarded 'Best private education institution in Singapore' and 'Best private education institution for Engineering'.
PSB Academy conducts graduate employment surveys, showing high employment rates and career progression for its graduates.

Soon Tat Lee is an Assistant Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee graduated with a BSc (Hons) in Speech Science from the National University of Malaysia and pursued a PhD at the School of Psychology, University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee's expertise includes cognitive and linguistic mechanisms involved in bilingual language processing, language testing, and test validation.

Soon Tat Lee has worked on developing language tests that assess specific language constructs in language pairs such as Malay-English and Mandarin-English, aiming to enhance language learning in multilingual contexts.
Soon Tat Lee has published papers related to translation norms for Malay and English words, lexical tests for Malay speakers, and assessing children's native language in Mandarin.

A team of students from Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia has emerged champions of the HSBC Malaysia Business Case Challenge 2015.
The team, T&F Consulting, will represent Malaysia at the regional HSBC/HKU Asia Pacific Business Case Competition 2015.

The Competition is scheduled to take place over three days from June 3-5 2015, with the initial rounds at The University of Hong Kong and the final round at the HSBC Main Building in Central, Hong Kong.

Students at the University of Nottingham Malaysia can do an optional internship over the summer between year 1 and year 2 or between year 2 and year 3 to gain experience in the field of Psychology. The internship can be clinical-, scientific-, or business-focused and helps prepare students for the job market.

The internships are part of the Nottingham Advantage Awards (NAA) and students receive a certificate and study credits upon completion, which will show on their transcript. There are three workshops throughout the summer for students to share experiences, and each student is assigned a mentor.

Student testimonial: One student's internship experience focused on drug addiction recovery, HIV/AIDS awareness, and outreach programs at Poliklinik Khafidz and Persatuan Insaf Murni. The internship raised awareness on reducing the spread of HIV/AIDS.

Student testimonial: An intern at Adapt Enrichment Centre in Ara Damansara worked on early intervention programs for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder. They learned how to communicate and interact effectively with children with ASD and developed tailored teaching approaches for academic subjects and life skills.

The internships offered by the School of Psychology at UMN prepare students for real-world situations, help them apply classroom learning into practical settings, and foster personal development and valuable skills necessary for their future careers.
The internships at UMN provide students with hands-on experience, reinforce their career aspirations, and help them bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical skills.

The internships offered by the School of Psychology at UMN provide students with opportunities to work with passionate professionals, gain valuable skills, network, and contribute to meaningful projects in various fields related to psychology.

The internships focus on enhancing students' technical and soft skills, fostering personal growth, building confidence, and providing valuable insights into potential career paths within psychology and related fields.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a 'Curb Your Ego' Campaign developed by students to encourage respect and humility within the community.
The campaign was initiated by students at Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) as part of their Entrepreneurship & Business module.
The Curb Your Ego Campaign at the University of Nottingham Malaysia was launched on 1 April 2013.
The students involved in the campaign introduced Pledge-bands (rubber wristbands) as a way for staff and students to show support.
The campaign focused on creating awareness among staff in the first week and targeted students in the second week.
There are plans to extend the campaign to University of Nottingham campuses in the UK and China during a student exchange program.
The committee members of the campaign include Cassandra Tam Chiu Ying, Joel Kuan Kok Hao, Cham Jia Shen, Wong Xiao Cheng, Lee Kai Rong, and Ter Ven Siew.

Developing Sustainable Societies is a multidisciplinary platform tackling environmental problems and helping make societies resilient to global change.

Developing Sustainable Societies collaborates with major non-governmental organizations (NGOs) like World Wildlife Fund and companies like Sime Darby Plantation to contribute to the conservation of biodiversity in tropical Asia.
The Management and Ecology of Malaysian Elephants (MEME) project under Developing Sustainable Societies focuses on the conservation of elephants and sustainable management of agricultural landscapes.

Developing Sustainable Societies works with experts from Nottingham Geospatial Institute to provide insights into issues like landcover change and impacts of climate change on flooding in tropical Asia.

Nottingham University Business School is involved in promoting interdisciplinary collaboration within Developing Sustainable Societies and is a signatory to the United Nations Principles for Responsible Management Education (PRME).

The Social and Environmental Responsibility Group at Nottingham University Business School drives sustainability-related developments and projects on the Malaysia campus and advises on adopting sustainable practices.
Experts from Developing Sustainable Societies are interested in working with commercial and non-commercial partners, policymakers, and the media to make a real-world difference.
For general enquiries about Developing Sustainable Societies, contact Prof Chris Gibbins at christopher.gibbins@nottingham.edu.my.
For enquiries about the MEME project, contact Ms Vivienne Loke at vivienne.loke@nottingham.edu.my.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia celebrated its 8th UNM Resume Competition on 5th December 2024, organized by the UNM Careers Advisory Services.
The event aimed to enhance students’ employability skills and provide opportunities for recognition from industry leaders and potential employers.
The competition took place in the Student Lounge, Block H1, with winners receiving over RM4,000 in cash prizes.
The competition was followed by a resume speed-review session by the judges, including Professor David FitzPatrick and other distinguished guests.
There were three categories of winners: Foundation, Year 1 and Year 2; Year 3 and Year 4; and Postgraduates.
Representatives from key employers like Maybank and Avery Dennison Materials Sdn Bhd were in attendance at the event.
Participants had from 7th to 26th October 2024 to submit their resumes, with a total of 217 submissions.

The UNM Resume Competition continues to prepare students for successful careers in the global workforce.

The University of Nottingham renewed its partnership with Kasetsart University through the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on 21 August 2024.

The MoU was signed by Professor Jane Norman, Provost and Deputy Vice-Chancellor at University of Nottingham; Professor David FitzPatrick, Interim Provost and CEO of University of Nottingham Malaysia; and Kasetsart University’s Acting President, Dr Chongrak Wachrinrat, along with Associate Professor Dr Apisit Songsasen.

The partnership aims to deepen collaboration across all campuses, fostering a multidisciplinary approach, advancing knowledge, sparking innovation, and creating enriching opportunities for students and faculty.

The MoU facilitates student exchanges between the University of Nottingham’s tri-campus network and Kasetsart University, enhancing students' adaptability, cross-cultural communication skills, and professional networks.
The renewed collaboration with Kasetsart University represents a significant milestone in the University of Nottingham’s journey toward academic excellence and global engagement.
By forging strong international partnerships, the University of Nottingham continues to solidify its position as a leader in higher education.

The Master of Business Administration (MBA) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a comprehensive program focusing on leadership, strategy, and decision-making in a global context.
The MBA program is accredited by EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), AACSB, and AMBA.

The elective modules available for the MBA program include Corporate Finance, Portfolio Management and Investment Analysis, Business and Commercial Law, Business Ethics, Business Intelligence in the Digital Economy, Entrepreneurship in Practice, Innovation Management, and Leadership and Change Management.
Students are required to complete a total of 12 taught modules (8 core modules and 4 elective modules) and a Management Project as part of the MBA program.

Entry requirements for the MBA program include a second-class honors degree (2:2) or its international equivalent in a relevant field, at least three years of full-time post-graduation work experience, and English language proficiency (e.g., IELTS 6.5 or equivalent).

The University of Nottingham Malaysia through the School of Politics, History and International Relations (PHIR) has engaged over 175 organizations with an outreach of 402 participants in capacity-building sessions over the past four months to enhance the competency of internal and third-party auditors in detecting and reporting incidences of forced labor in Malaysia.
The effort was in direct response to Malaysia being downgraded to Tier 3 in the 2021 Trafficking In Persons (TIP) Report by the US State Department.

University of Nottingham Malaysia, Interim Provost and CEO Professor Sarah Metcalfe acknowledges the cooperation from industry associations such as MARGMA and Government agencies including NSO MAPO, MPOCC, MSPO as well as participating plantation and manufacturing companies.

Forced labor entails the retention of identity documents or passports, payment of excessive recruitment fees, contract substitution, poor pay and work conditions, involuntary overtime, and lack of freedom for workers to resign.

Denis Low, Director for Corporate Affairs at Supermax Corporation Berhad said, 'While Supermax has taken and will continue to take every measure to ensure there are no instances of forced labor or workers rights violations at any of our sites, we cannot underestimate the positive impact these trainings have had; it is a mind-opening experience.'

The 'Enhancement of Manufacturing and Oil Palm Third-Party Audits Compliance and Due Diligence with Certification Bodies' capacity-building project led by UNM’s School of PHIR runs from 30 August 2021 to 28 February 2022.

The project is funded by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office, UK and was supported by various organizations including the National Strategic Office Council for Anti-Trafficking in Persons and Anti-Smuggling of Migrants (NSO MAPO), Ministry of Plantation Industries and Commodities (MPIC), Ministry of Human Resources (MOHR), Malaysian Rubber Glove Manufacturers Association (MARGMA), Malaysian Palm Oil Certification Council (MPOCC), Malaysian Sustainable Palm Oil (MSPO), and Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO).

UNM hosted a multi-stakeholder panel discussion with representatives from MPIC, MPOCC, International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), among others, to discuss further efforts to enhance multi-stakeholder cooperation in tackling forced labor in Malaysia.

The DELF and DALF are diplomas awarded by the French Ministry of Education to prove the French-language skills of non-French candidates.
There are six independent diplomas, which correspond, respectively, to the six levels of the Council of Europe's Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFRL).
DELF Scolaire is at the moment one of the popular international and definitely recognized foreign examinations.

Candidates who receive the DELF DALF diplomas as an attestation of their level of French acknowledged by the Ministry of Education of France benefit from having a diploma that is recognized internationally.
Holders of the DELF B2 or DALF diplomas are exempted from language entrance examinations in French universities.
At the end of French 1A or 1B, you can sit for DELF A1. At the end of French 2A or 2B, you can sit for DELF A2. At the end of French 3B, you can sit for DELF B1.
Registration: 01 May 2024, Wednesday to 30 May 2024, Thursday.
Exam date: 04 June 2024, Tuesday (oral) 09 June 2024, Sunday (written).
Test centre: The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Fees: DELF A1 RM252.00, DELF A2 RM297.00, DELF B1 RM378.00, DELF B2 RM414.00.
Ee-Soo Lee completed her Bachelor of Science (Hons) degree with a major in Biochemistry at the University of Malaya, Malaysia.
During her undergraduate studies, she developed a diagnostic kit for detecting biomarkers in the serum of cancer patients.
She pursued her PhD studies in Vascular Biology at the University of Groningen, the Netherlands, focusing on biomechanical regulation of endothelial phenotype.
She completed her postdoctoral training in Adipose Tissue Biology.
In 2023, the American Heart Association recognized her work on ACKR1 with the Paul Dudley White International Scholar Award.
Ee-Soo Lee has been a lecturer in biology and physiology and an Assistant Professor at the School of Pharmacy, University of Nottingham Malaysia since 2024.
Ee-Soo Lee's teaching philosophy is rooted in the belief that education is a transformative and lifelong experience that empowers individuals to grow intellectually, professionally and personally.
She teaches biology and physiology courses for the Bachelor of Pharmacy (Hons), Master of Pharmacy (Hons), and Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Biomedical Science programs at the School of Pharmacy.

Her current studies focus on Transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β) signaling, with an emphasis on ALK4, ALK5, and ALK7 receptors in the regulation of endothelial cell functions and adipose tissue remodeling.

Chiew Foan Chin is a Professor in Plant Biotechnology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Associate Professor Ko Choong Woo is currently an Associate Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Ko Choong Woo's expertise includes nonlinear mechanical vibrations, vibro-impact dynamics, fracture and fatigue, and condition monitoring.

Professor Chew Ging Lee, Dean of NUBS Malaysia, attended the 5th International Business School Shanghai Conference 2014, hosted by the Antai College of Economics and Management, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, on October 9-10, 2014.
The conference saw contributions from 230 participants from over 35 countries on the theme of Innovation and Entrepreneurship.

Discussions at the conference focused on new international accreditation standards for management education, emerging opportunities for Asian business schools, and the role of innovation and entrepreneurship education in driving sustainable development.

Plenary speakers at the conference included Professor Zhou Lin, Dean of the Antai College of Economics and Management, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Professor William Boulding, Dean of the Fuqua School of Business, Duke University, USA, Professor Alfons Sauquet Rovira, Dean of ESADE Business School Spain, Professor Soumitra Dutta, Dean of the Johnson Graduate School of Management, Cornell University, USA, and Professor Cai Hongbin, Dean of the Guanghua School of Management, Peking University, China.
Professor Lee also participated in a gathering of business school deans from the Asia-Pacific region.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus carried out ‘Challenge-based Obesity Awareness Intervention for Youth and School Children’, which is a project to raise awareness of obesity and its related problems.
The obesity awareness team was led by Dr Suresh Kumar Mohankumar from Department of Biomedical Sciences and Dr Soma Mitra from the School of Bioscience.
The first phase of the project consisted of an ‘Intra-school poster competition’ among SMK Convent Kajang, SMJK Yu Hua Kajang, SMK Dato’ Klana Putra Lenggeng, and SMK King George V, Seremban.
Winners from the first phase then proceeded to the next and final ‘Inter-high school poster competition’ held in UNMC.

At the awards presentation day, the Nutrition club and Biomedical Sciences Society from UNMC conducted interactive games for visitors and provided hands-on health education activities at their booths.
The winners of the competition were awarded cash prizes, gym memberships, and certificates.
The project was funded by Tanita Healthy Weight Community Trust and Impact Nottingham.

A team of students from the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) emerged as the national First Runners-Up in the KPMG International Case Competition 2018 National Finals held recently in Petaling Jaya.

The National Finals of the competition saw nine shortlisted teams from various universities in Malaysia working on proposed solutions for a case study on improving the business performance of a Dubai-based hospitality firm.

The team from UNMC, Team Nolan & Gladstone, comprised of second and third-year Business School students Phung Pei Shan and Amirrudin Bin Azmi respectively, third-year School of Economics student Leow Chok Nam, and fourth-year Mechanical Engineering student Kam Shi Khai.

The team's strategy focused on recommendations for customizations in the hospitality industry through the use of big data analytics, neural networks, and artificial intelligence, on technologies such as facial recognition, to tap into the purchasing power of the millennial generation.

Members of the UNMC team received conditional internship offers from KPMG and were invited to a luncheon with KPMG Partners, together with the Champion team from Taylor's University, and Second Runners-Up Xiamen University Malaysia Campus.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is proud to announce the return of the prestigious UNAM-UNM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Award Essay Competition in 2025.
The competition encourages students, including those awaiting results from SPM, IGCSE, A-Levels, and equivalent qualifications, to share their perspectives and propose actionable solutions.
This year’s essay competition invites young minds aged 17 to 23 (as of 31 December 2024) to explore the theme: Meaningful Education for a Nation’s Progress, Innovation, and Inclusiveness.

Submission Requirements: Word count: 1,500 to 2,000 words, A strong understanding of educational issues, Clear, inspiring writing with a persuasive call to action, Recognition of challenges and practical solutions to key issues, Reference to the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) as relevant
Students can submit their essays in Word or PDF format by 2 April 2025 (Wednesday).

Entries will be evaluated by a distinguished panel of judges from UNM and UNAM. The top three winners will receive prizes: 1st Prize: RM2,000.00, 2nd Prize: RM1,500.00, 3rd Prize: RM1,000.00. Additionally, five entries will receive commendations for exceptional quality.
The gap between the last competition in 2019 and its return in 2025 was largely a result of the global challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
In 2024, under the leadership of its new President, Dato' Seri Mustapa, UNAM reignited its collaboration with UNM to bring this esteemed competition back to life.
Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Ismail played a key role in the groundbreaking ceremony in January 2002 for UNM’s purpose-built campus in Semenyih.
He was conferred a Doctor of Laws honoris causa during UNM’s first graduation ceremony in 2002 and later received the University Alumni Laureate Lifetime Achievement Award in 2013.
As a founding member of UNAM, he was honoured as an Ambassador for Peace on World Peace Day in 2005.
As we celebrate UNM’s 25th anniversary, this competition serves as a tribute to his enduring legacy and passion for education for all Malaysians.

Professor Shearer West has started her role as President and Vice-Chancellor at the University of Nottingham. She is the seventh Vice-Chancellor in the University's history and the first woman in the role.

An academic art historian, Professor West has also held a number of significant leadership roles in universities and higher education – including, most recently, as Provost and Deputy Vice-Chancellor at the University of Sheffield.

In her first few months in office the new Vice-Chancellor will be meeting staff, students and stakeholders regionally and internationally – across the University’s campuses in Nottingham, China and Malaysia.

The Nottingham Advantage Award is an employability award designed to increase students' employability and help them get the most out of their time at University.
Participation in the Nottingham Advantage Award is included on the degree transcript and recognized at the graduation ceremony.
The award provides skills development, recognition, experience for CV, examples for job interviews, and lasting memories from university.
The Nottingham Advantage Award spans the entire University to make students more employable and enhance their university experience.
Undergraduate students with enthusiasm for activities outside their main academic studies are encouraged to apply for the Nottingham Advantage Award.
The Nottingham Advantage Award involves a mixture of activities delivered by academic schools and non-academic departments to enhance learning and recognize contributions outside the core curriculum.
Teaching elements of the Nottingham Advantage Award amount to around 20 hours, with around 40 hours of independent study required for assessment.
There are no extra exams for the Nottingham Advantage Award, but students are required to engage in reflective activities like keeping a journal or creating an e-portfolio.
Students interested in completing three (3) modules for the Nottingham Advantage Award should take them during their first two years of study to be eligible.

The University collects and processes personal data of potential employees for employment purposes.
The personal data collected may include information such as name, identification number, contact details, education background, skills, etc.
Sensitive personal data collected may include ethnicity, religion, health information, criminal records, etc.
The University uses personal data for purposes such as assessing job applications, administration, compliance with laws, and corporate governance.
Personal data is obtained from applicants directly through resumes, application forms, certificates, etc.
Personal data may also be obtained from third-party service providers or internal sources such as company assets.
Applicants have the right to request access to and correction of their personal data by contacting the Human Resource Department.
Personal data may be disclosed to authorized third parties for specific purposes as outlined in the document.
The University may amend the Notice and Choice Principle Statement periodically and will communicate changes accordingly.
The University's policies comply with the Personal Data Protection Act 2010.

Khoo Chong Siang graduated with a BSc (Hons) in Finance, Accounting, and Management in 2018 from the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Khoo Chong Siang is now the CFO and co-founder of Foodlab Venture in Kuala Lumpur.
Foodlab is a shared cloud kitchen that provides kitchen space and support for local food entrepreneurs, including marketing, accounting services, and sales tracking.
Khoo's future plans for Foodlab include expanding to a minimum of three shared kitchens and offering services outside of the Klang Valley.
Khoo faced challenges in starting Foodlab, including navigating through the Movement Control Order (MCO).
Khoo's role as the Chief Financial Officer at Foodlab involves ensuring the company's practices are sustainable to support local food businesses during the pandemic.
Khoo started by building a food surplus reselling startup before venturing into the creation of Foodlab.
Khoo highlights that his degree life at UNM was memorable, especially his exchange year to the Ningbo campus and studying with friends at the outdoor cafeteria.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus has emerged as champions at the 2016 ICAEW Regional Business Case Challenge.

The winning team from the Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia comprised of final-year students Fabiolla Netto, Evonne Chen May Yie, Ngam Li Hsian, and Ian Lim Chen Wei, and second-year students Roy Lam Phoung and Tan Jia Wei.
Team captain Fabiolla Netto was crowned the Best Speaker in the competition.
Dr. Pek Chuen Khee is a Senior University Teaching Fellow at NUBS Malaysia and served as the group's mentor for the competition.
"Soft-skills are hard requirements, which can be developed through student competitions like the ICAEW Regional Business Case Challenge," according to Dr. Pek.

"At Nottingham, we believe that a holistic education should include our graduates' ability to lead, manage, communicate, and address challenges of the less privileged," said Professor Christine Ennew, CEO and Provost of UNMC.

The exercise challenges PhD students to present a compelling oration on their thesis topic and its significance in just three minutes.
The first 3MT was held at the University of Queensland in 2008 with 160 RHD students competing.
Enthusiasm for the 3MT concept grew and its widespread implementation by universities has led to the development of an international competition.
The strong support for 3MT exists in Australia and New Zealand with 44 institutions coming together to participate in the 2013 Trans-Tasman 3MT Competition.
The global reach of the competition can be seen by the extent of participation with universities in Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom, and Vietnam also hosting local 3MT events.

Jasmin Irisha Jim Ilham and Dulanga Witharanage from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) have been selected to be part of the Malaysian Youth Delegation 2016 (MYD 2016) at the 22nd Conference of the Parties (COP22), United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) in Marrakech, Morocco due to be held from 7 to 18 November 2016.
Both Jasmin and Dulanga, who are from the Faculty of Environmental and Geographical Sciences, had to undergo a rigorous application process to be selected as part of MYD 2016.
Shortlisted applicants were required to go through an interview session, where they were questioned deep into their understanding and knowledge of climate change, the Paris Agreement and UNFCCC.
Applicants were finally shortlisted taking into consideration their academic merits and achievements, as well as their contributions towards community and environmental initiatives.
Jasmin and Dulanga are representatives of MYD and will be observing the negotiation process whilst shadowing the Malaysian negotiators alongside two other youth candidates from Malaysia.
Jasmin and Dulanga’s participation is funded by UNMC.

They are expected to take part at the Conference of Youth 12 (COY12) from 4 to 6 November, where they will join youth from across the globe to address climate change and promote sustainable lifestyles.
Last year, UNMC students, Emily Oi, Jolene Journe Tan and Thomas Lai Yoke Hwa represented Malaysia at COP21.
Issues relating to climate change have never been more important and pertinent globally which needs to be addressed urgently.
More youth should be motivated to address climate change that affects humankind; regardless of country, religion and social background.
The Malaysian Youth Delegation will be the voice of the Malaysian Youth at COP22.
We eagerly look forward to use this platform to engage in this global agenda after having been exposed to relevant issues during our studies.
We are very grateful to UNMC for sponsoring us, and all our family and friends for supporting us.
Jasmin (left) and Dulanga at the 5th Asia-Pacific Climate Change Adaptation Forum in Sri Lanka
