Two final year students from the University of Nottingham Malaysia, Jason Lee Jun Wei and Kueh Jia Lee, emerged as the champions of the ABB Intervarsity Innovation Challenge 2019.

The Bachelor of Education (BEd) TESOL programme is designed for individuals aspiring to teach English as a Second or Other Language (TESOL) at primary or secondary school levels. The programme offers practical experience and the opportunity to spend up to one year in an international school.

The curriculum of the BEd (Hons) in TESOL equips students in planning, delivering, and assessing teaching content, mastering classroom management, and TESOL methodologies. It includes school placements throughout the program, with a final year assessed school experience.
The BEd (Hons) in TESOL does not confer UK Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) but provides a solid foundation for teaching roles globally.
Entry requirements for the BEd (Hons) in TESOL include A Level qualifications of CCC, IB Diploma requirements of 24 points overall, and other equivalent qualifications.
English language requirements for the program include IELTS score of 6.5, TOEFL score of 90, or equivalent English proficiency exams.
Malaysian students for the BEd (Hons) in TESOL program are required to pay RM42,000 per year, while international students are required to pay RM50,000 per year.

The Semenyih Campus of the University of Nottingham Malaysia is located 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and houses various schools, a sports center, library, student accommodation, and offers easy access to public transportation.
Career opportunities after completing the BEd (Hons) in TESOL include roles such as Teacher, Curriculum Planner/Developer, Social Entrepreneur, Instructional Designer, and Education Entrepreneur.

Frequently asked questions about the BEd (Hons) in TESOL cover topics such as program details, entry requirements, job outlook, teaching opportunities in Malaysia and abroad, and skills developed during the course.

The BSc (Hons) International Business Management at the University of Nottingham Malaysia equips students with the skills and knowledge to thrive in a global business environment. This three-year programme combines cutting-edge modules in economics, strategic management, marketing, and international business, providing a comprehensive understanding of global business operations.

Accredited by the prestigious triple crown—EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), AACSB, and AMBA—this degree ensures exemptions from professional examinations, accelerating your pathway to becoming a qualified professional.

With opportunities to customise your learning through optional modules in areas such as digital marketing, marketing analytics, human resource management, and entrepreneurship, students can align their studies with their career aspirations. Guided by expert faculty and supported by state-of-the-art facilities, graduates will be prepared for diverse roles in international business, consultancy, management, and entrepreneurship.
The programme integrates sustainability and ethics, ensuring students are ready to lead responsibly in the global marketplace.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia entry requirements for the BSc (Hons) International Business Management include A Level qualifications, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD), Gaokao and Senior High School Diploma (China), Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE) / Indian School Certificate (CISCE) - Class XII, Advance Placement (AP), Diploma - Local Institutions, Foundation - Local Institutions, and Nottingham's Foundation Programme.
In addition to the entry requirements, applicants must have a grade B in Mathematics at SPM/GCSE/IGCSE/High School Diploma level or equivalent.
English language requirements for entry include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level, GCSE O-Level, and others, with specific score requirements in each element.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers careers opportunities such as Chartering Executive, Business Development Analyst/Consultant, Growth Marketer, Marketing Associate, and Data Analyst for graduates of the BSc (Hons) International Business Management program.

The School of Pharmacy and Alumni and Donor Relations Office (ADRO) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) organized an online webinar titled “Women in healthcare: From the front line to the industry” on 27 November 2021.
The session was moderated by UNM alumna Dr Grace Ch’ng, who is currently a teaching fellow at the School of Pharmacy.
The speakers were alumni from Malaysia and the United Kingdom in different disciplines in the healthcare fields.
The list of speakers included Dr. Lim Su Wen (PhD in Biosciences, 2014), Melody Kan (Master’s in Pharmacy, 2011), and Natalie Lim (BSc (Hons) in Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences, 2012).
The event attracted more than 90 participants including students, alumni, and the general public.
Despite women’s excellent representation in the healthcare sector, they still remained underrepresented in senior and leadership positions.
Fresh graduates were advised to equip themselves with additional skill sets alongside their degree as digital innovation is becoming prevalent in the industry.
The event left the audience with valuable knowledge and experience for those joining the workforce.

The workshop on cross-cultural competencies was organized for NUBS Malaysia MBA students at the final stage of study.

The title of the workshop was 'Cross-Cultural Management - The Cornerstone to Global Leadership'.
The speaker of the workshop was Professor Betty J Chung, Professor of Cross-Cultural Management and Leadership Development at KAIST College of Business.
Professor Chung provided a framework of cultural dimensions and tools to bridge cultural gaps during the workshop.
Professor Chung has over 20 years of experience in the field of cross-cultural management and leadership development.

Applications are invited for a fully funded 2-year Mphil studentship post (1-year probation in the first instance) in the Division of Biomedical Sciences, School of Pharmacy, University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Successful applicant will be involved in sampling, propagating dust mites and investigating the ozone therapy effect on the dust mites.
The student will gain extensive hands-on training in the field of Mite Allergy and Applied Immunology. The project has the potential to advance to the PhD level.
Candidate with experiences in mammalian cell culture will be an added advantage but not a prerequisite for the application.
Tuition-fee waiver and monthly stipend RM1800 will be provided for successful candidate.
Undergraduate degree related to Biomedical Sciences / Pharmacy / Biosciences / Molecular Biology / or other related disciplines with a first or upper second class.
Possess a good command of English, both spoken and written.
Possess good communication and interpersonal skills.

Willingness to travel, possess own transport with valid driving license. The candidate is required to travel for field sampling and propagating the dust mites’ culture in International Medical University, Bukit Jalil (Year1) and mammalian cell culture work in University of Nottingham Malaysia (Year2).
Willingness to work with dust mites and ozone therapy effect on the dust mites.

Other necessary attributes include self-motivated, ability to work independently and a team, hard-working, resourceful and willing to learn/share. Biweekly/ monthly progress report is expected from the candidate.
Please email your application together with your curriculum vitae, academic transcripts and degree certificate to Dr Kenny Voon via email at Kenny.Voon@nottingham.edu.my before 31st Oct 2023.
Only shortlisted applicant will be contacted for interview.

China and its global partners will embark on projects in transport, energy, mining, technology, and tourism.
Dr Ben Barton is an Assistant Professor in the School of Politics, History and International Relations.
Dr Ben Barton has developed a policy brief urging the UK to adopt a clear stance on the Belt and Road Initiative.
Dr Barton's policy brief explains ways in which the government can help make the Belt and Road Initiative into a global public good.

The Asia House panel discussion drew a distinguished audience comprising ambassadors, diplomats, peers from the House of Lords, British civil servants, and senior members of the University of Nottingham.
The event was further broadcast on Asia House TV and fueled further social media interest.
Dr Barton's policy brief has become his most-read work so far in his career.
Dr Barton's work lays the foundation for the UK to assert itself by using all available policy instruments to help improve the Belt and Road Initiative.

Rasyad A. Parinduri is an Associate Professor at the Nottingham School of Economics. He received his M.A. in Economics from the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor and Ph.D. in Economics from the National University of Singapore.
Rasyad teaches econometrics, labor economics, and behavioral economics at the Nottingham School of Economics.
Rasyad has published in journals such as the Oxford Economic Papers, Economics of Education Review, Journal of Development Studies, and World Development.
Rasyad's teaching includes modules on Advanced Labour Economics, Applied Econometrics II, Experimental and Behavioral Economics, and Introduction to Microeconomics.
Rasyad has published papers on various topics such as the effects of social health insurance, land acquisition attitudes, trade liberalization, and education on political participation.

Commencing from the academic year 2024/2025, students will be entitled to a 2.5% early payment discount if they were to pay the full academic year fee before or on 31st August 2024.

Payments made after the due date would not be entitled to any early payment discounts. The early payment discounts will also not be applicable for any subsequent withdrawals during the academic year from the program/course.
Early payment discount is not applicable to sponsoring bodies. All such discounts will be calculated based on net payment due after all other scholarships and discounts.
The actual tuition fees payable are in Ringgit Malaysia and any shortfall or excess from any translation of foreign currencies to Ringgit Malaysia and bank charges must be borne by the student.

Foundation 2024/2025 Spring 21/01/2025
Foundation 2024/2025 Summer 20/05/2025
Undergraduate, Post Graduate & Postgraduate Taught (for Existing Students) (Except PGT by Module, Offshore & PGR Progression Course) 2024/2025 Autumn 18/02/2025
Failure to settle the outstanding tuition fees will result in a late penalty of 5% per annum being imposed on any outstanding balance or a minimum of RM100 whichever is higher.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) held a STEAM Carnival with over 700 students from 18 schools engaged in various workshops and activities related to Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics (STEAM), from 22 April to 24 April 2024.

The Interactive BioDome, an eco-exhibition at UNM, was developed collaboratively by the Faculty of Science and Engineering (FOSE) and students from the Tenby International School Setia EcoHill as part of UNM’s STEAM Ambassador Programme.

The 'talking plants' project in the BioDome enabled plants to communicate with visitors through collaborative mechanics and functions employing sensors, microcontrollers, speakers, and immersive technologies.
MDEC and CelcomDigi were supporting partners at the STEAM Carnival, conducting coding, drone technology activities, and showcasing electric bikes for students.

Professor Sam Kingman emphasized UNM's focus on STEAM education to prepare graduates for the ever-changing workplace expectations by connecting different academic disciplines and encouraging creativity and critical thinking skills in real-world contexts.

Non-Malaysian nationals who wish to study full-time in Malaysia must apply for a Student Pass (Visa) as per Regulation 13 of the Immigration Regulations 1963.
International students must apply and obtain the Visa Approval Letter (VAL) before entering Malaysia and cannot enter once their applications have been submitted for VAL processing.
Students holding various other passes like Diplomatic Exemption Order, Dependant Pass, etc., are required to apply for a Student Pass and cannot convert existing passes to Student Visa.

Students changing courses or institutions must submit a new Student Pass application and processing fees for different circumstances like changing courses, transferring in/out from another institution.

Malaysian Immigration Department requires specific documents for the visa application process including passport copies, academic certificates/transcripts, vaccination card, and various forms based on citizenship.
Students transferring from other academic institutions in Malaysia need to provide additional documentation like release letter, attendance report, academic results, and visa cancellation letter.
Foundation and undergraduate students aged 25 and above are required to submit a resume/CV with personal particulars, previous education, and work experience.
Upon receiving the Visa Approval Letter (VAL), students must apply for a Single Entry Visa (SEV) before traveling to Malaysia to avoid issues with the Malaysian Immigration authorities.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia applies for the Student Pass on behalf of students after tuition fee deposit and notifies them through email.
International students who defer, withdraw, or complete studies must shorten/cancel their student pass before leaving Malaysia as per the Malaysian Immigration Department guidelines.
Contact details for Student Visa Office: Hotline: +603 8924 8088, Telephone: +603 8724 8075, Email: Apply.Visa@nottingham.edu.my

The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Electrical and Electronic Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) prepares students for dynamic careers at the forefront of technology and innovation.

The curriculum integrates core engineering principles with innovative topics such as VLSI Design, Embedded Systems, Power Systems, Electrical Machines, Robotics, Drones, Autonomous Vehicles, Renewable Energy, Artificial Intelligence, Digital Signal Processing, and Software Programming.
Students gain valuable hands-on experience from their first year through project-based learning in state-of-the-art practical lab facilities.

Graduates emerge with advanced technical skills, project management expertise, and leadership capabilities, making them highly sought after by employers in sectors such as semiconductors, embedded systems, IoT, power generation, robotics, autonomous systems, renewable energy, telecommunications, and advanced technology.

Accredited Excellence: Accredited by the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) and Engineering Accreditation Council (EAC) Malaysia, meeting academic requirements for Chartered Engineer status.

Comprehensive Curriculum: Covers advanced topics such as power systems, renewable energy, artificial intelligence, and digital signal processing, preparing students for diverse engineering challenges.
Practical Focus: Gain hands-on experience through construction projects, group designs, and a final-year individual project, developing real-world problem-solving skills.
Cutting-Edge Tools: Offers training in modern tools, programming, and simulation software, ensuring proficiency with the latest technologies in engineering.

Career-Ready Graduates: Combines technical expertise with project management and leadership training, equipping graduates for impactful roles in energy, telecommunications, and electronics industries.

UNM scholarships are available for both Malaysian and international students.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia reserves the right to withdraw a scholarship if the recipient is found ineligible or does not adhere to scholarship terms and conditions.
Scholarships at UNM are applicable for tuition fee reduction only, and no allowance or stipend is provided.
Students are required to accept the scholarship offer by the given deadline to retain the scholarship.
Students can only hold one scholarship during the duration of their course.
Students must inform the Sponsorship Unit of any other scholarships or sponsorships currently held or awarded at a later date.
Further scholarship conditions include meeting scholarship requirements for satisfactory progress and agreeing to act as an ambassador for the university.
Scholarships at UNM may require attending scholarship or recruitment events and providing testimonials if requested.
Scholarship recipients may be contacted by the University approximately three years after graduation for updates on their career progress.
Scholarships co-funded with external organizations involve passing on details to these organizations for selection and reporting purposes.
Financial aid at UNM is provided in the form of allowances, grants, and more to support eligible candidates.
At UNM, a student is entitled to only one scholarship from the list of available scholarships.
Scholarship criteria vary for different subjects and degrees, both undergraduate and postgraduate.
There is a fixed number of seats available for each type of scholarship at UNM.
For more details on scholarship seats, eligibility, and conditions, students can contact the scholarship department at 03 8924 8609 or email them at sponsorship@nottingham.edu.my.

Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia recently delivered a one-week business module for the 22nd JPA-BMCC Management Development Programme, a collaborative management development programme between the Malaysian Public Services Department (Jabatan Perkhidmatan Awam - JPA) and the British Malaysian Chamber of Commerce (BMCC).

NUBS Malaysia has delivered this module in the bi-annual programme, which aims to provide senior government officers opportunity to gain hands-on experience and exposure to the dynamics of modern-day business management systems.
The training took place from 27 February to 3 March 2017 and focused on the theme of ‘Forging Cohesion Though Integrity and Sustainability’.

NUBS Malaysia faculty members involved in the programme are Dr Eunice Lim, Director of Executive Education; Dr Mohan V Avvari, Associate Professor of Strategic Management; Dr Maniam Kaliannan, Associate Professor of Human Resource Management; Dr Anita Chakrabarty, Senior University Teaching Fellow of Marketing; and Ms Vanitha Ponnusamy, Assistant Professor of Organisational Management.

The internship opportunity is at CNN International in international locations and is part of the Time Warner College Associate Programme (TWCAP) which is a 10-week summer program offered in primary locations such as New York City, Los Angeles, and Atlanta.

Eligibility criteria for the internship include being an undergraduate rising junior or senior with a minimum GPA of 3.0. Applicants should have previous experience or exposure in one of the internship tracks, demonstrated leadership abilities, a positive attitude, and the ability to work in a team environment.
Applicants must be able to work at one of Time Warner's primary locations in the U.S. such as New York City, Los Angeles, and Atlanta. Visa sponsorships are not available for this programme.

To apply for an internship position within Time Warner, interested candidates need to visit the Careers site at http://www.timewarner.com/careers/ and apply for one of the TWCAP internship opportunities.
Time Warner is an equal opportunity employer seeking interns from diverse backgrounds in terms of gender, ethnicity, and geographic locations.

8 April 2021Space, Symbol and Identity: Children in the Post New Order Indonesian CinemaIgak Satrya Wibawa, Universitas AirlanggaThis presentation argues that although post-New Order Indonesian cinema, produced during Indonesia’s reform era (2000-2015), has favoured diversity in its representation of children to challenge the New Order’s mono-cultural ideological legacy and its homogenous version of national identity, child characters have continued to be placed within the main narrative in order to be used as symbols to project Indonesian national ideals.

Comparative measures: Covid-19 in South Korea & Malaysia - 9 December 2020 The COVID-19 pandemic has put a renewed focus on the social, political and religious dimensions of public health. While a sound understanding and accurate monitoring of the SARS-CoV2 virus are critically important, the success and failure of governments in controlling the pandemic are also influenced by the shifting perceptions of different social groups, a rapidly evolving public discourse and political expediencies. The pandemic is as much a public health as a social challenge.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia is organizing its first ever virtual STEM carnival for students nationwide.
The STEM carnival aims to grow the involvement of secondary school students in STEM related disciplines from its current rate of 47% to its goal of 60%.
The UNM virtual STEM Carnival will take place from 14 to 20 February 2022 and is free for students.
The carnival will include workshops on various STEM fields, 'Career in STEM' panel session, live workshops, and International STEM Mini-Competitions.
The STEM Grand Challenge will be held exclusively for Malaysian students during the virtual STEM Carnival.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia aims to help teenagers realize that STEM can be fun and engaging.
The Carnival workshops are designed to apply advanced and complex STEM concepts to everyday life and relevant modern-day scenarios.
The STEM Carnival is organized by the students and staff members of the Faculty of Science and Engineering (FOSE) at UNM.
For more information about the UNM virtual STEM Carnival, visit: https://bit.ly/33KVr7e
For media enquiries regarding the STEM Carnival, please contact Josephine Dionisappu, PR and Communications Manager at University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The University Counselling Service is available for all staff, and confidentiality policy applies equally to staff and students.
Staff can refer themselves to the service or be encouraged to seek help by their line manager or human resources.
Appointments should be made during regular working hours with minimal requests outside these hours, and must be requested one day in advance. Line managers may allow staff to attend appointments.
Staff may consult the 'Policy for Psychological Wellbeing and Avoidance and Management of Stress'.
Counsellors do not work for the organization, and confidentiality is offered in its strictest form.
Issues that staff may seek counselling for include illness, relationships, job difficulties, anxiety, depression, bereavement, and loss of meaning and purpose.

Dr Michael Yap, Senior University Teaching Fellow, gave a guest lecture at HELP University to staff and students of the University of London programme on 25 March 2015.
The lecture was entitled Malaysian Economy: Past Performance, Challenges, and The Way Forward.
The lecture discussed success factors in the economy such as trade openness and the role of foreign direct investment in export-oriented manufacturing.
Challenges to Malaysia's continued prosperity were highlighted as the country aims to become a high-income economy by moving up the value chain.
Issues raised in the lecture included promoting local entrepreneurship, improving the education system, and overcoming political obstacles to reform.
The lecture was followed by an active Q&A session.
The lecture was posted on 2nd April 2015.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Alumni and Donor Relations Office (ADRO) and School of English organized a Poetry Workshop – Father’s Day Alumni Exclusive on Friday, 19 June 2020.
The workshop was designed to help alumni create a poem dedicated to their fathers in conjunction with Father’s Day celebration.
The workshop was conducted by Professor Malachi Edwin Vethamani, who is the Head of the School of English at UNM.

Professor Vethamani is a poet, writer, critic, and bibliographer with publications including Coitus Interruptus and Other Stories (2018) as well as two collections of poems - Life Happens (2017) and Complicated Lives (2016).
The workshop required participants to write a special poem to their father, and Professor Vethamani guided the participants throughout the session.
The best poem written received an exclusive prize of an autographed book by Professor Vethamani and will be featured on ADRO social media platforms.
The alumni found this workshop informative, worthwhile, and a good start for creative writing.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus unveils a new Bachelor of Science with Honours in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience from September 2011.
Psychology is the study of mental processes, while Cognitive Neuroscience is concerned with the scientific study of the biological substrates underlying cognition, perception, and action.
University of Nottingham Professor Sir Peter Mansfield was awarded a Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine for work in the development of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).
Psychology graduates gain a range of skills increasing employability, and the BSc (Hons) in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience equips students with valuable scientific training for future careers.

First-year Electrical and Electronic Engineering student, Joanne Khoo Jia Yu, emerged as the champion of IET Hack//Planet Malaysia, a hackathon organized by The Institute of Engineering and Technology (IET).
The IET Hack//Planet competition was organized by IET Volunteers from the IET Young Professional Section (YPS) Malaysia as part of the IET’s 150 Anniversary Celebration.

Joanne's sustainability-focused project for the Green Planet theme involved building a bicycle generator using recycled materials like a faulty alternator, an old car battery, and spoiled extension cords.
Joanne's project aimed to make renewable energy systems more approachable and affordable for households to reduce reliance on fossil fuels for electrical energy sources.
Joanne expressed gratitude to her family, friends, and teachers for their support and contributions to her project.

The International Summer School Programme at the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus offers the opportunity to study Doing Business in Asia for two weeks from 2nd July 2025 to 16th July 2025.

The entry requirements for the International Summer School Programme include being undergraduates and above from any institution worldwide, having good English language ability, and being aged 18 or over. Formal academic requirements are not necessary.

The two-week International Summer School Programme costs RM9000 per person (approximately USD 2000) with exclusive discounts available, including an early bird discount and partner discounts for universities sending 5 or more students or 10 or more students.
The application deadline for the International Summer School Programme is 1 June 2025, and applicants should complete the online application form by that date.

The International Summer School Programme includes engaging lectures on Asian business, workshops, guest speaker sessions, networking events, cultural activities, meals, and airport pick-up and drop-off services.

Accepted payment methods for the International Summer School Programme include debit or credit card payments and bank transfers. A deposit of RM1000 is required within 2 weeks of submitting the application, and the balance fee payment should be made by 1 June 2025.
A free airport pick-up service is available for participants traveling to the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus for the International Summer School Programme.

Full fee refunds are available for cancellations made 3 weeks before the event, but no refunds are available later than that. Participants are responsible for their travel arrangements, visas, travel documents, inoculations, travel insurance, and health insurance.
For enquiries about the International Summer School Programme, individuals can contact Anushia Thamotharem at telephone: +60 (0)3 8924 8750 or email: SummerSchool.Malaysia@nottingham.edu.my

The BSc (Hons) Biotechnology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) equips students with cutting-edge knowledge and practical skills to drive innovation in industries like healthcare, renewable energy, and crop and food production.

The programme combines core modules in molecular biology, genomics, and proteomics with specialized topics such as genetic engineering of microorganisms and crops, industrial bioprocesses and bioproducts, pharmaceuticals, and food hygiene and safety.
The BSc (Hons) Biotechnology program includes industrial placements in Year 2, providing hands-on experience essential for career growth, job prospects, and entrepreneurship.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Semenyih Campus is located 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just 45 minutes' drive from the famous city center with its iconic Petronas Twin Towers.
Public transport is plentiful with free shuttle services operating on some routes, and taxi/Grab services in Malaysia are very reasonable and widely used by the student community.
All candidates are considered on an individual basis for the BSc (Hons) Biotechnology program, and a broad range of qualifications are accepted.
English language requirements include a minimum IELTS score of 6.0 with no less than 5.5 in each element.

Other accepted qualifications for entry include A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior School Certificate Examination, Advance Placement, Diploma from local institutions, Foundation from local institutions, and Nottingham's Foundation Programme.
Applicants must have at least a credit in Mathematics at SPM/GCSE/IGCSE/High School Diploma or equivalent.
IELTS, TOEFL iBT, and PTE (Academic) test results must be less than two years old.

The studies focus on how the brain mechanisms in relation to any specific cognitive function can change due to the ageing process.

Hold request activation: 'hold requests' (Flexi loan) in our library system starting Monday, 26 September 2022.
Requests can now be made on borrowed books and Central Store books.
With Flexi loan, borrowed items will be issued out for seven days unless the item is in high demand, in which case, the patron will only get the item for two days.
Books on loan will automatically be renewed daily unless requested, or the borrower's library account has an overdue item or has accumulated fines of RM20 and above or has expired.
For hold requests of multiple copies, patrons only need to request by title, and the system will choose the next available copy for the patron.
Patrons should pick up requested items quickly from the library as items will only be held for two days.
Patrons will be fined RM1 per day, per item for overdue books requested by another patron.

The MSc in Organisational Psychology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia blends psychology with contemporary management practices.
The program focuses on enhancing organizational performance, employee well-being, and leadership capabilities.
The program offers flexible study options, either full-time or part-time.
Entry requirements include a second-class honours degree (2:2) or its international equivalent in a relevant field.
English language requirements include IELTS score of 6.5 or equivalent, with specific requirements for each element.
IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, and MUET test results must be less than two years old.

The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a pre-university programme that offers tailored pathways and flexible modules for a smooth transition into chosen undergraduate degrees.

Students can choose from various core and optional modules in English, Critical Thinking, Study Skills, Mathematics, Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Information Technology, Psychology, Business, Humanities, and Social Sciences.

Entry requirements for the Nottingham's Foundation Programme include a minimum of 5 Credits in SPM, O-Level, or equivalent, and specific requirements for progression into different undergraduate programs such as Engineering, Mathematical Sciences, Computer Sciences, Science, Business, and Economics.
English language requirements for the programme include minimum scores in IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, SPM, GCSE, IGCSE, IB MYP, MUET, and UEC.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a full-time program with a duration of 1 year (2 semesters) and intakes available in April and September each year.
The tuition fees for Malaysian students are RM35,000 and for international students are RM38,000 for the Nottingham's Foundation Programme.

The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is conducted at the Malaysia Campus in Semenyih, which is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and offers various facilities including schools, sports center, library, and student accommodation.
Scholarships are available for the Nottingham's Foundation Programme offering up to 25% off tuition fees based on academic performance.

The Score-Stove™ project, led by the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering at The University of Nottingham, aims to develop a wood-powered generator capable of cooking food using thermo-acoustic technology.
The generator built by City University produced 23 watts, and an electrically-heated wood-burning stove built by the Nottingham team produced 36 watts of power.
Alstom has provided €100,000 of funding for field trials in Nepal. Engineers Without Borders is supporting four students in developing the Score-Stove™ stove at Kathmandu University.
The Alstom Foundation provides financial support for projects that improve living conditions in communities in environmentally friendly ways.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus recently organised the Nottingham Life Cycle, a community charity bicycle ride in aid of Pusat Pemulihan Komuniti, Semenyih, an education centre for autistic children.
The event attracted 40 riders comprising of alumni, staff and their family member in a 20 km ride along the Semenyih-Broga route.
The riders were led by Professor Christine Ennew, CEO and Provost of UNMC and Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, managing director and group CEO of Malaysian Airlines and alumnus of the University of Nottingham.
"Bringing awareness of the importance of educational inclusions and raising funds for Autism is a cause which is very close to my heart," said Professor Christine Ennew.

All donations collected were channeled to the UNMC foundation, and funds will be made available to UNMC’s projects which relate to Autism, among its beneficiaries are Pusat Pemulihan Komuniti, Semenyih.

Nottingham Life Cycle is a brain child of Professor Sir David Greenaway, Vice Chancellor of the University of Nottingham, who heads an annual community charity bicycle ride organised since 2011 in the UK.
The University of Nottingham has 43,000 students and is ‘the nearest Britain has to a truly global university, with campuses in China and Malaysia.

It is also the most popular university among graduate employers, the world’s greenest university, and winner of the Times Higher Education Award for ‘Outstanding Contribution to Sustainable Development’.
The University of Nottingham is ranked in the World's Top 75 universities by the QS World University Rankings.
It's biggest-ever fundraising campaign, The Nottingham Campaign, is delivering the University’s vision to change lives, tackle global issues and shape the future.

Ahmad Fuad Rahmat is an Assistant Professor at the Faculty of Arts at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Fuad returned to Malaysia in 2011 for a foray into Malaysian media and civil society, focusing particularly on interfaith dialogue.
Fuad was the founder and instructor of Sekolah Falsafah, a grassroots initiative aimed to promote Western Philosophy to a wider Bahasa-speaking audience.
Fuad is currently a trainee at the Centre for Lacanian Analysis.

Before academia, Fuad was a member of Projek Dialog, responsible for designing various media-driven initiatives to encourage intercultural engagement among Malaysians, such as Pesta Filem Kita and Leveraging Media for Advocacy Objectives.
Fuad hosted Night School, a weekly show on BFM radio that made academic and theoretical discourse accessible for the general public.
Fuad has expertise in Lacanian psychoanalysis, post-colonial theory, and Marxism.
Fuad has taught undergraduate courses like Cultures of Everyday Life, Communications Technology, Transnational Media, and Writing for the Media, as well as postgraduate courses.
Ahmad Fuad Rahmat has publications like 'Decolonization and Psychoanalysis: The Underside of Signification' and 'Exploring the mother’s geography: On Klein’s settler unconscious'.

The Postgraduate Student Teachers (PST) programme fulfills the University of Nottingham policy on students who teach.

The PST programme consists of face-to-face seminars as well as online courses that you can complete or use as an information resource in your own time. There are seven face-to-face courses, two of which are compulsory and five optional.
All courses are aligned to the Professional Standard of Framework (PSF) areas of activity, core knowledge, and professional values, designed for teaching and supporting learning in higher education.

The Professional Standards Framework is a nationally-recognized framework for benchmarking success within higher education (HE) teaching and learning support, governed by Higher Education Academy (HEA).
Higher Education Academy (HEA) is the national body which champions teaching excellence.

The Vice-Chancellor’s Global Award Prize recognizes an individual student for their global graduate attributes.
The Vice-Chancellor sponsors this prize to recognize students' growth professionally and personally and their ability to work independently.
The University is looking for evidence of 'Global Graduate Attributes' in the student's application.

Attributes include a broader international perspective, understanding of a diverse society, applying disciplinary concepts in cultural contexts, cross-cultural awareness, commitment to social good, and defending universal values.
For complete details on eligibility and application details and deadlines, visit the Nottingham Advantage Award website.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a Mathematical Sciences MPhil/PhD program.

For the MPhil program, applicants need an upper second-class honours degree in math or related field.
English language requirements include IELTS (Academic) score of 6.0 with no less than 5.5 in each element, TOEFL (iBT) score of 80, PTE (Academic) score of 65, or MUET Band 4.

The Tropical Conservation Ecology Lab at University of Nottingham Malaysia focuses on the ecology and conservation of Asian megafauna including Asian elephants, rhinos, tapirs, and large cats.

The main project at the Tropical Conservation Ecology Lab focuses on studying the behavior and ecology of Malaysian elephants to aid the Malaysian government in making better-informed management decisions.
The lab also focuses on urgent issues such as human-wildlife conflicts and assessing the effectiveness of mitigation strategies like elephant translocation and electric fencing.

Current projects at the lab include The Management & Ecology of Malaysian Elephants (MEME), Impact of traditional agriculture on forest structure, and Terrestrial Ecosystem Assessment & Monitoring Network (TEAM) among others.

Collaborators of the lab include Department of Wildlife and National Parks Peninsular Malaysia, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (NRE), RIMBA, and Smithsonian's Conservation GIS among others.
Alumni of the lab include Tariq Mahmood, Pamela Ooi, and Wiwit Juwita.

The Master of Pharmacy (MPharm) programme at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is a globally recognised degree designed to prepare students for a rewarding career as a registered pharmacist in the UK.
The full-time program provides an integrated curriculum that combines scientific, clinical, and professional expertise over four years.
Students benefit from professional placements in hospitals, community pharmacies, and other healthcare settings, gaining hands-on experience and patient interaction.
The University of Nottingham ranks 12th globally for Pharmacy and Pharmacology (QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024).
The University offers the MPharm program with a Malaysian fee of RM60,000 per year for year 1 and 2, and GBP £30,750 per year for year 3 and 4.
International students have a fee of RM70,000 per year for year 1 and 2, and GBP £30,750 per year for year 3 and 4.
Entry requirements for the MPharm program include specific qualifications such as A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, etc.
English language requirements for the program include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, and other language proficiency tests.
The University of Nottingham's MPharm degree is a full-time, 4-year program.

The MPharm program includes core modules such as Fundamentals of Pharmacy, Digestive System, Autoimmune and Allergy, Infections 1 and 2, Dermatology, Prescribing Competencies and Practice, and Advancing Therapies, Practice and Care 1 and 2.

Major plantation organizations, a non-profit, and academia have agreed to cooperate in building human-elephant coexistence.
The agreement exchange formalized the “Achieving Coexistence with Elephants” (ACE) Project in the southern landscape of Peninsular Malaysia involving plantations in Johor.
The project aims to promote cooperation between agricultural communities, NGOs, and academia to conserve wild elephants and increase safety among participating smallholders and plantations.

Salman Saaban, the Director of Protected Areas in the Department of Wildlife and National Parks Peninsular Malaysia (PERHILITAN), highlighted the importance of the initiative for conservation efforts involving plantations and conservation groups.
The project involves studying elephants' roaming behavior and habitat needs, including the impact of linear infrastructure on elephants.
The coalition conducted a four-day training on human-elephant conflict and coexistence focused on plantation managers and their sustainability teams in March 2022.
The eventual project outcome aims to enable agricultural communities to autonomously coexist with elephants by managing interactions and implementing early-warning systems.
The coalition has identified five potential elephant corridors in the landscape and is in the process of selecting two corridors with the highest potential for advocacy.

The MA in Teaching of English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a full-time program that can be completed in 1-2 years or part-time in 2-4 years, starting in September 2025.
The Malaysian fee for the MA TESOL program is RM 58,000 per program, while the international fee is RM 60,000 per program.
The MA TESOL program is designed to enhance understanding of TESOL theory and practice, offering opportunities for reflection and real-world application.
The MA TESOL program does not confer Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) but provides expertise for teaching roles in global contexts and supports further professional growth.
The MA TESOL program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a comprehensive curriculum covering language teaching methodology, curriculum design, and language assessment.
To earn a MA TESOL degree, students must complete and pass four modules (including two core and two elective) and a dissertation.
One compulsory elective module for MA TESOL students is Practice-based Inquiry, along with another elective module like Assessment in Language Education.
The MA TESOL program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia integrates cross-cultural insights into TESOL, preparing graduates for roles in international education contexts.

The entry requirements for the MA TESOL program include a relevant second-class honors degree (2:2) or international equivalent, along with English language proficiency requirements such as IELTS 6.5, TOEFL 90, or equivalent.
A 15,000-word dissertation is required for the MA TESOL program and should be related to one of the selected modules on an approved topic.

The Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with facilities such as business, education, science, engineering schools, sports center, library, and student accommodation.
Career opportunities for MA TESOL graduates include roles like TESOL Specialist, Curriculum Developer, Language Assessment Specialist, Teacher Trainer, and Educational Consultant.
The program coordinator for the MA TESOL at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is Dr. Tiong Ngee Derk.

NUBS Malaysia academics presented papers at the 8th Annual Symposium of the International Centre for Corporate Social Responsibility (ICCSR) held at the University of Nottingham Ningbo Campus in China.
The symposium took place from 11th to 12th July 2011 at the University of Nottingham Ningbo Campus (UNNC) with keynotes, a practitioner-oriented panel discussion, and parallel tracks.
Rebecca Chung-hee Kim, Avvari V Mohan, and Vanitha Ponnusamy from NUBS Malaysia presented papers at the symposium, sharing a variety of ideas on CSR in Asia.

Rebecca Chung-hee Kim, along with co-authors, presented a paper on the link between religion and CSR in an Asian context with a focus on religions in South-East Asia: Islam, Confucianism, and Hinduism.

Avvari V Mohan and Vanitha Ponnusamy presented a case study on John Hardy (JH), a jewelry producer in Bali, Indonesia, showcasing how a small and medium enterprise can integrate economic, social, and environmental benefits through sustainable business strategies.

The MSc Business (International Management) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) offers advanced knowledge and practical skills in business and international management.
The program is designed to prepare students for leadership roles in the global business landscape.
The program is accredited by EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), and Association of MBAs (AMBA).
The program includes core modules in finance, business analytics, and global human resource management, along with specialized studies in international business strategy and innovation.
Students can choose between an academic dissertation or a business-focused project.
The program focuses on global market dynamics, strategic decision-making, business analytics, ethics, sustainability, and corporate social responsibility.
Graduates are equipped with expertise in managing global operations, decision-making, and navigating dynamic business environments.
The program is delivered by a globally recognized business school accredited by EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS).
The entry requirements include a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent, preferably in business studies or management.
Applicants without a degree in business studies or management must demonstrate completion of equivalent modules in the relevant discipline.
English language requirements include IELTS 6.5, TOEFL 90, PTE 71, or MUET Band 4.5.
IELTS, TOEFL, and PTE test results must be less than two years old, and MUET results are valid for five years.
The program is a one-year full-time program with six compulsory modules in Semester 1 and 2, and students complete a dissertation or business project in Semester 3.
Teaching methods include lectures, small group teaching, lab work, and seminars.
Modules are assessed by a combination of exams and coursework at the end of the relevant semester.
Malaysian fee for the program is RM58,000 per programme, and the international fee is RM66,000 per programme.
The Semenyih Campus is located 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with a sports center, library, and student accommodation.
The campus offers modern facilities and is located in central Asia for easy travel opportunities.
Career opportunities for graduates include roles such as International Business Consultant, Global Marketing Manager, and Business Development Manager.
The program equips students with skills and knowledge to accelerate their careers in various industries.

Future events are planned to reconnect and celebrate the vibrant UNM community.

Nottingham University Business School has been granted EQUIS accreditation, joining an elite global group of business schools in management education.
EQUIS accreditation applies to all of the Business School’s international operations, including campuses in the UK, China, and Malaysia.

The Business School aims to add AACSB accreditation to complete the 'triple crown' of accreditations.

Nottingham University Business School's ambitious multi-campus strategy is endorsed by the EQUIS accreditation, confirming the quality of its staff, students, programs, and facilities.
Professor Leigh Drake, the Director of the Business School, expressed delight at being part of the select international group of top business schools with EQUIS accreditation.

The MA in English with Creative Writing at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a unique blend of creative and critical practices, equipping students with advanced skills in professional writing and the creative process.

The full-time MA English with Creative Writing lasts 12 months and is divided into two semesters and a summer period. Students will take four 15-credit modules per semester and complete a Creative Project over the summer to be submitted in September.
Taught modules are assessed by a 5,000-word assignment or equivalent, and students must also submit a 14,000-word dissertation. There are no examinations.

Entry requirements for the Master of Arts in English with Creative Writing include a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent. Applicants will be asked to submit an example of their written work.

English language requirements for the program include IELTS 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element), TOEFL iBT 90, PTE Academic 71, and MUET Band 4.5. Test results must be less than two years old.

The MA in English with Creative Writing at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) offers a unique blend of creative and critical practices, equipping students with advanced skills in professional writing and the creative process.

This programme is ideal for those aspiring to careers in creative industries, publishing, or professional writing, while also offering modules in English language and literature to broaden your expertise in the field of English studies.
An MA degree not only demonstrates advanced expertise but also enhances your employability, opening doors to roles in writing, teaching, publishing, and cultural industries.

The full-time MA English with Creative Writing lasts 12 months and is divided into two semesters and a summer period. You will take four modules per semester and then complete a Creative Project over the summer to be submitted in September.
Taught modules are assessed by a 5,000-word assignment or equivalent, and you must also submit a 14,000-word dissertation.
English language requirements for the MA in English with Creative Writing program: IELTS 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element), TOEFL (iBT) 90, PTE (Academic) 71, MUET Band 4.5.
Malaysian fee for the MA program: RM50,000 per programme. International fee: RM50,000 per programme.

The University of Nottingham has been ranked amongst the top universities in the world in the QS World University Rankings. In the latest results, Nottingham has improved by seven places, up from 77th in 2014 to joint 70th in 2015, placing the University amongst the top 1 per cent of global universities.

The most recent rankings particularly emphasize Nottingham’s academic reputation and the international diversity of staff and students. The University also scored very highly in the assessment of its reputation amongst graduate employers, placing 45th in the world.
The University is consistently named as one of the most targeted institutions by leading graduate employers.

The QS World University Rankings further endorse this position with all five faculty areas ranked within the world top 125: Life Sciences and Medicine (=67th), Social Sciences & Management (=76th) and Arts and Humanities (=90th), Engineering & Technology (=116th), and Natural Sciences (=124th).

Tributes have been paid following the death of Professor Sir Colin Campbell, former Vice-Chancellor of the University of Nottingham.
In 1988 he made history as the country’s youngest Vice-Chancellor when, then aged 43, he took up the role at Nottingham.
He was then the university’s fifth Vice-Chancellor and served until 2008.
Sir Colin played a key role in the commissioning of the Jubilee Campus expansion scheme.
He was instrumental in raising Nottingham’s profile internationally – overseeing the opening of campuses in China and Malaysia.

Vice-Chancellor Professor Shearer West said: 'From the award-winning Jubilee Campus to the pioneering University of Nottingham Ningbo, the first Sino-foreign University in China, he had a vision to grow the university not just through infrastructure, but through student numbers, reputation and by forging new links.'
Dr Paul Greatrix, Registrar at the University of Nottingham, said: 'So much of the university we know today would not be here without his influence.'
His legacy in Nottingham includes Jubilee Campus, on which he has a building in his name, as well as the university’s campuses in China and Malaysia.
In 2006 Nottingham also established the first Veterinary School to open in the UK for 50 years.
He was made an honorary citizen of Ningbo in 2004 in recognition of his contribution to the construction and development of the city.
He was made a Datuk by the Government of Malaysia in 2009.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Collaborates with Noble Gateway to Promote Ecological Sustainability
There are three living species of elephants: the Asian elephant (Elephas maximus) the African bush elephant (Loxodonta africana) and the African forest elephant (Loxodonta cyclotis).
Elephants are known to live in matriarchal-led, close-knit social groups.

After the great apes, elephants are considered to be the world’s most intelligent land mammal. Elephants are known to have remarkable memories. They can also make and use tools; breaking off leafy branches and using them as fly swatters.

Elephants are sentient beings. They exhibit empathy towards other elephants who are in distress, offer protection to young or injured elephants and are capable of understanding deaths; for instance, they would stay by the dead elephant’s body and attempt to bury it.

Wild elephants help to maintain the forest’s ecosystem dynamics by playing a vital role in seed dispersal especially for fruits with large seeds and in nutrient cycling hence known as mega-gardeners of the forest.

Wild elephants are known as ecosystem engineers because they can modify habitats for many other animals. As they travel, they create pathways and when they dig the soil for nutrients, they create saltlicks. Some of these geological changes in the landscape can last for generations.

Asian elephants can grow up to 2.7 metres in height with a weight of between 3,000 and 6,000 kilogrammes, while African elephants can grow up to 3 metres in height and weigh between 4,000 and 7,500 kilogrammes.
Adult elephants can eat up to 150 kg of food a day from more than 100 species of plants. Their diet consists of plant material like bamboo, grass, leaf, bark, twig, fruit and tuber.

Elephant dung creates mini habitats for other wildlife. It provides a good shelter for frogs and invertebrates such as beetles, ants, centipedes, millipedes, scorpions, crickets, spiders and termites.
Elephants have the longest gestation period of all mammals; 22 months!
Malaysia is one of the 13 remaining countries in Asia still blessed to have elephants in the wild.

An elephant can poop up to 18 times in a day and produce about one tonne of dung per week. Elephant dung plays an important role in keeping the soil fertile and provides nutrients to seeds that the elephant swallows and defecates.

MEME, together with PERHILITAN, have put GPS collars (a movement tracking device) on more than 50 wild elephants in Peninsular Malaysia to better understand their range as well as how infrastructures like roads affect their movement.

Well-connected wildlife habitats are vital for the survival of elephants. When infrastructures such as roads cut across wildlife habitat, it becomes a barrier that prevents elephants from moving from one side to the other. Apart from that, oncoming traffic increases the risks of elephant mortality.

Due to land competition and habitat fragmentation, humans will come into contact more frequently with elephants and conflict may occur. To prevent further loss of elephant range, we need to support and help farmers, so they are able to share the landscape with wild elephants (co-exist).
The closest living relatives of elephants are the dugongs, manatees, aardvarks, and hyraxes.
Elephants cannot jump!

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus is collaborating with Universiti Sains Malaysia to monitor media coverage of the 14th Malaysian general elections.
The project will analyze media performance in treatment of political figures, parties, key policy and economic issues, electioneering, and gender representation.
The project will evaluate the framing of identity politics during the elections to encourage a critical Malaysian citizenry.
The initiative aims to provide evidence-based analysis of media performance and accountability during the elections.
The project builds on the 2013 Watching the Watchdog initiative with the Centre for Independent Journalism.
The project plans to release interim findings before the election and a comprehensive report after the elections.
For more information, contact Gayathry Venkiteswaran (019-7257970) or Lim Hong Siang (016-2267977).

The MA in Media, Communications and Culture at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers an interdisciplinary approach, blending theoretical and practical skills to help students thrive in the dynamic media landscape.
The MA program provides critical insights into global media transformations, exploring contemporary issues such as postcolonialism, digital media, and the culture industry.

The program includes an optional 1-week Digital Storytelling and Production module at CNN Academy in Abu Dhabi, fully funded for students to gain hands-on content creation experience with CNN experts.
The MA program offers flexible pathways, allowing students to specialize in media, cultural policy, or combine both.
The University provides access to cutting-edge facilities, including a Digital Media Lab, to prepare students for careers in media, journalism, marketing, public relations, and more.

Applicants are required to have a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent for entry into the MA in Media, Communications, and Culture program at University of Nottingham Malaysia.
English language requirements include a minimum score of 6.5 in IELTS (with no less than 6.0 in each element) or equivalent scores in TOEFL, PTE, or MUET.
The full-time MA Media, Communications and Culture course at the University of Nottingham Malaysia lasts 12 months and is divided into two semesters and a summer period.

Optional modules for the MA program include Approaches to Theory, Issues and Challenges in Contemporary Media, Mass Media, Postcolonial Theory, Working in the Culture Industry: Case Study Workshops, and Digital Storytelling and Production.

Malaysian students are required to pay RM58,000 per program, while international students are required to pay RM65,000 per program for the MA in Media, Communications, and Culture program at University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Professor Chung Lim Law is a Professor of Chemical and Process Engineering in the Faculty of Science and Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Professor Chung Lim Law has been working on developing a low-temperature drying technique for the past 10 years to preserve antioxidants and vitamins in bio-origin products.
The low-temperature drying technology developed by Professor Chung Lim Law is more energy-efficient and cost-effective compared to hot air or freeze-drying alternatives.
Professor Chung Lim Law recommends direct communication with companies to understand industry problems and contribute to technological development.

Students from the International Communications Studies degrees in the School of Modern Languages and Cultures (SMLC) have been the subject of an exploratory study into the effects of international exchange and mobility.

Results of the study were presented at two international education conferences in Asia: QS Apple Conference in Taipei, Taiwan, and Asia Pacific Association for International Education (APAIE) Conference in Beijing.
The study was conducted by Dr. Sean Matthews and Dr. Vanaja Nethi, from the Fischler School of Education, Nova Southeastern University, USA.
The study involved interviews with 20 students who had studied the Part I, Cultural Politics module in 2013/14.
The majority of participants in the study were from a group who took the module at Nottingham Malaysia.
The study provided insights into issues related to transnational education (TNE) and the internationalization of Higher Education.

The CropBase Scholarship project focuses on developing an ontology-driven crop base knowledge system to support decision-making by crop growers.

The project involves combining and expanding existing crop ontologies, modifying them for consistency, including data on underutilized crops like Bambara groundnuts, and implementing a web tool for crop selection support.
The knowledge in the project is represented using Web Ontology Language (OWL) and OWL 2 based on description logic (DL) for efficient reasoning.

Successful candidates for the project need a strong background in computer science, excellent Java programming skills, knowledge of ontology, and interest in rule-based reasoning and/or AI techniques.
The supervisors for the project are Abdur Rakib from the School of Computer Science at UNMC and Natasha Alechina from the School of Computer Science at UoN.
The project was posted on 17th December 2012.

IGNITE Magazine is UNMC’s online student media platform, operated by students under the guidance of academic staff from the School of Modern Languages and Culture (SMLC). Students from any UNMC faculty who are interested in contributing as writers, editors, photographers, public relations officers and advertising managers are invited to join the IGNITE family and contribute to the official Student Media at the UNMC, while gaining NAA credit in the process.
Interested students from any faculty and year are encouraged to apply. Those who are self-motivated, passionate and able to work under tight deadlines will make the most out of this module.

This will be a semester long module. Participating students (writers/ photographers) are required to attend a minimum of three (3) Editorial meetings. According to their skill and interest as indicated in the application form, they will be assigned to a Section and a respective Editor at the discretion of the IGNITE management team.

Assessment Writers and Photographers' Portfolio of Published Content (75%): Writers must publish an article (with the approval of their Editor) once a month, throughout the semester, i.e. a minimum of 3 articles over the academic semester. In a similar framework, photographers must publish at least 3 images in 3 separate Ignite articles.

Advertising Managers’ Business Strategy and Final Report (75%): Advertising managers should work together as a team and submit a business strategy proposal within the first month of the semester, outlining the potential clients they plan to approach. At the end of the semester, the advertising managers will present a report that details the successes (and failures) they achieved in attempting to secure advertising revenue for Ignite.

Public Relations Officer’s PR Strategy and Final Report (75%): The public relations officers will work together to submit a team report within the first month of the semester, detailing their strategies and methods for improving the quality of Ignite’s interactions with the UNMC student body (digitally or otherwise). At the end of the semester, the PR officers will submit a group report detailing the successes (and failures) of these strategies and methods.

The Environmental and Geographical Sciences program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers MPhil, MRes, and PhD degrees. Full-time durations are MPhil: 1-2 years, MRes: 1-2 years, PhD: 3-4 years. Part-time durations are MPhil: 2-4 years, MRes: 2-4 years, PhD: 6-8 years.
The program start dates are February, April, June, and September 2025, except for MRes, which starts in February, June, and September.

Entry requirements for the program include a master's or Master of Philosophy degree with at least a second-class honours degree in science, engineering, geography, or related subjects for a PhD. Soon Tat Lee is an Assistant Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee graduated with a BSc (Hons) in Speech Science from the National University of Malaysia and pursued a PhD at the School of Psychology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee is a psycholinguist and speech-language therapist with expertise in cognitive and linguistic mechanisms involved in bilingual language processing.
Soon Tat Lee's work includes developing language tests for specific language constructs in understudied language pairs such as Malay-English and Mandarin-English.
Soon Tat Lee has publications related to lexical tests for Malay speakers, translation norms for Malay and English words, and assessing children's native language in Mandarin.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) organised its first international alumni dinner in Dubai on 26 May 2022 at the Sheraton Grand Hotel.

Jag mentioned that 'This inaugural alumni dinner in Dubai marks the beginning of a new and exciting alumni engagement programme for the university which is linked to the university's global ambition of enabling our alumni anywhere in the world.'
The alumni dinner aimed to bring together both UNM staff members and alumni to rekindle friendships and reminisce about their time in Malaysia.
Yousaf Rizwan (Mechanical Engineering, 2014) mentioned, 'It was a pleasure to reconnect with old colleagues, and I was excited to learn that we have such a strong alumni community here.'

Merna Ehab (Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, 2021) advised all students, 'UNM and its incredible memories bonds all of us to this huge incredible family. Please take advantage of every moment, it will indeed be the best years of your life.'
The event ended with a photo session with all attendees. It was a night to celebrate memories while making new ones.

'Media, Politics and Identity in Contemporary South-East Asia' was the theme of the Voices II seminar at University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Voices II seminar series examined the changing role of media in shaping identity in contemporary society.
Speakers at Voices II seminar included intellectuals and media producers/activists addressing issues of media reform, social justice, and democracy.
Speakers at Voices II seminar discussed the politics of media forms and the representation of subaltern groups in media.
Speakers at Voices II seminar included Alberto Gomes, Jacqueline Ann Surin, Anil Netto, Chua Beng Huat, and Wan Zawawi Ibrahim.
The seminar brochure from the Voices II series is available for download in PDF format.

IT Services manages a number of computer rooms offering PCs with network access, printing, and some with 24/7 access, open to all staff and students of the University.
IT Services assigns email and storage on the network for every staff and student, implementing secure protocols for sending and retrieving mails with extensive spam-filtering.

The print, copy, and scan services are available in IT computer rooms and the library, using your University Card or University username to store credits chargeable at the library circulation counter. Scanning is free of charge.

Video Conferencing allows face-to-face communications and meetings to be conducted with remote parties through the Internet or digital telephony, with suites available across the University's UK, Ningbo, and Malaysian campuses.
E-Learning materials are created and delivered through Virtual Learning Environments (VLE), facilitating course management, collaborative group projects, self-test exercises, and online assessments.

Wireless access is available for mobile devices via wireless access points installed throughout the campus, allowing staff and students to connect their mobile devices to the Internet using their University username and passwords.

Chris Gibbins is a Professor at the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Chris Gibbins moved to Nottingham Malaysia in January 2017 to become the Head of the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences.
Chris Gibbins was a Senior Lecturer at the University of Aberdeen, Scotland, before joining the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Chris Gibbins specializes in teaching freshwater ecology, hydrology, sustainable catchment management, biogeography, and data analysis.
Chris Gibbins is an Honorary Professor at the University of Aberdeen, Scotland, and a Visiting Professor at the University of Lleida, Spain.
Chris Gibbins has collaborated on various international projects related to river ecology, sediment dynamics, invertebrate communities, and flow-biota interactions.

This module is aimed at all students who have the passion in turning sustainability ideas into action.
Students are encouraged to join the student committee of UNM SEEN (Sustainable Environmental Education Network) - either WasteNott Project or Gardening.
The module aims to raise awareness amongst the UNM Community on waste problems that have been occurring on campus, in Malaysia and globally.
Students will learn the solutions to waste that can be incorporated into daily lives at an individual level, community level, as well as corporate level.
The topic of wastes will also be linked to the United Nation's Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDG) to be achieved by 2030.
Students will gain experience in leadership, communication, team working, and more.
Open to all students.
Students are required to join one project group from the list below, with 10 credit hours, which is about 35-40 hours during the 2024-25 academic year: WasteNott project or Gardening Project.
Assessment: Portfolio and logbook.
To register for this module, please self-enrol via Moodle from 01 October 2024, 10.00 am.
Registration is open on a first-come, first-served basis.

Professor Trevor Parfitt passed away on November 23rd in Manchester at the age of 65.
He obtained his doctorate in 1983 from the University of Manchester.
Trevor held teaching positions at the American University in Cairo for 12 years, the University of East London for 6 years, and the University of Nottingham Malaysia for seven years.
He later took a new position at Chulalongkorn University in late 2018.
Trevor's scholarly work focused on critique of power relations and development projects for emancipatory purposes.
He published works such as 'The African Debt Crisis', 'The End of Development?: Modernity, Post-Modernity and Development', and 'Development Projects for a New Millennium'.
Trevor made influential interventions in debates on development projects, including a defence of the 'tyranny of participation'.
Trevor was diagnosed with brain cancer shortly after arriving in Thailand.
Trevor was known for his irreverence towards power, sense of humor, and wise advice.
Trevor had a student following at Chulalongkorn University and maintained his sense of humor during his illness.

The School of English at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) collaborated with the Malaysian Institute for Debate and Public Speaking (MIDP) and MY Poetry School (MPS) to host the first-ever KL Youth Literary Arts Festival (KLYLAF).
The KL Youth Literary Arts Festival (KLYLAF) provided opportunities for emerging young artists between the ages of seven to 29 years old in Malaysia.
The festival included various activities like artist panels, workshops, open mic and collaborative performances, mentoring sessions, a poetry slam, as well as networking opportunities.

The physical events of the KL Youth Literary Arts Festival (KLYLAF) were held at Merdekarya, Pusat Kreatif Kanak-Kanak Tuanku Bainun, and Nero Event Space in Petaling Jaya Performing Arts Centre (PJPac).
The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) supported the KL Youth Literary Arts Festival (KLYLAF) and has a commitment to the Malaysian literary and performing arts communities.
UNM encourages students to partake in the organization of events like KLYLAF to experience what happens behind the scenes and supports the local arts community.
UNM Assistant Professor and alumna, Dr Sheena Baharudin, is involved in supporting the local arts community and empowering the youth through collaboration, creativity, and openness.

The university has a policy on disclosure and confidentiality which requires the university to inform students that any data and information collected will be kept confidential.
Any disclosure related to the disability will be kept confidential and will only be disclosed with the students' approval or when it is required by law.
We strongly advise students to disclose their disability before they submit their application form so that we can advise the student accordingly.
The Disability Advisory services will contact the student to discuss the reasonable adjustments based on the recommendation from their medical specialist.

Students are responsible to ensure that the University is aware of your disability by alerting the University through direct contact with the Disability Advisory services, indicating disability on the application forms, extenuating forms, or graduation forms, or direct contact with the staff from the school such as your school's Disability Liaison Officer (DLO) or your personal tutor who will need to inform the Disability Advisory services.
Dr Tang Kin Boon, Assistant Professor of Finance and Economics, spoke about graduate unemployment on a Chinese language radio station.
Dr Tang discussed the unemployment rate in Malaysia, which stood at 4.7% and rose to 5.1% in June 2020, the highest level in 30 years.
Out of the 745,000 unemployed persons in September 2020 in Malaysia, 43% were in the age group of 15-24 years, with a youth unemployment rate of 12.6%.
Youth unemployment in Malaysia is the second highest in the ASEAN-5 region after Indonesia and followed by Singapore, Philippines, and Thailand.
Dr Tang mentioned that nearly half of the 291,400 unemployed youths in March 2020 were graduates.
Dr Tang also shared how Nottingham University Business School Malaysia prepares students for the job market and adversity.

The Nottingham Advantage Award is available at all Nottingham campuses and is open to all undergraduate students enrolled in any course in any school.
Postgraduates who started the award during their undergraduate course at Nottingham may complete the award as a postgraduate.
The minimum time to complete the award is two (2) academic years. Students are advised to complete 30 credits before their final year to lessen their burden in the final year.
To be eligible for the full Award, you need to complete 30 credits.
University policy states that you can earn up to 20 credits towards the Advantage Award per academic year to prioritize your course of study.
Registration for the Nottingham Advantage Award requires following simple steps and choosing modules as an Award student.
Applying for modules involves receiving email notifications about module opportunities each academic semester and following specific application processes for each module.
The Award is designed to complement academic studies, and students are expected to prioritize academic commitments over participation in the Award.

The Bachelor of Arts with Honours in International Relations at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) provides a comprehensive understanding of the political, social, and economic dynamics shaping global interactions.

Dr Teo Wing Leong from the School of Economics at the University of Nottingham Malaysia analyzed Budget 2021.
Budget 2021 was tabled by the Minister of Finance in the Parliament on 6 November 2020 due to the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic on the Malaysian economy.

Measures proposed in Budget 2021 include allocating RM17 billion to the COVID-19 Fund, increasing cash handouts to the B40 group, allowing unemployed EPF contributors to withdraw RM500 monthly from Account 1 for 12 months, and extending loan moratoriums for B40 and microenterprises.
Budget 2021 aims to increase cash handouts to families with a monthly household income below RM5,000 compared to previous years.
Some commentators express concerns that cash handouts becoming a regular feature in the government budget may lead to a culture of dependency.
The proposal to allow unemployed EPF members to withdraw RM500 per month for 12 months is not limited to the B40 group but applies to all unemployed EPF contributors.
The loan moratorium extension proposal in Budget 2021 targets B40 and micro enterprises with loans below RM150,000, with the option to reduce monthly repayments by 50% for six months.
Budget 2021 forecasts a GDP growth of 6.5%-7.5% in 2021, contingent upon the development of the COVID-19 situation and the effectiveness of control measures.
Dr Teo Wing Leong is the Head of School of Economics at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

The Malaysian Universities Poetry Writing competition is sponsored by the Ministry of Higher Education and organised by the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus’s (UNMC) School of English.
The competition is open to both Malaysian and international under-graduate students studying in Malaysian universities from any field of study.
All submissions must be original work written in the English language with a maximum of three poems per writer, each not exceeding 40 lines.
All entries for the competition must reach the organisers by 9 October 2017, and submissions must be made online through email at MUP_Competition@nottingham.edu.my.

The first prize winner of the poetry competition will receive a cash prize of RM1,000, second prize is RM750, and third prize is RM500. Short-listed and long-listed poems will also receive cash prizes.
The prize-giving ceremony for the poetry writing competition will be held at The University of Nottingham, Malaysia Campus on 17 November, and winners will be notified by email.
