Dr Vengadeshvaran Sarma, Assistant Professor of Business Economics in the Nottingham University Business School, is advocating a sustainable policy framework that benefits landowners without hurting their future growth prospects.

Dr Tapan Kumar Nath, Associate Professor in the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences, setting out the evidence to assist governments to formulate policies that support sustainable forest conservation through partnerships between local communities and forest management agencies.
Dr Sarma has been studying the long-term social and economic effects on rural communities who have been forcibly evicted from their land.
Dr Nath aims to institutionalize participatory forest management in Malaysian policy.
Dr Nath organized a tree-planting event in North Selangor to reforest degraded peatland swamp forests with over a thousand seedlings planted.

Professor Hai-Sui Yu, FREng, founding director of the Nottingham Centre for Geomechanics (NCG), and Pro-Vice-Chancellor at The University of Nottingham, has been awarded the Outstanding Contributions Award by the International Association for Computer Methods and Advances in Geomechanics (IACMAG).
The Outstanding Contributions award was announced during the 14th international conference of the IACMAG in Kyoto, Japan.
Almost 500 delegates from around the world were in attendance.
During the awarding ceremony, Professor Yu was presented with a medal and a certificate by Professor John Carter, President of IACMAG.
Geomechanics is a fundamental subject concerned with the behavior of earth and granular materials such as soil and rock, when subjected to loading and external environmental changes.

It underpins much of the practice and design in many engineering disciplines including civil engineering, mining engineering, environmental engineering, offshore and resource engineering, highway engineering, oil and petroleum engineering, and powder technology and chemical engineering.

The 29th International Congress for Conservation Biology (ICCB) will be held in Kuala Lumpur from 21 to 25 July 2019, organised by the Society for Conservation Biology (SCB).
Dr Wong Ee Phin, an Assistant Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, is the Chair of the Local Organising Committee for the ICCB and the President of the Malaysian Chapter of the SCB.

Dr Wong, along with Reef Check Malaysia Project Manager Edmund Lau Chai Ming and actress Maya Karin, met with Dato' Seri Anwar Ibrahim to discuss conservation issues in Malaysia and collaboration between the government and conservation organizations.
The ICCB event in Kuala Lumpur is aimed at fostering cross-sectoral discussion about biodiversity with various conservation communities.
University of Nottingham Malaysia academics including Dr Christopher Gibbins, Dr Alex Lechner, Dr Tapan Kumar Nath, and Dr Lee Jiin Woei will be involved in the committees during ICCB 2019.
The Society for Conservation Biology focuses on advancing the science and practice of conserving Earth's biological diversity and uniting new conservation trends with community resources.
The ICCB 2019 is expected to attract between 1700 and 1800 delegates from over 70 countries.

An IT account is issued to each new student as part of the registration process at University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Steps to activate your IT account: Visit IT Accounts, Click 'All Students', Read the Code of Practice and supporting policies, Enter your surname, date of birth and student ID, Tick 'I have read and understood the statement on this page', Click 'Continue', Your username, temporary password and email address will be displayed on screen, Click 'Continue', Enter your username and temporary password and click 'Next', Set your security questions and responses, Click 'Save Answers' and then click 'Continue', Click 'Change My Password', Enter the temporary password you just used to log in and click 'Continue', Follow the on screen instructions to set a secure password, Click 'Change Password' and remember your new password, Sign out and close IT accounts.
IT account holders at University of Nottingham Malaysia can manage their own password and change it for various services.
Recommendation to change password every 6 months or sooner to avoid problems.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC), together with Universiti Teknologi MARA (UITM) and the National Space Agency (ANGKASA) co-hosted the 10th 7-SEAS International Workshop of Technologies and Sciences on Transboundary Haze 2016 at ANGKASA from 21 to 24 September 2016.

Aerosol-meteorology is the study of effects of tiny particles in the environment and its impact on weather and climate, providing an in-depth study on haze and other factors which affect the environment.

UNMC was privileged to host the 10th 7-SEAS International Workshop, with state-of-the-art technologies on issues like air quality, haze, clouds, fires, and remote sensing discussed by more than 100 participants from all over the world.
Professor Andy Chan, the Dean of the Faculty of Engineering at UNMC, chaired the event and mentioned the importance of collaboration with other ASEAN countries on air quality technologies.

The cost of living in Semenyih is lower compared to most cities in Malaysia.
Whilst you are at the University, your living costs will vary depending on your accommodation and lifestyle.
Before you arrived, make sure you have enough money or funding to cover your tuition fees, accommodation and general living cost.
On-campus accommodation ranges from RM550 - RM1200 per month and includes water, electricity, and WIFI. Rooms with air-conditioning are also available.
Off-campus accommodation ranges from RM300 - RM900 per month and may not include facilities, electricity, and water bills.
Food expenses are estimated at RM500 - RM700 per month, depending on lifestyle and choices.
Laundry costs RM4.50 per use of the washing machine and dryer.
Free shuttle buses are provided from Semenyih campus to various locations including the nearest train station, supermarkets, and the KL Campus.
Social life expenditures for students include movie outings, phone bills, and travel within Malaysia and nearby countries in South East Asia.
Movie outings typically cost about RM15 per person.
Phone bills are around RM30-RM70 monthly.
Travel options include buses, trains, and flights, depending on budget.

The University of Nottingham offers Psychology MRes, MPhil, and PhD programs.
The MPhil program can be completed in 1-2 years full-time or 2-4 years part-time.
The MRes program can be completed in 1-2 years full-time or 2-4 years part-time.
The PhD program can be completed in 3-4 years full-time or 6-8 years part-time.
Start dates for the programs are in February, April, June, and September 2025.
Malaysian fee for the programs is RM50,000 per year, while international fee is RM56,000 per year.
Intake for MPhil and PhD programs is in February, April, June, and September. For the MRes program, intake is in February and September.
Entry requirements for the PhD program include a good master's degree in psychology and an upper second-class honours degree in psychology or related discipline.
Entry requirements for the MRes and MPhil programs include an upper second-class honours degree in psychology or related discipline.
English language requirements include IELTS score of 6.5, TOEFL score of 90, PTE score of 71, or MUET Band 4.5.

BAE Systems Digital Intelligence and the University of Nottingham Malaysia have agreed a partnership to examine how unsupervised machine learning can be used in the discovery of previously undefined risk, known as 'missed risk' in the context of financial crime.

Teams from both organisations will work together using BAE Systems existing FinCrime Testing Service (FTS) data for digging out complex signals which are difficult to identify with current traditional rules.
The team will initially focus on three use cases: detecting human trafficking, crypto risk assessment, and uncovering shell companies.

Dr. David Nicholson, Senior Data Scientist for BAE Systems Digital Intelligence, expressed that new insights from machine learning could assist customers by spotting unknown risky events in the data and informing better predictable solutions for the future.
Sugeeta Bhanoo, Head of Capabilities, APAC, for BAE Systems Digital Intelligence, highlighted the strategic partnership with the University of Nottingham UK and Malaysia to work with global partners.
Last year, UNMC students Khoo Phey Yeong, Koh Ming Wee, and Lim Gaik Lin won the Food and Drink Undergraduate Prize for their project 'Osmotic Dehydration of Tropical Fruits'.

The Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) offers an in-depth exploration of how brain function shapes behaviour and cognition.

The entrance requirements for the BSc (Hons) in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience include: A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD), Gaokao (NCEE) and Senior High School Diploma (China), Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE) / Indian School Certificate (CISCE) - Class XII, Advance Placement (AP), Diploma - Local Institutions, Foundation - Local Institutions, Nottingham's Foundation Programme.

IELTS (Academic): 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element), TOEFL (iBT): 90 (minimum 19 in Writing and Listening, 20 in Reading and 22 in Speaking), PTE (Academic): 71 (with no less than 65 in each element).

Ir. Dr. How Ho Cheng has established expertise in areas such as advanced packaging and assembly materials development, failure and root cause analysis, materials characterization techniques, and yield improvement methodology for high-volume manufacturing environment.
Ir. Dr. How Ho Cheng has been a full-time academic since December 2013.
Ir. Dr. How Ho Cheng's teaching expertise includes Materials and Manufacturing, Design, Manufacture and Project, Making Metals Perform, and Additive Manufacturing and 3D Printing.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia recently hosted receptions for its alumni and current MBA students in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, bringing together graduates from business and other disciplines, as well as industry professionals and staff from the University, in a casual setting aimed at expanding networks and sharing expertise.

Nottingham in the City – Kuala Lumpur was held at Bridge Bar, G-Tower, Kuala Lumpur on 30 June 2018 recently, and attended by students and alumni of the University, CEOs and managing directors of multinational corporations, local business organisations, and founders of start-ups.
The reception in Singapore was held at the City Campus of PSB Academy, the University’s partner institution in Singapore.

Dr Dilip S. Mutum, Associate Professor of Marketing at NUBS Malaysia, recently received a Highly Commended Paper award at the 2019 Emerald Literati Awards Distribution Ceremony, during the International Symposium on Applied Structural Equation Modeling and Methodological Matters (SASEM) 2019, at Novotel Melaka, Malacca, Malaysia on 23 August 2019.

Dilip received the award for the article 'Religious symbolism in Islamic financial service advertisements', published in the Journal of Islamic Marketing, which was co-authored with Muhammad Mohsin Butt (Air University School of Management, Air University, Pakistan), the late Professor Ernest Cyril de-Run (Faculty of Economics and Business, University Malaysia Sarawak) and Ammen U-Din (Nottingham University Business School Malaysia).

Dilip also won the 'Best Paper' award in the Information Systems track at the same conference for a paper titled 'Smartwatch Adoption: A Multi-Group Analysis of Status-Quo Satisfaction' co-authored with Ezlika Ghazali, Michele Hui-Jing Pua and Zalfa Laili Hamzah (University of Malaya); and Professor Ramayah Thurasamy (Universiti Sains Malaysia).

The City Internships Summer Internship Programme offers an eight-week internship placement in London, New York, Los Angeles, or Hong Kong in various industries such as Banking & Financial Services, Legal & Professional Services, IT & Technology, Art & Design, Marketing, Advertising & PR, Property & Construction, Media, Publishing & Entertainment, or Science & Engineering.

The internship placement is complemented by career seminars, workshops, guest speakers, networking events, social events, weekend excursions, and extensive support before, during, and after the program.

Entry requirements for the program include being a university or college student with a Bachelors or Masters degree in any discipline, achieving a 2:1 or 3.0 GPA or equivalent, graduating between 2012-2016, being at least 18 years old, and being proficient in English.

The City Internships program fees vary based on the location and package chosen, with fees covering internship placement, daily transportation, meal plans, career seminars, planned events and excursions, and support for the duration of the program.

The application process involves applying online, enrolling in the program with a deposit, and working with an Internship Adviser to secure an internship placement that matches both the participant's aspirations and the host company's requirements.
Application deadline for the program is Friday, 28 February 2014, with program dates ranging from 21 June to 23 August 2014 for the different locations.
Successful applicants will receive a scholarship to undertake an MPhil/PhD degree, covering tuition fees and providing a local stipend.
One project focuses on Visual Word Processing in Bilingualism, and the other project focuses on Mechanisms of Attention Operating within Working Memory.
Applicants should have a good command of English, communication skills, interpersonal skills, ability to work independently, and be proactive and resourceful.
Applications with current curriculum vitae can be sent to specific contacts at the School of Psychology in Malaysia.
Applications deadline is on 31st January 2012.

Learning spaces across the campus are opened to all students and staff. Learning@The Core is located on Level A, Block H and Learning@Vetro is on Levels B & C, Block F3.

These learning spaces offer the opportunity to create new, vibrant, and cutting-edge learning spaces, showcasing new services, innovative technologies, and a variety of individual and group learning and study areas to support student preferences.
Latest supportive technologies with full WiFi coverage, including PCs, AV equipment, and loanable laptops are available in the learning spaces.
Print/copy/scan facilities are also provided in the learning spaces.
Student advisers at the Learning@The Core are trained PG student advisers providing academic peer support and handling enquiries.
The learning spaces are university-wide facilities shared by all staff and students.
Borrowing conditions for laptops, tablets, and AV equipment are covered by specific borrower's agreements at the library and Learning@The Core.
Plasma smart-board/screen devices and LCD TV screen devices can be borrowed within two-hour slots at different locations on campus.
Fines are incurred for late return of borrowed items, with specific rates for different types of equipment.
Non-return of borrowed equipment incurs fines, with specific fines for individual items within a set.
Borrowed equipment can be renewed once a day if there is no prior booking, with a maximum six-hour checkout period per day.
The BA (Hons) International Communication Studies at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a dynamic and interdisciplinary education in global media, culture, and communication.
The programme blends theoretical knowledge with practical skills, preparing students for careers in media, public relations, and digital communication.

Students will explore media theory, cultural politics, and international communication, while engaging in hands-on projects such as documentary filmmaking. They will develop proficiency in a global language, enhancing their ability to communicate across cultures.
The programme provides opportunities to study at the Ningbo campus in China, further enriching the international learning experience.
The programme includes modules such as Beginners French, German, Japanese, Korean, Mandarin, or Spanish, Culture and Society, Media and Communications Theory, and Global Music Studies.

Entry requirements for the International Communication Studies degree include A Level qualifications, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao and Senior High School Diploma from China, Senior School Certificate Examination from India, and other relevant qualifications.
English language requirements for the program include IELTS, TOEFL, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, and other accepted qualifications.

The internship program is with the International Society of Educational and Cultural Exchange Inc. Foundation in Japan.
Internships will follow the Japanese academic calendar with school semesters starting in April and September annually.
The internship duration is 6 months, from April 2016 to September 2016.
The internship will take place at a Junior and Senior High School in Kanagawa, Japan.
The application deadline for the internship is 13 December 2015 at 17:00 Malaysian Time.
Applicants need to have excellent English skills in speaking, writing, listening, and reading.
Priority for the internship will be given to Education majors or related majors.
Applicants must be currently enrolled at their colleges/universities for at least one year to be eligible for the internship.
Applicants must obtain permission from families or guardians and their colleges/universities to apply for and join the internship.
The internship application materials include an application form, digital photograph, passport ID page, academic transcript, recommendation letter, and formal letters from college/university.
The internship provides accommodation, meals, transportation, health insurance, stipend, and a one-way airplane ticket from Malaysia to Japan.

The Students as Change Agents module aims to provide students with an opportunity to take an active part in making changes to their and future students’ teaching and learning experience.
Students can apply with an identified staff partner from their School/Department for the Students as Change Agents module.
Previously, projects promoted by various Schools/Departments were available from all three Faculties for the 2018-19 academic year.

Examples of previous projects for the Students as Change Agents module include establishing accredited work placement modules, investigating lecture capture, and evaluating curriculum content focusing on year-to-year transition.
The Students as Change Agents module develops skills in project management, communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, and teamwork.
The Students as Change Agents module assessment includes contact with UNMC staff, assessment time, and group/independent study time, with approximately 80 hours spent on group/independent study.
To apply for the Students as Change Agents module, students can email Mr. Jaya Kumar Karunagharan.
Students who wish to conduct the project over a single semester can enroll in the Students as Change Agents module during the second registration period in February 2019.
By registering to accredit the Students as Change Agents module, students agree to the Terms and Conditions.
University of Nottingham Malaysia presented the Long Service Awards to celebrate the commitment and contribution of staff who have been working at the University for 15 years.
The awards were presented to the staff by University of Nottingham Malaysia Provost and CEO Professor Graham Kendall on 23 November at the University’s Staff Appreciation Dinner.

Members of staff who completed 15 years of service in 2018 include Dr Rohaizan Osman, Dr Gnanam Gnanagurunathan, Sugunamalar Vijayaratnam, Dr Chung Jenn Hwan, Shazril Azly Bin Ahmad, Dr Svenja Hanson, and Margaret Rozario.

Ajit Singh is an Associate Professor in Agronomy at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Dr. Singh obtained his Ph.D. from the University of Ibadan, Nigeria in 1999.
Dr. Singh has taught courses such as Field and Horticultural Crop Production, Crop Physiology and Nutrition, and Field Experimentation at Usmanu Danfodiyo University, Sokoto, Nigeria.
Dr. Singh has authored 50 publications in major scientific journals and supervised numerous postgraduate and undergraduate students.
Dr. Singh's expertise includes Crop Agronomy, Plant Nutrition, and Biometry.
Dr. Daniel Seal is a Chartered Clinical Psychologist from the UK.

Dr. Seal worked with specialist clinics and hospitals in London, helping adults, adolescents, and children cope with various difficulties such as anxiety, depression, autism, ADHD, schizophrenia, chronic pain, learning difficulties, and brain injury.
One of Dr. Seal's specialist interests is working with individuals who have Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).
Dr. Seal is working with the University of Malaya's Hospital (PPUM) and the UN's refugee arm (UNHCR) to train others to deliver psychological interventions.
Dr. Seal's website address is: www.resolve.my.
Dr. Seal has taught courses such as Social Psychology, Statistics, Qualitative Methods, and Introduction to Clinical Psychology at the University of Nottingham.

The Malaysian Universities Poetry Writing Competition (MUPWC) 2017 was sponsored by the Ministry of Higher Education and organized by the School of English, University of Nottingham Malaysia at Semenyih.

Dr Mohd Nor Azman Hassan represented the Deputy Minister of Higher Education, Datuk Dr Mary Yap Kain Ching at the event.

Third Prize winner: Ding Xue Er with the poem 'Howl' from University of Nottingham Malaysia.

A team from University of Nottingham Malaysia, comprising three engineering students Ng Wei Quan (Mechanical Engineering Y2), Ong Qian Yee and Jasmine Jill Yong Jia Yi (Chemical Engineering Y1) collectively known as Team Vision, emerged as the First Runners-Up in the L'Oreal Brandstorm 2020 competition, which was held digitally on 20 April 2020.

L’Oreal Brandstorm is an annual international innovation case competition that takes place in 60 countries and provides a platform that enables students to showcase their talents and enhance their creativity and entrepreneurial skills.
The theme this year was to pitch an idea on building a plastic-less future in the beauty industry by creating an innovation that reduces or eliminates the use of plastic.
The team chose to reinvent Garnier by replacing the plastic with empty fruit bunches (EFB) from oil palms.

Due to the current COVID-19 pandemic, the national finals of this competition was held online, where the students faced off against two other teams from Sunway and Taylors University, and emerged as the first runner-up of the competition.
They were grateful for the opportunity to take part in this competition and gain experience from it.

Professor Graham Kendall, CEO and Provost of University of Nottingham Malaysia, said, 'Even in a time of adversity, this team worked together so diligently to put forth an innovative idea, and their hard work has indeed paid off. We are extremely proud of our engineering students who have emerged first runners-up at the L’Oreal Brainstorm 2020.'

The School of Education's Overseas Programme 2.0 took seven undergraduate students and a special participant from the School of Engineering to Sri Lanka for a two-week summer excursion.
The group visited three out of four campuses of Gateway College located in Colombo, Negombo, and Kandy, each with unique features specific to their geographical locations.
Activities during the trip included attending musical productions, talent shows, class observations, and presenting insights into cybercrime in the Malaysian context.
Students also had interactive sessions with Gateway Graduate School Colombo and participated in a free and easy English lesson on literary analysis at Gateway Negombo.
Student reflections highlighted themes such as Hospitality, Motivation, and Inspiration, emphasizing the impact of the trip on their future aspirations as educators.
The post about the excursion was written by Rynnie Son and was posted on 11th October 2016.

Economics degrees typically cover three broad areas of studies: Microeconomics, Macroeconomics, Econometrics.

For Macroeconomics, Stephen D. Williamson's book 'Macroeconomics, Pearson, 6e, 2018' is recommended.

The Nottingham MBA is a programme for individuals seeking to improve their managerial skills and develop their potential to manage and lead in the current dynamic and complex organizational environment.

The Nottingham MBA is highly valued for middle and senior managers or entrepreneurs in both public and private sectors looking to develop their management skills for senior positions and enhance their career prospects and leadership capabilities.
The program has been in Malaysia since the year 2001, with many alumni holding senior management positions both in Malaysia and internationally.

Complementing our existing BSc (Hons) Economics degree, NSE Malaysia has launched a new BSc (Hons) Economics and International Economics degree in the 2015-2016 academic year.

The new BSc (Hons) Economics and International Economics degree allows students to specialise in various aspects of international economics, with strong emphasis on both international trade and international finance.

The BSc (Hons) Economics and International Economics degree retains all the core compulsory modules of the existing BSc (Hons) Economics degree, but augments it with 5 additional core compulsory modules in international economics:

1. Economic Integration I
2. Economic Integration II
3. International Trade
4. Advanced International Trade I
5. Advanced International Trade II
The BSc (Hons) Economics and International Economics degree is ideal for students who would like to obtain a solid understanding of international economics in this increasingly globalised world.
The BSc (Hons) Economics degree is ideal for students who would like to have more flexibility in choosing economics modules.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus hosts University of Nottingham’s annual Tri Campus Arts Festival, a major theatre festival involving students from Malaysia, China, and the United Kingdom.

UNMC students from various disciplines collaborate in the performances at the Tri Campus Arts Festival.

A first year Environmental Science student at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus had a literature review of the Southeast Asian monsoon published in the academic journal Geoscience Frontiers.

Afsoon Fanaiyan's achievement was announced on 16th October 2020.

The BSc (Hons) in Business Economics and Finance at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) combines rigorous academic training with practical insights, preparing students for a thriving career in the dynamic world of business, economics, and finance.
The three-year full-time program is delivered by the internationally renowned Nottingham University Business School which is accredited by EQUIS, AACSB, and AMBA.
The program ensures exemptions from professional examinations, accelerating your pathway to becoming a qualified professional.
The course offers a perfect blend of theoretical knowledge and practical experience, paving the way for diverse career opportunities in financial institutions, consultancy, policymaking, and beyond.

The program features cutting-edge modules like Quantitative Methods, Economics of Regulation, and Sustainable Business Practices, equipping students with vital analytical, problem-solving, and leadership skills.
Students will develop a robust understanding of key areas such as corporate finance, financial markets, business ethics, industrial economics, and econometrics.

The course offers a comprehensive business and economic knowledge, advanced analytical and decision-making skills, digital-rich learning, industry-ready expertise, leadership and communication development, and global career opportunities.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Semenyih Campus is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just 45 minutes' drive from the city center.
The program entry requirements at the University of Nottingham Malaysia include English language requirements and specific qualifications like A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, and others.
Additional requirements include a grade B in Mathematics at SPM/GCSE/IGCSE/High School Diploma level or equivalent.
IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or English Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, and other language proficiency tests are accepted for entry.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to undergraduate degrees at UNM.

Career opportunities after completing the Business Economics and Finance BSc (Hons) course include roles like Market Risk Analyst, Investment Banker, Financial or Credit Analyst, Data or Product Analyst, and Business Development Executive.

The UNICEF Internship Programme offers eligible/qualified students at both Headquarters and country offices the opportunity to acquire direct practical experience in UNICEF's work.

Eligibility requirements for the UNICEF Internship Programme include being a currently-enrolled graduate or post-graduate student in a field related to UNICEF’s interests, fluency in English and one other UNICEF working language, excellent academic performance, and a demonstrated interest in international development.

Applicants for the UNICEF Internship Programme must have a strong commitment to the values and principles of the United Nations and UNICEF's mission, guiding principles and Convention on the Rights of the Child.

To be considered for internship opportunities in Malaysia, interested individuals need to email a letter of interest, a letter of recommendation from their university, and a resume to the Operations unit via kualalumpur@unicef.org.
Only selected candidates will be contacted for further consideration for UNICEF internships.

A team of students from University of Nottingham Malaysia won the HSBC Malaysia Business Case Competition for the second time, having won the competition in 2015. The teams were also First Runners-Up in 2016 and 2014.

The team represented Malaysia in the HSBC/HKU Asia Pacific Business Case Competition 2018 that took place in Hong Kong recently after sweeping the champions title at the national level of the HSBC Malaysia Business Case Competition 2018 held in April 2018. The competition was held from 5 to 8 June 2018.

The Nottingham team consisted of third-year Business School student Low Song Yong, second-year Business School students Phung Pei Shan and Phileon Phua Wei Soon, and third-year School of Economics student Rynn Leow Chok Nam.

The team received a cash prize of RM15,000, together with gift plaques and certificates. The first, second and third runners-up positions were taken by Taylor’s University, Sunway University and Multimedia University, respectively.

After advancing to the Quarter-Finals at the regional-level HSBC/HKU Asia Pacific Business Case Competition held at The University of Hong Kong in June, the Nottingham team went on to receive the ‘Most Collegial Team’ Award, with team member Phileon Phua also receiving the ‘Most Collegial Student Award’.
The regional competition was won by the student team from Yonsei University, Korea, who received a USD10,000 cash prize.

If you are a University of Nottingham Staff Member you can check availability and book a room through the Web Room Booking System via the following link: Web Room Booking System

Your request will be submitted to the Room Booking Services and as soon as this is scheduled onto the system, you will receive a confirmation email. If there are any problems with your booking we will contact you directly. Confirmation of your booking will normally be sent to you within 24 hours.

If you have made the booking via the Web Room Booking System you will need to log onto the system as usual and select ‘My Bookings' (which can be found at the bottom of the page). This will show you a list of all your current bookings and provide the option to cancel. Alternatively if the booking was confirmed via any other method (e.g. email) then please send us an email outlining the cancellation details (including the date, time, room and booking description) to RoomBooking@nottingham.edu.my

If you wish to make a change to your booking please send an email to explain what you would like to change (including the original date, time, room, booking description) to RoomBooking@nottingham.edu.my

We always try to allocate the room you requested or a room within your preferred area/building. However, in some cases this is not possible so we will try to provide an alternative room. If the room you have been allocated is not suitable please let us know and we can let you know if there are any other options.
Booking requests for recognized student societies must go through the Student Association. Please visit the Student Services Office, 1st floor Block H Building.

The Web Room Booking System is usually opened up for users to submit requests for the next academic year in August. Please note that any requests for the next academic year are not guaranteed or confirmed and may not be scheduled until after the final teaching timetable is confirmed in the Autumn semester.
If the issue relates to your username and password or access rights you will need to contact the IT Service Desk.
For issues regarding the room booking process contact RoomBooking@nottingham.edu.my
For Audio Visual issues please contact IT Service Desk.
For room maintenance/layout issues please contact the Estate Office or submit a support request via MaintainX Portal

The International Relations (IR) and International Communication Studies (ICS) Career Showcase took place on November 2nd 2016 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
The event was jointly organised by the Careers Advisory Office, PHIR-Nott, and the School of Modern Languages and Cultures (SMLC).
Six speakers from various organisations participated in the event: Major Mohd Ridzuan M Shariff, Barry Lim, Shaza Onn, Thomas Benjamin Daniel, Lynn D’Cruz, and Maureen Johnson.
The event included a 5-minute introduction from each speaker followed by a 30-minute personal session with each speaker where students could ask questions.
The participants were divided into small groups of 20 based on their preference of speakers.
The IR and ICS Careers Showcase started in 2015 by the Careers Advisory Office and is an annual event.
The showcase provided students with the opportunity to network, ask questions, and learn about job scopes, internship opportunities, challenges, and work-life balance.
The event was informative and provided students with insights into various companies and working cultures.
Participant feedback indicated that the event was a valuable experience and helped them feel more prepared for the future.

Teck Leong Lau joined the University of Nottingham in June 2006 to start up the Civil Engineering Department in Malaysia.
Teck Leong Lau's expertise includes serving the Civil Engineering Industry for over 10 years and working as a Project Engineer and Project Manager in Consultancy Firms in the UK.

Large fruit bats of the genus Pteropus are severely threatened by hunting and deforestation.
The island flying fox is already classified as 'endangered' on Malaysia’s National Red List.

Patrick Joseph, Director of Academic Services received the Lord Dearing Award for his contribution in supporting student learning experience at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) during the graduation ceremony held on 25 July 2015.

The Lord Dearing Award is conferred to staff of the University who makes a world-class contribution towards creating a student learning environment which is nurturing as well as challenging, creative and innovative.
Patrick was among the pioneer staff at UNMC, having joined us in 2000, in the early days when we were setting up.
Earning the ranks to his current position as UNMC’s Director of Academic Services, he continues to engage with students, responding to their feedback personally.

He also directs the campus strategy relating to Admissions and Students Administration, Wellbeing & Learning Support, Careers Advisory Services, Student Association, Alumni and Donor Relations, Sports and Community Engagement. Some of these functions are nation-leading provisions.
Patrick was one of the first member of staff to join UNMC when the University started off by offering courses in business, engineering and computer studies.
Today, UNMC offers more than 70 courses and has more than 5,000 students.
In the past 15 years, he has served in several roles in the University including student recruitment, examination and teaching facility management, student registry and now Academic Services.

The Smart Manufacturing group is dedicated to supporting Malaysian manufacturing to revitalize the economy and support growth across the sector.

The Smart Manufacturing group encompasses a multidisciplinary team of established academics in mechanical, materials and manufacturing engineering, electrical and electronic engineering, civil engineering, and computer science.

The academic staff of the Smart Manufacturing group have recognized expertise in areas such as additive manufacturing, augmented reality, automation and robotics, composites and smart materials, computational simulation, computer vision, data mining and machine learning, intelligent control systems, and laser materials processing.
The Smart Manufacturing group collaborates with Dongguan University of Technology in China through a joint Doctoral Training Programme.

The Smart Manufacturing group benefits from global expertise, including support from the Institute of Manufacturing at the University of Nottingham UK which has supported over 200 regional companies across the supply chain.

To open a bank account in Malaysia, students will need an original passport with a student pass, a 'Letter of Opening a Bank Account' issued by the International Student Support, an offer letter issued by Student Registry, the EMGS approval letter issued by the Visa Office, a copy of E-Val issued by Malaysian Immigration, and a minimum deposit in Malaysian Ringgit (MYR) of RM250 - RM300.
For students below 18 years old, parents need to sign an indemnity form provided by the bank for opening a new bank account.
There is a minimum waiting period of 1-2 months to open a bank account in Malaysia.
Students are advised to bring sufficient cash until the bank account is successfully opened and ensure they have Malaysian currency before entering Malaysia or change at the airport upon arrival.
Without a Student Visa, students can open a bank account only with Affin Bank. With a Student Visa, students can open a bank account with Maybank or CIMB.
Contact person for further information: Ms. Rita Vengidesan, International Student Support Officer. Tel: +6 (03) 8924 8750. Email: international.support@nottingham.edu.my

Introduction to Bahasa Malaysia A will run during the Spring semester of 2016. There will be no level B class this semester.
You will acquire the four skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing together with basic grammatical structures which will enable you to use the language for basic communication.
You will attend an one and a half-hour weekly evening class over eight weeks. The course will run at 12:00 on Wednesdays in B1C24 starting from 15 February 2017.
You will also be expected to undertake a minimum of two hours’ self-study per week to develop their linguistic skills effectively.
Work in class is communicative with regular opportunities for pair and group work.

The Women in Science, Engineering and Technology (WinSET) Working Group of UNMC provides support by influencing policies, practices and culture of the University, and providing informed advice around career advancement to create equal opportunities for men and women in academia.

The Careers Advisory Service (CAS) at University of Nottingham Malaysia has collaborated with Forage to offer all UNM students practical work experience through free Virtual Work Experience Programs.
Forage provides virtual experience programs designed by leading companies for UNM students.
Students will work through resources and tasks simulating intern or full-time employee work, taking 5-6 hours to complete each program.
Programs include video instructions, real-life examples, tasks reflecting real work, and curated resources.
Benefits of the programs include sampling real work at leading companies, trying different career paths, building skills, and boosting the CV with personalized certificates.
Students and alumni can participate in the programs with no lengthy application process by choosing a program, creating an account on the Forage website, and starting right away.

Process Integration for Resource Conservation is a textbook written by Professor Ir Dr Dominic C. Y. Foo and published by CRC Press.
The textbook presents state-of-the-art process integration techniques for resource conservation problems like water minimisation and gas recovery.
The book aims to provide final year undergraduate and postgraduate chemical and environmental engineering students with systematic design techniques for resource conservation.
The first book launch event was held during the 15th Conference on Process Integration, Modelling and Optimisation for Energy Saving and Pollution Reduction (PRES 2012) in Prague, Czech Republic.
Professor Ir Dr Dominic C. Y. Foo is the Professor of Process Design and Integration at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

Chinese New Year is celebrated on a grand scale across Malaysia and it is no different at University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM). To usher in the Lunar New Year UNM traditionally hosts two grand celebrations, one by the Careers Advisory Services (CAS) and the other by the Graduate School.
The Graduate School at University of Nottingham Malaysia held its early Chinese New Year celebration on 23 January with a luncheon for its postgraduate students.
During the celebration, attendees had the opportunity to sample an array of sumptuous Chinese dishes and Mandarin oranges were distributed to all attendees, symbolizing gold and good fortune.
The festivities included the tossing of yee sang, a Teochew-style raw fish salad, to represent the rise of good fortune.
The event was an opportunity for international students to learn about Chinese culture in Malaysia and share the joy of the celebration, promoting cultural exchange.
The Chinese New Year celebrations by Career Advisory Services (CAS) at University of Nottingham Malaysia will take place on 19 February when students return to the University.
The CAS event will feature delectable food, activities, Mandarin oranges, fortune cookies, and traditional classical music to create a festive atmosphere.

CAS will use the event to create awareness about its services, events, and activities, and students will have the opportunity to network with their career advisors and participate in career tests and IQ quizzes.

Cookies may be sent to the browser on the user's computer when visiting the website, enabling recognition upon return visits and personalization of web pages.
The website contains security measures to protect against the loss, misuse, or alteration of personal data.
The privacy policy does not cover linked websites that are outside the control of The University of Nottingham.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia is running a Food Series of 5 events that explore Forgotten and Future Foods to engage directly with the public on topics exploring the current and future trends of food from farm to table.

The events are organised across three distinct themes (Foraging, Farming and Table) and include a food study tour to an Orang Asli Kampung, panel discussions and presentations on foraging and edible weeds, the effects of aquaculture on the environment, and a film screening.
The final session, the Chefs’ Table, will be held on April 13 from 2 to 4 pm and will focus on culinary consciousness and creativity about forgotten recipes and ingredients.
The Food Series was designed to address how changing climates, landscapes, and lifestyle choices are shaping the future of food and diets.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus collaborates with the Ministry of Education, Malaysia (MOE) in training special needs teachers.
The partnership trained and assessed 292 primary school teachers from all over Malaysia at various centres located in Kuching, Sandakan, Kota Kinabalu, Kuala Terengganu, Batu Pahat, and Melaka.
UNMC's School of Education academic staff managed the evaluation of the program by assessing participant competence across Malaysia.
The graduation ceremony organized by MOE's Programme Delivery Unit was officiated by the Minister of Education Malaysia II, Datuk Seri Idris Jusoh.

Professor Christine Ennew, Pro-Vice–Chancellor/ Provost and CEO of UNMC congratulated the Malaysian Government on making education accessible to all, especially children requiring specially trained teachers.

UNMC has previously conducted professional development sessions for teachers in Malaysian public schools, Chinese independent schools, and for volunteer teachers at United Nations High Commission for Refugees supported schools.
For more information on courses offered at UNMC, visit www.nottingham.edu.my or www.nottingham.edu.my/contact.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) was recently conferred with membership of the International Council of Islamic Finance Educators (ICIFE) as an Institutional Member.
The ICIFE was established under the Malaysian Economic Transformation Programme in an Entry Point Project co-led by Bank Negara Malaysia and the International Islamic University of Malaysia.
The main objective of the ICIFE is to increase and maintain the professionalism of educators in Islamic Finance at national and international levels.

UNMC joins a host of regulators, accrediting bodies, education, and commercial institutions affiliated with the ICIFE, including Bank Negara Malaysia, the Association of Islamic Banking Institutions Malaysia (AIBIM), and others.
Gwendolyn Chan Hui Pei, an STPM student from SMK Batu Lintang in Kuching bags the first prize in an economics essay competition.
The essay competition was organised recently by University of Nottingham Malaysia’s (UNM) School of Economics together with World Bank Group Inclusive Growth and Sustainable Finance Hub in Malaysia.

The topic for the essay competition was “What would be the economic consequences for Malaysia if technology replaces 50% of current jobs in the country? Who would benefit, and who would lose? Would we be better off ultimately?” and it was open to all pre-university and high school students in Malaysia.
The School of Economics introduced this essay competition in 2014 as a way to get high school students in Malaysia to explore some of the critical issues in economics.
In her winning essay, Gwendolyn, an Economics student, highlighted how technology has taken over the workforce in the past, how it is currently happening and will continue to do so in the future.

One example she cited was how bank tellers in the US were replaced by ATMs. Although it was not well received at first, the introduction of ATMs led to the growth in the stock market that further created more job openings.

In second place was Lee Ricson from Hin Hua High School, while third place went to Oah Xin Yi and Shyla Sharma, Cambridge A Levels students from Inti International College Penang. Ricson won RM800 while Xin Yi and Shyla received RM600.

The consolation prize winners were Alex Peter from Institut Pendidikan Guru Kampus Bahasa Antarabangsa, Chung Po Ching Stephenie from Tenby International School, and Hiew Tzy Hwan and Naveelan Selvan from University of Nottingham Foundation in Business and Management. All consolation prize winners received RM350 in cash.
The contest winner last year was Shirel Leena Ponnudurai from the Nexus International School.
The contest ran from 1 April to 1 June and attracted a total of 48 entries from students across the country.

Professor Dr Dominic CY Foo launched his book at the Process System Engineering Conference (PSE China) at Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China in July 2016.
The book launched in China was a Chinese translation of the English textbook 'Process Integration for Resource Conservation' published by Professor Foo in 2012 with CRC Press/Taylor and Francis.
The Chinese edition of the book was translated by a team from Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, China.
The Chinese team included Dr Xiaoping Jia, postgraduate student Zhiwei Li, and Dr Fang Wang from the School of Environment and Safety Engineering.
The book launch garnered interest from many academics at the event.
The textbook authored by Professor Foo is suitable for final year undergraduate and postgraduate students in chemical, environmental, and energy engineering courses.
The textbook focuses on process integration techniques like pinch analysis and mathematical optimization.
Professor Dr Dominic CY Foo is a Professor of Process Design and Integration at the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering at UNMC.
Professor Foo is the founder of the Centre of Excellence for Green Technologies at UNMC and is an active member of professional engineering bodies in Malaysia and the UK.
Professor Foo has published three books and over 110 papers in international refereed journals.

Professor Foo is the Editor-in-Chief for Process Integration and Optimisation for Sustainability (Springer) and Subject Editor for Process Safety & Environmental Protection (Elsevier), among other roles.
Professor Foo has received several awards including the Innovator of the Year Award (2009), Young Engineer Award (2010), and the Outstanding Young Malaysian Award (2012) among others.

University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a multi-stakeholder exercise involving several hundred participants to identify conservation priorities in Peninsular Malaysia.
The results are published in the open access academic journal Cogent Environmental Science.
Malaysia is part of the Sundaland Biodiversity Hotspot and is ranked 12 globally in terms of its National Biodiversity Index.
Malaysia boasts 306 species of mammals, 742 species of birds, 567 species of reptiles, and over 15,000 plant species.
The country aims to increase terrestrial protected areas from 13.8% of the total land area in 2015 to 20% by 2025.
The Sumatran rhino has disappeared, and there is a decline in the number of Malayan tigers in Malaysia.
Improvements in policy and management, strengthening of environmental laws, funding and resource allocation increases, and public awareness are suggested for conservation.

This programme prepares aspiring education professionals to work with students of all ages whose first language is not English, as well as other stakeholders in the education field.

Combining linguistics, educational theories, technology, pedagogy, and content knowledge, the programme offers a rich environment to develop a sound understanding of English language components, enhancing teaching and interactions with students.
Nottingham is ranked 47th globally for Education and Training (QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024).
Students will engage with an extensive network of trusted partners, including national and international schools, educational NGOs, enterprises, and edtech companies.
The degree encourages critical comparisons of global education systems, preparing graduates for diverse educational settings.
This programme also paves the way for further teaching qualifications in regions not requiring Qualified Teacher Status.

Specialised TESOL Focus: This programme equips you with expert knowledge in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages, ensuring you are prepared to meet the demands of global language education.
Global Perspective: Explore and compare educational systems worldwide, fostering a deep understanding of international teaching practices and cultural diversity.
Career-Ready Skills: Enhance your expertise in curriculum development, classroom management, and TESOL-specific methodologies, making you a sought-after graduate in the education sector.
Pathway to Further Qualifications: This degree provides opportunities for progression to a four-year Bachelor of Education with Qualified Teacher Status or other advanced education qualifications.
Entry requirements: English language requirements include IELTS 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element), TOEFL (iBT) 90, and PTE (Academic) 71.

Malaysian students can pay their fees for Foundation, Undergraduate, and Postgraduate programs either 100% at the start of the semester or 50% at the start of each semester.
For Postgraduate students at the MRes, MPhil, and PhD levels, fees can be paid 100% at the start of the semester or 50% at the start of each semester.

Different payment options are available for specific Postgraduate programs like MSc Management Psychology, MSc Finance and Investment, MBA Part-Time, and School of Political, History, and International Relations.
Payment methods accepted include NottinghamHub, cheque or bank draft, credit/debit card, bank transfers, and direct bank-in. Cash payments are not accepted.
The University offers a 2.5% early payment discount for students who pay the full academic year fee before or on a specified date.
A refund policy is in place for tuition fee refunds upon withdrawal, with percentages based on the number of days from the start of registration/session.
Students facing financial difficulties can opt for an Instalment Plan offered by the University.
Important deadlines for tuition fee payments are specified for different courses and semesters, and late penalties apply for outstanding fees.
Contact details for inquiries regarding payment of tuition fees are provided for students.

The School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences (EGS) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia has co-organised the alumni sharing series titled 'Success Stories from the Environmental and Geographical Sciences Alumni'.
The alumni sharing series started on 18 March 2022 and will end on 13 May 2022.
The alumni sharing series features five alumni from the EGS sharing their personal journeys, career ups and downs, and professional development.
All sessions of the alumni sharing series are moderated by Dr Alison Wee, an assistant professor at EGS.
Emily Oi, a Senior Analyst at the Malaysian Green Technology and Climate Change Corporation, was the first speaker of the alumni sharing series.
Jasmin Irisha, a Climate and Environment Consultant at UNICEF Malaysia, was the second speaker of the alumni sharing series.
Dulanga Witharanage, a Country Team Coordinator at Market Development Facility, Sri Lanka, was the third speaker of the alumni sharing series.
The participants of the alumni sharing series include students, alumni, and friends from different University of Nottingham campuses in Malaysia, the UK, and China.

Upcoming sessions of the alumni sharing series will feature Mathialagan Magendran, a Board of Director of UN Global Compact Network Malaysia & Brunei on 22 April, and Shazia Hussenbux, a Global Sustainable Sourcing Lead at Oatly, Sweden on 13 May.
Registration for the upcoming sessions of the alumni sharing series is still open at https://bit.do/EGSalumnistories

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus was founded in 1999 and hosts nearly 5000 students, with around 40% of them from beyond Malaysia's borders.
The Exams Office organizes and administers all written exams for courses at the University's main campus in Semenyih, Malaysia.

Specific arrangements for exams can be made for students with learning difficulties, physical impairments, visual or hearing impairments, or long term medical conditions, with necessary evidence and support.
Exam timetables are typically available 4-6 weeks before exams begin, with autumn semester timetables released in early December and spring semester timetables in mid-March.
Examinations can be scheduled with constraints to student choice, room sizes, and a commitment to no more than two exams per day, without consecutive exams where possible.
Examinations may be scheduled on consecutive days due to the logistical difficulty of accommodating many exams involving thousands of students.
Locations of examinations are published and are unlikely to change; any changes will be separately communicated to registered students.
Some modules may have 'in class' exams held within the school and will not appear on the exam timetable.
Exam results can be obtained from respective Faculty/School Offices or via Blue Castle.

Professor Ir Dr Dominic Foo was interviewed by the online media channel Pocketimes to discuss the water pollution problem that plagued many Selangor residents in September 2020.

Professor Foo mentioned that many factories in the country have been practicing illegal waste dumping for a long time, which usually goes unnoticed as the dumped chemicals get diluted by river water when in small quantities.
Professor Foo highlighted that Malaysia's leniency towards businesses might lead to repeated offenses by factories despite fines for pollution incidents.
The cost of installing a waste treatment facility can range from a few hundred thousand to millions of ringgit, posing financial challenges especially for small-medium enterprises.
Practice like proper waste disposal and reporting illegal waste dumping are key steps individuals can take to combat illegal pollution according to Professor Foo.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia is located at Jalan Broga, 43500 Semenyih, Selangor Darul Ehsan, Malaysia.
For media inquiries, contact Josephine Dionisappu, PR and Communications Manager, University of Nottingham Malaysia at josephine.dionisappu@nottingham.edu.my.
The full interview of Prof Foo can be accessed through the YouTube portal.

Associate Professor Dr Nafis Alam was conferred an Award for Outstanding Contribution to Education at the recent World Education Congress (WEC) held at Mumbai, India on 14 November 2014.

The award was presented to Dr Alam in recognition of his exemplary role in his contributions to Islamic finance education in the areas of leadership, innovation, and interface between academia and industry.

The WEC focuses on the evolving culture of education and educational pedagogy, with the objective of deep systemic change as well as providing a platform for discussion on effective learning strategies for institutions of higher education.
The WEC presents awards to institutions and individuals in the higher education sector who have achieved high levels of excellence and who provide exemplary leadership and a role model.

Dr Nafis Alam shared the award this year with Datin Professor Ir Dr Siti Hamisah Bt Tapsir, Deputy Director General, Private Higher Education Management Sector, Department of Higher Education, Ministry of Education, Malaysia.
Previous recipients include various distinguished personalities who have contributed in diverse areas, from a wide range of education institutions in Asia, US, Europe, and Australia.
Professor Ting Kang Nee from the School of Pharmacy at the University of Nottingham Malaysia participated in the 'Creating a Joyful Civilisation Ecological Village' event organized by Noble Gateway.
The event aimed to raise awareness on the importance of the ecological village concept, emphasizing sustainability, waste and pollution reduction, and benefits to mental and physical well-being.

UNM representatives toured Noble Gateway's ecological farm and learned about their sustainable practices, including cultivation of Traditional Chinese Medicine herbs using zero pesticide and herbicide practices.
Noble Gateway has been successful in soil rehabilitation through composting and addition of cultured bacteria, enhancing soil biodiversity and nutrient availability.
SEAFILM is a seaweed-based natural filtration medium for household washing machines developed by Professor Kang Nee's team, supported by the United Nations Development Programme grant.
The event marked the first collaborative activity between UNM and Noble Gateway, fostering connections between UNM and other organizations committed to sustainability.
Noble Gateway is an organization aiming to build a self-sustaining community through the ecological village concept, the first of its kind in Malaysia.

The SEAFILM project is supported by the ASEAN Secretariat, the Mission of Japan to ASEAN, and UNDP, through the ASEAN Blue Innovation Challenge, focusing on eco-friendly methods to use and protect ocean resources.

The PYROASIA Symposium 2023 will be held on 26 and 27 June 2023 at The Majestic Hotel Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with a social visit/lab visit to Genting on 28 June 2023.
The conference is organized by University of Nottingham Malaysia together with the co-organizers PYROASIA Forum and Frontiers Lab, Japan.
Participants are invited to submit their original work for presentation, focusing on all thermo-chemical conversion technologies for fuel production.
The conference topics include Analytical Pyrolysis, Bio-oil upgrading, Combustion, Hydrothermal operations, LCA biomass and bioenergy processes, and more.

Important dates for the conference: Abstract submission from 1 November 2022 to 10 May 2023, Early-Bird Registration from 1 December 2022 to 20 May 2023, and Regular Registration from 21 May 2023 to 10 June 2023.
The PYROASIA Symposium 2023 is organized by the Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Nottingham Malaysia, in collaboration with PYROASIA Forum and Frontier Lab, Japan.
Selected papers from the conference will be recommended to specific journals for submission, including the Journal of Analytical and Applied Pyrolysis and Energies.
The Conference Chair is Dr. Suchithra Thangalazhy Gopakumar, with Co-chair Dr. Sathrugnan Karthikeyan from Frontier Lab.
International Advisory Members for the conference include professionals from various academic institutions in Japan, India, Malaysia, Brunei, Thailand, Indonesia, and China.

The Special and Inclusive Education MA program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a full-time program that can be completed in 1-2 years or part-time in 2-4 years, with a start date of September 2025.
The program fees for Malaysian students for the MA in Special and Inclusive Education is RM58,000 per program, while for international students it is RM60,000 per program.
The MA in Special and Inclusive Education does not confer Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) but provides a strong foundation for advancing inclusive education practices globally.

The MA in Special and Inclusive Education program focuses on critical topics such as effective support strategies, complexities of inclusive education, and the rights of children to be fully included in schools.

For the MA in Education: Special and Inclusive Education, students need to complete 180 credits, including core modules like Debating Special and Inclusive Education and Practice-based Inquiry, as well as electives and a dissertation.

The entry requirements for the MA in Special and Inclusive Education program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia include a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent, and English language proficiency test scores like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, or MUET.

Malaysian applicants without standard entry requirements but with relevant work experience may be considered for entry at the discretion of the School, provided they have passed the Accredited Prior Experiential Learning assessment through the Malaysian Qualifications Agency.

The Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with facilities such as business schools, education schools, science and engineering schools, sports center, library, and student accommodation.

The MA in Special and Inclusive Education program provides career advancement opportunities in roles such as Special Education Teacher, Inclusion Coordinator, Education Policy Developer, and Consultant in Special Education or Inclusive Education.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a variety of On-Campus Student Accommodations where learning facilities and amenities are all just a short walk away.
Newer accommodation consisting of six halls of residence are located in Student Village North (J Halls), while Student Village South (I Halls) consist of five halls of residence.
Each residential hall has its own Hall Wardens (staff) and Hall Tutors (postgraduate students) who will be available to care for your safety and welfare.
Entrance into your halls are via door access control using your student ID card.
Security is provided by a team of in-house security officers and outsourced security guards. The University also has over 400 CCTV cameras throughout the campus.

University of Nottingham Malaysia accommodation may use facilities such as a swimming pool, indoor and outdoor sports facilities, gyms, jogging track, and an outdoor amphitheater which are all located within the campus.

Progressing and continuing students are encouraged to apply for accommodation before the end of the semester or academic year.
New students may apply for on-campus accommodation as soon as they have their University student ID which is usually issued soon after they have submitted their course application.
The University's on-line accommodation application portal, OLAA, allows students to preview room options, submit applications, and manage offers.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers various room types for on-campus accommodation, ranging from single ensuite bathroom, twin shared, to four shared rooms, with or without air-conditioning.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia provides special rooms for residents with special needs, which allow for easy access and other facilities.
Light cooking and heating up of food and drinks are allowed within the designated pantry area in on-campus accommodations.

The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Civil Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) features a comprehensive, accredited pathway to becoming a Professional/Chartered Engineer. Spanning four years, this course equips students with in-depth knowledge of structural, geotechnical, hydraulic, environmental engineering, and Building Information Modelling (BIM) blending theoretical principles with practical applications.

Backed by esteemed recognition from the Board of Engineers Malaysia and Joint Board of Moderators (IStructE, IHE, CIHT, ICE and PWI), graduates of this programme meet international professional standards, opening doors to diverse career pathways.
Ranked among the top 100 globally for Civil Engineering (QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024), UNM stands out for its commitment to sustainable infrastructure and engineering innovation.
Geotechnics 1, Group Project, Hydraulics 1, Mathematical Methods for Civil Engineering, Portfolio of Civil Engineering Studies 1, Structural Analysis 1

Advanced Mathematical Methods for Civil Engineering, Civil & Structural Steel Design Project, Fundamentals of Materials, Geotechnics 2, Hydraulics 2, Portfolio of Civil Engineering Studies 2, Structural Analysis 2
Building Information Modelling (BIM) Project, Geotechnics 3, Hydraulics Design, Industrial Training, Structural Concrete Design
Group Design Project, Investigative Project
All candidates are considered on an individual basis and we accept a broad range of qualifications.
English language requirements: A Level BBC, including Mathematics and Physics, excluding Critical Thinking and General Studies.
IB Diploma 26 points with 5, 4 at Higher Level, including Mathematics: Analysis and Approaches (HL) and Physics (HL).
STPM BBC+, including Mathematics and Physics, excluding Pengajian Am.
UEC 5 B3s including Mathematics and Physics, excluding Bahasa Malaysia and Chinese language.
Australian Year 12 ATAR 82.
Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) 77% average based on 6 subjects, including Advanced Functions, Calculus and Vectors, and Physics.
Canadian Secondary School Diplomas from other provinces are acceptable and will be assessed based on the University’s requirements.
Gaokao (NCEE) and Senior High School Diploma (China) A 70% average in the Gaokao, including at least two required subjects (Mathematics and Physics) at 75% and 73%, respectively.
Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE) / Indian School Certificate (CISCE) - Class XII 78% average from the best four subjects, including Mathematics and Physics at 80% and 70%, respectively.
Advance Placement (AP) 4, 4, 3, including AP Calculus and AP Physics.

Diploma - Local Institutions Entry to Year 2 is assessed on a case-by-case basis, typically requiring a minimum GPA of 3.20 out of 4.0 and good grades in relevant subjects, including Mathematics and Physics.
Foundation - Local Institutions Acceptance is at the School’s discretion and requires a minimum GPA of 3.20 out of 4.0 and good grades in relevant subjects, including Mathematics and Physics.
Nottingham's Foundation Programme Successful completion is required, with a minimum score of 45% in all Mathematics and Physics modules.
IELTS (Academic) 6.0 (with no less than 5.5 in each element)
TOEFL (iBT) 80 (minimum 17 in Writing and Listening, 18 in Reading and 20 in Speaking)
PTE (Academic) 65 (with no less than 59 in each element)
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a 1-year pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM’s undergraduate degrees.
Semenyih Campus is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just 45 minutes’ drive from the famous city centre with its iconic Petronas Twin Towers.

Students will have to undergo practical training or internships as part of their course. This provides them with hands-on experience in the field that will help them understand engineering principles in real life.

Nottingham University Business School Malaysia recently organised a study tour to Shanghai, China for its MBA students.
The study tour included visits to pioneer companies like Dow Jones Consulting Shanghai, BDO China, and Worldmark in mainland China.
Students learned about the synergy of Eastern principles and Western methodologies in business at Fotile in the Zhejiang Province.
The study tour also included visits to The University of Nottingham Ningbo Campus and Xian Jiaotong-Liverpool University in Suzhou.
Participants attended a lecture, campus tour, and visited the China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park during the study tour.
The tour culminated at the West Lake in Hangzhou, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The MA in Special and Inclusive Education is designed for teachers and education professionals looking to deepen their knowledge and expertise in special and inclusive education.
The programme covers topics such as effective support strategies, inclusive education complexities, and the rights of children to be fully included in schools.
The MA Special and Inclusive Education does not confer Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) but provides a strong foundation for advancing inclusive education practices globally.
For the MA in Education: Special and Inclusive Education, students need to complete 180 credits, including core modules, electives, and a dissertation.
The core modules for the MA programme include Debating Special and Inclusive Education and Practice Based Inquiry.
Optional modules for the MA programme include Communication and Literacy and Responding Mindfully to Challenging Behavior.

Entry requirements for the MA programme include a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent, with English language proficiency demonstrated through IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, or MUET scores.
Malaysian applicants without standard entry requirements but with substantial work experience may be considered for entry upon passing the Accredited Prior Experiential Learning (APEL) assessment.
Career opportunities after completing the MA programme include roles such as Special Education Teacher, Inclusion Coordinator, Education Policy Developer, and Special Education Consultant.

Associate Professor Camilla Jensen and PhD student Nasra Kara have published a new review of the 'Trade Policy Review for Malaysia' in the journal The World Economy.
The paper reviews the recently completed Trade Policy Review for Malaysia.
In the case of Malaysia trade has been liberalised and subjected to structural changes to a very high extent over the last three decades.

Reform has been less effective when it comes to trade‐related policies such as investment policies and other national policies that de facto rather than de jure affect competition due to differential treatment of different firms, brands and individuals.
The faltering levels of investment in Malaysia are mirrored by less effective reforms in trade‐related policies.
An area where Malaysia has been successful is the reorientation towards services.
The tourism industry in Malaysia is mature and a major export industry today.
Nascent service industries such as health, finance, ICT related services and education hold promise to become important export earners in the future.
For this new phase of structural change to be truly successful, Malaysia must prioritise trade negotiations and integration with her own region and especially ASEAN.
The publication was posted on 28th March 2012.

The Alumni and Donor Relations Office (ADRO) of UNM hosted a webinar titled Employment post-COVID: Industrial insights and what you can do to prepare yourselves.
The webinar was moderated by Professor Maniam Kaliannan from the Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia.
Two industrial insiders, Ong Yoke Pei and Chin Wai Hong, who are also UNM alumni, shared their experience and gave advice as guest speakers.
Ong Yoke Pei is currently a manager in the UK-based recruitment firm Hays and has over five years of experience in recruitment.
Chin Wai Hong is a Senior Certified Practitioner (SCP) of the Society of Human Resources Management and a KPI professional.
Key advice shared by the speakers included thinking like a business owner, continuous learning of new skills, and embracing a Hunter mindset.
Chin Wai Hong emphasized the importance of learning new skills and knowledge, as well as embracing a Hunter mindset.
Ong Yoke Pei highlighted the importance of social networking in today's job market, suggesting potential job opportunities through platforms like Instagram.
The event was well received by attendees who stated that they acquired plenty of knowledge and would attend future ADRO events.
One of the attendees, Khaw Kai En, left an in-depth review of the session expressing how fruitful and informative it was to them.

Dr Sumit Mandal, Associate Professor in the School of Politics, History and International Relations, is intrigued by the era of interconnectedness between Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore.
Dr Mandal situates the Malay world against the broader backdrop of the Indian Ocean to observe patterns of trade, migration, and cultural exchange.
Dr Mandal published the book 'Becoming Arab: Creole histories and modern identity in the Malay world' with Cambridge University Press in 2018.
The book explores Arab communities in the Malay world in the 16-18th centuries, tracing their origins to Hadhrami Arabs migrating from Yemen.
Dr Mandal suggests that the colonial system introduced in the 19th century shaped the racialised lens through which modern-day communities in Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia view one another.
In 2020, 'Becoming Arab' was awarded the Harry J. Benda book prize by the US-based Association for Asian Studies for Dr Mandal's outstanding scholarship in Southeast Asian studies.
Dr Mandal's expertise has been utilized in the planned revamping of the Malay World Gallery in the Islamic Arts Museum of Malaysia.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus signed a Collaboration Agreement to develop the next generation of palm oil mills and refineries with FELDA and Unitesystem.

The technologies to be tested in the pilot schemes include the ultrasonic cavitation based oil-water separation system, the continuous water sterilisation system, the recycling of water through a membrane/hydrodynamic cavitation system, the refining of CPO to refined edible oil using an advanced membrane system, power generation through a gasification system, extraction of bio-nutrients from the various processes into pharmaceutical grade products and nano-technology for the processing of liquid fertilizers.
The palm oil industry is a major industry in Malaysia and Indonesia but due to the shortage of land for new plantations there is a great urgency to increase the productivity.
FELDA is the largest oil palm company in Malaysia and one of the largest in the world with more than 860,000 ha of plantations in Malaysia.

The pilot plant, called an Integrated Recovery and Regeneration System (REGEN), integrates various technologies which convert all solid biomass waste and POME into valuable products and bio-energy.

Project lead, Professor Denny K. S. Ng from the University’s Faculty of Engineering in Malaysia, mentioned that the by-products of palm oil production are a problem for the industry and the environment.
Professor Denny K. S. Ng hopes that the new technology will be a best practice example of sustainability in palm oil processing.

Professor Mei Fong Chong, from the University's Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering in Malaysia, has developed a POME treatment system known as Integrated Anaerobic-Aerobic Bioreactor (IAAB) to turn the effluent into water for reuse in the palm oil milling process.
The IAAB technology treats POME efficiently and cleanly, harnessing a valuable renewable energy source.
The collaboration between University of Nottingham Malaysia and industry partners aims to help individual palm oil mills in Malaysia meet waste disposal and treatment regulatory parameters.
According to the National Biomass Strategy, Malaysia’s output of palm biomass is expected to increase to 100 million dry tonnes by 2020.

Registration takes place at the start of each new academic year. Students have to sign a registration form which is your agreement to observe the University regulations, please refer to the registration timetable in order to know when and where you should proceed for registration.

Proof of accommodation fee payment is required upon check-in. Alternatively, pay in cash when checking-in. Collect your keys, a checklist and a form. Go through the checklist when you enter your room. Inspect your room/flat/house and make sure it is in good condition. If not, immediately report to the Accommodation Office. Read the terms, rules and regulations in the form. Agree to abide by the rules and regulations and to stay for the allocated period by signing the Check-in Form. Submit the completed Check-in Form back to the Accommodation Office.
