The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) has announced the appointment of Professor Fon Sim Ong and Professor Andrew Morris, to the positions of Vice Provost (Teaching and Learning) and Dean of Faculty of Science respectively.
Prior to this Professor Ong was the Dean of Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, a position she has held for 2 years and Professor Morris was the Head of School for the School of Pharmacy at UNMC.

Professor Ong has more than 20 years experience in academia in the Malaysian higher education sector. She has held positions at both public and private universities, lecturing undergraduate and postgraduate students.

Professor Morris joined UNMC in 2005 and was instrumental in establishing at UNMC, the first ever international Pharmacy programme accredited by Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain (RPSGB). In 2010 he became Head of the School of Pharmacy at UNMC.

In his new position as the Dean of the Faculty of Science at UNMC, he will oversee the Schools of Biosciences, Biomedical Sciences, Computer Science, Geography, Pharmacy and Psychology and the Foundation in Science Department.
More information is available from Josephine Dionisappu, PR & Communications Manager at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus on josephine.dionisappu@nottingham.edu.my.

Initially joining the MDF as a Business Advisor, Dulanga later took on the role as their Environment Anchor before she landed her current position.

Having been part of the NGO sector since 2016, Dulanga received funding from UNM to be a part of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Conference of the Parties 22 (COP22) in 2016 that took place in Marrakech, Morocco, where she represented the Malaysian Youth Delegation.
Her career plans for the future are to keep exploring the International Development sector and discovering pathways to address climate change while simultaneously eradicating poverty.
Finally, Dulanga has the following advice for students who want to pursue careers as environmental scientists: 'Don’t limit yourself. Keep your options open.'
Professor David Greenaway, the Vice-Chancellor of The University of Nottingham, has been knighted in the Queen’s Birthday Honours 2014.
Professor Greenaway received the honour in recognition of his wide-ranging achievements in higher education and public service.
He has led the University as Vice-Chancellor since 2008 and made a significant contribution on the national and international stage, both within the education sector and in broader public life.
He is a Member of the Government's Asia Task Force and Higher Education Task Force, Chair elect of the CASE Europe Board or Trustees and a Deputy Lieutenant of Nottinghamshire.
The knighthood was conferred at an official ceremony at Buckingham Palace.
As the Vice-Chancellor, he leads an institution with more than 44,000 students worldwide, 7,000 staff and a turnover of £570m (RM3.1 billion).

The University is a trailblazer in global higher education, as the first foreign university in the world to establish a campus in mainland China (2004) and the first British institution to open a fully operational overseas campus, the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, in 2000.
Both Universities have gone from strength to strength since their establishment, and now have a combined total of more than 11,000 students.
Professor Greenaway has recently completed a major independent review that will help to shape the way doctors are trained in the UK.
Professor Greenaway has served as a consultant to the World Bank, the European Commission, the United Nations, the Department for Transport and the UK Treasury.
Professor Greenaway, 62, has played a personal role in the University’s biggest-ever fundraising campaign – so far cycling 3,000 miles over the last three years to raise more than £750,000.

HSK (Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi) is an international standardised exam that tests and rates Chinese language proficiency.
HSK consists of six levels, namely levels 1 to 6, each assessing different language proficiency skills.
HSK Speaking Test (HSKK) assesses the test takers' oral Chinese abilities and consists of three levels: Primary, Intermediate, and Advanced.
Non-native Chinese speakers, including Chinese Malaysians, can take the HSK exam to evaluate their Chinese language proficiency.
The HSK certificate is essential for educational decisions, employment recruitment, and a way to assess and improve Chinese language proficiency.
The HSK exam has different test structures for each level, combining listening, reading, and writing sections with varying durations and passing criteria.
The fees for HSK/HSKK tests vary based on the level of the exam, ranging from RM120 to RM460, plus an additional 8% SST.
The test date for the HSK Exam in Malaysia 2024 is 22 June 2025, with a registration deadline of 23 May 2025.
The test centre for the HSK Exam is the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
For registration and inquiries about the HSK Exam, you can contact via email at hanyutest@nottingham.edu.my or by phone at +6 03 8924 8295.
Preparation for the HSK exam involves self-study, language courses, and practice exams; resources like textbooks, online courses, and study guides are helpful.
The HSK certificate does not have an expiration date, but validity requirements may vary for different organisations and employers.
Candidates can retake the HSK exam to improve their scores and proficiency level; there are no restrictions on the number of retakes.
After completing the HSK exam, results are available on the official HSK website, and physical copies of the certificate can be requested from the test centre.
Fees for the HSK test range from around RM100 to RM450, subject to change, and candidates should verify the latest fee information with authorised testing centres.

University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) Assistant Professor Dr Wong Ee Phin is the local chair for the 29th International Congress for Conservation Biology (ICCB) held from 21 to 25 July 2019 in Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre.

The local organising committee (LOC) comprises of volunteers from various academic institutions including Universiti Malaya, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Universiti Malaysia Terengganu, local non-governmental organisations and private sectors.

During the congress, the LOC has contributed to activities under the Equity, Inclusion and Diversity sessions, collaborative sessions with Conservation Optimism, ICCB 2019 declaration, local tours and also supported joint events between SCB and the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

The international congress was attended by more than 1300 delegates from 87 countries, namely conservation stakeholders and academics, who presented results and findings from the diverse field of conservation biology, covering genetics, ecology, biogeography, landscape connectivity, technology, community, psychology, culture, economics, endangered species recovery and many more.
The congress featured many interesting talks on a wide-range of topics, from diversity in science, community involvement in conservation, to the endangered Sumatran rhinos.
University of Nottingham Malaysia also supported thirteen pre-congress short courses at UNM’s Malaysia campus and Kuala Lumpur Teaching Center.
The Careers Night was a social event targeted at students and early-career professionals at the conference to enhance their employability and professional development.
The SCB released The 2019 Kuala Lumpur Declaration: The Species Extinction Crisis is a Crisis of Humanity developed from the ICCB 2019, with the LOC contributing to the drafting of this declaration.

A genetics tool called a Polygenic Risk Score (PRS) was developed to help European women assess breast cancer risk and was found to work in Asian women, helping to predict their future risk of developing breast cancer.

The study on breast cancer risk in Asian women was published in the Nature Communications science journal.

This counselling service is registered (Reg No: 00090) with the Malaysian Counselling Board in accordance with the Malaysian Counsellor's Rules and Regulation (Code of Ethics) 1999.

The Counselling Service is confidential. This means that we do not disclose verbal or written information without your permission or agreement. In rare cases, disclosure may occur without your consent if there is good reason to believe that you or others are at risk.
Brief notes are kept in a secure place only within the Counselling Service.

As a core aspect of everyday practice, counsellors understand both the legal and ethical implications of providing confidentiality and of keeping records concerning their clients. As such all notes are recorded in short factual notes, and stored in a secure, locked place within the Service.

The Department of Languages at HELP University recently hosted a guest speaker, Dr Malachi Edwin Vethamani, who is known as a poet, writer and professor of English Literature.
Dr Malachi has served as a professor primarily in the area of Modern English Literature.

Dr Malachi read out randomly chosen excerpts from two of his recently published books, “Complicated Lives” and “Life Happens” as well as one of his short stories from “Coitus Interruptus and Other Stories.”
During his session, Dr Malachi provided insights on how poetry was a form of self-expression.

“A lot of poems are written in reflection and cover areas of broken dreams, family relationships that may or may not be complicated and most of all about love and its many challenges today,” he said during the reading session.
The purpose of Dr Malachi's readings was to expose students to poetry and the benefits of putting pen to paper and delving into literature.

Kuganeshwary Anathan, currently pursuing her final year in the Bachelor of Education (TESL) at HELP, felt the poetry reading session gave her exposure to listening to excerpts by a well-known author and writer.
The poetry reading session provided Kuganeshwary the opportunity to experience other forms of expressions apart from her English language course study materials.
Kuganeshwary remarked, “I have not attended any poetry readings before, so this was an interesting and enlightening experience for me.”

Dr Kirsten McKenzie has received a grant from the Faculty of Science Pump Priming fund to investigate somatosensory illusions.
The study focuses on somatic (touch) sensations such as pain and misrepresentations of bodily events like phantom limb syndrome.
Phantom limb syndrome and medically unexplained symptoms account for up to one third of visits to medical practitioners.
Electroencephalography will be used to record the electrical impulses in the brain to understand the neural timings involved in illusory touch sensations.
The project was posted on 4th August 2011.

Dr. Teo, the Acting head of the School of Economics at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, provided commentary on Malaysia's new budget announced on Friday, 25th October.
Most of Dr. Teo's commentary was in Chinese language.
The government introduced a 6% consumption tax, which was higher than the market expectation of 4%.
There will be a reduction in corporate income tax rate and income tax rate for SMEs by one per cent, aimed at enhancing competitiveness and increasing personal income.
The government plans to increase Real Property Gains Tax (RPGT) to address housing price issues, with the rate for gains on properties disposed within 3 years set to 30%.
The government also raised the minimum property purchase price for foreigners to 1 million ringgit to discourage foreign ownership.
Dr. Teo emphasized that Malaysia's current fiscal deficit situation is reasonable compared to other countries, and the government must ensure it does not increase.

The Bachelor of Science (Hons) Economics and International Economics programme at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) provides a comprehensive exploration of global economic systems and their impact on international trade, development, and policy.

Modules include Economic Integration, Introduction to Macroeconomics, Introduction to Microeconomics, Quantitative Economics, Current Economic Issues in Malaysia, Growth and Development in Long-Run Historical Perspective, and The Politics of Economics and the Economics of Politicians.

Entry requirements for the Economics and International Economics BSc program at UNM include A Level with BCC grades, IB Diploma with 24 points overall, STPM with BC+C+ grades, and various other international qualification equivalents.
English language requirements for entry include IELTS score of 6.5 or above, TOEFL score of 90 or above, or equivalent proficiency in English.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia campus is located at Semenyih Campus, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, and 45 minutes' drive from the city center.
The campus offers facilities such as business, education, science, and engineering schools, a sports center, library, and student accommodation.
The Economics and International Economics BSc (Hons) program at UNM is a full-time 3-year degree program.
The cost of the Economics and International Economics BSc (Hons) program is RM45,000 per year for Malaysian students and RM55,000 per year for international students.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers career opportunities in roles such as Economist, Investment Banker, Management Consultant, Data Analyst, and Financial Analyst for graduates of the Economics program.

The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Civil Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) features a comprehensive, accredited pathway to becoming a Professional/Chartered Engineer.

The course equips students with in-depth knowledge of structural, geotechnical, hydraulic, environmental engineering, and Building Information Modelling (BIM) blending theoretical principles with practical applications.

Backed by esteemed recognition from the Board of Engineers Malaysia and Joint Board of Moderators (IStructE, IHE, CIHT, ICE, and PWI), graduates of this programme meet international professional standards.
Ranked among the top 100 globally for Civil Engineering (QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024), UNM stands out for its commitment to sustainable infrastructure and engineering innovation.
Core modules include Geotechnics, Hydraulics, Structural Analysis, Building Information Modelling (BIM) projects, and industrial training.

Entry requirements include specific grade standards in Mathematics and Physics for various education systems like A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao (NCEE), Indian School Certificate, and others.
English language requirements include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE AS Level, SPM, GCSE O-Level, and other language proficiency tests.
The campus is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with facilities such as sports center, library, and student accommodation.
Malaysian fee: RM55,000 per year, International fee: RM65,000 per year.

Future Food works towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) specifically to end poverty (Goal 1), promote healthy lives and well-being (Goal 3), and foster sustainable consumption and production patterns (Goal 12).
Future Food is led by a team of academics from a variety of disciplines, ranging from plant biotechnology and business to media, languages, and cultures, embracing a multidisciplinary approach.

FSSIDS is established as a consortium to harness the biodiversity in the region for food production, nutrition security and the preservation of food cultural heritage, and to use scientific evidence to improve food systems in small islands and developing states across the Asia Pacific region.

Developing Technologies to Improve the Pre- and Post-Harvest Life of Fresh Produce focuses on improving the quality of food crops, including their nutritional value, appearance, yield, flavour, and shelf life, as well as helping consumers make healthy dietary choices.

Nishanth Chemmangattuvalappil is a Professor of Chemical Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, specializing in product and molecular design, mixture design, machine learning, and integrated biorefineries.

Nishanth Chemmangattuvalappil's current work focuses on the application of molecular design concepts on reactive systems, integration of molecular design techniques into the design of biorefineries, and application of machine learning tools in product design.
Recent publications by Nishanth Chemmangattuvalappil include works on biochar energy potential prediction models, design of fragrant products, and computer-aided frameworks for bio-oil additives.

The 2019 Food Series - Event 4 [Urban Ecology and Food (a panel session) is presented by UoNARI-M and Crops For the Future, held at the University of Nottingham Teaching Centre in Kuala Lumpur on March 17, 2019.
The event will discuss ecological niches in urban spaces and the anthropogenic influence on urban greening, focusing on urban farming and gardening initiatives for enhancing food accessibility.
The panel session will feature guest speakers Benjamin Ong, Ruben Cortes, and Shao-Lyn Low, moderated by Dr. Tapan Kumar from the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences at UNM.

Cancer is the second leading cause of death worldwide, after heart attack and stroke. In Malaysia, breast cancer and colorectal cancer are the most common, with over 15,000 new cases in 2018 alone.
Dr Kasturi Muthoosamy looks to nanotechnology as a more acceptable alternative to current diagnostic methods for colorectal cancer which are somewhat invasive and cause fear in some patients.
Dr Muthoosamy's innovation is a biosensor, imaging, and therapeutic agent combined, aimed at binding to cancerous cells in the colon and emitting a red fluorescence signal for detection.

Dr New Siu Yee aims to develop biosensors that are cheap to construct, and simple to use without the need for sophisticated instruments or highly trained healthcare professionals, yet clinically sensitive.
Dr New Siu Yee's biosensor works by detecting the protein telomerase, a cancer biomarker found in 80% of cancerous tumors.
Dr Muthoosamy was selected to represent Malaysia at the Women in Chemistry seminar in the Netherlands.
Dr New Siu Yee won an Invention and Innovation Silver Award at the Malaysia Technology Expo 2020.

Associate Professor Salleh Hassan, Associate Professor of Accounting at Nottingham University Business School Malaysia, was invited to be a panelist at the ACCA-MIA Audit Roundtable in September 2010.

The roundtable discussion focused on the effective role of audit in light of recent high-profile corporate failures and its value in identifying threats to a company's viability in view of the global financial crisis.
The ACCA-MIA Audit Roundtable included panelists from various organizations such as the Malaysian Institute of Accountants, the Audit Oversight Board of Malaysia, and PricewaterhouseCoopers Malaysia.
The roundtable discussion was facilitated and moderated by Mr. Robert Stenhouse, a member of the ACCA Council and Director at Deloitte LLP.

Students from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) were national champions of the 1st IEM-METD Student Design Award organized by the Mechanical Engineering Technical Division (METD) of The Institution of Engineers Malaysia (IEM).

The design competition had a theme of “Construction Mechanization for Productivity Improvement” and was organized in conjunction with the CIDB-IEM Construction Fair 2016 held in Kuala Lumpur Conventional Centre (KLCC).

The competition was open to students from Malaysian public and private universities. Out of the eight finalist teams shortlisted by the panel of judges from IEM, there were three participating teams from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC).
In the final round, the teams from UNMC won the first, third, and consolation prizes for the Best Design Award category.

The first prize was presented to Team Vicissitude from third year Mechanical Engineering and Civil Engineering students, namely, Ng Zheng Yu, Lee Hong Yang, Chong Weng Fai, and Ivan Lim Zhi Tao, who won RM 2,500 cash and a plaque.

The first prize-winning team presented a new and innovative machinery called T-Rex, based on the Archimedes Screw Pump Principle, to accelerate the excavation process significantly in a construction project.
The third prize was presented to team The Vibes from Mechanical Engineering students.
Team The Vibes proposed a shaking table with the ability to produce a wide range of vibrating frequencies for construction applications.
The team who won the consolation prize is Team Magglas from Mechanical Engineering and Civil Engineering students.
Team Magglass proposed using electromagnets to eliminate human errors and provide automated correct positioning of large heavy glass panels during structural glazing of high-rise buildings.
Dr. Lim Chin Seong, assistant professor at the Department of Mechanical, Materials, and Manufacturing, was the team supervisor for the UNMC engineering teams.

The Bachelor of Science with Honours in Environmental Science at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is a comprehensive programme that equips students with the knowledge and skills to address today’s critical environmental and sustainability challenges.

The Malaysian government has identified mushrooms as a high-value commodity.
The mushroom industry in Malaysia has quadrupled the areas of mushroom production since 2010.
Dr Chin Chiew Foan, from the School of Biosciences, focused on plant molecular genetics in the project.
Leong Chia Choong, a PhD student supervised by Dr Ho, grew and analyzed unidentified mushroom strains for the project.
The team discovered that the majority of Malaysian oyster mushroom crops are Pleurotus Pulmonarius instead of Pleurotus Ostreatus.
The team used next-generation sequencing technology to unveil the genomic sequence of the oyster mushroom species for the first time.
The genetic profile identified favorable traits in the species related to biological activities, nutritional content, yield, growth rate, and resistance to bacteria.

To enroll in the Bachelor of Pharmacy (BPharm) course at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, students must complete secondary education (SPM or equivalent) and a pre-university education meeting the entry requirements specified on the BPharm course webpage.

Pharmacists are in demand in Malaysia, especially in urban areas, due to the increasing demand for healthcare services, a growing elderly population, and the need for qualified professionals in various settings including pharmaceutical companies, regulatory bodies, and academia.

The Bachelor of Pharmacy (BPharm) and Master of Pharmacy (MPharm) courses at the University of Nottingham Malaysia are four-year programs, while the BSc (Hons) Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences and BSc (Hons) Biomedical Science are three-year courses.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers various scholarships and financial aid opportunities for local and international students, such as the High Achievers’ Scholarship and the Dean's Excellence Scholarship.

The pharmacy courses at the University of Nottingham Malaysia cover subjects like pharmaceutical chemistry, pharmacology, biology, physiology, pharmaceutics, pharmacy practice, professionalism, leadership, simulated pharmacy workshops, and practical placements in hospitals or community pharmacies to develop patient consultation skills.

Pharmacists who graduate from the School of Pharmacy at the University of Nottingham Malaysia are recognized globally and are eligible to work in various settings internationally, but it is important to check local regulatory requirements for practicing as a pharmacist in specific countries.

The Student Registry Office oversees administrative matters that concern students, including issuing letters, processing withdrawal & suspension applications, producing official transcripts & certificates, maintaining the student records database, updating student details, setting the academic calendar, managing & updating course information.

The Quality Manual determines a great deal of the policy and procedure within the Registry Office. This document is the University’s central source of information relating to policies and procedures and is relevant to both staff and students.

The Student Registry Office is located on the First Floor, Block A (Administration Building) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, Jalan Broga, 43500 Semenyih, Selangor Darul Ehsan, Malaysia. The office hours are from 9:00 am to 5:30 pm, Monday - Friday. Contact information: telephone: +6 (03) 8924 8663, email: student_registry@nottingham.edu.my

The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Chemical Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) prepares students to tackle challenges in industries like energy, pharmaceuticals, food, and manufacturing.
The program is recognized by the Institution of Chemical Engineers (IChemE) and the Board of Engineers Malaysia (BEM) and supports pathways to Chartered Engineer or Professional Engineer status.
UNM ranked 82nd globally for Chemical Engineering in the QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024.

The curriculum includes laboratory work, problem-solving, and industry-driven projects with a strong emphasis on sustainability, process design, optimization, dedicated support, global exposure, and hands-on experience.

Accredited by the Institution of Chemical Engineers (IChemE), Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining (IOM3, UK), and the Board of Engineers Malaysia (BEM), meeting academic requirements for Chartered or Professional Engineer status.
The University has been ranked as a top 4 chemical engineering program in the UK and a top 15 department globally.

The entry requirements for the program include specific qualifications such as A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior High School Diploma from China, Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE) from India, and other international qualifications.
English language requirements include specific scores in IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, and IB English.
Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to undergraduate degrees at UNM.
The Chemical Engineering MEng program is a four-year, full-time program.
The tuition fee for Malaysian students is RM55,000 per year, and for international students, it is RM65,000 per year.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia, in collaboration with Shin Ansan University and Kyung-In Women’s University, organized the English Summer Programme of 2019 through the Centre for English Language & Foundation Education (CELFE).

The programme aimed to enhance students’ English proficiency through skills such as reading, writing, academic discussions, and presentations. Students had access to university facilities such as the library and sports complex.
Students were also able to participate in co-curricular activities like swimming lessons and badminton matches to enrich their experience.
The programme included visits to Kuala Lumpur and Malacca to immerse students in Malaysian culture. Korean students engaged with the local student population, fostering cultural exchange.
Student assessments included examinations in English oral, listening, and writing skills to gauge their improvement over the course of the programme.
The programme aimed not only to enhance students’ English skills but also to build on relationships established by previous cohorts.
The programme was a 4-week experience that resulted in significant English proficiency growth and the formation of treasured friendships and lifelong bonds.

Joshua Ho Cheng Wei was the Academic Mentor for the English Summer Programme 2018 and 2019, and Ms. Chin Li Yeun was the Director of English Language Education at the Centre for English Language & Foundation Education (CELFE).
The programme was concluded on 1st August 2019 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus offers a French Beginners weekend class for learning French basic topics useful for everyday conversation.
The French language course aims to provide a solid understanding of beginner French, working towards CEFR A1/2 of the Common European Framework Reference of languages.
Students are strongly recommended to complete all worksheets along with quizzes for each section to enhance learning.
The course learning objectives include exchanging greetings, identifying personal documents, talking about family, job, or studies, using numbers, discussing the weather, ordering meals, etc.
The venue for the French course is online, with a duration of 6 weeks, 2 hours per lesson twice per day, on every Saturday.
The intake for the French course is on 31 May 2021, with registration required by 17 May 2021 and payment from 18 to 29 May 2021.
The fees for the French course are RM695.00, inclusive of all teaching materials and a certificate of completion provided in an online format via email/MS Teams.
For inquiries and registration for the French course, you can contact Jean-Christophe Graffe at Jean-Christophe.Graffe@nottingham.edu.my.
The course materials for the French class include PDF files of textbooks and exercises, with visual materials also provided for students.

The BA (Hons) in International Communication Studies with English Language and Literature at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a full-time program lasting 3 years, with the next intake scheduled for September 2025.
The course fees for Malaysian students are RM42,000 per year, while international students are charged RM50,000 per year.
The program integrates global media studies, linguistics, creative writing, and literature, preparing students for careers in media, translation, education, and international relations.
Students can specialize in a global language such as French, Japanese, Mandarin, Spanish, German, or Korean to enhance their communication skills in multilingual contexts.
The curriculum emphasizes practical application alongside academic rigor to equip graduates for various career paths with creativity and confidence.

The course includes modules such as Beginners and Intermediate language studies, Cultural Studies, Introduction to Linguistics, Media and Communications Theory, Studying Literature, and optional modules like Community Interpreting, Cultural Politics, and Introduction to Translation.

Entry requirements include A Level qualifications with specific grades, IB Diploma with 24 points overall, STPM with BC+C+, UEC with specific grades, or equivalent qualifications from various educational systems.
English language proficiency requirements include specific scores in tests like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCSE, and others, with varying minimum score criteria.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia campus is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, providing a green jungle backdrop with facilities such as schools, sports center, library, and student accommodation.
Career opportunities for graduates of this program include roles like Content Writer, Digital Executive, Public Relations Associate, Social Media Manager, and Copywriter.

The study used functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging to investigate the brain areas involved in illusory sensations of touch.
The experiences were mediated by decision-making areas in the medial parietal and medial prefrontal cortex, rather than in primary sensory areas.
The study provides evidence for a top-down influence on somatic misperception.
Authors: Lloyd DM, McKenzie KJ, Brown R & Poliakoff, E. (2011)
Journal: Neuropsychologia, 49: 3430-3438.
The work was published on 28th October 2011.

Malaysian students for the April 2025 intake of the Foundation Programme can register provisionally using their official SPM forecast grades.
Malaysian students who will get their SPM results in 2025 and can provide the official forecast grades from schools are eligible to apply.
The fees for the Nottingham Foundation Programme for Malaysians are RM35,000 for the entire 2-semester programme.
If successful, applicants for the April 2025 intake will receive a conditional offer based on the actual SPM grades to provisionally register with the University.
Registration for the September 2025 intake is based on submitting actual SPM grades before registration.
Accepted applicants must pay a non-refundable course deposit of RM1,000 and read the Welcome to the University of Nottingham Malaysia document.
Students who register provisionally with forecast grades must sign an agreement of understanding and meet minimum requirements once actual SPM results are out.
Actual SPM grades need to be submitted within a week of release, and decisions post-results are based on a thorough review.
High Achievers’ Scholarships (HAS) at University of Nottingham Malaysia are awarded based on actual SPM results.
Refunds for fees due to not meeting entry requirements are subject to a percentage refund policy based on the number of days from the class start date.
Students can contact study@nottingham.edu.my for enquiries if they have not yet applied.
For those who have already applied, enquiries can be directed to admissions@nottingham.edu.my.

In addition to the UK higher education academic standards and quality, University of Nottingham Malaysia will adhere to the MQA Standards related to candidate selection.
HEP’s are responsible for creating and administering policy and processes pertaining to credit transfer which MQA will evaluate during programme accreditation.
HEPs must evaluate the suitability of an applicant for a programme through appropriate assessments.
HEPs must establish the Malaysian CGPA equivalency based on the final average, grades or scores provided in the academic transcripts.
You must read the Checklist for applications before applying.
You must upload copies of your certificate and transcripts, as well as any other supporting documents. We will not be able to assess your application without them.

If, for any reason, the final grades or average are not available in transcripts, you will be asked to provide additional information. In most cases, you will be asked to contact your previous institutions to obtain the information needed.

For applicants who do not meet this requirement, the following may be applicable to you: - Must have relevant working experience. - You will be asked to submit additional documents. See Checklist for applications document. - Schools to conduct rigorous assessments and if deemed necessary, applicants may also be required to attend an interview.

During the visa application process, Education Malaysia Global Services (EMGS) will also request additional documents from international students. Having an offer letter does not guarantee your visa application will be successful. You must meet all the requirements of a Student visa application.

All international students will have the option of applying for their Visa Approval Letters (VAL) through two methods: Option A - Applying via the UNM Visa Office, Option B - Applying directly to EMGS.

International students will not be required to do a pre-arrival medical examination but must fill up and submit the 'HEALTH DECLARATION FORM' for their VAL application.

All international students who defer, withdraw, terminate, and complete studies are required to shorten/cancel their present student pass before leaving the country; failure to comply will result in their passport being blacklisted by the Immigration Department.
All new international students are advised to submit their student pass application early to avoid delays as the process can take up to three months.
Visa documents submission deadlines vary depending on the intake months for different programs, with specific dates stated for each intake.
The visa fee for students applying through EMGS includes processing fees for VAL and Student Pass, i-Kad fee, medical insurance for one year, post-medical check-up, and SST.
Visa fees are non-refundable once the VAL application has been submitted; students are advised to not book their flight until their VAL has been approved.

After the VAL is approved by Immigration, students are required to wait for the VAL to be sent to them, check requirements for Single Entry Visa (SEV) based on their nationality, and follow specific procedures for SEV application and entry into Malaysia.

Upon arrival in Malaysia, students are required to present their passport, VAL/SEV to Immigration, report to the International Student Support and Visa Office, and follow the post-medical check-up process before receiving the Student Pass endorsement sticker.

If you miss some form of assessment or believe an assessment was affected by extenuating circumstances then you must complete an Extenuating Circumstances Form and upload via MyNottingham as soon as possible and no later than 7 days after having missed the assessment.
All forms must be accompanied by relevant documentary evidence.

If you miss an examination, you should contact the School Examinations Office at the earliest possible opportunity and you will subsequently need to fill in an extenuating circumstances form which is found within the relevant section of the quality manual.

Evidence needed for the extenuating circumstances form could be a medical certificate, a letter from an appropriate medical professional, a letter from University Wellbeing Services, or a written statement about a crime supported by written evidence from the police.
Extenuating Circumstances Policy and Procedures information is available.
Completing the extenuating circumstances form is required.

The International Conference on Extremism and Radicalisation was organized by the University of Nottingham Malaysia’s (UNM) School of Politics, History, and International Relations (PHIR) and involved experts from Malaysia and Southeast Asia.
The conference focused on '(Re)Assessing the Threat of Violent Extremism and Radicalisation' in Malaysia and Southeast Asia.
The conference discussed the impact of unbiased language in shaping public perception, influencing policy, and impacting extremism and radicalisation.

Farlina Said, a Senior Analyst from the Institute of International Strategic and International Studies (ISIS) Malaysia, explained the different levels of terrorism starting from radicalisation to extremism and finally terrorism.
Dr Athanasios (Thanos) Gkoutzioulis facilitated discussions at the conference to bridge the gap in understanding around extremism and radicalisation.
Journalist and filmmaker Zan Azlee highlighted the importance of fostering civil disagreement in media messaging.
Religion was discussed as a 'vehicle' for individuals to propagate and justify extremist beliefs by misusing and manipulating religious doctrines, texts, or symbols.
The conference concluded with a call to advocate unbiased language and comprehensive understanding in discussions of extremism and radicalisation.

UNM Provost and CEO Professor Graham Kendall and Director of Academic Services Patrick Joseph will officially open the Tri Campus Games 2019.
The opening ceremony is expected to kick off with a gamelan performance by Malaysian school children from SMK Engku Hussian.

"Our Tri-Campus Games, and our other tri-campus initiatives, create an excellent platform for our students to collaborate and work with the best talents from our other campuses in the UK and China. As a global university, with a footprint in three countries and two continents, we are able to hold these type of events, which are not possible in the majority of other institutions. These events build a competitive spirit within the teams, as well as provide mobility opportunities for students, which provides a truly global experience during their time at the University of Nottingham Malaysia," said Professor Kendall.

Each year the Tri Campus Games is a week-long festival of sporting activities and is a unique event within higher education, taking place at one of the University's international campuses each year involving nearly 200 student athletes from over 20 different nations.
Underpinned by the ethos 'Friendship Through Sport', the Games offer a fantastic opportunity for sporting and educational exchange in the friendly spirit of competition.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a Train-the-Trainer Program for an Advanced Technical Course on Large Language Model (LLM) from 27th September to 3rd October 2024.
Dr. Simon Lau participated in the Train-the-Trainer Program co-organized by the Taiwan AI Academy and AI Nusantara from 27th September to 3rd October 2024 at Academia Sinica, Nangang, Taipei.
There were 30 delegates from various academic institutions and companies in Malaysia participating in the program.

The program began with the 7th Annual AI for All Trades and Professions Conference organized by the Taiwan AI Academy, where AI experts from multinationals and Taiwan institutions shared insights into AI development and applications.

The training program focuses on artificial intelligence, particularly Large Language Models (LLM) and Lang Chain methodologies, covering foundational concepts, data processing, fine-tuning methods, and project discussions.
The program aims to equip attendees with practical skills and insights into the evolving landscape of LLM technologies.
The program was posted on 21st October 2024.

Going Viral is a podcast series that was developed by Adesh Chopra, Maryam Ahmad Zambri, Rebekah Cheng and Zoe Liow, students from the School of Media, Language and Culture at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM).
The podcast series brings to light the perspectives of university students in regard to the COVID-19 pandemic whilst exploring their crises and conflicts.
The topics covered in the podcast include safety, classes, relationships, graduation, life after graduation, and even racism.
The response to the podcast series has been positive with the common consensus being that the series is relevant and relatable.
Professor Graham Kendall, CEO and Provost of UNM, mentioned that the podcast provides an excellent platform for students to discuss the issues they are facing during the pandemic.

The Computer Science MPhil/PhD program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers specializations in areas such as image processing and computer vision, artificial intelligence and applications, human-computer interaction and ubiquitous computing, software engineering and E-Learning.

The Computer Science MPhil/PhD program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia has intake sessions in February, April, June, and September.

The entry requirements for the Computer Science MPhil/PhD program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia include a master's degree with a distinction or merit grade, plus an upper second-class honors degree or a first-class honors degree in computer science or a relevant area.
English language requirements for the program include minimum scores in IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, or MUET exams.
The Malaysian fee for the Computer Science MPhil/PhD program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is RM50,000 per year, while the international fee is RM56,000 per year.

Dr Chai Ai Bao from the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering at UNMC received an Early Career Academic grant of £2,000 (RM10,463) from the Association of Commonwealth Universities (ACU).

The grant was launched in 2013 to assist young academic staff from ACU institutions to attend conferences in other commonwealth countries, with a maximum amount of £2,000 per grant covering travel, visa costs, conference fees, accommodation, and subsistence.
In 2016, there were 30 grants available, and Dr Chai was selected from some 220 applications from ACU institutions, which has over 500 member institutions in 37 countries across the Commonwealth.
Dr Chai will use the grant to participate in the 7th International Conference on Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (ICMAE) from 18 to 22 July 2016 in London, United Kingdom.
Dr Chai obtained her PhD in the field of mechanical aspect of polymer from the University of Malaya in Kuala Lumpur and was appointed as an Assistant Professor in the Department of M3 in 2014.

The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a pre-university programme designed to prepare students for undergraduate study at the University of Nottingham Malaysia. The programme features tailored pathways and flexible module options to ensure a seamless transition to your chosen degree.
The programme fee for Malaysian students is RM35,000 and for international students is RM38,000.

English language requirements for Nottingham's Foundation Programme vary depending on the specific undergraduate program. For example, Master of Pharmacy and Bachelor of Pharmacy programs have specific subject requirements such as Biology, Chemistry, Physics, and Mathematics or Additional Mathematics.
Applicants must meet MQA prerequisites at SPM, GCSE, IGCSE, High School Diploma, or equivalent levels in addition to specific requirements for progression to certain undergraduate programs.
Candidates must achieve a minimum of 5 Credits in SPM, O-Level, or equivalent for entry into the Nottingham's Foundation Programme, with specific subject requirements for certain programs.

In addition to academic requirements, English language proficiency is essential for admission. IELTS, TOEFL, and PTE (Academic) results must be less than two years old, with specific score requirements for each test. MUET results are valid for five years.

The Nottingham's Foundation Programme offers pathways to undergraduate degrees in Science, Engineering, Arts, Social Sciences, Business, Economics, and more. Students must complete a certain number of core and optional modules based on their chosen pathway.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme duration is one year with intakes in April and September each year. It consists of two semesters.
Malaysian students pay RM35,000 and international students pay RM38,000 for the Nottingham's Foundation Programme.
Scholarships are available for the Nottingham's Foundation Programme, offering up to 25% tuition fee reduction for eligible students based on their academic performance.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is not offered on a part-time basis, only full-time.
International students are welcome to apply for the Nottingham's Foundation Programme.

Team Shield & Regeneration comprising University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) students Ler Jie Sze (Finance Accounting & Management), Christopher Khoo Jinn Wei (Mechanical Engineering) and Cheong Zhao Shen (Mechanical Engineering) emerged as the national champions in the 2021 L’Oreal Brandstorm Malaysia competition

Another group of UNM students - Team Gamine comprising Poa Yee Shuang (Finance, Accounting & Management), Jacyln Hu Xin Yiu (Economics) and Lua Yun Xin (Economics and International Economics) clinched the runner-up position

L’Oreal Brandstorm is an annual international innovation competition that takes place in over 60 countries and provides a platform to enhance students’ entrepreneurial and creativity skills, in addition to offering participants the opportunity to come up with innovations for the beauty industry
The business case to be solved differs each year and participants in the 2021 edition were challenged to ‘invent the beauty shopping experience through entertainment’
Team Shield & Regeneration will represent Malaysia in the Worldwide Finals which is scheduled to take place at the end of June 2021

When we first started the competition, we went in not expecting to make it to where we did. Every single round was challenging, but each time, our idea got better and more solid thanks to the mentors that guided us along the way,
Their idea was to push skincare for males through gaming. As gaming is a booming industry, they believed that skincare could grow alongside it

Although the idea was very different from conventional strategies in skincare marketing, they believed that the uniqueness and innovation involved in their idea would be the differentiating factor and they planned to use that to their advantage

We would strongly recommend anyone that is considering participating in this competition to just go for it! There's truly no limit to the soft and critical skills that can be picked up along the way, and we are truly honoured to be a part of this

Professor Sam Kingman, Interim Provost of UNM, stated: 'We’re incredibly proud of both teams for their achievements at the L’Oreal Brandstorm Malaysia competition. It’s good to see that our students are putting their best foot forward even in these difficult times'
In rankings recently published by The Economist, Nottingham University Business School has been placed in the top 100 – against tough competition from the USA, Europe, Asia, and Australia.
The School appears on the list with some of the world’s most prestigious institutions, including Dartmouth College, Harvard, Stanford, and INSEAD business schools.

The Economist 2011 Top 100 MBA ranking rates business schools against each other in terms of opening new career opportunities and/or furthering the current career of graduates, personal development, increasing salary, and offering the potential to network.

Professor Martin Binks, Dean of Nottingham University Business School, commented on the MBA program's quality and flexibility, including specialist MBAs in Finance, Entrepreneurship, and Corporate Social Responsibility.
Majority of our MBA graduates are in key management positions in leading organizations in Malaysia as well as in other countries.

The Economist ranking is distinctive for being the most 'student-centric' of all the MBA rankings because it claims to measure the way business schools meet the demands that students have of an MBA program.
Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia offers Master of Business Administration, Master of Business Administration - Finance, and Master of Business Administration – Entrepreneurship.

The MA in Teaching of English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) at University of Nottingham Malaysia is a full-time program lasting 1-2 years or part-time lasting 2-4 years starting in September 2025.
The Malaysian fee for the MA in TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia is RM58,000 per program, and the international fee is RM60,000 per program.

The MA TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia is designed to enhance students' critical understanding of the latest developments in TESOL theory and practice through blending theory and practice.

The MA TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia does not confer Qualified Teacher Status (QTS), but it provides valuable expertise for teaching roles in global contexts and supports further professional and academic growth.
The MA TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a comprehensive curriculum covering critical areas like language teaching methodology, curriculum design, and language assessment.
Entry requirements for the MA TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia include a relevant second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent.
English language requirements for the MA TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia include IELTS 6.5, TOEFL 90, PTE 71, and MUET Band 4.5.
The 15,000-word dissertation is a requirement for the MA TESOL program at University of Nottingham Malaysia and should be related to one of the selected modules on an approved topic.

Career opportunities for MA TESOL graduates from University of Nottingham Malaysia include TESOL Specialist, Curriculum Developer, Language Assessment Specialist, Teacher Trainer, and Educational Consultant.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers an annual economics essay competition open to all pre-university and high school students in Malaysia.
The essay competition topic for this year was 'Why is climate change an issue in Malaysia? What climate change mitigation and adaptation measures would you suggest to the government? Discuss.'
The School of Economics at the University of Nottingham Malaysia organized the essay competition in collaboration with the World Bank Group Inclusive Growth and Sustainable Finance Hub in Malaysia.

The prize-giving ceremony for the economics essay competition was attended by World Bank Country Manager for Malaysia Dr Yasuhiko Matsuda, UNM Dean of Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences Dr Jason Pandya-Wood, and UNM Head of School of Economics Dr Teo Wing Leong.
Other winners of the economics essay competition included students from Sunway International School, Methodist College Kuala Lumpur, Asia Pacific School, and Chung Hua Middle School No.1 in Kuching.
The School of Economics at the University of Nottingham Malaysia has been organizing the economics essay competition since 2014 and has partnered with the World Bank for the past two years.

At University of Nottingham Malaysia, we aim to celebrate the numerous outstanding accomplishments of our graduates, especially those who have made significant contributions to their professions and communities, as well as demonstrated leadership and excellence in their respective fields and industries.

The Nottingham Alumni Awards presents you with an opportunity to nominate yourself or other deserving alumni in five different categories, highlighting your achievements and recognising how far you have progressed in your career after graduation.
The award ceremony for Nottingham Alumni Awards 2024 will be held on December 6, 2024, from 7pm to 9pm at Pullman KLCC Hotel, with registration starting at 6.30pm and a business casual dress code.

Alumni who are active in initiating and contributing to business opportunities, innovative and creative in creating new ideas with the potential for growth, are eligible for the Business and Entrepreneurial Award.
Alumni who have carved a career in the arts, cultural, and creative industry and demonstrated artistic ingenuity, influence, and creativity, are eligible for the Arts, Cultural and Creativity Award.

Alumni who have distinguished themselves through career achievements in the world of science, environmental, and sustainability, and can demonstrate impact in their profession or beyond, are eligible for the Environmental and Sustainability Award.

Alumni who have made exceptional contributions to creating positive social change, improving lives, and have a positive impact regionally, nationally, or internationally, through community service work, philanthropy, or volunteering, are eligible for the Community Service Award.

University of Nottingham Malaysia offers employment opportunities that require individuals to submit their resume and personal data for potential employment consideration.

The Personal Data Protection Act ensures that personal data collected from potential employees is handled according to the law, and applicants must consent to the processing of their personal information along with sensitive data.

The Company, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus Sdn Bhd, processes personal data of potential employees, including information like name, identification number, contact details, education, skills, etc., for purposes related to employment.
Sensitive personal data such as race, religion, health, political opinion, and criminal records may also be collected and processed by the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Personal data collected may be used for job application assessment, administrative purposes, compliance with statutory laws, corporate governance, and other employment-related activities.

Personal data is usually obtained directly from the applicant through sources like resumes, application forms, and certificates. In some cases, data may be obtained from external sources or third parties for verification purposes.
Applicants have the right to access and request corrections to their personal data by submitting a request form to the Human Resource Department at University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus Sdn Bhd.

Personal data may be disclosed to third parties like service providers, statutory bodies, and professional advisors for purposes related to employment, reference checks, and other necessary activities.

Applicants have the right to limit the processing of their personal data and can request to stop such processing by contacting the Human Resource Department at University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

Providing mandatory information is necessary for employment consideration, and failure to provide such information may result in the inability to offer employment with University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus reserves the right to review and amend its data protection policies, communicating any changes to applicants as necessary.

The Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Biomedical Science Programme at University of Nottingham Malaysia has been awarded accreditation by the Institute of Biomedical Science (IBMS), United Kingdom.

The Division of Biomedical Science, School of Pharmacy at University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a UK-quality education locally, making it the only UK university offering this programme in Malaysia.

With IBMS accreditation, graduates from University of Nottingham Malaysia can apply for registration as biomedical scientists with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) in the UK after completing the IBMS Certificate of Competence training portfolio.

IBMS accreditation allows the institution to become a member of the Heads of University Centres of Biomedical Science (HUCBMS) and offers benefits such as international recognition, peer review, curriculum development, graduate employability, and networking opportunities.

Professor Ting Kang Nee, Head of the School of Pharmacy, expressed excitement about the IBMS accreditation and emphasized the institution's commitment to academic rigor, quality, and continuous improvement in curriculum.
The announcement about the Biomedical Science Programme achieving IBMS accreditation was made on July 31st, 2024.

Two final year students at The University of Nottingham are set to celebrate the end of their exams by taking on an incredible challenge in support of charity Water.
Ahmed Mashadani and Andreas Aristidou will be cycling 3,000 miles to deliver a bottle of water from University Park Campus, Nottingham to Laayoune, in Western Sahara.
The pair hope that the symbolic gesture will raise awareness of drought and the difficulty of finding clean and accessible water without the help of charities like Water.
Ahmed Mashadani spent the summer of 2012 driving from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus near Kuala Lumpur to Nottingham to raise money for the Red Cross, passing through 21 countries.
To prepare for the challenge ahead, Ahmed and Andreas began training for their ride six months ago using bikes in the gym.
Wendy Chapple, Associate Professor at Nottingham University Business School, is Ahmed’s personal tutor and believes in his determination to complete the goal of the charity ride.

Two alumni wins the YOUth of Tomorrow writing competition - The University of Nottingham - Malaysia Campus

Ashley Marilynne Wong (BA (Hons) English with Creative Writing, 2018) won The YOUth of Tomorrow writing competition under the poem category with her piece titled Six Ways to Expose Your Daughter to Domestic Abuse while and Shafiqah Alliah Razman (BA (Hons) English Language and Literature, 2021) won the short story category with her piece titled Diari Sepi Seorang Mudi. Both winners graduated from the School of English.

The Empower’s The YOUth of Tomorrow writing competition aimed at providing a platform for writers to express the right of freedom. The competition was held from 16 August to 1 September 2021 and the announcement of the winners was made online on 15 September 2021.
The winners were awarded a cash prize of RM400 and an e-certificate. Ashley’s poem and Shafiqah’s short story are available on the Empower’s new feminist website.

In 2020, Shafiqah’s creative non-fiction “Fear, Let Me Be Free” had the honour of being in the Top 20 of The Freedom to Express Myself without Fear - another essay competition organised by Empower Malaysia. It was a competition for aspiring writers aged 13 to 23 with the theme of The Freedom to Express Myself without Fear. That piece revolved around Shafiqah’s experience in overcoming age-old stereotypes and how she slowly conquered the fear of expressing herself.

Here are some inspiring words from Ashley, “Dare to write – and by extension speak – your heart out. Be ambitious, true to yourself and limitless,”. Shafiqah says, “Have courage and be kind, and don’t limit yourself. Have faith, believe in yourself and give yourself chances. Life has ways of surprising you, so we should keep exploring, discovering and expressing! Don’t worry; you will find your footing.”

A student at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) was part of the winning team in the 5th Proctor & Gamble (P&G) ASEAN Business Challenge 2013.
The competition aimed at giving students the opportunity to learn about and experience P&G's brand development, marketing strategy, and staff development.
Participants had the chance to propose a marketing plan for a P&G brand and execute those ideas in the real world to assess business results.
The competition was held in two stages: a national level selection and the P&G ASEAN finals in Singapore.
Team Entrée from Malaysia, represented by Tan Jing Yang from UNMC, won the title of overall winner for the Asean category.
The team's case study focused on increasing revenue for Downy, a P&G brand.
Team Entrée was awarded with a MacBook Air each and an all-expense paid trip to Singapore for winning the competition.
UNMC student Tan Jing Yang was part of Team Entrée, which is the first Malaysian team to win the Asean Business Challenge.

A team of Business School students from the University of Nottingham Malaysia emerged as champions of the P&G CEO Challenge 2020 Malaysia, which was held in 2 December 2019.

The Nottingham team was one of eight teams that were shortlisted for the national finals based on scores achieved in an online case study that attracted entries from student teams across universities nationwide.

At the national finals, the Top Eight teams spent six to eight hours a day over two days analysing and solving a business strategy case study, vying for the opportunity to compete with teams from the Asia-Pacific region in the Regional Finals to be held in Singapore in March 2020.
Team Nottingham consisted of third-year Business Economics and Finance students Tan Sze Khan and Dominic Yeong Yew Win, and third-year Finance Accounting and Management student Anson Lee Kar Lok.

September 2015 marks the 15th anniversary of The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC), as well as its 10th anniversary since moving to the campus in Semenyih.

As the first British university to have a full-fledged international campus, The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) celebrates its 15th anniversary this year in a land that is truly Asia.

Enriching Lives with Global Education is the theme to commemorate this milestone; which epitomises the university's commitment in providing an international education experience, while inspiring our students and staff to improve the academic and professional communities they belong to worldwide.

So we invite you to join us in our yearlong celebration, share the pride, and as we move forward in this spirit, we hope that you too will reflect on your journey with UNMC and revel in the success that you are part of.
As part of the 15th-anniversary celebration, we had a campaign in July where we welcomed questions from anyone for our Provost Christine.

The inaugural Nottingham Charity Run organized by students at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) in aid of Hospis Malaysia raised RM18,000 and attracted 805 participants.
Sammy Kiprono won the first prize for the 10km recording a time of 35 minutes. Other winners were Chan Pick Fun for the 10km women’s category and Sze Yung Hui for the 5 km family run.

The UN Refugee Agency Malaysia offers comprehensive internship opportunities for students studying or working in, or intending to work in the field of refugee protection and assistance, providing practical and theoretical experience in refugee protection, advocacy, international law, field operations, and community work.

Required qualifications for the internship include completion of a first degree (Bachelors or equivalent), fluency in English (additional language knowledge is advantageous), and experience in refugee protection work is desirable but not mandatory.
The duration of the internship with UNHCR Malaysia is a minimum of three months for applicants studying in non-Malaysian universities or colleges and two months for applicants studying in Malaysia.

Interns with the UNHCR Malaysia are not financially or materially compensated, and are responsible for arranging their living accommodations, though assistance may be provided by the Intern Coordinator and other interns.
UNHCR Malaysia accepts internship applications throughout the year, and internships can start at any time during the year.
To apply, applicants are required to fill out a form and send it to UNHCR along with a statement of intent and an updated CV.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers MPhil and PhD programs in Education.
The duration for MPhil is 1-2 years for full-time students and 2-4 years for part-time. The duration for PhD is 3-4 years for full-time students and 6-8 years for part-time.
Start dates for the programs are in February, April, June, and September 2025.
The Malaysian fee for the programs is RM50,000 per year, and the international fee is RM56,000 per year.
All doctoral candidates at the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus are based in Malaysia.
MPhil students must submit a thesis of up to 60,000 words, while PhD students must submit a thesis of a maximum of 100,000 words.
English language requirements for admission include IELTS (Academic) 7.0, TOEFL (iBT) 100, PTE (Academic) 76, and MUET Band 5.
Malaysian students pay RM50,000 per year, while international students pay RM56,000 per year for the programs.

The School of Media, Languages, and Cultures at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is seeking suitably qualified candidates for the Part-time University Teacher Register for language programs.
The hourly rate for part-time language lecturers at the University of Nottingham Malaysia ranges between RM120.00 and RM150.00 depending on qualification and experience.

Key responsibilities include teaching core languages like Spanish, French, and Korean, preparing class materials and exams, providing feedback on student work, grading assessments, and administrative duties.

Applicants must have a degree in language teaching or equivalent qualification, native or near-native command of a language (Spanish, French, Korean), relevant teaching experience, and be proficient in online teaching tools.
Non-Malaysian applicants must have a valid work permit or residence pass and be willing to travel to the Semenyih campus.
Applications for the Part-time University Teacher Register are accepted on a rolling basis, with hiring typically occurring in July/August and December/January.
Applications should include a CV, details of work permit/visa, and teaching permit (if any), as well as referee contact details.

For inquiries and applications, contact Ms Seungyeon LEE at Seungyeon.Lee@nottingham.edu.my, cc JOBS FASS at jobs.fass@nottingham.edu.my with the subject line “Application for University Teacher (Language) Register”.
Details of applicants will be kept on file for 24 months unless otherwise requested.

HSK (Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi) is an international standardised exam that tests and rates Chinese language proficiency.
HSK consists of six levels: HSK (level 1) to HSK (level 6), assessing different language skills.
HSK (level 1) assesses basic language skills while HSK (level 6) is the highest level for comprehensive understanding and expression in Chinese.
HSKK (HSK Speaking Test) assesses oral Chinese abilities and has three levels: Primary, Intermediate, and Advanced.
Test takers for HSK 3 and above are required to take both HSK and HSK Oral Test starting from January 2023.
The HSK Exam Malaysia in 2025 will be held on 22 June 2025, with a registration deadline on 23 May 2025.
The HSK exam serves as a reference for educational institutions, employers, and language learners to evaluate proficiency and make decisions.
The test fees for HSK/HSKK range from RM120 to RM460, including 8% SST.
Registration for the HSK exam requires submission of necessary materials and payment through various methods such as credit card, e-pay, bank transfer, or cheque.
For bank transfers or direct bank-in, the transaction reference should indicate 'Chinese proficiency test HSK 2025'.
For payment by crossed cheque or bank draft, the back of the cheque should indicate 'Chinese proficiency test HSK 2025' and the name of the remitter.

The Universitas 21/partner university exchange is a competitive programme that offers undergraduate students the opportunity to study at a partner university for one semester or one academic year as part of their Nottingham degree.
To be eligible to apply to the programme, students must have completed at least one year of their degree study (Undergraduate - UG) at the UNM.

To be eligible to apply to the programme, students have to obtain a passing mark of a minimum of 60% in order to progress onto the exchange scheme. No students taking resits are permitted to progress onto the exchange scheme.
To be eligible to apply to the programme, students must be studying for an undergraduate degree programme which is also offered at the host university.

Exchange Quota: There are limited quotas for Engineering, Business School & selected schools in Faculty of Science. Quota will be determined by the host campus and subject to change on a yearly basis.

Partner University factsheets/websites include information on Concordia University, Canada; Sciences-Po De Toulouse, France; Tec De Monterrey, Mexico; University of Birmingham, UK; University of Queensland, Australia; University of Glasgow, UK; Texas A&M University, Texas, USA; The University of Groningen, The Netherlands; Aarhus University, Denmark; University of Strasbourg, France; Shiga University, Japan; Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Yonsei University, Seoul, South Korea.

The credit gained while studying abroad will count towards your Nottingham degree. Each school participating in the U21/University-Wide Programme has a coordinator responsible for approving your academic study while abroad and for providing advice and support on all academic matters.

The Knowledge Without Borders Network (KWBN) presents its inaugural lecture, 'The Future of Internationalisation: Malaysian Perspectives' at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
KWBN is an international collaboration between the academic community, students, and professionals in the field of internationalisation of higher education.
KWBN offers programs and activities including seminars, conferences, networking, exchange programs, fellowships, secondment opportunities, and establishing a virtual resource center.
The inaugural lecture on 'The Future of Internationalisation: Malaysian Perspectives' will be delivered by Dr. Rozilini M Fernandez-Chung on June 19, 2012.

Dr. Fernandez-Chung will explore the historical context of internationalisation in Malaysia and assess the challenges in responding to changing local and global conditions of international higher education.

The School of Languages at UNM offers students the opportunity to enhance their degree by integrating a language module into their studies.
Open to students from all disciplines, our language courses provide a structured and engaging way to develop practical communication skills.
Our language modules begin from Stage 1 (Beginner) to Stage 3 (Upper Intermediate).
New students will undergo a placement assessment upon arrival to ensure they start at the appropriate level.
Offered modules: French, German, Japanese, Korean, Mandarin, Spanish.
Our modules focus on speaking, listening, reading, and writing, with 3–5 hours of weekly contact.
Learning is enhanced through digital tools such as Moodle, virtual classrooms, and the Language Resource Centre, supporting independent study and skill development.
Students also have the option to audit language modules for a modest fee, subject to availability.
The School of Languages is committed to providing high-quality language education that enhances both academic and professional success in today’s multicultural world.

The Biomedical Sciences degree at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a wide variety of specializations designed to maximize career options.
Biomedical Sciences graduates can pursue further education such as MSc or PhD and work in academia or the industrial sector.
Biomedical Sciences graduates can apply for graduate-entry into medical programs using the scientific knowledge and skills developed during the degree.

Biomedical Sciences graduates also acquire highly-transferable skills such as analytical thinking and critical reasoning that are applicable in non-scientific fields like IT, finance, management, and accountancy.
Soon Tat Lee is an Assistant Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee graduated with a BSc (Hons) in Speech Science from the National University of Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee pursued a PhD at the School of Psychology, University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Soon Tat Lee is a psycholinguist and speech-language therapist with a focus on bilingual language processing.
Soon Tat Lee develops language tests that assess specific language constructs in understudied language pairs such as Malay-English and Mandarin-English.

Soon Tat Lee's publications include 'LexMAL: A quick and reliable lexical test for Malay speakers', 'Translation norms for Malay and English words', and 'Assessing Children’s Native Language in Mandarin Using the Adapted New Reynell Developmental Language Scales-Mandarin (NRDLS-M)'.

The Healthier Lives cluster consists of six subgroups: Nutrition and Clinical Health, Precision Medicine and Drug Discovery, Disease Epidemiology and Prediction, Health Education, Prevention and Outreach, Mental Wellbeing, and Emerging Health Technology led by various departments within the university.
One of the projects in the Healthier Lives cluster involves developing biomarkers to monitor the treatment effect on breast cancer patients, funded by the National Cancer Council Malaysia.

Another project focuses on investigating the cellular uptake, metabolism, and bioavailability of fat-soluble vitamins in overweight and obese individuals to develop a personalized dosing regimen for effective vitamin supplementation.

Todd Landman, Professor of Political Science and Pro-Vice-Chancellor for the Faculty of Social Sciences at The University of Nottingham in the UK hosted a networking session on human rights on 6 October at the University of Nottingham Kuala Lumpur Teaching Centre.
The event featured a presentation of Professor Landman’s new book, The Rights Track: Sound Evidence on Human Rights and Modern Slavery, published by Anthem Press.

The event also featured University of Nottingham Malaysia Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences Dr Jason Pandya-Wood and award-winning filmmaker and leader of Beyond Borders Malaysia, Mahi Ramakrishnan.

Professor Landman has worked in the field of human rights for over 25 years. He is currently working on modern slavery measurement, antislavery governance, and the relationship between human rights and modern slavery, among other topics.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is proud to announce the return of the prestigious UNAM-UNM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Award Essay Competition in 2025!
The competition is open to all students aged 17 to 23 years of age (as of 31 December 2024) in Malaysia.
Submission must be by a single author.
Topic: Meaningful Education for a Nation's Progress, Innovation and Inclusiveness.

Criteria: The submission should be between 1,500 to 2,000 words; Must be an original piece of work; Demonstrates a good understanding of the issues of education; Well-written and inspiring with a persuasive call to action on the issues; Demonstrates an understanding of the obstacles to those actions; Provides thoughtful suggestions; and May want to make references to the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the essay.
The following prizes will be awarded: First prize: RM 2,000.00; Second prize: RM1,500.00; Third prize: RM1,000.00.
The winning submissions will be selected by a panel of judges from the University of Nottingham and the United Nations Association of Malaysia.
Only one (1) entry per student is permitted.
Entries by previous winners of the competition will not be considered.

Entries to the competition must be unique (i.e. not published elsewhere or submitted to other essay competition) and original in content. Entries found to contain plagiarism will be disqualified. A bibliography acknowledging references to existing work is required.
The deadline for submission is 02 April 2025, Wednesday.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with CelcomDigi Berhad to develop AI-driven technologies for students and employees and co-develop Industrial XR / Metaverse solutions.
The partnership between UNM and CelcomDigi focuses on AI, 5G networks, psychology in technology, Industrial XR / Metaverse, and other areas of common interest.
The MoU includes collaborative efforts for developing AI and Industrial XR / Metaverse solutions that benefit students and employees at both institutions.
UNM students will have opportunities to participate in internship and work placement programs at CelcomDigi through the collaboration.
CelcomDigi will be a one-stop-center for UNM's connectivity solutions and managed service partner for 4G/5G/Direct Internet Access, WiFi, and SDWAN.
The collaboration aims to provide reskilling and upskilling opportunities for CelcomDigi employees through micro-credential courses or part-time postgraduate degree programs.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Interim Provost stressed the importance of developing future digital talents through collaborations like this one with CelcomDigi.
Parties involved will engage in thought leadership activities discussing the importance of bridging the gap between academia and workplace, and accelerating the adoption of AI technologies.
