Dr. Gianfranco Scribano is an Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Dr. Scribano obtained his M.Sc. in Aerospace Engineering in 1999 and then he received his Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering in 2004 both at Politecnico di Milano, Italy.

Dr. Scribano's expertise is on combustion emission reduction and fluid-mechanics. He uses experimental techniques such as PIV (Particle Image Velocimetry), PDI (Phase Doppler Interferometry) in both reactive and non-reactive flows.
Dr. Scribano teaches courses such as Thermofluids 2, Thermofluids 3, and Computational Fluid Dynamics.
Dr. Scribano has published in international journals and conferences and is an inventor of 6 patent applications for combustion devices and aerosol generators.
Ng Zheng Yu, a final year mechanical engineering student from the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) won the IMM-IOM3 Materials Lecture Competition (MLC) 2017 on 16 May 2017.
The Materials Lecture Competition is jointly organised by the Institute of Materials, Malaysia (IMM) and the Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining (IOM3).

Zheng Yu presented a 16-minute lecture, titled 'Graphene Based Magnetic Nanocomposites for Dye Removal Application,' which used his University’s final year project topic as the main foundation of the presentation.
Zheng won a cash prize of RM3,000 and a trophy as the winner of this competition.
UNMC Associate Professor Ing Kong, Zheng Yu's final year project supervisor, said: 'Zheng Yu is an outstanding, highly reliable and motivated student.'

Zheng Yu's journey to the competition finals began on 1 March when he won the UNMC-M3 Materials Lecture Competition jointly organised by UNMC’s Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE) Student Chapter and Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering (M3) UNMC.
On 18 April 2017, Zheng Yu represented UNMC in the national semi-finals which was held at Asia Pacific University of Technology and Innovation (APU).
Zheng Yu was recognized for the excellent slides' structure, content flow, technical information, and presentation style.
Zheng Yu emerged as the MLC 2017 national champion after a round of debate and discussion among the competition judges.
Zheng Yu's success in the competition has qualified him to represent Malaysia in the Young Persons' World Lecture Competition (YPWLC) 2017 in Perth, Australia on 12 October 2017.
According to Zheng Yu: 'I had never imagined that this could happen, to be the national champion and to represent Malaysia in Perth.'

The project 'FoodPlus' focuses on understanding the physiology and shelf life of underutilized brassica crops.

The project aims to investigate the postharvest performance of underutilized brassica crops, including factors like shelf life, respiration rate, ethylene production, turgor loss, phytochemicals, and mineral composition.
The project will also assess consumers' attitudes towards new crops with reduced packaging and the potential of these crops in Malaysia and the UK.
The project will involve growing a subset of brassica crops at CFFRC and conducting postharvest testing, including interventions to extend shelf life.
The study will generate trait data for variation in nutritional content and explore consumer preferences towards new crops and novel packaging.
The project will be conducted partly at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus and partly at the University of Reading UK.
Level: PhD

The study involves assessing the effect of a carotenoid-rich fresh fruit drink on skin and perceived attractiveness.
The study involves comparing the effects of a smoothie made from carrots and Malaysian fruits with a control group receiving mineral water.
Carotenoids are natural lipophilic orange and yellow pigments found in fruits and vegetables.
The smoothies consumed by the students contained local Malaysian fruits such as Chiku, Kedondong, Pulasan, Dragon fruit, and Star fruit.
PhD student Tan Kok Wei recruited 80 volunteers for the study.

POCER 2022 is co-organised by the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) along with other institutions including Xiamen University Malaysia (XMUM), UCSI University, and the International Bioprocessing Society.
The 6th POCER 2022 expects participation from over 300 scientists, academicians, and industrial participants from more than 100 institutions and 30 countries.
The 6th POCER 2022 will lead to the establishment of the world's 1st Algae Biotechnology Consortium (ABC) with over 30 local and international institutions and industrial partners.
The ABC will focus on algae cultivation, algal biotechnology, algae storage and identification using artificial intelligence, and commercialisation of algae-based products in ASEAN.

The ABC was formed based on scientific and industrial engagement in algae upstream and downstream processing led by University of Nottingham Malaysia's Co-Director of Future Food Malaysia, Professor Ir Ts Dr Show Pau Loke.

A University of Nottingham graduate has been appointed as a Federal Court Judge. Datuk Prasad Abraham, 65, a Malaysian national, was former President of Nottingham Malaysian Graduates Association, following his law degree at The University of Nottingham, UK.
Since graduating in the early 1970s, Dr. Abraham continued his links with the University and School of Law and in 2008 was awarded an Honorary Doctorate for his outstanding contributions.
He was also conferred with The University of Nottingham Alumni Laureate Lifetime Achievement Award 2015.
Head of School of Law Professor Nigel White said: “Prasad Abraham's many friends in the School of Law are delighted to hear that he has been appointed to the Federal Court in Malaysia.

Dr. Abraham arrived at The University of Nottingham UK in 1971 to study Law. He contributed to the University’s alumni as President of The University of Nottingham Malaysian Graduates Association and continued to be an active member of the association.

In the judicial arena, he was appointed as a Judicial Commissioner of the Malaysian high court in 2009. A year later he was appointed as a High Court Judge and was subsequently appointed to the Appeals Court.

University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus CEO and Provost Professor Graham Kendall said: “Datuk Prasad holds one the highest positions in the judiciary of Malaysia. The University is immensely proud of his achievement. Other than the late HRH Sultan Azlan Shah, Datuk Prasad is the only other Malaysian alumni from the University of Nottingham to have reached this position.”

“Datuk Prasad is a close friend of the university, who has been, and remains supportive, of the University of Nottingham both in Malaysia and in the UK. We are very pleased to be able to offer our congratulations on this significant achievement,” Professor Kendall said.

The Master of Engineering with Honours in Mechatronic Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia integrates mechanical, electrical, electronic, and computer engineering to create innovative, intelligent systems. The program equips students with advanced skills in automation, robotics, and control engineering.

The program is recognized by the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) and the Engineering Accreditation Council (EAC) Malaysia, meeting the academic requirements for Chartered Engineer status.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia is ranked 100th globally for Engineering Technology (QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024).

The entrance requirements for the program include specific qualifications like A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior School Certificate Examination, Advance Placement, Diploma from Local Institutions, Foundation from Local Institutions, and others.

English language requirements for entry include qualifications like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language, GCE AS Level English Language, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, IB English A1 or A2, IB English B, and others.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a 1-year pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM's undergraduate degrees.
The Malaysian fee for the Mechatronic Engineering program is RM55,000 per year, and the international fee is RM65,000 per year.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a field study at PetroSains as part of the Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) module for Year 2 undergraduate students from the School of Computer Science.

Petrosains is a Science Discovery Centre located in the PETRONAS Twin Towers, Kuala Lumpur, occupying level 4 and 5 of both Tower 1 and Tower 2, covering a total exhibit area of more than 7,000 square meters.

Students on the field study learned to integrate theoretical perspectives of interaction design with practical experiences gained at Petrosains, focusing on user interactions with exhibits and learning to engage visitors with interactive technologies.

Dr Daniel Loy, PetroSains’s Director of Innovation and Learning, shared challenges in designing public interactive exhibits and presented students with 3 'problematic' exhibits to re-design for their coursework.

A 'pitching' session will be held in April, where PetroSains staff will visit the UNMC campus to give feedback on students' design ideas and award prizes to the winners of the UNMC-PetroSains Design Challenge.

NottinghamHub (Campus Solutions) is the university’s applicant and student administration system. Staff use this system to administer student records, students use it to complete registration, apply to study courses, enroll onto modules, update their details, and pay university fees.
Some of the university terminology has changed. A glossary of new terms can be found in the New Terminology document.

Students login to the NottinghamHub portal with their IT username and password, the same as used for University email and Moodle access. If login issues persist, students can raise a support ticket via the IT Service Desk.
NottinghamHub is accessible from any location on various devices but is best viewed on a desktop computer or laptop.
For staff and students, password changes can be made via the IT Accounts portal. Changing the password will also affect other systems and services like email and Moodle.
NottinghamHub provides various university support services such as Disability Support, Financial Support, and Change in Study Plan. Users can access this support by clicking on the 'Help' tile.

Payments can be made via the 'Pay amount due' button in NottinghamHub. Detailed guides are available on the university website for making payments including tuition fee deposits and optional purchases.
Users can request a refund by emailing to Finance-Refund@nottingham.edu.my for more information.

Information on scholarships and financial assistance can be found by clicking into the Account history in NottinghamHub. Aid impacts amounts due per semester, and users can contact the Finance Office for settling account queries.

To view official receipts online, users can log in to NottinghamHub, click on the Finance Tile, access the Payment History, and view and print official receipts. Further support is available by contacting the UNM Finance Office.
The University requires online registration for each year of study. Instructions for registration are emailed to the students, and more details can be found on the University website.

Instructions for online registration are sent via email with the subject: Invite to Online Registration. Students need to log in using their university username to complete the online registration process, available by clicking the banner in NottinghamHub.
Users can view their student ID number by logging into NottinghamHub and clicking on the ‘Profile’ tile where the ID number is displayed.
Users can make module choices during the 'Change of Mind' period in the first two weeks of classes for each intake. Changes can also be made at the start of the second semester.
Exam timetables are published at least a month before the examination period, and users will receive an email notification when the timetable is available.
Marks, progression, and award details are accessed through the Blue Castle system.
To request documents like confirmation letters and transcripts, users can utilize the self-service options available in NottinghamHub under the 'Help' tile.
NottinghamHub users can upload documents such as scholarship letters or supporting evidence by following the instructions under the ‘Documents’ tile.

To register for graduation and purchase ceremony tickets, users will receive an email from the Graduation office when registration opens. The process involves logging into NottinghamHub and following the provided link on the ‘Graduation’ tile.
Users can defer their graduation to a later ceremony by selecting the appropriate option on the Graduation Registration form available through NottinghamHub.
Inter-ceremonies in March and October each year cater to students requiring their awards before the next main ceremony. More details are available on the Graduation webpage.

Khameel B. Mustapha is an Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

Khameel B. Mustapha received B.Eng in Mechanical Engineering from University of Ilorin (Nigeria), MSc in Mechanical Engineering from King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals (Saudi Arabia), and Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering from Nanyang Technological University (Singapore).

Khameel B. Mustapha teaches courses like Engineering Design and Design Project, Design, Manufacture & Project, Mechanics of Solids, and Additive Manufacturing & 3D Printing.

A team of students from University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) won the IMechE YMS Competition by designing an interior air-cooling device utilizing energy generated from renewable sources.
The competition took place online via Microsoft Teams in August 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The team integrated a dehumidification system into the air cooler to prevent moisture buildup, making their system more energy-efficient and affordable.
The use of liquid desiccant solution as a dehumidifying agent with conventional evaporative coolers resulted in a system that is more energy-efficient and affordable.

Nittikorn Chian-Promchan, Brian Soon Sen Yao, Jonathan Lee Kah Sheng, and Kenji Eu Zhong Qian were the students from the Departments of Mechanical, Materials & Manufacturing Engineering, and Electrical & Electronic Engineering who participated in the competition.

A rising badminton star from The University of Nottingham has won gold at the United Kingdom national University championships.

Li Lian Yang, 24 and a Malaysian national, scooped the Women’s singles title at the British Universities and Colleges Sport (BUCS) National Championships, defeating fellow Malaysian Lyddia Cheah 2-1 in Sheffield.
Li Lian made the switch in September last year from training full-time with the Malaysian national squad to a sports scholarship at The University of Nottingham.
Li Lian is in her first year of a Mathematics and Economics degree programme at Nottingham.
Li Lian and her team have their sights firmly set on the British Universities’ team title, held as part of BUCS Big Wednesday in March.
The University of Nottingham hosts an elite badminton programme in the brand new 24-court David Ross Sports Village.
Head of Badminton Martyn Lewis, a former Great Britain international, mentioned the outstanding commitment and professionalism of the players in the program.
Other highlights from The University of Nottingham in the championships included a bronze for Yang and mixed doubles partner Rohan Midha.
Yang and fellow sports scholars Serena Midha, Tiara Samuel, and Emily Witts head to Hong Kong next month for a week-long training camp with some of the world’s top players.

Students from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus are developing their leadership and management skills by running a series of education and healthcare workshops for indigenous Malaysian children living in a nearby Orang Asli village.
The workshops are set up in collaboration with AIESEC, the world’s largest student-led organisation.
Many Orang Asli live in remote forest areas where levels of poverty are high and a third of children of primary school age do not move on to secondary school.
The education sessions for children aged four to eight take place four evenings a week for around two hours in the community hall.
Students in the School of Pharmacy from both the UK and Malaysia campuses have worked with the Orang Asli community.
During the workshop, basic hygiene advice, oral hygiene sessions, and health screening were provided for the children and adult villagers.
Financial support for the health education and screening activities was provided through a donation from the Masters Foundation, a UK-registered charity.
The students plan to continue their work with the village and are planning longer-term, sustainable interactions with the community.
Dr. Andrew Morris, Head of the School of Pharmacy at the Malaysia Campus, praised the outreach projects as valuable for both the Orang Asli villagers and the Nottingham Pharmacy students.

Dr Sheena Baharudin, an Assistant Professor of Literature at the School of English, is a poet and alumna of University of Nottingham Malaysia, having completed her PhD in English in 2021.
Dr Sheena Baharudin shared her journey into poetry, starting from her undergraduate years studying English, and her love for poetry inspired by various sources throughout her life.

Dr Sheena Baharudin highlighted the empowering aspect of stepping into the world of spoken word poetry as an introvert, which helped her develop her sense of agency and connect with a community of like-minded individuals.
Poetry's attention to detail, particularly in words and their sound properties, attracted Dr Sheena Baharudin to this form of writing.
Dr Sheena Baharudin believes in the mystical quality of poetry and its ability to resonate strongly with her.
Dr Sheena Baharudin emphasized the importance of addressing the 'whys' of writing, finding meaning in the craft, and connecting with readers through one's work.
Dr Sheena Baharudin encouraged emerging writers to write with the intention of connecting with others, as writing is both a solitary and a communal act.
Dr Sheena Baharudin highlighted the significance of poetry in preserving stories and experiences throughout human history and emphasized the deep connection to art in today's fast-paced world.

NUBS Malaysia hosted the 2019 edition of the ‘Nottingham In the City’ Alumni Reception for alumni and invited guests of Nottingham University Business School Malaysia, held on 6 July 2019 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia’s Teaching Centre in Kuala Lumpur.
The event was attended by students and alumni of the School, and members of the Nottingham Graduates Association Malaysia.

A highlight of the event was the ‘Conversations’ series that featured guest speaker Robert Boxwell, director of international management and professional development consultancy Opera Advisors, who spoke on salient issues regarding the US-China Trade War and ways of strategising amid possible changes in the global economic environment.

MBA Finance alumnus Haw Hui Mun, Senior Relationship Manager, Business Banking at Bank Pembangunan Malaysia Berhad, mused, “The value of the Nottingham MBA goes on beyond graduation – not only has it unlocked other career opportunities for me, it has also made my Saturdays and after-work hours interesting with meet-ups such as this.”

President of the Nottingham Graduates Association Malaysia, Goh Hoon Huar, said, “I am thrilled by this initiative undertaken by the Business School. I enjoyed the networking, the interesting talk by the speaker, and the timely updates on the University by faculty members.

According to Dean of Nottingham University Business School Malaysia Dr Lau Chee Kwong, “We are delighted that the Nottingham in the City 2019 event has brought together many alumni of the Business School in an evening of reunion and reminiscence.”
The University of Nottingham is a global community of over 280,000 graduates.

Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia has had more than a decade's experience in providing international quality teaching and scholarship in various areas of business, management and finance, and is part of an elite global group of business schools accredited by the European Quality Improvement System (EQUIS) and Association of MBAs (AMBA).
Lim Kai Shen, an alumnus from the School of Economics, was awarded a Fullbright Scholarship to pursue his PhD in Population Health Sciences at Harvard University.
Receiving a Fullbright Scholarship is a tremendous privilege as it has a history of producing global leaders in various fields including politics, business, and academia.

Kai Shen intends to pursue a career in academia after completing his doctorate and use his academic knowledge to work alongside civil service and political leaders to ensure the Malaysian health system performs at a high level globally.

Kai Shen advised scholarship applicants to align their academic goals with personal goals, clearly demonstrate how they intend to achieve their goals, and show how it aligns with the scholarship program.

The Bachelor of Education (BEd) TESOL programme is designed for individuals aspiring to teach English as a Second or Other Language (TESOL) at primary or secondary school levels, offering theoretical knowledge with practical experience, including placements in international schools.

The curriculum equips students with skills in planning, delivering, and assessing teaching content, classroom management, TESOL methodologies, learning, curriculum design, pedagogy, and global education systems.
The BEd (Hons) in TESOL does not confer UK Qualified Teacher Status (QTS) but provides a strong foundation for teaching roles in regions not requiring QTS.

Entry requirements for the BEd (Hons) in TESOL include specific grades in A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior High School Diploma, Advance Placement, Diploma, Foundation Programme, IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level, GCE AS Level, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, IB English, OSSD, CBSE/CISCE, and language requirements.
Malaysian students are charged RM42,000 per year, and international students are charged RM50,000 per year for the BEd (Hons) in TESOL.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) opened as the first overseas branch campus of a British university in Kuala Lumpur in September 2000.
HRH Tuanku Ja'afar and HRH Sultan Azlan Shah, alumni of the University of Nottingham in the UK, were involved in the official launch of UNM in September 2000.
In 2001, UNM established a local campus in Semenyih surrounded by lush greenery.
In 2002, the University of Nottingham Malaysia celebrated the graduation of its first cohort of students.
During 2003-2004, construction of the campus continued in Semenyih, symbolizing the commitment to creating a world-class learning environment.
The campus development was completed in 2005, featuring modern facilities like lecture halls, laboratories, libraries, and accommodation.
In 2006, UNM opened a satellite campus in Kuala Lumpur at Chulan Tower, enhancing accessibility for working professionals and postgraduate students.
UNM received an 'Excellent' rating in the Malaysian Higher Education Rating System (SETARA) in 2010 and later a 'Competitive' rating in 2022.
UNM launched its Future Students Centre in Petaling Jaya in September 2023 to expand reach and enhance engagement with prospective students and partners.

The International Society of Educational and Cultural Exchange Inc Foundation (ISECE) offers an Assistant Language Teacher (ALT) Internship Programme in Japan.
Internships with ISECE have a duration of 6 months and follow the Japanese academic calendar, starting in April and September annually.
The internship opening is for a Junior and Senior High School in Kanagawa, Japan.
The internship application deadline is 11 November 2015, 17:00 (Malaysian Time).
Interns will work Mondays to Fridays from 2pm to 11pm with a break from 6pm to 7pm.
Accommodation for interns will be provided in a separate building from student dormitories.
Eligibility criteria include excellent English skills in all aspects and applicants must be currently enrolled at colleges/universities for at least one year.
Application materials include an application form, digital photograph, passport ID page, academic transcript, recommendation letter, and English proficiency test scores.
Accepted interns will receive accommodation, meals, transportation fees, full coverage of Japanese National Health Insurance, a stipend, and a one-way airplane ticket from Malaysia to Japan.

Nottingham University Business School Malaysia has secured the maximum nine exemptions from examination papers at the ‘Fundamentals’ level of the ACCA (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants) Qualification.

Students of the BA/BSc (Hons) Finance, Accounting and Management degree at Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia who have graduated or will graduate between 1 January 2016 and 31 December 2020, will be entitled to exemptions from the ‘Knowledge’ papers of the ACCA Fundamentals level.
Such graduates will also be entitled to exemptions from the remaining six ACCA Fundamentals level ‘Skills’ papers provided they have taken and passed certain specified modules.
In addition to the nine exemptions, NUBS Malaysia also now participates in the ACCA Accelerate programme.

Under ACCA Accelerate, students of the School’s BA/BSc (Hons) Finance, Accounting and Management degree programme will be able to register with ACCA during the second or third year of their undergraduate studies, before they complete their degree.
NUBS Malaysia has had more than a decade's experience in providing international quality teaching and scholarship in various areas of business, management and finance.

The School’s flagship BSc (Hons) Finance, Accounting and Management degree programme provides students with a critical understanding of the theory and practical techniques of finance and accounting within an economic, organisational and decision-making framework.

The programme provides a robust preparation for professional examinations in accounting, and enjoys maximum exemptions from the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA), The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW), the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants (CIMA), and CPA Australia.
ACCA works through a network of 95 offices and centres and more than 7,110 Approved Employers worldwide, who provide high standards of employee learning and development.
ACCA has consistently held unique core values: opportunity, diversity, innovation, integrity and accountability.
ACCA believes that accountants bring value to economies in all stages of development and seek to develop capacity in the profession and encourage the adoption of global standards.

The BSc (Hons) Biotechnology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia equips students with cutting-edge knowledge and practical skills to drive innovation in industries like healthcare, renewable energy, and crop and food production.

The program combines core modules in molecular biology, genomics, and proteomics with specialized topics such as genetic engineering of microorganisms and crops, industrial bioprocesses and bioproducts, pharmaceuticals, and food hygiene and safety.
The program is accredited and offers a pathway to global career opportunities in biosciences, pharmaceuticals, and sustainable industries.
The program includes industrial placements in Year 2, providing hands-on experience essential for career growth, job prospects, and entrepreneurship.
The BSc (Hons) Biotechnology program at UNM incorporates industrial training or internships to provide practical experience and exposure to real-world applications of biotechnology.

Entry requirements include A Level grades of BCC, including two science-based subjects from Biology, Chemistry, Physics, or Mathematics, and equivalent requirements for other qualifications such as IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma, Gaokao, Senior School Certificate Examination (CBSE), and other qualifications.
English language requirements include minimum scores for various English proficiency tests such as IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCSE O-Level, MUET, among others.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers various scholarships and financial assistance schemes for deserving students.
Malaysian students pay RM52,000 per year for the BSc (Hons) Biotechnology program, while international students pay RM58,000 per year.

The BA (Hons) in International Communication Studies with Film and Television Studies is a dynamic three-year programme that combines theoretical insights with practical media production. Students will explore the political, cultural, and economic forces shaping global communication, specializing in film and television.

The curriculum covers media theory, visual communication, and the historical development of cinema and television. Practical modules like Documentary Film and Practice allow students to create, film, and edit their projects.

Using state-of-the-art digital media labs, the program equips students with both academic knowledge and practical skills that will prepare them for careers in media, advertising, content creation, and international communications.
Students will gain fluency in a European or Asian language, enhancing their global career prospects.
Students can specialize in global languages such as French, Japanese, Mandarin, Spanish, German, or Korean.

The typical modules include Beginners French, German, Japanese, Korean, Mandarin, Spanish, Culture and Society, Media and Communications Theory, Producing Film and Television, Reading Film and Television, and Global Music Studies.

The Film and TV in Social and Cultural Context module aims to extend students' awareness of the meanings of film and television texts by considering their relationships to a range of historical contexts.

The entry requirements for 2025 entry include A Level qualifications of BCC, IB Diploma of 24 points overall, STPM of BC+C+, UEC of 3 B3s and 2 B4s, and equivalent qualifications for international students.
English language requirements for different qualifications include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or English Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, and others.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a 1-year pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM’s undergraduate degrees.

The Semenyih Campus of the University of Nottingham Malaysia is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and 45 minutes' drive from the city center, with facilities such as a sports center, library, and student accommodation.
Career opportunities after completing this program include roles such as Content Creator, Design Marketing Analyst, Media Planner, Media and PR Executive, and Production Associate.

Northeastern University (NEU) in Shenyang, China and University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for enhancing global academic collaboration.
The MoU between NEU and UNM aims to enhance teaching and learning experiences, develop innovative educational programs, and share best practices.
One area of collaboration under the MoU is student recruitment, focusing on attracting a diverse and talented pool of students to both institutions.
The partnership between NEU and UNM includes cooperation on international seminars, conferences, and workshops to facilitate academic discourse and knowledge exchange.
The MoU also allows for other academic exchanges that both Universities may agree upon, ensuring a wide range of collaborative initiatives.
The signing of the MoU between Northeastern University and University of Nottingham Malaysia marks the beginning of a promising bilateral collaboration for academic excellence and global engagement.

All residential halls are within easy walking distance to the academic buildings and on-campus conveniences like retail, food and beverage outlets, plus indoor and outdoor sports and leisure facilities.

The University offers various room types within its 11 halls of residence, totaling about 2,400 beds, ranging from single ensuite bathroom, twin shared to four shared rooms with or without air-conditioning. Special rooms are available for residents with special needs.

All rooms come with internet connection and each floor has a pantry-area where light cooking is allowed. Maintenance and room cleaning services are available, as well as coin-operated laundry facilities.
Rentals for on-campus accommodation are inclusive of water, electricity, and WIFI. Rooms with air-conditioning have a separate meter reading for air-conditioning usage.
During the semester months, students may enjoy activities such as Night Market (Pasar Malam) on Tuesdays and Campfire Night @ Radius on campus.

Applying for UNM’s on-campus accommodation is done through the Online Accommodation Application portal, where students can submit preferences and necessary information. Accommodation spaces are limited, so early application is encouraged.

On-campus accommodation is housing provided by the university within its campus boundaries, offering proximity to academic buildings, access to university resources, a sense of community, and easy access to campus activities.

Off-campus accommodation refers to housing options not within the university’s premises. Benefits of off-campus housing may include more independence, varied housing options, and experiencing living outside the university environment.
Both new and returning students can apply for on-campus accommodation via the Online Accommodation Application portal at UNM.

While UNM strives to accommodate as many students as possible, on-campus housing availability might be limited. It is advisable to apply for accommodation early to secure a place in your preferred residence.
International students are encouraged to apply for on-campus accommodation at UNM to provide a diverse and inclusive living environment for students from various backgrounds.

The Mandarin Language students from the University of Nottingham Malaysia took part in a Traditional Chinese [芋粿 Kuih] Cake Baking Workshop at the BS Bakery Shop in Klang on the 13th of February 2020.

Wendy Kor Show Chooi, with over 25 years of baking experience, hosted the learning experience at the bakery, where students learned about '紅龜粿' Angku Kuih, '包子' Pau, and participated in a hands-on baking workshop.

Students were split into smaller groups during the workshop to make the traditional Chinese '芋粿' Kuih or cakes from scratch, allowing them to learn Chinese culture, Mandarin vocabulary related to cooking and baking, and replicate famous pastry recipes.

UNM's Mandarin Teaching Fellow, Kwan Hwee Ling, mentioned that the field trip fulfilled the aim of the session and some students felt that the bakery's use of organic ingredients and the quality of the baked goods exceeded their expectations.

Noor Husna Ahmad Toha, the 3rd Year Mandarin Language Representative, found the field trip to be a fun and unique way to fulfill Mandarin Language learning objectives, providing real-life interactions with authentic Chinese culture and native speakers.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) introduced the Student Experience Innovation Fund in 2024 to enhance the student experience.

The Student Experience Innovation Fund had a total budget of RM150,000 and supported projects in various categories like student well-being, support and communications, industry and community engagement, and equality, diversity, and inclusion (EDI).
Six projects were selected from 21 applications based on their alignment with UNM's strategic aims, objectives, impact, feasibility, cost-effectiveness, and sustainability.
Another project, 'IT Service Desk Plus', was introduced to provide immediate IT support to students at high-traffic locations on campus, reducing wait times and improving response efficiency.
The Campus Services department implemented a sustainable waste management system in on-campus accommodation to promote environmental responsibility among students.
UNM launched an Entrepreneurial Camp to empower future entrepreneurs by providing hands-on experience and essential entrepreneurial skills.
A student-led community outreach initiative focused on sustainable food systems, agriculture, and waste management, involving peer educators recruited through student clubs.
The Exchange Theatre project used interactive drama to support student transition, cultural understanding, and discussions about cultural differences.
The successful projects funded in 2024 have created a more engaging, inclusive, and supportive environment for students at UNM.
The Student Experience Innovation Fund demonstrates UNM's commitment to fostering a student-centric campus and ongoing growth in shaping the student experience.

A two (2) hour introductory workshop will cover appropriate and inappropriate ways to deliver feedback, the concept of a critical friend, active listening, boundaries of the student observer role, issues of confidentiality, and criteria for evaluating teaching.

Students will be expected to keep field-notes containing their observations and reflections upon their experience. They will be asked to compare their activities under this module to the traditional ways of evaluating teaching (i.e. SEM and SET), analyzing the difficulties and benefits they encountered in offering constructive feedback.

We find that gaze is not always drawn to 'salient' areas of the visual scene in the real world. Aspects of the task determine where the eye will be directed to obtain task-specific information.

Current projects include studying the predictive use of gaze by humans in everyday tasks and in games, the strategic use of gaze by Orangutans in various activities, and the ability of apes to discriminate between levels of antioxidants in different food items.

Chloe's short story was longlisted in the 2022 Malaysian Short Story Writing Competition and published in the related collection, A Chance Encounter at Sungai Chiling and Other Stories.
Chloe's works have been included in the Wasteland of Malaysian Poetry in English exhibition.
Chloe's published work in the anthology A Chance Encounter at Sungai Chiling and Other Stories was launched at the Georgetown Literary Festival 2023.
"The first creative writing circle I went to was what I consider to be the starting point of my journey as a writer at UNM," said Chloe.
UNM felt like a small global society, only so much friendlier to Chloe.
Chloe mentioned that UNM's experienced educators and published authors expanded her perspectives and ignited her creative passion.
Chloe spent time in Particle, UNM’s digital literary magazine, and the Literature and Drama Society (LADS).
UNM encouraged Chloe to grow and be vulnerable, building her self-esteem.
Chloe said her experience at UNM gave her the courage to submit her work to national and international contests and achieve her dream of getting published.

The Master of Science in Biotechnology at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is a comprehensive one-year programme that prepares students to address real-world challenges using advanced biotechnology solutions.

The programme provides an in-depth understanding of antimicrobial drug resistance, plant and crop improvements, genetic engineering techniques, bioprocessing, synthetic biology, and bioinformatics, with applications across three specialisations: Agricultural, Industrial, and Medical and Pharmaceutical Biotechnology.

Specialised Pathways: Tailor your expertise with focused pathways in Agricultural, Industrial, and Medical and Pharmaceutical Biotechnology, equipping you for diverse and high-demand industries globally.
Comprehensive Curriculum: Gain hands-on skills through modules in advanced molecular methods, professional skills, and industry-focused studies, designed to meet global biotechnology standards.
Industry Alignment: Benefit from practical exposure and off-site visits, learning directly from industry leaders, and enhancing your employability in competitive biotechnology sectors.

The entry requirements for the Biotechnology MSc program include a second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent in Biotechnology, Agricultural Sciences, Microbial Sciences, Medical Sciences, Pharmaceutical Sciences, Genetics, Microbiology, or related life sciences subjects.

Applicants must hold a degree from a recognized university and certain programs may require prior qualifications in related fields. English language requirements include IELTS 6.0, TOEFL (iBT) 80, PTE (Academic) 65, and MUET Band 4.
Learning methods for the program include lectures, seminars, tutorials, practical classes, supervision, field trips, lab sessions, e-learning, and fieldwork.
Fees for Malaysian students are RM50,000 per program, while international students pay RM55,000 per program.
The Biotechnology MSc program is offered at the Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham, located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport.
The campus features schools of business, education, science, and engineering, along with a sports center, library, student accommodation, and green surroundings.

A compound in papaya leaf juice is known to help with blood clotting and can restrict the internal bleeding caused by dengue fever.
Funding from the Malaysian Ministry of Higher Education is supporting a team of chemical engineers at University of Nottingham Malaysia to extract the bioactive compound 'carpaine' for a dengue pill.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection found in tropical and sub-tropical climates and causes flu-like symptoms, potentially progressing to Dengue Haemorrhagic Fever.
The carpaine compound is extracted using alcohol, followed by an acid-base extraction procedure to yield crude material that is further purified to at least 95% purity.
University of Nottingham aims to work with industry partners to produce a carpaine medication for dengue, with expected extensive approvals and clinical trials taking up to ten years.

Students who are studying at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) can apply to study at the overseas campuses in China and the UK for a period of one semester or one academic year through the Inter-campus Exchange Programme.
To be eligible to apply to the programme: students must have completed at least one year of their degree study (Undergraduate - UG) at the UNM.
Students have to obtain a passing mark of minimum 55%-70% (depending on courses) in order to apply onto the exchange scheme. The first semester result will be used for the exchange application.

Students need to maintain their current year average of 55%-70% in their second-semester result in order to progress for the exchange programme. Failure to maintain will result in the cancellation of the progress for the exchange.
No students taking resits are permitted to progress onto the exchange scheme.

Pharmacy is a vital component of the healthcare industry. It is the science and practice of preparing, dispensing and reviewing drugs and medication to ensure they are safe and effective for patients.
Pharmacists are highly trained healthcare professionals working closely with doctors, nurses and other healthcare providers to ensure patients receive the best possible care.
Pharmacists also advise on the appropriate use of medicines, and they play a critical role in the prevention and management of chronic conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, and asthma.

Pharmacies are an essential resource for patients who need access to medications, medical advice, and support for managing their health. They are an integral part of the healthcare system, helping to improve patient outcomes and promote the health and well-being of communities across the globe.

Pharmacists are responsible for accurately dispensing medications to patients. They must carefully review the prescription to ensure that the correct medication, dosage, and instructions are provided.

Pharmacy is a field that offers numerous opportunities for career growth. Pharmacists can progress from entry-level positions to management roles or choose to specialize in areas such as pediatrics, oncology, psychiatry and more.

One of the main benefits of pursuing a career in pharmacy is job stability and growth prospects. According to New Straits Times, Malaysia’s Health Ministry has plans to increase the number of pharmacist positions in the public sector.
Pharmacists are needed in various healthcare settings, including hospitals, community pharmacies, and long-term care facilities.
Pharmacy graduates can expect diverse career options and a chance to make a meaningful impact on society.

To become a pharmacist in Malaysia, individuals typically need to complete these steps: Complete your pre-university education after high school or secondary school. Enrol and complete an undergraduate degree approved by the Pharmacy Board Malaysia (PBM)... Complete an internship or work placement... Sit for and pass the Pharmacy Board Malaysia (PBM) examination... Obtain a license from PBM to practice as a pharmacist.

The International Multilateral Partnership Against Cyber Threats (IMPACT) is the cyber security executing arm of the United Nations' specialised agency - the International Telecommunication Union (ITU).
IMPACT brings together governments, academia and industry experts to enhance the global community’s capabilities in dealing with cyber threats.
IMPACT provides ITU’s 193 Member States access to expertise, facilities and resources to effectively address cyber threats.
Interns will also assist in general office support and ongoing projects.

Applications must include a cover letter and a current CV.

The start dates for the program are in February, April, June, and September 2025. The Malaysian fee is RM50,000 per year, and the international fee is RM56,000 per year.
All doctoral candidates for the Education MPhil/PhD program are based at the Malaysia campus.

For admission to the PhD program, candidates need a master's degree with a merit grade or a first-class honors degree in a relevant discipline. For the MPhil program, an upper second-class honors degree in a relevant discipline is required. English language proficiency tests like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, or MUET are also necessary.

The University admits students who are under the age of 18 years. The usual personal and academic support arrangements will apply to such students.
The University requires a parent or guardian of students under 18 years to confirm their acceptance of the support and welfare arrangements by signing a consent form.
Parents must ensure accommodation suitability for students under 18 years as university residential accommodations are generally intended for adults.
Courses may include field trips or excursions, and parents need to provide consent for students under 18 years to participate.
The University is alcohol-free, but parents need to advise students accordingly as the University cannot supervise individual students.
Students under 18 years are not permitted to hold office within student associations.

Emergency contact details are crucial for students under 18 years, and consent for necessary medical treatment will be given by a senior university member if parents cannot be reached during emergencies.
The University is obligated to protect students under 18 from abuse and will report any suspicions or allegations of abuse to the appropriate authorities.
It is a criminal offense for anyone in a position of trust, including university staff, to engage in sexual activity with someone under 18 years.
For international applicants under 18 years, it is encouraged to provide details of a guardian based in Malaysia for emergency contact and parental responsibilities.

Fun social events such as Logic Lockdown – Escape the Room, Halloween Movie Night, helloWorld, and a School Welcome Dinner were also carried out as part of the celebration.
The School of Computer Science extends its gratitude to the core and supplementary committee members for their diligent work behind the scenes, which ensured the success of the 2024 TECH Fest.

Special thanks also go out to the Careers Advisory Service, Computer Science Society and Students‘ Association for their contribution and support in making this year’s event a resounding success.

Mandarin is the world's most commonly spoken first language and the second most popular language on the Internet. More students are choosing to study Mandarin at UNM.

Applicants with a second-class honours degree (2:2) or international equivalent will be considered on a case-by-case basis, depending on their profile of performance or work experience.
IELTS (Academic): 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element) is required for English language proficiency.
TOEFL (iBT): 90 (minimum 19 in Writing and Listening, 20 in Reading and 22 in Speaking) is accepted for English language proficiency.

A team of communications experts at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus monitored the 2013 Malaysian election campaign for media bias.
The project released five preliminary and two comprehensive final reports, as well as 28 individual publication reports on media bias during the Malaysian election.
The project was a collaboration between The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus and the Malaysian Centre for Independent Journalism.
Lead analyst Dr. Tessa Houghton conducted media monitoring of the New Zealand elections in 2008 and contributed to the quantitative methodology for the project.
Professor Zaharom Nain highlighted political party ownership of Malaysian media and the lack of critical media education as contributing factors to media bias.
The recent general election in Malaysia was one of the closest since the country's independence from Britain 56 years ago.
The Barisan Nasional won the recent election, but the opposition coalition, Pakatan Rakyat, established itself as a viable alternative government for Malaysia.
Opposition leader Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim accused the government of electoral fraud after the recent election.
Media monitoring during the election scrutinized coverage of political figures, parties, and key issues across various media outlets in Malaysia.
The final reports on media coverage during the election were presented at a public forum at Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia.

Tim Gocher is Hon. Professor of Sustainable Business in the Business School at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Tim's background is in private equity, energy, and technology.
After nine years at Deloitte and J.P. Morgan, and an MBA from London Business School, Tim became Managing Director at listed investment bank Interregnum (ParkMead) plc.
Tim was awarded the OBE in the 2022 Queen's Birthday Honours List for services to British investment and economic development in Nepal.
Tim is married to Pooja Gurung and has three children: Daniel, Benjamin, and Elizabeth.
Tim lectures at Nottingham University Business School Malaysia Campus in the areas of sustainable/climate finance and impact investment.
Tim also has an interest in university Intellectual Property (IP) commercialization and how that contributes to national competitiveness.
Tim Gocher is the founder and CEO of Dolma Fund Management - the first international private equity fund manager for Nepal.
Dolma Fund Management's fund investments have generated over 10,000 jobs in Nepal across renewable energy, healthcare, and technology industries.
Dolma's funds were the largest FDI investor in Nepal in the 2022/23 fiscal year.
Tim is also Chairman of Dolma Foundation, a British non-profit organization providing full scholarships for marginalized children in Nepal.

All international students must obtain a Student Pass (Visa) to study in Malaysia.
Education Malaysia Global Services (EMGS) is a one-stop centre mandated by the Ministry of Higher Education Malaysia to manage all student pass applications.
The Immigration Department of Malaysia issues all student passes, and the University of Nottingham Malaysia does not have the authority to approve or reject student pass applications.
New international students applying for their Visa Approval Letter (VAL) can choose to apply via the UNM Visa Office or directly to EMGS.
New international students applying for their VAL are required to pay an additional fee of RM2,000 as a deposit, which will be refundable upon completion of studies.

All international students who defer, withdraw, terminate, and complete studies are required to shorten/cancel their present student pass before leaving the country, in line with Malaysian Immigration Department guidelines.

The visa fee of RM 4,660 includes UNM, EMGS, and Immigration processing fees, Student Pass, Multiple Entry-Visa, i-Kad, medical insurance, post-medical health check, GST, and Visa Office processing fee.
Visa processing fees (RM2,660) are non-refundable once the VAL application has been submitted, and students can inquire about withdrawal eligibility for a refund.
The eVAL issuance, SEV application, and post-arrival procedures are important steps for international students entering Malaysia legally.

International students are not allowed to work part-time throughout the academic year, but can work part-time for 20 hours per week during semester breaks in approved sectors such as petrol kiosks, restaurants, mini-markets, and as waiters.

The event called KS Maniam’s Writing: A Celebration took place at the Kuala Lumpur Teaching Centre, University of Nottingham, Kuala Lumpur on 9th March 2019.
The event was co-organised by the School of English, University of Nottingham Malaysia and his publisher Maya Press.
KS Maniam published his first work, a poem in 1964 when he was 22 years old.
KS Maniam's short stories have won first prize at national level short story competitions organized by the New Straits Times in 1987 and 1990.
KS Maniam is the inaugural recipient of the Raja Rao Award in 2000 for his outstanding contribution to literature of the South Asian diaspora.
KS Maniam is known for his novels, short stories, and plays.
A new volume of KS Maniam's poems is expected to be published soon.
KS Maniam's works have been taught in Malaysia and abroad.
KS Maniam's novel, 'The Return' was taught in the Literature in English component for Form 5 students.
The celebratory event included readings and performances of KS Maniam's works by academics, writers, and actors.
Professor Malachi Edwin Vethamani from the School of English, UNM, had a conversation with KS Maniam during the event.
Messages from Malaysian-born Shirley Lim, Preeta Samarasan, and poet Muhammad Haji Salleh were read at the event.
Malaysian poet Wong Phui Nam gave a tribute to KS Maniam during the event.
There were two short performances from KS Maniam's plays during the event.
The event concluded with a round of applause for KS Maniam for his contribution to Malaysian Literature in English.
Professor Vethamani described the event as very timely for a Malaysian deserving of all the accolades bestowed upon him.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers field courses including Tropical Environmental Science Field Course (GEOG2055 UNMC) in year 2 and Tropical Ecology (GEOG4062 UNMC) in year 3.

The Tropical Environmental Science Field Course is based on Tioman Island off the east coast of Peninsular Malaysia and covers topics such as ecological assessment of coral reefs, mangroves, and marine turtles.
The Tropical Ecology Field Course is held at the Krau nature reserve and covers topics like forest structural assessment and plant-animal interactions.
The field courses are typically delivered over a 7-day residential stay.

The Centre for English Language and Foundation Education (CELFE) provides English language support to the entire student population at the University of Nottingham Malaysia through non-credit bearing workshops that are offered year-round.
The workshops are free of charge and are open to all current students of the university.
Some workshops are designed to provide students with guidance on personal development in areas such as study skills, professional development, and mental wellbeing.

Topics covered in the in-sessional workshops include Grammar in Writing, Citation and Referencing, Presentation Skills, Structuring Academic Arguments, Reading Academic Texts, and Becoming Reflective Learners.
Postgraduate students have access to one-to-one writing consultation sessions at the Writing Centre at CELFE for personalized task-specific writing support.
The Writing Centre does not provide proofreading or editing services for theses and dissertations; it is strictly for postgraduate students.
For inquiries about CELFE's in-sessional support and the Writing Centre at CELFE, contact in-sessional.english@nottingham.edu.my.
The Underutilised Crops Food Product Innovation Competition was organized by the University of Nottingham Malaysia's (UNM) School of Biosciences on 25th August 2024.

The competition showcased culinary creations using underutilized crops like moringa, butterfly pea flower, keladan fruits, turkey berry, passion fruit, split gill mushroom, ambarella, sentul fruit, and soursop.
Winners of the competition included Noridayu binti Sulaiman for Moringa Chapatti, Nor Hafizah binti Abu Hassan for Moringa Murukku, and Maimizan binti Dzulkapli for Sweet and Sour Dried Jelly.
Judges of the competition included Dr. Anita Chakrabarty, Encik Wan Mohd Hafiz Bin Wan Daud, and Encik Ritakamal Sadiman.
The event aimed to promote sustainability through innovative agricultural practices and combat food waste by transforming overlooked crop parts into marketable food items.
The competition highlighted the role of innovation in agriculture, food sustainability, and the potential for developing diversified food items.

The 8th Asia-Pacific Drying Conference (ADC 2015) will be held in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on 10-12 August 2015.
Delegate fee for the conference is RM1700 or USD540, while student fee is RM1300 or USD420.
Abstract submission deadline for the conference was 15 April 2015.
Paper submission deadline for the conference was 30 June 2015.
Contact person for the conference is Prof. Chung Lim Law, email: adc2015@nottingham.edu.my.

The conference topics include Challenges in industrial drying, Drying of chemicals, food & Agricultural products, minerals, other materials, paper & woods, dehydration & dewatering equipment, environmental impact of drying and life cycle analysis, among others.

Sponsorship opportunities for the conference are available, and interested parties can contact Prof. Chung Lim Law for details.
The Association of Commonwealth Universities (ACU) holds an annual summer school at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus to address global food security.
36 students from 19 Commonwealth countries attended the ACU Annual Summer School at UNMC in August 2014.
Students selected for the program came from various disciplines such as social science, agriculture, bioscience, and business.
The program included keynote talks on topics such as gender equality, climate change, food policy, safety, site visits, and local sustainable food production demonstrations.
The summer school emphasized a multidisciplinary approach to addressing global food security issues.
Students were grouped and tasked with designing practical solutions related to challenges in food security by the end of the week.
The ACU summer school aims to provide learning and mobility opportunities for students from Commonwealth countries.
Professor Christine Ennew, CEO and Provost of The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, highlighted the success of the summer school in addressing global challenges.
The ACU is the world's first and oldest international university network, with over 500 member institutions across the Commonwealth.

Former Chancellor and UNNC President Professor Yang Fujia passed away on 17 July 2022 at the age of 86.
Professor Yang Fujia became Nottingham's sixth Chancellor in 2001, the first time a Chinese academic had held the role in a UK university.
In 2004, Professor Yang Fujia helped establish UNNC, the first Sino-foreign university in China.
Professor Yang Fujia was born in Shanghai in 1936 and attended Fudan University where he remained as a teacher after graduating in 1958.
Professor Yang Fujia joined Nottingham in 2001 and served as UNNC's first President.
Professor Yang Fujia promoted the establishment of the University of Nottingham Ningbo China, a Sino-foreign cooperative education model in China.

The University of Nottingham offers a Senior Executive position in Student Recruitment (Domestic) at its Malaysia campus to achieve domestic student enrollment targets.

Job responsibilities include driving student engagement, implementing recruitment strategies, providing training to representatives, establishing relationships with recruitment agents, sustaining partnerships with schools and institutions, and delivering presentations on studying at UNM.

Job requirements for the Senior Executive position at the University of Nottingham Malaysia include possessing a Bachelor's degree, having two to three years of experience in domestic student recruitment for higher education, effective communication skills, proficiency in English, negotiation and presentation skills, ability to supervise staff and student ambassadors, motivation, and willingness to travel and work beyond regular hours.
Interested candidates can submit their applications via email for the Senior Executive, Student Recruitment (Domestic) position by 16 March 2025.
The Master of Business Administration (MBA) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is designed for professionals seeking to advance their careers in business and management.
The MBA program is accredited by the EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), AACSB, and AMBA.
The MBA program equips students with expertise in finance, marketing, operations management, and strategic leadership.
The MBA program includes core modules and elective modules to tailor learning to align with career aspirations.
Students engage in experiential learning through group projects, case studies, and interaction with industry leaders.
Students undertake a Management Project to apply practical insights to solve real-world challenges.
The MBA program emphasizes developing problem-solving, analytical, and leadership skills along with exploring business ethics, sustainability, and innovation.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a second-class honours degree (2:2) or its international equivalent as an entry requirement for the MBA program.
Applicants must have at least three years of full-time post-graduation work experience, including some management experience.
English language requirements for the MBA program include IELTS 6.5, TOEFL 90, PTE 71, or MUET Band 4.5.
The MBA program consists of 12 taught modules (8 core modules and 4 elective modules) and a Management Project.
The Kuala Lumpur Teaching Centre (KLTC) is a facility where select postgraduate programs are delivered, including business programs.

Career opportunities after completing the MBA program include roles such as Chief Executive Officer, Management Consultant, Operations Director, Marketing Director, Financial Controller/Chief Financial Officer.

The third season of the Voices series, entitled 'Questions of Democracy in Culture and Media', was held at the Annexe Gallery and at the Petaling Street Community Art Project space in Kuala Lumpur during April, May, and June 2013.
2013 saw Malaysians going to the polls to exercise electoral democracy.
Malaysia is not party to the 1951 Refugee Convention Act, which impacts the rights of asylum seekers in the country.
The 2012 Peaceful Assembly Act in Malaysia prohibits foreigners from participating in public protests.
The Voices III series examined the roles of theatre practitioners, university students, Muslims, sexual minority rights activists, and refugee advocates in carving out space for democracy.
Speakers in the Voices III series included Thilaga Sulathireh, Yante Ismail, Jo Kukuthas, Fahmi Reza, and Professor James Piscatori.

BrowZine is a journal discovery tool which enables you to browse, read and monitor current scholarly journal content subscribed by the university and open access journals on your mobile device, laptop or desktop PC (Personal Computer).

BrowZine works by establishing direct connections to the publishers themselves, therefore, collections contained within database aggregators such as EBSCO and ProQuest may not show as available, or may show different holdings.

The forum on special education needs held at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus was an initiative by the School of Education, led by Associate Professor Dr. Jackie Dearden from the School of Education, University of Nottingham, UK.

In 2013, UNMC partnered with the Ministry of Education and College of Allied Educators to provide training in special needs to 292 primary school teachers from all over Malaysia at various centers located in Kuching, Sandakan, Kota Kinabalu, Kuala Terengganu, Batu Pahat, and Melaka to train special needs teachers.

The panel discussion during the forum on special education needs included Dr. Alefiya Nomanbhoy, Dr. Tida Tubpun, Dr. Wong Tze Peng, and Dr. Daniel Seal, who are experts in special needs education and clinical psychology.

The discussions at the panel included topics like good international inclusive education models and the current perception and status of inclusive education for students with special needs in Malaysia.
The forum emphasized the need for continued advocacy for equality and equity in education for students with special needs through measures such as awareness raising and skill training.

Interlibrary loan or ILL is a library service where we borrow materials for you not in our collection from other libraries nationally and internationally.
The ILL service is for academic purposes only and it is important to check carefully that what you need is definitely not in our collection before you apply.
This service is provided to all registered borrowers, in connection with their academic and teaching purposes.
You can request for books, journals, journal articles, conference proceedings, and reports.

The average time is three weeks. This time can be much shorter (especially for articles/photocopies), but it can also be longer. It depends upon the location of the lending library, how fast the lending library responds to the request, and also the efficiency of the postal service.
A standard RM5 handling fee will be charged for all requests successfully fulfilled within your yearly quota. Also, any additional requests above your yearly quota will charged at RM15 each.
You may send a well-trusted representative to pick the item up for you. You are responsible for the item and any fees incurred regardless of who collects it for you.
Items need to be collected within three weeks or before the given due date.
You may keep an ILL item anywhere from one to six weeks, depending on the lending library. (The lending library sets the loan period.)

Quinine is still used for anti-malaria treatment but is associated with side effects ranging from sickness and headaches to more severe reactions like blindness and deafness.

The study on quinine and tryptophan was funded by the University of Nottingham's doctoral award scheme and led by Dr Simon Avery and Dr Kang-Nee Ting from the Schools of Biology in the UK and Biomedical Sciences in Malaysia.
Dr Simon Avery suggested that modifying tryptophan levels through diet or dietary supplements could potentially reduce adverse reactions to quinine in patients.

The DELF and DALF are diplomas awarded by the French Ministry of Education to prove the French-language skills of non-French candidates.
There are six independent diplomas, which correspond, respectively, to the six levels of the Council of Europe's Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFRL).

The DELF DALF examinations presented in Malaysia include DELF DALF Tout Public for General Public, DELF Junior for children aged 12 to 17, DELF Scolaire for schoolchildren in selected Government schools, DELF Prim for children aged 8 to 12, and DELF Pro for professionals working in a French-speaking environment.
Candidates who receive the DELF DALF diplomas enjoy benefits such as having the diploma recognized internationally and being proof of proficiency for education or work purposes.
Holders of the DELF B2 or DALF diplomas are exempted from language entrance examinations in French universities.
The University of Nottingham in Malaysia offers DELF preparation books available at the Library and SMLC International Language Studio.
Diplomas for DELF exams arrive from France Education International about 2 months after the end of the exams and can be collected at the FASS counter by providing necessary identification.

Payment methods for DELF/DALF 2025 registration include credit card payments, online banking, crossed cheques or bank drafts payable to 'The University of Nottingham in Malaysia Sdn Bhd', and bank transfers to specified bank accounts.
Steve MJ Janssen is the Dean of Faculty of Science and Engineering, Professor of Psychology, and MSc Developmental Disorders Course Director at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Steve MJ Janssen obtained his PhD in Psychology in December 2007 from the University of Amsterdam.
Steve MJ Janssen has conducted various studies to understand the reminiscence bump, including its imperviousness to age, gender, education, and culture effects.

Steve MJ Janssen is actively involved in teaching various psychology modules at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Since its inception, Yayasan Sime Darby has awarded scholarships worth more than RM240 million to 3,208 students both in and outside Malaysia.

The BSc (Hons) Finance, Accounting and Management at the University of Nottingham Malaysia provides a world-class education that integrates finance, accounting, and business management.
The program is a comprehensive three-year degree that equips students with the skills to excel in today’s competitive global economy.
The BSc program is accredited by the prestigious triple crown—EFMD Quality Improvement System (EQUIS), AACSB, and AMBA—ensuring exemptions from professional examinations.
Students gain a solid foundation in financial management, corporate reporting, organizational behavior, and business ethics.
Optional modules in taxation, auditing, and international finance allow students to tailor their studies to align with their career goals.
The program provides access to state-of-the-art facilities and small group tutorials for students to master essential skills such as financial analysis, strategic decision-making, and leadership.
The University offers a variety of optional modules such as international finance, taxation, and sustainable business practices to tailor the degree.
The course modules cover various subjects like business finance, business law, computers in business, economic principles, and fundamentals of financial and management accounting.
The University accepts a broad range of qualifications for admission to the program, including A Levels, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, and other equivalents.
Applicants must meet English language requirements and have at least a grade B in Mathematics at SPM/GCSE/IGCSE/High School Diploma level or equivalent.
International students are welcome to enroll in the Finance, Accounting and Management BSc (Hons) program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The duration of the Finance, Accounting and Management BSc (Hons) program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is three years for full-time students.

Financial analyst, investment banker, management consultant, tax accountant, financial planner, auditor, risk analyst, financial controller, business development manager, and commercial banker are some of the roles graduates can pursue.

The International Symposium on Environmental DNA for Conservation and Biomonitoring in Southeast Asia (eDNAConBio) 2025 will gather experts to discuss the latest advancements in environmental DNA technology.
The symposium will demonstrate how scientific advancements inform and shape effective policies in conservation and sustainability.
The 10th International Workshop for Mangrove Biodiversity Studies by eDNA Metabarcoding 2025 is held in conjunction with the eDNAConBio 2025 symposium.
The symposium will take place on 18-19 February 2025 at The University of Nottingham Teaching Centre, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
Registration opens on 07 January 2025, and the closing date for abstracts submission is 06 February 2025.
Finalisation of the symposium program will be on 08 February 2025, and registration without walk-in is closed on 14 February 2025.
Keynote speakers for the eDNAConBio 2025 include Professor Michio Kondoh, Professor Yoshihisa Suyama, Professor Tadashi Kajita, and Dr. Yuki Minegishi.
The registration fee for delegates is RM250, and for students, it is RM150. A 6% sales and service tax will be added to the fee.
Payment for registration can be made via bank transfer to HSBC Bank Malaysia Berhad, account number 301-879391-101.
After submitting the online form, participants will receive an individual invoice via email for payment confirmation.

The Organising Committee of the eDNAConBio 2025 includes Dr. Alison Wee Kim Shan, Dr. Amy Then Yee Hui, Professor Tadashi Kajita, Dr. Kenny Voon, Mr. Frankie Thomas Sitam, Dr. Abe Woo Sau Pinn, Mr. Harris Wei-Khang Heng, and Ms. Leanne Frances Yee.

The BSc (Hons) in Business Economics and Finance at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) combines rigorous academic training with practical insights, preparing students for a thriving career in the dynamic world of business, economics, and finance.
This three-year full-time programme is delivered by the internationally renowned Nottingham University Business School which is accredited by EQUIS, AACSB, and AMBA.

The programme features cutting-edge modules like Quantitative Methods, Economics of Regulation, and Sustainable Business Practices, equipping students with vital analytical, problem-solving, and leadership skills.

With flexible pathways and a focus on sustainability, this course offers the perfect blend of theoretical knowledge and practical experience, paving the way for diverse career opportunities in financial institutions, consultancy, policymaking, and beyond.

The entrance requirements for the BSc (Hons) Business Economics and Finance course at the University of Nottingham Malaysia include A Level qualifications with grades BCC (excluding Critical Thinking and General Studies) or equivalent qualifications.
The Malaysian fee for the BSc (Hons) Business Economics and Finance course is RM45,000 per year, while the international fee is RM55,000 per year.
The BSc (Hons) Business Economics and Finance course at the University of Nottingham Malaysia starts in September 2025.
The Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham is located at Semenyih Campus, which is 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and just 45 minutes’ drive from the famous city centre.
The Malaysia Campus offers facilities such as a sports center, library, and student accommodation, providing students with modern amenities in a central Asia location.
UNM offers several types of financial aid, including scholarships for deserving students studying the Business Economics and Finance BSc (Hons) course.

The Business Economics and Finance BSc (Hons) course at the University of Nottingham Malaysia uses a variety of teaching methods, including lectures, seminars, tutorials, workshops, group projects, and case studies.

MyNottingham is the new administrative portal for applicants, students and staff to access services and data.
MyNottingham interfaces with Campus Solutions, bringing financial, admissions, and student records together in one system across all three campuses.
MyNottingham can be accessed from any location across a variety of devices, 24 hrs a day.
MyNottingham is not an app and is best viewed on a computer.
MyNottingham will evolve with subsequent releases, providing more functionality as it progresses.
MyNottingham maintains a 'To Do' list of key actions and integrates events in the University calendar.
Students can seek help with Disability Support, Financial Support, or Change in Study Plan through the 'Support' section.
Students who have forgotten their password can retrieve it by using their University email addresses or the email address linked to their user ID.
Students can change their password by clicking on the arrow next to their name at the top right of the MyNottingham screen.
The site aims to be accessible for all users; users encountering issues can contact the IT Service Desk for support.
All transactions since 1 January, including tuition fees, accommodation charges, payments made, and any refunds, are visible in MyNottingham.
Payments can be made via the 'Pay amount due' button in MyNottingham.
To request a refund, users can click on 'Financial support' in the Support section and enter the relevant details.
To change personal details, users can click on their name at the top right corner of the screen and follow the instructions in the Overview of MyNottingham portal video.
Students can view their timetable through the Timetable section linked to the SWS system, where course/module selection is available.
Grades and exam results are currently accessed through the Blue Castle system.
Once a document is uploaded, it needs to be processed and verified by staff members before the notification disappears.
Users have 60 minutes to take down an uploaded document and replace it with an alternative version; after that, they should upload the correct document and contact the IT Service Desk.
Teng-Jin Khoo is a Senior Tutor, Associate Professor, and Digital Learning Director at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Tim Gocher, Chairman and Founder of the Dolma Foundation and Honorary Professor of Sustainable Business at Nottingham University Business School Malaysia, spoke to MBA students on 'Financial Aspects of Sustainability - Impact Finance', as part of the MBA Sustainable Decisions and Organisations core module, on 16 March 2016 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus Kuala Lumpur Teaching Centre.

Tim's background is in investment banking and urban development with particular knowledge of energy, technology and real estate sectors. After nine years at Deloitte and J.P. Morgan, and an MBA from London Business School, Tim became Managing Director at listed investment bank Interregnum plc.
The Dolma Foundation is a British non-profit organisation founded by Tim in 2003 that provides full scholarships for the poorest children in Nepal and support for developmental community projects.
MBA students at NUBS Malaysia benefit from the School’s links with the local and regional business community, and regularly organises interactive sessions between business leaders and MBA students.
