Exchange students learn independence, adaptability, and gain broader perspectives through studying in different countries within a year.
Encouragement for students to undertake exchanges, advice to work harder during exchange, and reassurance that the experience is valuable for personal growth.

On-campus, students can find Asian, Western, and Mediterranean food options, including provisions for vegetarians. There is also a 24/7 convenience store that offers frozen and fresh food for students on the go.

In Semenyih town, students can enjoy wallet-friendly Malaysian cuisine or opt for familiar fast food. Thrill-seekers can engage in activities like ATV racing, ziplining, and paintball at a nearby adventure park.

The BSc Nutrition programme at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is accredited by the Association for Nutrition (AfN) in the UK and the Malaysian Allied Health Professions Council (MAHPC).

The difference between a degree in nutrition and a degree in dietetics is that nutrition prepares students for diverse roles in clinical settings, public health organisations, communities, and industries, while dietetics primarily prepares students for careers in clinical and hospital settings.

One of the main methods used to obtain student feedback from all students is through anonymised Student Evaluation.
Evaluate is a new wireless, 'in class' tool used to capture Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) and Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) data.  Evaluate will be available from September 2014.
Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) is an evaluation of an individual lecturer, usually seeking comment on that staff member’s teaching as delivered in one particular teaching session.
SET scores are considered when a staff member applies for promotion or for confirmation in their employment.
The open-ended comments from Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) remain confidential to the member of staff.
Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) is an evaluation of the learning experience over the duration of an entire module, focusing on the learning resources and outcomes.
Feedback from Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) is considered during the module review process and attempts are made to improve the module for the next delivery.
The Centre for Green Technologies (CEGT) is a major national centre for clean energy and renewable industries.
Malaysia is focusing on sustainable green technologies to stimulate economic activity while reducing environmental impact.
The Centre for Green Technologies aims to play a major role in Malaysia's transition to a renewable energy economy.

The Centre for Green Technologies academic staff expertise includes computational techniques, environmental protection technologies, lean and green manufacturing, sustainable energy and fuels, and sustainable process design.
The Centre for Green Technologies is co-led by a Fellow of the Academy of Sciences Malaysia (ASM).
Green technologies aim to identify how industries can be more efficient, recognize energy's importance, and reduce environmental degradation.
The Centre for Green Technologies reduces Malaysia's carbon footprint, promotes sustainable economic growth, and fosters collaboration with commercial organizations and universities.
International students are welcome to be part of UNM's Centre for Green Technologies.

Dr Linda Quayle was among the invited speakers at a conference held by Universitas Brawijaya, Malang, Indonesia, to mark the Golden Anniversary of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

The Bachelor of Pharmacy (Hons) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is a four-year programme designed to prepare students for a rewarding career as a registered pharmacist in Malaysia.
The Bachelor of Pharmacy (Hons) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is accredited by leading professional bodies and ranks 12th globally for Pharmacy and Pharmacology.
The curriculum includes molecular and cellular pharmacology, pharmaceutical sciences, clinical therapeutics, and healthcare delivery, with specialized modules on community and industrial pharmacy.
The programme emphasizes interdisciplinary collaboration to integrate pharmacy expertise with advancements in healthcare technologies.

The entry requirement for the Bachelor of Pharmacy (Hons) includes BBB at A level, 30 points in IB Diploma, BBB in STPM, 2 As in UEC, ATAR 86 in Australian Year 12, 80% average OSSD and specific grade standards in other qualifications.
English language requirements for the programme include IELTS 6.5, TOEFL 90, PTE 71, and specific grade requirements for English language exams such as GCE A Level, SPM, GCSE O-Level, and others.
The Pharmacy (BPharm) degree is recognised by the Malaysia Pharmacy Board and the Malaysian Qualifications Agency.
The cost of studying the Pharmacy (BPharm) degree at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is RM60,000 per year for Malaysian students and RM70,000 per year for international students.

Dr Dilip Mutum, Associate Professor of Marketing, and Dr Mamunur Rashid, Assistant Professor of Finance, are co-editors of a new book on Islamic finance, marketing, and management, together with Dr Mohammad Mohsin Butt, Associate Professor of Marketing at Curtin University Malaysia.
The book, entitled 'Advances in Islamic Finance, Marketing, and Management: An Asian Perspective', is published by Emerald Publishing.
The volume contains contributions from 35 experts and is targeted at both academics and practitioners who are interested in and are involved in making Shariah-centric strategies.

The book is divided into three sections: Islamic equity and mutual funds, risk and performance of Islamic banks, long-term investment and Sukuk, the dynamics of credit portfolios, financial crimes in an Islamic perspective; Islamic marketing theory, halal marketing in several Asian markets, halal logistics; management of Zakat institutions, corporate social responsibility in Islamic organizations.

Professor Claire O’Malley and Professor Fon Sim Ong were recently appointed as Deans of the Faculty of Science and Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

Professor Claire O’Malley started her career at the University of Nottingham UK in 1989 and holds a doctorate in Education and a Bachelor's degree in Psychology & Philosophy from the University of Leeds, UK.
Professor Fon Sim Ong has more than 20 years of experience in academia in the Malaysian higher education sector and joined UNMC as the Professor of Marketing in May this year.
The Bachelor of Arts Honours in Education (TESOL) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a full-time 3-year program starting in September 2025.
The Malaysian fee for the Education (TESOL) program is RM42,000 per year, while the international fee is RM50,000 per year.

The Education (TESOL) program equips students with skills to support language learners and promote inclusive educational practices by combining linguistics, educational theories, technology, pedagogy, and content knowledge.
Nottingham is ranked 47th globally for Education and Training according to the QS World University Rankings by Subject 2024.
The Education (TESOL) program encourages critical comparisons of global education systems and prepares graduates for diverse educational settings.
The program offers a pathway to further teaching qualifications in regions not requiring Qualified Teacher Status.
The Education (TESOL) program modules cover topics like behaviour and classroom management, education and society, special education needs, curriculum studies, and literacy in school and society.
Entry requirements for the program include A Level CCC, IB Diploma 24 points overall, STPM C+C+C+, UEC 5 B4s, Australian Year 12 ATAR 74, and other qualifications as listed.
English language requirements like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or English Literature grades are specified for admission.
The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is mentioned as a pathway to progress to undergraduate degrees at UNM.

The Malaysia Campus of the University of Nottingham is located in Semenyih, 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with various facilities including schools, sports center, library, and student accommodation.

Career opportunities for graduates of the Education (TESOL) program include roles such as Teacher, Curriculum Planner/Developer, Educational Consultant, Instructional Designer, and Education Entrepreneur.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia participated in the 27th Intervarsity Biochemistry Seminar alongside 10 other universities.
The 27th Intervarsity Biochemistry Seminar was hosted by UPM on May 14th with a theme of 'Where Life meets Sciences'.

Miss Wong Xin Yi won the best oral presentation at the 27th Intervarsity Biochemistry Seminar with the title 'Enhancement of bone cell growth and differentiation by using nanocomposite scaffolds with incorporation of Lignosus rhinocerus'.

Miss Ling Sii Gii won the best poster presentation at the 27th Intervarsity Biochemistry Seminar with the title 'Assessing antifungal activity of zinc oxide nanoparticles against Saccharomyces cerevisiae'.
The two students from the University of Nottingham Malaysia who won the first prizes for oral and poster presentations were supervised by Prof. Sandy Loh, Dr. Lim Siew Shee, and Dr. Yuh-Fen Pung.

Tim Gocher, Honorary Professor of Sustainable Business at Nottingham University Business School Malaysia and Chairman of the Dolma Impact Fund, speaks to MBA students from NUBS Malaysia, Singapore and Nottingham University Business School UK on the 'Role of the Private Sector in Rebuilding a Post-Crisis Nation', on 1 June 2015.
Tim highlighted the severe economic impact of the earthquake on Nepal, where economic losses could amount to as much as USD10 billion, or approximately 50% of Nepal's GDP.

The fund was established with support from the UK government through its Department for International Development, and targets positive financial returns alongside social and environmental outcomes, thus not being reliant on aid.
It is also promoting ecotourism with a focus on 'Treks to Rebuild Communities' through its eco-tourism arm, Dolma Ecotourism.

In working with the Government of Nepal on efforts in rebuilding the nation, Tim emphasises the need to build strong local firms in conjunction with aid income, in the areas of construction, power, tourism, and agriculture.
The Dolma Foundation aims to work in conjunction with banks, the British Embassy in Kathmandu, and the Investment Board of Nepal/the Nepal Ministry of Finance.

Ungku Maryam Jamilah Binti Ungku Mohsin, a standout PhD candidate at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM), has won the 2024 Three Minute Thesis (3MT®) competition with her presentation on the effects of microplastics on respiratory health.

Maryam's track record began in 2021 as a Biomedical Science (BMS) student at UNM, where she won awards for her pitch and project proposal exploring the link between air pollution and COVID-19-induced respiratory complications in Malaysia.
Maryam excelled in the Rapid Oral Presentation category at the Malaysian Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (MSBMB) conference.

Our university has a site license of EndNote which allows for EndNote to be installed on every computer on the campus. All Students and Faculty members have the right to use EndNote outside of campus, even on your personal computers. This is covered under the site license.
EndNote Online is accessible on the web from any location, and you can easily transfer references between EndNote and EndNote Online.
EndNote Online is available to all staff and students at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
No. Contact your School for more information on the referencing style you should be using.

Sometimes you may want to exclude an author from an in-text citation, so for example when you insert a reference it might usually say: 'The theory XYZ demonstrates this ... (Smith, 2002).' However, you wish to write this in a different format, e.g. 'Smith (2002) describes Theory XYZ which demonstrates this...'.

Close down all the Browser windows where you are logged into EndNote Web Delete all temporary internet files and cookies Open EndNote Web again at http://www.myendnoteweb.com Try Word again and Find Citation.
You can change the author order using the Edit Citation feature within Word.
You'll need to amend the output style. When amending output styles it is usually a good idea to save a copy rather than overwriting the original output style.

You can do this by amending your output style: Choose Edit Output Style Edit the relevant Output style Click on the Title Capitalization in the Bibliography section Choose 'Sentence style capitalization'.

Jee-Hou Ho received his B.Eng (Hons) and M.Eng degree in mechanical and production engineering from Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore and PhD degree from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Jee-Hou Ho is an Associate Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia in the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering.

Dr. Ho is a Chartered Engineer of the Engineering Council UK, a member of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE), a member of Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and a graduate engineer registered with the Board of Engineers Malaysia (BEM).
Jee-Hou Ho's teaching includes courses such as Statics and Dynamics, Advanced Dynamics and Vibration, Robotics and Automation Technology, Group Design Project, and MSc/MEng/BEng Individual Project.
Jee-Hou Ho has published over 90 papers in peer-reviewed journals, conferences, and book chapters, and co-authored a book titled 'Applied Engineering Failure Analysis: Theory and Practice'.

Computer science graduates are in demand in Malaysia due to the nation's growing digital economy and technology industry, with initiatives by the government to develop the sector.

University of Nottingham Malaysia offers mentorship programs to boost participation of women in science.
Mentorship is described as a two-way relationship that offers a human aspect and requires mutual trust.
Dr. Ho Weang Kee, an Associate Professor at the School of Mathematical Sciences, emphasizes the importance of a positive attitude and willingness to learn in a mentor-mentee relationship.

Dr. New Siu Yee, an Associate Professor at the School of Pharmacy, advises mentees to be sincere, open to opportunities, and emphasizes the importance of mentor support in staying persistent in the science field.
Dr. Alison Kim Shan Wee, an Assistant Professor at the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences, stresses the significance of being reliable, persistent, and committed in a mentorship.
Challenges in mentorship include communication, self-confidence, overcoming doubts, and maintaining a connection across geographic differences.
Mentorship is viewed as essential for advancing women and girls in science, promoting greater participation among the younger generation.

Siew Yee Lau is an Assistant Professor at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM).

The Applied Psychology MPhil/PhD program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers full-time options of 1-2 years for MPhil and 3-4 years for PhD, as well as part-time options of 2-4 years for MPhil and 6-8 years for PhD.
The program has multiple intakes in February, April, June, and September 2025.

The entry requirements for the Applied Psychology MPhil/PhD program include a master's degree in a relevant discipline related to applied psychology for PhD applicants, and an upper second-class honours degree in a relevant discipline for MPhil applicants.
English language requirements for the program include a minimum IELTS score of 6.5 with no less than 6.0 in each element, or equivalent scores in TOEFL, PTE, or MUET.
Malaysian students are charged RM50,000 per year for the program, while international students are charged RM56,000 per year.

The Semenyih Campus of the University of Nottingham Malaysia is located 48km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and offers facilities such as business, education, science, and engineering schools, a sports center, library, and student accommodation.
The University's Career Advisory Services (CAS) provides support for students' career development, offering resources, guidance, and connections to employers and industries.
The program director is actively involved in providing career advice to students.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia works with a number of international academic services, educational agencies and counselors in countries across the globe to help students find the right course and offer support and advice through the application process.
Staff at the University's International Office work closely with all representatives, ensuring they provide up-to-date advice on scholarships, visa applications, and admission deadlines.

Dr Lau Chee Kwong, Dean of Nottingham University Business School at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, will conduct a webinar on Accounting Considerations of the Covid-19 Pandemic and Economic Recession on Thursday 30 April 2020 from 2pm to 3pm.

The webinar will cover topics such as impairment of assets, impairment of financial assets, government grants, onerous contracts, fair value measurement, accounting estimates, and measurement uncertainties.
The online webinar is organized by the Malaysian Institute of Accountants (MIA) and is complimentary for all MIA members.
For more information, please email swu@mia.org.my.

The new textbook on Resource Conservation, 'Process Integration for Resource Conservation,' was written by Professor Ir Dr Dominic C. Y. Foo from the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus and published by CRC Press.

The book aims to provide final year undergraduate and postgraduate chemical and environmental engineering students with systematic design techniques for resource conservation and serves as a valuable reference tool for industry players aiming for cost savings and resource conservation.
A PVC plant in Malaysia saved RM 150,000 on water bills and achieved a 30 percent reduction in fresh water feed by employing process integration techniques highlighted in Professor Foo's new book.
Professor Foo's book launch took place during the 15th Conference on Process Integration, Modelling and Optimisation for Energy Saving and Pollution Reduction (PRES 2012) in Prague, Czech Republic.

Professor Foo's book was also launched at the 4th International Conference on Chemical and Bioprocess Engineering (ICCBPE 2012) in conjunction with the 26th Symposium of Malaysian Chemical Engineers (SOMChE 2012) in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, Malaysia.

Professor Ir Dr Dominic C. Y. Foo is the Professor of Process Design and Integration at the Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering and the Director for the Centre of Excellence for Green Technologies at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

Professor Foo's book is accompanied by free worksheets and calculation files that can be downloaded from the publisher’s website and includes a prototype software named RCNet for setting benchmarked targets on waste reduction in process plants.

SNS is a high-speed internet link for students living in the halls of residences of The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
All campus halls have access points that broadcast WLAN connection to the residents.

To connect to SNS, students need to go to Wi-Fi settings on their device, select 'eduroam', enter their University username followed by @nottingham.edu.my, enter their University password, and accept the certificate if prompted.

For Android/iPhone/iPad devices, specific instructions need to be followed including selecting 'PEAP' in EAP method, selecting 'Do not verify/validate' or 'None' in the CA certificate field, selecting 'MSCHAPv2' in Phase-2 authentication, and using the university's email as Identity and password.

For further assistance with SNS, students can contact the SNS Helpdesk @ Nexus Hall, email sns@nottingham.edu.my, visit the web support page snshelp.nottingham.edu.my, or contact the phone support at 03-8924 8085.

Overseas exam arrangements are only made for students who are normally resident overseas and have external resits, have been given permission by the International Office under mobility arrangements, have to be overseas during the exam period as a requirement of their course, or other exceptional circumstances approved on an individual case basis.
Overseas exam arrangements will not be made for students who are on holiday or temporarily overseas during the published examination periods.

The University resit fee is RM50.00 (if you are taking first sits only, this charge does not apply). Administrative fee is RM300.00 per examination period regardless of the number of individual examinations taken in that session.

Nottingham's first civic college was opened in the city centre in 1881, four years after the foundation stone was laid by former Prime Minister, W E Gladstone.
An anonymous benefactor offered £10,000 for a college on condition that a suitable building be erected by the Council and that the college should be provided with £4,000 a year.

After the First World War, the college outgrew its original building. A generous gift by Sir Jesse Boot of 35 acres of land at Highfields presented the solution, and in 1928, the College moved to what is now the main campus, University Park.
The College was initially accommodated in the elegant Trent Building and was officially opened by King George V in November of that year.
In 1948, the college was awarded the Royal Charter and became The University of Nottingham, now able to award degrees in its own name.
During this period, the School of Agriculture was established when the Midland College of Agriculture at Sutton Bonington merged with the University.
The University of Nottingham continued to grow and still focuses on its development and has a number of campuses in the UK and overseas.

The Bachelor of Arts with Honours in International Communication Studies with Performing Arts is a three-year, full-time programme designed to explore the dynamic relationship between communication, media, and the performing arts on a global scale. Students will engage with the psychological, cultural, political, and economic factors shaping international communications.

The curriculum combines theoretical knowledge with practical skills, offering a deep understanding of communication theories, media, and the performing arts industries. A core element is the study of a European or Asian language, enhancing linguistic proficiency and cultural awareness.
Performing Arts Expertise: Hone your creative skills in drama, theatre, and performance while understanding their cultural significance across diverse contexts.
Language Proficiency: Specialise in a global language—French, Japanese, Mandarin, Spanish, German, or Korean—building effective communication skills for multilingual, multicultural environments.
Adaptive Career Prospects: Develop versatile skills in public relations, digital media, and creative writing, preparing you for careers in media, cultural policy, and performing arts.
Interdisciplinary Approach: Explore media production, cultural analysis, and communication theories, equipping yourself for diverse career paths with confidence and creativity.
Global Perspective: Study international communications within a global context, understanding the cultural, political, and economic forces shaping the media landscape.
The BCC (excluding Critical Thinking and General Studies) is a required A Level entry qualification for the program.
An overall yield of 24 points is needed for the IB Diploma.
For Australian Year 12, an ATAR of 78 with consideration for relevant subjects is required.
The Malaysian student fee for the program is RM42,000 per year.

Assistant Professor Guy Burton presented a paper entitled How do Palestinians perceive China’s rise? at a workshop organized by the China Policy Institute (CPI) at Nottingham University in the UK and Durham University.

The workshop intended to examine China’s strategic interests in the Middle East, especially in the wake of Beijing’s establishment of its ‘One Belt, One Road’ and Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank projects.
Dr. Burton was one of seven panellists invited to give a presentation at the workshop.
A version of the paper Dr. Burton presented is available as a working paper by the CPI.
Dr. Burton is revising the paper for publication as a chapter in a book based on the workshop, which should be available next year.
International Exchange students from partner Universities are exempted from paying tuition fees to the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Application deadline: 1 May for Autumn or full-year intake, and 1 October for Spring intake.
Visa application deadline: 1 May for Autumn or full year, and 1 October for Spring intake.

International Exchange applicants must be current students at a university or college of higher education from abroad, having completed one year of study with a minimum GPA of at least 3.0 (or equivalent).
All international mobility students studying in Malaysia will need to obtain a Student Mobility Pass.

International students are required to have medical insurance coverage throughout their period of study in Malaysia, arranged through the Group Hospital and Surgical Insurance Programme of the University.
The estimated monthly expenses for an international student living in Malaysia range from RM2,500 to 3,500, covering accommodation, meals, utilities, local transportation, and entertainment.

Dr Ho Weang Kee, Associate Professor of the Faculty of Science and Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia, has been awarded a prestigious Wellcome Trust Career Development Award (WTCDA) totalling GBP £1.92 million (RM11.3 million) to develop novel breast cancer risk stratification and communication methods in diverse Asian populations.

Dr Ho plans to refine breast cancer risk assessment in the Asian population through developing innovative methods to harness valuable insights from existing, less powerful datasets in underrepresented populations.

The Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) offers an in-depth exploration of how brain function shapes behaviour and cognition. This degree emphasizes hands-on learning, offering opportunities to use advanced technologies and experimental techniques.
Graduates are equipped to pursue further studies or careers in areas like clinical psychology, neurotechnology, education, or cognitive science.

The entrance requirements for the BSc (Hons) in Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience at the University of Nottingham Malaysia include various qualifications such as A Level, IB Diploma, STPM, UEC, Australian Year 12, Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD), Gaokao, Senior High School Diploma, Senior School Certificate Examination, Advance Placement (AP), Diploma from Local Institutions, Foundation from Local Institutions, and Nottingham's Foundation Programme.

English language requirements for the program include IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, GCE A Level English Language or Literature, SPM, GCSE O-Level, IGCSE, MUET, IB English, OSSD English, and CBSE/CISCE Class XII or Class X.

The Nottingham's Foundation Programme is a 1-year pre-university course that prepares students for direct progression to UNM’s undergraduate degrees, enhancing language, critical thinking, and study skills.

The Seemly Campus of the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a range of facilities including business, education, science, and engineering schools, a sports center, library, student accommodation, and public transport options like shuttle services and taxi/Grab services.

Keely Ong Xin Rong graduated from University of Nottingham Malaysia studying Applied Psychology and Management in 2023.
Keely secured a position as a Service Executive at UOB Singapore shortly after her graduation.
Keely shared advice for current students on navigating their career path after graduation.
Keely mentioned that the Applied Psychology and Management (APM) courses at UNM provided a blend of essential business-centered and psychology modules.
Keely highlighted the importance of updating and building her LinkedIn profile to market herself to potential employers.
Keely's diligence in updating her LinkedIn profile led to job opportunities, including a job offer from UOB Singapore during her final semester at Nottingham.
Keely mentioned being asked about her internship experiences and involvement in clubs and societies during job interviews.
Keely decided to take up the role with UOB Singapore for a fresh start and learning opportunities in a new city.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia campus was opened in Malaysia in 2000.
A purpose-built park campus was opened in Semenyih, Malaysia in September 2005.
In 2015, the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus celebrated its 15th year anniversary.
In September 2004, a purpose-built campus was opened in Ningbo, China, as part of a joint venture.
The University became the first foreign university to establish an independent campus in China.

Dr Linda Quayle gave a plenary address at the second conference of the Philippines International Studies Organization (PHISO) in Davao.
The title of Dr. Quayle's presentation was 'The role of great powers in shaping regions: Hegemony, alliances, and Southeast Asia'.
The larger collaboration is led by Dr. Matteo Dian (University of Bologna) and Dr. Hugo Meijer (European University Institute).
Dr. Quayle also participated in the PHISO International Book Workshop, along with other Series Editors for the Routledge 'International Relations in Southeast Asia' book series.
The object of the Workshop was to hear and give feedback on proposals for book chapters and monographs.
Virtual reality is used in the teaching curriculum at the School of Pharmacy by Dr. Jim Chai.
Dr. Jim Chai collaborated with Dr. Wong Ying Jing from the Faculty of Science and Engineering on the virtual reality project.
Postgraduate students in the School of Computer Science are creating a standalone app for the virtual reality headset.
Virtual reality is aimed at enhancing practical competencies and professional knowledge of pharmacy students.
The pandemic has increased the interest in virtual reality for education and skills development.
Dr. Jim Chai aims to expand the virtual pharmacy project to include simulating a virtual customer.
The School of Biosciences and the School of Geography are offering two new scholarships for the BSc Environmental Science and MSc Environmental Monitoring and Management programs.
The BSc Environmental Science program at the School of Biosciences is a three-year program that focuses on developing a fundamental scientific understanding of environmental and ecological processes.

Two University of Nottingham scholarships are available for the BSc Environmental Science program. Applicants must be Malaysian nationals with good A levels, and the scholarship covers fees for the first year only.
The MSc Environmental Monitoring and Management program at the School of Geography is a one-year full or part-time program designed for graduates in science or environmentally related subjects.

Two University of Nottingham scholarships are available for full-time study in the MSc Environmental Monitoring and Management program. Applicants must be Malaysian nationals with a first or upper second class degree in a relevant subject.
For more information about the scholarships, contact Salma Abd Kadir at Salma.AbdKadir@nottingham.edu.my or phone at +603 8924 8201.
The scholarships were announced on 16th August 2011.

The Politics of Economics and the Economics of Politicians (Nottingham Advantage Award module) complements our Economics course well as it covers numerous things we've learned in class, such as free trade and growth through technological progress i.e. the Solow growth model, so it was fun to apply the knowledge outside the class.
Two current first year students, Athirah Alffian and Veenitha Balachandran took the course and shared their thoughts.
The inseparable relationship between politics and economics, elucidated with examples of world leaders and economists who affect their local and world economies, are highlighted in this course.
A very intriguing feature is the comments section after every chapter, that showcases different economic perspectives from different participants.
The discussions were engaging and required critical thinking from every participant.
Overall, this module was a comprehensive professional experience and I learnt a lot from it.

The topic of the essay competition is: “What would be the economic consequences for Malaysia if technology replaces 50% of current jobs in the country? Who would benefit, and who would lose? Would we be better off ultimately?”
The essay competition is open to all pre-university and high school students in Malaysia.
The closing date is 1 June 2021, Tuesday.
First prize: RM 1,000.00
Second prize: RM 800.00
Third prize: RM 600.00
Three consolation prizes: RM 350.00 each
Winning essays will also be published in the World Bank's 'Development Digest' publication.
First prize: Gwendolyn Chan Hui Pei (SMK Batu Lintang, Kuching, STPM) - essay
Second prize: Lee Ricson (Hin Hua High School) - essay
Third prize: Oah Xin Yi and Shyla Sharma (Inti International College Penang, Cambridge A Levels) - essay
Consolation prizes (in no particular order): Alex Peter (Institut Pendidikan Guru Kampus Bahasa Antarabangsa, Program Persediaan Ijazah Sarjana Muda Penguruan) - essay
Consolation prizes (in no particular order): Chung Po Ching Stephenie (Tenby International School) - essay

For the first time in history, the University of Nottingham will hold a virtual graduation ceremony for all three of its campuses in the UK, China and Malaysia.
The event will be made even more memorable with the attendance of Nottingham alumni and ambassadors in this 24-hour global celebration.
The virtual festival will kick off at 10am Malaysian time on 24 July 2020 with various activities online to mark the celebration.
Students will graduate in absentia and their certificates will be sent to them due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
UNM’s Provost and CEO, Professor Graham Kendall, will deliver an online graduation speech.
Messages from various deans and staff members will be shared during the virtual celebration.
The celebration will end with messages from University of Nottingham Chancellor Baroness Young of Hornsey OBE and Vice-Chancellor Professor Shearer West.

In Malaysia, in 2008 373,047 road accidents and 6,527 fatalities were recorded.
Road accidents represent the fifth highest cause of death in Malaysia per year.
Hazard perception (HP) tests typically involve participants watching videos of driving scenes filmed from a driver's viewpoint.
The project will directly compare hazard perception skills in Malaysian and UK drivers.
Dr. Elizabeth Sheppard in the School of Psychology (Malaysia) and Dr. David Crundall in the School of Psychology (UK) are collaborating on the project.
Eye movements of participants while watching the videos will be recorded using state-of-the-art eye-tracking technology.

The Language Centre at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offers high-quality language learning to more than 200 students from all departments across the University.

The Language Centre's teaching philosophy emphasizes communicative teaching, a balance between listening, reading, speaking, and writing, and utilizing a variety of resources such as textbooks, videos, multimedia materials, and self-access resources.
The Language Centre staff at the University of Nottingham Malaysia come from many countries and professional backgrounds, enhancing opportunities for learners through a diverse teaching team.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Language Centre is committed to enabling learners to use the target language effectively for communication, expression, and cultural adaptation.
The Language Centre at the University of Nottingham Malaysia focuses on developing students' language abilities through a combination of listening, reading, speaking, and writing exercises in class.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Language Centre aims to create a dynamic learning environment where teaching methods and materials are drawn from staff members' strengths and are supported by technology.

The School of Education at the University of Nottingham Malaysia organized a study tour to Epsom College in Malaysia on Monday, 7 November 2016.

Students had interactive discussions about Epsom's aspirations and the core values of teaching and learning.

The school tour provided students with new insights and perspectives for their future career.

Scientists have discovered a way to create disease fighting proteins from tobacco plants which could lead to the development of a vaccine for Dengue Fever.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia team of scientists are working on a project to create a plant-based vaccine for Dengue Fever.
The project has produced a vaccine antigen (protein) within the plant that neutralises the Dengue virus.
The agroinfiltration method allows for rapid development of vaccines.
For developing countries, developing cost-effective vaccines from plants could have significant impacts in combating endemic diseases and saving lives.

Over 600 delegates consisting of broadcasters, media practitioners, and educators from more than 50 countries and territories met at the two-day 8th Asia Media Summit to discuss the consequences and implications of the digital media landscape.
The Asia Media Summit was organized by the Asia-Pacific Institute for Broadcasting Development (AIDB) and hosted by the Voice of Vietnam (VOV) in Ha Noi, Vietnam.
Dr. Joanne Lim from the School of Modern Languages and Cultures represented the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus at the Summit.
Dr. Lim participated in pre-event workshops on 'Media Quality Management', 'Broadcasting for All: Focusing on Gender', and 'Capacity-Building and Training Strategies in the Digital Media Landscape'.

The Summit explored digitalization, changing consumer experiences, training, accessibility, connectivity, gender equality, media representation, traditional versus new media, and social media empowerment.
Mr. Toshiyuki Sato and Mr. Tadashi Ideishi from Nippon Hoso Kyokai (NHK), Japan led a discussion on 'Media and Disaster: Japanese Experience'.
Mr. Saed Abu-Hijleh from the Center for Global Consciousness, Palestine discussed control over the media and activism in relation to the digital divide.
Mr. Rajendra Shende (United Nations Environment Programme, UNEP) emphasized the power of social media in addressing global issues like climate change and poverty.
Ms. Sopit Wangvivatana from Thai Public Broadcasting Service (Thai PBS) highlighted the importance of community voices and digital media during political turmoil.
Mr. Anothai Udomsilp from Thai PBS emphasized accountability, credibility, and commitment to society in broadcasting.

University of Nottingham Malaysia offers Foundation, Undergraduate, and Postgraduate courses for international students with different fee payment structures.
International students can pay their fees in various ways, including 100% of one academic year fee upon registration or 50% at the beginning of each semester.

Payment categories for Postgraduate students include Masters Level, School of Education, MSc Management Psychology, MSc Finance and Investment, MBA Part-Time, and School of Political, History and International Relations.
Payment methods for fees include NottinghamHub, crossed cheque, bank draft, credit/debit card, and bank transfers.
Effective immediately, funds from certain sanctioned countries will not be accepted by the University's bankers.
The University has partnered with Flywire for international payment processing to ensure timely and full payments.
A 2.5% early payment discount is available for students who pay the full academic year fee before or on August 31st, 2024.
The University has a refund policy based on a percentage basis with step reductions depending on the number of days from the start of registration/session.
Students can opt for an instalment plan if facing financial difficulties and can explore sponsorship/scholarship support options.
Important deadlines for tuition fee payments are specified for different courses and semesters.
Late penalties will be imposed for failure to settle outstanding tuition fees, and late applications for installment plans will not be accepted.
For inquiries regarding payment of tuition fees, students can contact the Finance Office via phone or email during specified operating hours.

All international students will not be required to do a pre-arrival medical examination, but must fill up and sign-off on the ‘HEALTH DECLARATION FORM’.
You are allowed to appeal your post-medical once but it is subject to the approval by EMGS.
The Visa Approval Letter or VAL is a letter issued by the Malaysian Immigration Department when your visa application is successful.
Students from some countries are required to apply for a Single Entry Visa (SEV) additionally to enter Malaysia with a VAL.
Education Malaysia Global Services or EMGS is the private body appointed by the Ministry of Higher Education to process all international student pass applications.
Incoming international students can apply for their Visa Approval Letter (VAL) via the UNM Visa Office or directly to EMGS.
Current students must renew their visa at least 4 months before their current student pass expires.
The UNM Visa Office provides Student Pass assistance to international students and can be contacted for support during the visa application process.
International students issued a Student Pass must renew their medical insurance on a yearly basis.
Contact the UNM Visa Office via email at apply.visa@nottingham.edu.my (new students) or visarenewal@nottingham.edu.my (returning students) or by phone at +603 8924 8075 or 8924 8078.

The internship is offered by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Indonesia for a duration of 6 months.
The internship is open to those who are enrolled in a postgraduate degree in a relevant field at the time of application.
Competencies required include commitment to UNV/UNDP mission, knowledge sharing, finance and accounting skills, and leadership qualities.

Minimum qualifications required for the internship include enrollment in a graduate-level degree program, knowledge of international relations and UN system coordination, interpersonal and communication skills, initiative-taking ability, diplomacy, fluency in English, and computer literacy.
Interns are not financially remunerated by the RC Office, and all costs related to participation must be borne by the nominating institution or the student.
The application deadline for this internship is Tuesday, 20th August 2013.

OLLE is the short name for the Peer Supported Online Language Learning Exchange – at UNNC it is a very special NAA – for one thing it was the first NAA here to be designed in partnership with students and for the past two years it has continued to be managed and delivered with student partners.
The Vis-à-vis student organization plays a huge contribution to student life and experience at UNNC as it supports buddying coaching and peer learning and makes a big contribution to OLLE.
OLLE is about learning to learn together beyond linguistic, cultural and geographical barriers.
With OLLE students from UNUK, UNMC and UNNC learn to learn a language together online.
The focus of OLLE is on developing a strong set of language learning strategies for life.
Mostly OLLE is about empowering yourselves to take control of your language learning and to discover new ways of learning.
OLLE is a tri campus NAA you too can join.
The deadline for applications for students at UNUK and UNMC is on 7 October 2016, Friday. OLLE will start on 3 October 2016, Thursday.
To apply for this module, kindly fill in the online application.
You can contact Marion Sadoux for more information on this module.

Watching the Watchdog 2.0 was a media monitoring project at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The project analyzed media coverage of the 14th general election in Malaysia.
Key findings from the 2018 media coverage analysis show bias in state-owned and some private media aligned with the ruling coalition.
Media coverage of the election focused more on parties and politicians rather than policies.
The project findings have been used for academic conferences and collaborations related to media reforms.
Post-GE14, there were resignations in the media, coinciding with changes in government leadership.
The project was funded by Open Society Foundations and Bersih and Adil Network Sdn Bhd.
University of Nottingham Malaysia provided the environment for conducting data analysis for the project.

All international students who defer, withdraw, terminated, and completed studies are required to shorten/cancel their present student pass before leaving the country.
Students who are progressing from one year to another of a course must renew their student pass.
An attendance of no less than 80% and obtaining a pass in all modules are required for student pass renewal.
Students are advised to submit their passport for student pass renewal at least four (4) months before the expiry of their current pass.
The student pass renewal fee is RM1,250 and payable after the renewal.
Students who do not qualify for student pass renewal include those who are NOT progressing to the following year and those who change to another course not the same as the earlier issued VAL.

Professor Andy Long will become the new Provost and Deputy Vice-Chancellor (DVC) of the University of Nottingham, from 1 July 2018.
As DVC Professor Long will lead operational planning and academic resources across the University and support the Vice-Chancellor in providing strategic leadership for the University.
He will line manage the five Faculty Pro-Vice-Chancellors and work with the Provosts of the University's China and Malaysia campuses to ensure a joined-up approach to our global operations.
Professor Long has studied and worked at the University since 1990 and is currently Pro-Vice-Chancellor of the Faculty of Engineering.
Vice-Chancellor Professor Shearer West mentioned, 'I am delighted that Andy will be our next Provost and Deputy Vice-Chancellor.'

Professor Long said, 'I am absolutely delighted to have been appointed to this role, and look forward to working with Shearer and with the University community to address the challenges that we face.'
Recruitment to the role of Pro-Vice-Chancellor for the Faculty of Engineering will commence shortly.

The Centre for English Language and Foundation Education (CELFE) recently hosted 16 students from Hanyang University, South Korea for a 2-week winter programme at the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus in Semenyih.

Dr Chee Kwong Lau is an Associate Professor of Accounting in the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Dr Lau specializes in International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) for corporate reporting.
Dr Lau has a Doctorate of Philosophy (PhD) in Accounting, a Master of Business Administration (MBA), and a Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) specialized in Finance.
Dr Lau is a Fellow member of the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (FCCA) and a Chartered Accountant of the Malaysian Institute of Accountants (CA).

Dr. Ahimsa Campos-Arceiz is an Associate Professor at UNMC’s School of Geography.
Scientists do a substantial amount of their work late at night and on weekends, with this work outside of normal hours increasing at about 5-6% per year.
Working habits vary across the globe, with Japanese, Chinese, and Indian scientists working hardest, submitting nearly 40% of their manuscripts outside regular office hours.
Belgian and Norwegian scientists did not work much on weekends, Finnish scientists did not work at night, and American and British scientists had average work habits.

Students interested in participating in the exchange program for Year 2025/2026 (Full Year/Autumn) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus can proceed with the online application by entering their UNM username and password.
The deadline for the online application for Inter-campus exchange to UK or China Campus & Selected University Partners for 2025/2026 is 28 February 2025.
There are penalties for withdrawal cases after acceptance into the program, except for visa rejection or school rejection, including a penalty of RM1,000 charged to the student's tuition account.
For international students applying for the exchange program, they are responsible for their Malaysian student visa requirements and can seek assistance from the UNM Visa Office.

Students from the same nationality as the host campus are not eligible to apply for the exchange program, and there are limited quotas for certain schools within the Faculty of Science and Business School.

UNM will not be responsible for any changes in SOP by the Government of Malaysia or the host country that may affect the exchange, and students are responsible for any risks during the exchange process.

The Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering and the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering (M3) organised an unprecedented alumni day on 5 September.

The Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering organised activities for their alumni on campus, including a workshop, badminton match, pub quiz, magic and musical talent activities, and a steamboat dinner.
The Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering alumni day included performances, games, alumni sharing sessions, a buffet lunch, and a photography session.
Alumni at both events enjoyed catching up with old friends and making new ones.
"I found that the courses were very good and helped me a lot in my current work. I also got to know many new friends and have very good experiences," said Lau Tze Yang (Mechanical Engineering,2014).

For Praveen (Chemical and Environmental Engineering, 2006), returning to campus was an emotional experience. "I had a solo campus tour just before attending this event. The campus has had many positive changes and I miss being around here. Nottingham means a lot to me," he said.

The University of Nottingham is one of the top choices for graduate recruitment among UK employers, coming 2nd in the list of universities targeted by the largest number of top employers in 2014-2015.
The majority of top employers have targeted between just 10 and 25 universities each for the 2014/15 recruitment period.

Top institutions like Manchester, Nottingham, Warwick, Cambridge, and Oxford have attracted the largest number of top graduate recruiters for campus fairs, recruitment presentations, and other local university promotions.
The number of graduates hired by organizations in The Times Top 100 Graduate Employers rose by 7.9% in 2014, showing the largest annual rise in four years.
The leading employers plan to expand their graduate recruitment further in 2015 with 8.1% more entry-level vacancies than the previous year.

International students who enter Malaysia on a student visa have few opportunities to undertake paid employment.
You are only allowed to work 20 hours per week during semester breaks only.
Guidelines for part-time work: International students are allowed to work on a part-time basis during semester breaks in sectors such as restaurants, petrol kiosks, mini markets, and hotels.

Application process for approval: International students must submit a supporting letter, photocopy of passport pages, offer letter from the employer, academic calendar, and supporting letter from the Dean/Head of School to the Immigration Department for approval.
The University must report students who do not attend classes to the Immigration Department.
The extension of the approval to work will only be given if the student maintains good academic achievement.
Foreign students can work for a maximum of 20 hours per week during semester breaks or holidays.
Foreign students are eligible to work off-campus in Malaysia in sectors like restaurants, petrol kiosks, mini markets, and hotels.

The Library will be implementing a new flexible loan system, in line with the libraries in UON and UNNC after migrating to the current library management system.
Effective from 30th August 2019, all items in your library account will automatically be renewed daily, unless there is a request for a particular item.
Under the new flexible loan system: there will no longer be items on short loan.
All borrowed items will be issued out for seven days, unless the item is in high demand, in which case, the patron will only get the item for two days.
Books on loan will automatically be renewed daily unless an item has been requested, or the borrower’s library account has an overdue item, or has accumulated fines of RM20 and above.
If there is a request for a borrowed item, a notification email will be sent to the patron.
For hold requests of multiple copies, patrons only need to request by title, and the system will choose the next available copy for the patron.
Patrons will be fined for overdue books requested by another patron. The fine for overdue items will be RM1 per day, per item.
Baroness Young of Hornsey OBE has been appointed as the University of Nottingham's new Chancellor, succeeding Sir Andrew Witty.
Baroness Young is a Crossbench peer and anti-slavery campaigner who works on legislation to eliminate modern slavery.

Baroness Young serves on the boards of national cultural organizations and chaired the Young Review and Agenda, addressing racial disproportionality and vulnerability of traumatised women in the justice system.
Baroness Young has accepted an Honorary Professorship with the Rights Lab and the School of Politics and International Relations at the University of Nottingham.
Baroness Young's role as Chancellor includes ceremonial duties, graduation ceremonies, and acting as an ambassador and strategic adviser for the University in the UK and overseas.
Baroness Young's appointment as Chancellor follows a nomination process involving staff, students, and alumni of the University of Nottingham.
Baroness Young's appointment as Chancellor is an unremunerated role.
Baroness Young succeeds Sir Andrew Witty, former CEO of GlaxoSmithKline, as Chancellor of the University of Nottingham.
Baroness Young's appointment is seen as contributing to the University's strategy of nurturing world-leading talent to create solutions for improving lives globally.

Under Sustainable Food Systems, the subthemes include Advancing Postharvest Technology for Food Quality, Innovating Agrifood Systems for Greater Efficiency, Developing Climate-Resilient and Smart Crops, Conserving and Utilising Agrobiodiversity, Integrating Urban Agriculture for Sustainable Food Systems, Leveraging Underutilised Crops for Food Security, Harnessing Beneficial Microbes for Sustainability, and Creating Novel Functional Foods and Feeds.

Under Advanced Nutrition for Lifelong Health, the subthemes include Advancing gastrointestinal health, Exploring natural product and food-derived bioactive substances for health and disease management, Promoting healthier dietary choices to prevent nutrition-related non-communicable diseases, Transforming obesity intervention through innovative strategies, and Promoting health for future generations through improved maternal and child nutrition and well-being.

Under Cutting-Edge Medical Biotechnology, the subthemes include Revolutionising Combinatorial Cancer Therapies, Synergistic Aptamer-Peptide Innovations, Advancing Vaccines, Biotherapeutic Peptides, and Enzymes, Pioneering Disease Prevention for Sustainable Health, and Molecular Pharming and Beyond for Health Applications.

Anurita Selvarajoo graduated with B.Eng. (Hons) in Civil Engineering (Environmental) from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia in 2006 and received her Ph.D. in Fuels and Sustainability from University of Nottingham Malaysia in 2013.
Anurita Selvarajoo currently works as an Assistant Professor at the Department of Civil Engineering, Faculty of Science and Engineering, University of Nottingham Malaysia.
Anurita Selvarajoo has authored over 50 papers in journals, conference proceedings, online articles, and book chapters.

Anurita Selvarajoo serves as a reviewer for several journals and is an affiliate member of the Young Scientists Network of the Academy of Sciences Malaysia and a graduate member of the Board of Engineers Malaysia and Malaysia Board of Technologies.
Anurita Selvarajoo's teaching responsibilities include modules such as Fundamentals of Materials and Group Design Project Year 1 in the Department of Civil Engineering.
Anurita Selvarajoo contributes to the supervision of Final Year Projects and facilitates workshops like Engineering Drawing, Technical Report Writing, and Concrete Mix Design.

Anurita Selvarajoo has published recent papers on topics such as the performance study of chia seeds and chia flour, utilization of natural plant-based coagulants and flocculants for palm oil mill effluent treatment, and the performance of fenugreek and okra for palm oil mill effluent treatment.

Anurita Selvarajoo's publications also cover areas like bio-pellets production, microalgae for biohydrogen and biogas, slow pyrolysis of agricultural materials, and the application of biochar in plant growth promotion.
Khor Sue Yee is an engineering alumna from University of Nottingham Malaysia and presently, the co-founder of Zero Waste Malaysia, a non-profit organisation that advocates sustainable development.
Zero Waste Malaysia was one of the 13 NGOs that was awarded funds by the Star Foundation.
The foundation has been awarding funds to deserving NGOs since 2004 and since then has awarded a total of RM19.1 million to more than 300 organisations.
The financial support, totaling RM15,000, will be directed to their monthly operational costs.
Many NGOs are suffering because of the lack of public donations and fewer engagements with corporations. This donation will definitely help us support our operational and other costs too.

Zero Waste Malaysia is registered with The Registry of Societies of Malaysia and aims to educate individuals, groups, corporations, and organizations alike to be cognizant and capable of executing their zero waste action plans.
In addition, the NGO gives talks to create engaging and stimulating conversation centered around sustainable living.

The Nottingham University Business School in Malaysia organized a Corporate Social Responsibility professional workshop entitled “CSR, Universal Value and Harmony in Asia”.
The workshop was supported by Integrating Global Society, Nottingham University.
Participants for this workshop were from a variety of stakeholder groups namely, the government, businesses, academia, religious groups and also from NGOs.
Speakers from Korea, China, India and Malaysia who play a pivotal role for pushing the CSR agenda in Asia presented their views at this workshop.
The participants were introduced to the new vocabularies of CSR in the Asian context and learnt about various business cases of CSR in Asia.
The workshop aimed at generating harmony through the CSR lens in the Asian context.
The workshop took place on 23rd June 2011.

While a business degree typically has a few Economics modules as part of its core requirements, a business degree focuses more narrowly on how a business is run, by studying various aspects of a firm such as accounting, human resource, operations, and marketing.
In contrast, a Business Economics degree integrates economic theories with practical business strategies, preparing graduates for strategic decision-making in diverse business environments.

Graduates of NSE Malaysia have been employed by reputable banks such as Alliance Bank, CIMB, Citibank, HSBC, OCBC, UOB, Royal Bank of Scotland, multinational companies such as Axiata Group, Frank Knight, Frost & Sullivan, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, PwC, and Wolters Kluwer as well as policy institutes such as Asia Strategy and Leadership Institute and Bank Negara Malaysia.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia discovered two new species and a new genus of freshwater mussel in Borneo for the first time in almost 100 years.
The discoveries were made in small streams in the Gomantong Forest Reserve, Sabah, and near the village of Kuala Mendalam, Sarawak.
The species are unique to Borneo and represent a new freshwater mussel group, or genus.
The team named the species Khairuloconcha sahanae and Khairuloconcha lunbawangorum.
The findings were published in the journal Aquatic Conservation.
The team also generated the first ever DNA sequence data of Bornean freshwater mussels in 2016.
The discovered mussels are very rare, known only from single sites that are highly threatened by habitat destruction.
The declines of existing populations of freshwater mussels on Borneo are likely due to industrial-scale deforestation and land-use changes.
Freshwater mussels play a crucial role in filtering water and nutrient cycling in freshwater habitats.
The University of Nottingham discovered the mussels during a four-year study in Malaysian Borneo and Brunei.

The Centre for English Language & Foundation Education (CELFE) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia recently organized a four-week immersive learning experience on campus from 2 to 29 July 2023.

The programme modules were designed to encourage active listening, foster student collaboration, and enhance critical thinking.
Participants engaged in classroom activities such as group discussions, role play, and Treasure Hunt to develop communication skills.
A visit to the microalgae lab was arranged for participants pursuing studies in Chemical Engineering.

Participants also explored Kuala Lumpur, visiting Batu Caves, Central Market, and KLCC.
The programme received positive feedback from participants for its well-structured modules and dedicated lecturers.
At the end of the programme, participants bid farewell to UNM and their mentors, cherishing the memories created.

The UNM-Petrosains collaboration in the Human-Computer Interaction module, led by Dr Marina Ng, explored an innovative approach to nurture 21st-century skills, particularly in creativity, collaboration, and communication, by incorporating a HCI Design Challenge as part of students’ learning.

During the 12-week course of study, students learned a user-centered design approach or design thinking process of brainstorming, designing, and prototyping new ideas to redesign some of Petrosains's less popular exhibits, with useful feedback and mentorship provided by the Petrosains Innovation Team.

At the end of the module, students presented their developed group prototypes at Petrosains to a panel of judges in a UNM-Petrosains Design Challenge competition, which experience was highly beneficial and appreciated by the students.

The winning prototypes included an interactive exhibit that used digital projection of oil flow animations and sound that could be activated when someone passes by the Oil Platform station and a 'Guessing the gases' exhibit that used a rotatable tube of different gases to allow users to observe the light spectra of gases, learn about each gas from a digital display, and answer quiz questions by pressing a button.
Lessons learned will be used to improve the Design Challenge learning opportunity to be offered to students in the coming year.
The design challenge learning process helped enhance students' creativity, team-working skills, and engaged them in their learning.

Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering academics Dr Ianatul Khoiroh and Professor Dr Ir Dominic Foo at the University of Nottingham Malaysia secured funding from Cquestr8 Sdn Bhd to explore accelerated weathering of limestone.
Cquestr8 Sdn Bhd was founded by chemical engineers Steve Willis and Jerry Joynson with over 60 years of experience in technical and innovative environments within large industrial organizations.
The funded study aims to investigate the reaction mechanism of accelerated weathering of limestone to capture and store carbon dioxide primarily as bicarbonate in the marine environment.
The project, which started on 1 June 2021, is being conducted by Boaz Chung Yi Heng, a MEng in Chemical Engineering student at the University.
Accelerated weathering of limestone (AWL) is a low-tech, scalable method that can mimic the natural weathering process, offering potential in reducing CO2 concentration in the atmosphere.
AWL is gaining interest for CO2 removal due to energy-saving potential, integration with gas streams from cement and steel plants, and helping to reduce ocean acidification.

The PhD scholarship project title is 'A Framework to Implement Verified Resource-Bounded Systems for Smart Spaces' funded by the Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI), Govt. of Malaysia, at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.

The project aims to develop functionally correct systems for smart spaces and study the social impacts of a prototype incorporating ontology-based modeling, agent-based technology, formal verification, and Android Google SDK software development techniques.

The successful candidate for the PhD scholarship must have a strong background in computer science/electronics or electrical engineering, excellent programming skills (particularly Java), and preferably knowledge of ontology and formal verification.

Applicants for the PhD scholarship must have English language qualifications, such as IELTS 6.0, TOEFL (iBT) 79, or PTE (Academic) 55, with specific score requirements, and results must be less than 2 years old.
The closing date for applications for the PhD scholarship is 8th August 2014.
The contact person for the PhD scholarship is Abdur Rakib from the School of Computer Science, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus, reachable at Abdur.Rakib@nottingham.edu.my.

The BA (Hons) International Relations with French at the University of Nottingham Malaysia is a multidisciplinary program that combines an in-depth exploration of international relations with French language mastery.
The program offers a robust curriculum covering areas such as global politics, international systems, and diplomacy, alongside advanced communication skills in French.
The entry requirements for the Bachelor of International Relations with French include A Level qualifications (BCC), IB Diploma (24 points overall), STPM (BC+C+), UEC (3 B3s and 2 B4s), among others.
English language requirements include an IELTS score of 6.5 (with no less than 6.0 in each element), TOEFL score of 90, or equivalent scores in other recognized English language proficiency tests.

The program provides students with the opportunity to develop skills such as critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication, preparing them for various career opportunities in diplomacy, international organizations, and policy analysis.
Career opportunities for graduates of this program include roles such as Diplomat, Translator, Consultant, Policy Analyst, and Public Relations Executive.
The Language Centre at the University of Nottingham Malaysia will host exams for various international languages, including Diplomas in Spanish, French, and Mandarin.
Members of the public can register for official language exams for French, Mandarin, and Spanish for summer sessions in May and June.
Candidates interested in Diplomas in Spanish (DELE) should register by 17 March for exams on 21 and 22 May, with fees ranging from RM265 to RM500 based on proficiency levels.
Registration for the Diploma of French-language studies (DELF) and Advanced Diploma in French Language (DALF) will be open from 10 April to 15 May for exams in June.
Registration for the Chinese language proficiency test (HSK) is due on 21 May for exams on 19 June, and 5 November for exams on 5 December.
Summer courses in French, Spanish, German, and Korean for beginners will commence on 31 May. Interested participants must register by 17 May.
The summer language courses aim to teach basic communication skills, daily conversations, restaurant interactions, and city navigation.
Classes for beginner French will be conducted online every Saturday over six weeks, with fees of RM695 covering teaching materials and certificates of completion.
Language Centre Director, Jean Christophe Graffe, highlighted the international recognition and lifelong validity of the language diplomas.
To study at a French university or in Francophone countries, a minimum requirement of DELF B2 is necessary.
For further information, individuals can contact Associate Professor Jean Christophe Graffe, Director of the Language Centre at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia's Faculty of Science and Engineering (FOSE) provides an outstanding educational experience and innovative solutions to industry and community problems.
The Faculty of Science and Engineering is supported by approximately 175 academic and 50 professional staff members.
All programs at the University of Nottingham Malaysia are taught in English, and the degrees awarded are equivalent to those in the UK.

Engineering programs available at UNM include foundation, undergraduate, and postgraduate degrees in various disciplines such as Chemical Engineering, Civil Engineering, and Electrical & Electronic Engineering.
Science programs at UNM include undergraduate and postgraduate degrees in subjects such as Psychology, Pharmaceutical and Health Sciences, and Environmental Science.

Admission requirements for the Faculty of Science and Engineering vary based on the program level, with prerequisites including high school diploma, SPM or its equivalent for foundation programs, and engineering foundation, A Levels, or STPM qualifications for undergraduate programs.
It typically takes 5 years from finishing secondary school to become an engineer in Malaysia, including foundation studies and obtaining an MEng degree at UNM.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia provides a variety of scholarships and financial aid opportunities for students in the Faculty of Science and Engineering, including merit-based and need-based options.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia conferred honorary degrees to four outstanding individuals at the University Summer Graduation Ceremony from 21 to 23 July.
The recipients of honorary degrees this year are Dato' Dr Afifi al-Akiti, Dato’ Gan Ah Tee, Dato’ Hooi Lai Lin, and Dato’ Beh Chun Chuan.
Dato' Dr Afifi al-Akiti is the KFAS Fellow in Islamic Studies at the Oxford Centre for Islamic Studies and Islamic Centre Lecturer in Islamic Studies in the Faculty of Theology at Oxford University.
Dato’ Gan Ah Tee is the Managing Partner of BDO Malaysia and Regional Senior Partner of BDO ASEAN with over 35 years’ experience in auditing, corporate finance, and advisory services.
Dato’ Hooi Lai Lin is the CEO and Director of Ken Rich Corporation Sdn Bhd, and she was appointed as an Honorary Professor of Entrepreneurship at the Nottingham University Business School.
Dato’ Beh Chun Chuan is the founder and Chairman of the BP Healthcare Group, an integrated healthcare provider in Malaysia.

The project known as Management & Ecology of Malaysian Elephants (MEME) started in 2011 and have collared 50 wild elephants with GPS-satellite collars to track their movements, producing one of the largest elephant movement databases in this region.

Over the last 40 years, Peninsular Malaysia has lost 68% of elephant range in human-occupied landscape, with two-thirds of the remaining areas where elephants are living near humans experiencing conflict. The elephant populations in Malaysia are estimated to be 1200-1500 individuals in Peninsular Malaysia and ~2000 individuals in Sabah.
The Group Managing Director of Sime Darby Plantation announced that the SOP developed by MEME is set to be implemented across all SDP estates before the end of 2020.
Human-Elephant Conflict (HEC) in Malaysia mainly involves elephants depredating on crops grown by farmers and plantations, causing economic losses. Last year, damages reached RM 14.2 million.
The Director-General of PERHILITAN stated that translocation is not a long-term solution for HEC and setting up electric fences to help communities is being explored.

CAS offers various support and services to support the students throughout their career development journey and guide them in identifying their strengths and interests.
CAS uses a systematic Career Development Roadmap to help students acquire self-awareness, explore career path and get ready for the future world of work.

CAS provides one-to-one and virtual resume review, and career advice sessions to all UNM foundation students, undergraduates, postgraduates, and alumni. The appointment can be booked through MyCareer portal.

CAS conducts initiatives on-campus and virtually such as careers fair, pre-careers fair series, 'Spotlight' sector-focused careers day, 'Elevate Your Potential' recruitment talks, international students career series, alumni sharing - career journey, careers talks, on-campus/ virtual interviews, and field trips.

The Get Ready Get Hired (GRGH) Certificate Programme requires students to complete three stages to qualify for the Certificate of Completion. The deadline to complete the programme and receive the Certificate is the 15th of April of the graduating year.

The Career Mentoring Programme allows students to realize their potential with guidance and support from experienced employers and alumni. Students will be rewarded with a Certificate of Participation upon completion of the programme.

Students are encouraged to use online resources on MyCareer portal, SharePoint, blog, and website; and hardcopy resources at Careers Resource Room (HB14). CAS provides guidance such as Careers Quick Tips and What Do Graduates Do.

CAS disseminates and updates careers opportunities through offline and online channels. Careers advisers share careers opportunities via MyCareer portal, e-job bulletin, e-internship bulletin, email blast, CAS Facebook, CAS Instagram, and CAS LinkedIn.
For any appointment and inquiries, kindly reach CAS at careers@nottingham.edu.my.

The Nottingham National Economics Quiz Competition 2023 was jointly organised by UNM’s School of Economics and the Nottingham Economics Society (NES).
The quiz competition was open to all pre-university students in Malaysia.
The quiz competition was held online on 3 April 2023 for the preliminary stage and 7 April 2023 for the final stage.
Participants were required to form a team of three to answer 10 to 20 questions for a total of 7 rounds.
The top three teams who demonstrated good knowledge of economics received money prizes totaling RM2,700.
All other participants received an e-certificate as a token of appreciation and recognition.
The next event after the quiz competition will be the Nottingham-World Bank Economics Essay 2023.

Spanish is considered to be the world's third most international and influential language on the Internet after English and Mandarin, spoken officially in 21 countries and widely used in countries like the US, Western Sahara, Philippines, and Morocco.

The teaching style and methodology of the Spanish team at the University of Nottingham Malaysia use a communicative approach based on real case scenarios, focusing on developing listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills.

The DELE Diplomas are official qualifications certifying the degree of competence and mastery of Spanish, granted by Instituto Cervantes on behalf of the Ministry of Education and Professional Training of Spain.

The DELE Diplomas are considered official qualifications to acknowledge Spanish language competence for professional or academic activities requiring an appropriate level of competence, aiding personal promotion in academic and professional spheres.

The team at the School of Pharmacy is studying curcumin from turmeric to develop effective dosage forms to treat colon cancer with minimal side effects, using natural molecules like chitosan and pectin.
Nanoparticles are being used to deliver curcumin into the colon to target tumor cells specifically, reducing side effects compared to conventional chemotherapy.
A project involving chitosan aims to create a diabetic drug delivery system that responds to blood glucose levels by releasing insulin gradually, reducing the need for daily injections.

KPMG Malaysia and the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) have signed an MOU to provide a platform to offer UNM students the opportunity to enhance their future careers.
The MOU was signed by UNM Interim Provost and CEO Professor Sarah Metcalfe and KPMG Malaysia Chief Operating Officer and Chief Information Officer Adrian Lee at a ceremony on 13 July 2022.
Through this new partnership, UNM students will have the opportunity for internships at KPMG and also become KPMG ambassadors.
Both KPMG and UNM will organize events and activities for students to gain industry exposure while they are still studying.

Other initiatives include industry training attachment opportunities for lecturers, annual appointment of selected students as KPMG Ambassadors, industry visit opportunities, hosting of technical as well as non-technical engagement programs including guest lectures and boot camps.

KPMG also signed an MOU with other universities in Malaysia including Universiti Malaya, Universiti Sains Islam Malaysia, Universiti Teknologi MARA, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Universiti Tun Abdul Razak, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, International Islamic University of Malaysia, Sunway University, Taylor's University, INTEC Education College, Multimedia University and Tunku Abdul Rahman University College.
Present at the signing ceremony was UNM Registrar Patrick Joseph and UNM Head of Careers Advisory Service Alicia Ch'ng.
