Nottingham University Business School (NUBS) Malaysia convened a panel session on 5 June 2015, at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus' partner institution PSB Academy Singapore, to discuss  the role of 'big data' and analytics in business.
Pankaj Sinha, Associate VP & Head of Operations, Hindustan Coca-Cola Beverages spoke on his experience in using the results of data analytics on the decision making support in Coca-Cola in India.

Jitinder Magoon, Chief Management and Strategic Advisor, Zecon Medicare Kuala Lumpur presented a case study showing how healthcare systems can benefit from data analytics, while Kenneth Khoo, Vice-President, APAC Region, Digital Route shared his experience of being tasked with modelling and using the results of data analytics in the telecommunications industry.

Bill Lee, Partner, Process Improvement, Information Management and Advanced Analytics, Ernst & Young Advisory Singapore, having presented earlier on data analytics and governance as a foreword to the panel discussion, also spoke on the challenges of data privacy and dilemmas surrounding the use of data collected for the greater good.
Lee also commented on the lack of sufficient talent in the area of data analytics.

Nottingham University Business School has campuses in the UK, China and Malaysia, with the MBA  programme offered in the UK, Malaysia, and the University’s overseas partner institution in Singapore, PSB Academy.
In 2014, NUBS Malaysia was appointed as the administrative centre for the Singapore MBA.
All MBA students at NUBS Malaysia have the option of taking up to two approved modules delivered by the UK campus or in Singapore, offering opportunities for a truly global study experience.
More information on the MBA programme at NUBS Malaysia can be obtained.
Information on MBA Previews for the September 2015 intake (Full-time and Part-time).

Seven alumni of the University of Nottingham Malaysia were recently announced as the winners of the Vice Chancellor Medal 2020.
The Vice-Chancellor’s Medal 2020 is awarded to students and staff for their excellent achievement.

The winners should have achieved exceptional achievement in any arena; contributed to the advancing of equality, diversity and inclusion in University life; have carried out notable endeavors that have made a difference to the University; have made a substantive contribution that has enhanced the reputation of the University of Nottingham; were involved in an activity that positively impacted the students, staff or local community; or an individual achievement or sustained achievement over a period of time.

The winners should have achieved exceptional achievement in any arena; contributed to the advancing of equality, diversity and inclusion in University life; have carried out notable endeavors that have made a difference to the University; have made a substantive contribution that has enhanced the reputation of the University of Nottingham; were involved in an activity that positively impacted the students, staff or local community; or an individual achievement or sustained achievement over a period of time.

The other student winners this year were Hasan Al-Akraa Mohamad, Geerthanaa Santhiran, Muhammad Rehhahn Daniel Tudball, Yap Jing Ying, Apurav Krishna Koyande, Chia Shir Reen, Omar Ashraf El Far, Wong Xin Yi, Amirah Qistina Binti Hazrin, Yew Guo Yong, Denesh Sooriamoorthy and Bernice Han Ziao En.

Vice-Chancellor, Professor Shearer West congratulated each of this year’s winners: “Across a particularly challenging year, it is extremely heartening to see so many colleagues’ and students’ exceptional contributions to our own community and those around us.

Vice-Chancellor, Professor Shearer West congratulated each of this year’s winners: 'I am very proud of the achievements of all of our winners, who have now joined a prestigious cohort of students and staff whose achievements and service have been outstanding.'

Earth Hour Carnival 2014 was hosted by The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) and featured a mini concert and exhibition on environmental awareness.
Organised by the UNMC’s Nature Club, this is the fourth year the University has participated in Earth Hour.
Some 400 students, alumni, staff and guests attended the event and joined a candlelit walk around the campus.
The event included informal workshops to raise awareness of energy conservation among UNMC students and generate interest in Earth Hour.
The carnival featured food stalls, sale of eco-friendly products, games booth with “recycle bowling”, a game played with recyclable materials, the donation of recyclable items and information booths.
Attendees pledged to adopt energy efficient habits in their daily lives.

Chen Siang Hui, a third-year civil engineering student at UNMC, noted that attendance at the event was better than in previous years, indicating increased environmental awareness in the UNMC community.
The countdown to Earth Hour featured performances by 'The Indonesians' and Big Bad Sheep, bands comprising UNMC students.
'The Earth Hour at UNMC was a success, it was a display of cooperation between different student societies within UNMC,' said Dion Visser from the Netherlands, part of the AIESEC team.

The UK/ASEAN Knowledge Partnership Dialogue was hosted at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus on Monday 11 March, 2013.
Delegates from six countries across the region visited UNMC as part of the UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office UK/ASEAN Knowledge Partnership project.
Professor Stephen Doughty, UNMC Vice-Provost for Learning and Teaching, welcomed the delegation and discussed Nottingham’s internationalization strategy and campus experience.

Presentations included discussions on the Malaysian transnational education policy context by key speakers from Malaysian Government Transformation Programme (PEMANDU) and Ministry of Higher Education.
Dr Sean Matthews from the School of Modern Languages and Cultures chaired the final discussion session on strategic challenges facing ASEAN partners in Higher Education.
Gavin Anderson, Director of the British Council in Malaysia, participated in the debate on language policies and educational challenges in the region.
The event took place on 26th March 2013.

Chin Ren Yi and Sameeta Sparks shared their experience in reaching out to frontliners and communities during the COVID-19 pandemic in a one-hour session on 26 June 2020 at 7pm through Microsoft Teams.
Both Chin Ren Yi and Sameeta Sparks are Nottingham alumni who started helping and reaching out to communities since the Malaysian government announced the movement control order (MCO) on 18 March.
The session was moderated by Assistant Professor Chan Wen Li, who facilitated the discussion.
Ren Yi shared on the 'mBL Mini Project' aimed to help the elderly or those with mobility restrictions to run errands and how his team reached out to the frontlines by providing free food.

Sameeta organised the BER5: Mindful webinar series where women experts discussed mental health. She also organized a doodling class for children and young adults to express their feelings and help in motivation.
The participants provided positive responses and feedback, thanking the organizer for conducting a good sharing session that would inspire them to give back to the community.

NCDs and their associated risk factors are a significant and growing global public health problem. The four major types of NCDs include diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, cancer and chronic respiratory diseases.
The National Cancer Society of Malaysia (NCSM) projects that one in every four Malaysians are likely to develop cancer by the age of 75 years.
Two in five Malaysian adults are overweight with BMI >40 and carry high risk for chronic diseases including type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular diseases.
Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) remain the leading cause of death in Malaysia as well as in the world.

The inter-ceremony graduation procedure has been set up for students who must have their award certificate more quickly.
Students can apply to have their awards conferred in absentia by the University in March or October through the inter-ceremony route.
If students choose the inter-ceremony route to receive their award certificate early, they will not be able to attend a graduation ceremony in person.

Students must contact the Student Registry by 13 February for the inter-ceremony in March and by 13 September for the inter-ceremony in October if they wish to apply for the inter-ceremony graduation.
To inquire about the inter-ceremony procedure, students can contact Graduation@nottingham.edu.my.

The Master of Engineering with Honours in Mechatronic Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia integrates mechanical, electrical, electronic, and computer engineering to create innovative, intelligent systems.
The program equips students with advanced skills in automation, robotics, and control engineering, preparing them to tackle complex engineering challenges in modern industries.

The program is recognized by the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) and the Engineering Accreditation Council (EAC) Malaysia, meeting the academic requirements for Chartered Engineer status.
Students benefit from innovative facilities and expert instruction in artificial intelligence, digital signal processing, and robotics.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) signed a Sponsorship of Award Agreement with PLYTEC Group on 3 August 2021.

The agreement promotes knowledge exchange activities for hosting joint seminars or workshops, exchanging scientific and technical information on Building Information Technology (BIM), promoting PLYTEC’s participation in UNM’s seminar and job fair, and exploring opportunities for student internships and dissertations with PLYTEC.
A total of 20 students from the Department of Civil Engineering were awarded the PLYTEC Innovation Award under the Building Information Group Design Project module.
Through the Public Works Department (JKR) Strategic Plan 2021-2025, the Works Ministry aims to have 50% adoption of BIM mechanism this year and 80% by 2025.
The Ministry plans for 50% of construction projects worth RM10 million and above to use the BIM mechanism, with a subsequent yearly increase before 2025.
Ts Louis Tay Chee Siong expressed congratulations to the award winners and highlighted the importance of innovation and creativity in the industry.
Professor Chan mentioned this sponsorship as a significant occasion for UNM and the Department of Civil Engineering, marking the first industry sponsorship received.

University of Nottingham Malaysia has partnered with Fuller Young International Limited for the development of functional food products from papaya for the treatment of dengue fever and age-related illnesses such as Alzheimer’s disease, dementia, Parkinson’s disease and hypertension as well as to boost the immune system.
A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed between UNM and Fuller Young International Limited on 8 July 2021 to mark this partnership.

Fuller Young International (FYI) is a functional food and nutraceutical company based in Queenstown, New Zealand. They possess expertise in planting papaya trees and papaya leaf extract processing in Japan and New Zealand.

Once this phase is completed, FYI will then begin the production of capsules that contain the compounds extracted from the papaya leaf. These capsules will be primarily marketed to consumers in Malaysia and the greater Southeast Asian region.

Tackling the process has been challenging during the pandemic, as most hospitals are under stress from COVID-19-related duties, which may lead to delays in conducting the clinical tests needed for the clinical-testing phase.

Climate Action in Malaysia provides students from all disciplines with an introduction to the climate change problem, and the information and tools needed to embed climate-friendly actions and behaviors in their day-to-day lives
Competencies linked to climate action will be valuable to graduates as governments, businesses and organizations increasingly seek to contribute to urgent climate solutions

Malaysia is a multiracial and multicultural country. The population comprises various ethnicities, including Malays, Chinese, Indians and indigenous groups.

Bahasa Malaysia is the official language of Malaysia. English is widely spoken as well, especially in the cities and in educational institutions.

Dr Victoria Ann Hasson, University of Nottingham alumna, delivered a lecture with ex-Labour Party member Sir Hugh Bayley at the University of Nottingham Malaysia on 16 October.
The lecture titled 'Why Parliament Matters for students' was organized by the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The interactive lecture allowed students to learn more about the UK Parliament in the context of their studies.
Sir Hugh Bayley served as a Labour Party member from 1992 to 2015 and was responsible for poverty reduction in the UK under Tony Blair's government.

Dr Victoria Ann Hasson graduated from the University of Nottingham in 2004 with Hispanic & Latin American Studies and holds a doctorate in parliamentary procedure and democracy from the University of Sheffield.

The visit of Dr Hasson and Sir Bayley to the University of Nottingham Malaysia was part of knowledge sharing and capacity building engagements with stakeholders in Malaysia, including an MP advocacy program at the Malaysian Parliament supported by the British High Commission in Malaysia.
The session ended with networking and engagement between British High Commission representatives, students, staff, and the speakers at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Among the attendees were University of Nottingham Malaysia Faculty of Arts and Science Professor Lee Chew Ging and Head of School of Politics, History and International Relations Professor William Case.

Christina Supramaniam, an Assistant Professor with the School of Biosciences, has been awarded the Faculty of Science Pump Priming award to develop a cost-efficient and reliable infection assay to study the relationship between Malaysian oil palm and its most dangerous pathogen, G. boninense, a white rot fungus.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a Student Complaint Procedure that involves three levels: Local Level, Head of School/Service review, and Faculty Dean/Registrar review.
Complainants have the opportunity to have their complaints independently reviewed by the Office of the Independent Adjudicator (OIA) after exhausting internal University processes.
The expected time limits for handling complaints are stipulated by the OIA Good Practice Framework, with complaints normally being completed within 90 calendar days of the formal stage at Level 2.

Students are required to raise complaints within specific time frames for each level: 1 month for Level 1, 1 month of outcome of Level 1 for Level 2, and 10 working days of outcome of Level 2 for Level 3.

Students at the University of Nottingham Malaysia are responsible for providing evidence to support their complaints and ensuring that any evidence not in English is translated when submitting complaints.

Staff dealing with complaints at the University are expected to resolve complaints promptly and fairly, with detailed records kept of any meetings and outcomes at each level of the complaints procedure.
The University provides forms and procedures for different levels of complaints, as well as guidelines for students and staff involved in handling complaints.

The Office of the Independent Adjudicator (OIA) is an external body that may review complaints if students are not satisfied with the internal resolutions, but only after exhausting all internal procedures.
In cases where a complaint cannot be resolved internally to the student's satisfaction, a formal 'Completion of Procedures' letter is issued before the complaint may be considered by the OIA.

An honorary associate professor at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) is among scientists campaigning to dispel the myth that palm oil and other drainage-based agriculture can be developed on tropical peat soils through current agricultural practices.

Dr Stephanie Evers, from UNMC, is lead author to one of the recent articles that highlights the problems facing industry and governments in developing or adhering to effective policies to manage the unique peatland eco-system.
Current estimates are that fires from dried peat have caused over 100,000 premature deaths, economic losses over $16bn to Indonesia and have exceeded the average daily emissions from all of the U.S.

Dr Evers said: 'Failing to recognise the devastating far-reaching consequences of the way in which peatlands are being managed and failing to work together to address them could mean that the next generations will in fact have to deal with an irreversibly altered, dysfunctional landscape.'

More information is available from Dr Stephanie Evers on Stephanie.evers@nottingham.edu.my, Josephine Dionisappu, PR & Communications Manager at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus on josephine.dionisappu@nottingham.edu.my or Lindsay Brooke, Media Relations Manager at The University of Nottingham UK on lindsay.brooke@nottingham.ac.uk.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia aims to study how genes and the environment work together by creating a registry of Malaysian twins through the Nottingham Malaysian Twin Registry.

The Nottingham Malaysian Twin Registry is the second known twin registry in Malaysia, established in March 2019 by Dr Steve Janssen and Dr Steve Stewart-Williams from the School of Psychology of the University of Nottingham Malaysia.
The main aim of the Nottingham Malaysian Twin Registry (NMTR) is to establish and maintain contact with adult identical and fraternal twins living in the Klang Valley.
Recruitment for the NMTR is ongoing with the goal of establishing contact with at least 200 Malaysian adult twins from various language, social, and ethnic backgrounds.
To join the registry, twins are required to answer a five-minute questionnaire about their family, education, and work background.
The University is hopeful of conducting more studies with twins in the future on topics beyond memory, including areas unrelated to psychology such as medical disorders.

Dr. Siang Yew Chong, an assistant professor in the School of Computer Science at the University of Nottingham, Malaysia Campus, has been awarded the 2011 IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation Outstanding Paper Award.

The award was jointly presented to Siang Yew and his co-authors, Dr. Peter Tino and Prof. Xin Yao from the University of Birmingham, UK, for their paper: S. Y. Chong, P. Tino, and X. Yao, ``Measuring Generalization Performance in Co-evolutionary Learning,'' IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation, Vol. 12, No. 4, pp. 479-505, Aug. 2008.
The IEEE Computational Intelligence Society represents an international community of contributors in all computational and theoretical aspects of mimicking nature for problem-solving.

The IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation Outstanding Paper Award recognizes outstanding technical contributions for the advancement in the theory, design, and applications of Evolutionary Computation.
The awards ceremony was held recently at the 2011 Congress on Evolutionary Computation (CEC 2011), New Orleans, USA.

The winners of the YM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen bin Tengku Ismail Essay Writing Competition 2017 were announced at the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus.

The essay competition was a collaboration between the School of Politics, History, and International Relations (PHIR) of the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus and the United Nations Association of Malaysia (UNAM).
The chosen topic for the essay competition was on Gender Equality, focusing on 'What Can be Done to Overcome Prejudice towards Gender Equality'.
The first prize winner was Govind Nair from Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak Campus.
The second prize winner was Bavani Ponnurangam Chinnathambi from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
The third prize winner was Emily Chen Sue Mei from UNMC.
Five consolation prize winners were also awarded.

Dr. Gianfranco Scribano is an Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the Department of Mechanical, Materials, and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
Dr. Scribano obtained his M.Sc. in Aerospace Engineering in 1999 and then received his Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering in 2004 at Politecnico di Milano, Italy.

Dr. Scribano's expertise is on combustion emission reduction and fluid-mechanics. He uses experimental techniques such as PIV (Particle Image Velocimetry), PDI (Phase Doppler Interferometry) in both reactive and non-reactive flows.
During his industrial working career, he has acquired hands-on experience in project management and new product development from concept analysis to production.

Applications are invited for a fully funded 3-year PhD studentship (tuition fee waiver + monthly stipend) in the School of Computer Science, Faculty of Science, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus
Project Title: Intelligent Pipe Crack Detection System by Using the Non-destructive Testing based Mindstorm Robot with Multiple NXT Sensors
Funded By: Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MOSTI), Project 01-02-12-SF0360, Govt. of Malaysia; Faculty of Science, University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus

The detection of cracks in solid infrastructure is a setback of immense significance. Particularly, the detection of cracks in buried pipes is a crucial step in assessing the degree of pipe deterioration for municipal and utility operators.
To examine and continue maintaining these pipes cost so much in terms of cash, manual labour and time, therefore automating the process is needed.
Another important outcome from this project is to determine the suitability of non-destructive testing (NDT) methods with multiple NXT sensors of the Mindstorm Robot.

Academic Requirements: Normally graduate of this University or any other approved higher education institution holding i. A Master's degree accepted by the Academic Board; ii. Other relevant or equivalent qualification with Master's degree accepted by the Senate or competent authority in Malaysia.

English Language Requirements: IELTS: 6.0 (no elements below 5.5); TOEFL (IBT): 79 (no element below 19); PTE (Academic): 55 (minimum 51); 1119 (GCE O): Grade C; GCSE/IGCSE: Grade C; CAE: 169 (no element below 162) or C

For further enquiry on the project and the application procedure, please send your CV together with a cover letter to explain your career aim and why you want to apply, to Assistant Professor Dr Chen ZhiYuan
The successful candidate is expected to take up the scholarship in September 2016 or no later than October 2016.

The Writers in Progress (WIP) Trainee Scheme is a dedicated trainee scheme for aspiring journalists launched by Poskod.my.
Applicants for WIP must be aged 18-25 and have not yet gained full-time, paid employment in print or online publishing.
WIP applicants should be passionate about journalism, have excellent English communication skills, and be interested in local issues that affect their city and community.
The deadline for applying to the WIP Trainee Scheme is 1st September.
Successful WIP applicants will join the team for three months, work part-time, receive one-to-one training sessions on journalism and multimedia skills, and get a monthly stipend of RM1,000.
Applicants for WIP should email Ling, the editor, at ideas@poskod.my with specific requirements detailed in the application process.
The Poskod WIP is supported by the Embassy of Finland, Malaysia.

University of Nottingham Malaysia offers procedures for timetabling and room bookings for staff members and students.
Common teaching spaces are allocated on a shared and needs basis, considering factors like suitability, expected student number, facilities, and room types.
University staff can book common facilities on an ad hoc basis via Web-Room Booking, with teaching activities given higher priority.
Teaching spaces are available outside standard teaching hours for society and club activities, with room booking requests by individual students made via the Student Association Office.
Ad hoc bookings should not be used for regular teaching activities, except for replacement classes.
Standard teaching hours for undergraduate students on campus are between 9am to 6pm on weekdays, with weekend and evening classes scheduled for postgraduate courses.
Students are expected to attend all compulsory modules and have a reasonable selection of elective modules, although clash-free elective modules are not guaranteed.

Medical evidence is required for the disability advisory services to better understand students' disabilities and provide proper support.

Students with seen or unseen disabilities are required to provide a letter from a psychologist, psychiatrist, or medical specialist detailing diagnosis, when diagnosed, duration, impact on activities, and any medication or treatment side effects.
Students with learning differences like Dyslexia, Asperger’s Syndrome, or ADD/ADHD need an assessment report from an educational psychologist or special needs specialist.

The Centre for the Study of Communications & Culture at the University of Nottingham Malaysia focuses on analyzing the interplay between national and transnational media and cultures and their impact on social structures, particularly in the developing world.

The Centre is concerned with problematising transnational media and culture and is interested in the area of 'new media' or information and communications technologies and the promises they offer for societal betterment.

The development of civil society and new media in the region has added a new dimension to the overall scenario, with the interactive and borderless nature of new media being highlighted for their transformative capabilities.

Collaborations of the Centre for the Study of Communications & Culture include institutions like Faculty of Communication Arts, Chulalongkorn University, Thailand, and School of Communication, Universiti Sains Malaysia among others.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) cricket team emerged victorious in the finals of the inaugural T-20 Tri-Series, which was held on 25 November 2018. Multimedia University and Inti University were the two other participating teams in the tri-series.

The format of the tournament required the teams to play against one another once in the league stage. Each win conceded the winning team two points. By the end of the league stage, the two teams with the highest points played the finals.
The star performers with the ball were Utkarsh Gupta, a student from Bachelors of Economics, Saleh Shadman, a PhD student in Engineering, Phahmee Ahanaf Khalid, who scored 49 runs off 34 balls.

The second match was between Inti University and Multimedia University. Inti posted a target of 192 runs which Multimedia University was unable to chase and lost by 22 runs. The star of the match was Hamza Abbas from Inti University, who scored 62 runs.
The Tri-Series tournament was an effort to further promote the game of cricket at UNM and provide the players with the necessary exposure they require to perform at a competitive stage.
The tournament victory was awarded to the entire team by the captain of UNM cricket team, Saleh Shadman, who emphasized that the team played as a unit and each member contributed when required.

Waris Khan of UNM made 90 unbeatable runs in the finals, winning the award of the Best Batsman of the tournament. Rahul Reddy of UNM was awarded the Best Bowler of the tournament with six wickets under his belt.

The Vinod Sekhar Incubation Centre (VSIC) was launched on 16 November 2016 at The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) by Professor Sir David Greenaway.

VSIC offers prospective UNMC students, academics, and staff with early-stage business support, access to academic expertise, mentoring support, and a structured training program to develop skills for setting up and running a business.

VSIC is located at Block B in UNMC and is designed to host eight designated rooms for start-up or spin-out companies, providing hot desks, cubicles, office units, meeting and training rooms, with a total space area of approximately 3,700 square feet.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus (UNMC) offers a world-class British education, ranked among the top 100 universities worldwide according to QS World University Rankings 2016/17, with around 5,000 students and 700 teaching and administrative staff from around the world.

Datuk Vinod Balachandran Sekhar is the Chairman and CEO of Petra Group, headquartered in Malaysia, and is a strong advocate of 'Social Capitalism' where business interests and societal concerns work hand in hand.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers a Bachelor of Pharmacy (BPharm) program that focuses on the science and practice of pharmacy and drug therapy with multiple modules contributing to a specific number of credits.

The BPharm (Hons) program at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) is a 4-year degree program that integrates therapeutic themes or disease states through 'Drug, Medicine and Patient' (DMP) modules.
The BPharm program at UNM typically takes four years to complete, with students spending all 4 years on the Malaysia campus for their studies.

The Master of Pharmacy (MPharm) program at UNM is a 4-year degree program, with students spending the first two years at the Malaysia campus before transferring to the UK campus for the final two years.
The MPharm program at UNM is designed for advanced clinical practice and specialized roles within the pharmacy profession.
The BPharm program at UNM is entirely Malaysia-based, providing a convenient and cost-effective option for local students.

The MPharm program at UNM offers a 2+2 structure, where students spend the first two years at the Malaysia campus and the final two years at the UK campus, providing international exposure and diverse learning experience.
Both the BPharm and MPharm programs at UNM span four years and offer a high standard of education aligned with UK standards.
Both BPharm and MPharm programs at UNM offer professional placements in diverse settings such as hospitals, community pharmacies, and the pharmaceutical industry.

Professor Yousif Abdalla Abakr, Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, is UNM academic lead for one project that will use waste to generate clean fuel using small-scale technologies that can be sited close to rural, as well as urban, communities.

Dr Ajit Singh, School of Biosciences, is UNM academic lead for the other project that will use a new process called hydrothermal carbonization. This technology has recently reached a point in its development where it is able to process thousands of tonnes of food waste into a renewable biocoal that can be used in a variety of industrial and domestic applications.

Studies from the Malaysian Housing and Local Government Ministry, in 2018 found that 76% of waste went to landfill. Not only does this cost the country RM 2.4 billion per annum, it also produces a threat to the environment and poses adverse health risks to the communities who live nearby.
The Malaysian partner of this project, Tex Cycle (P2) Sdn Bhd will investigating waste and recycling techniques including pyrolysis, gasification and waste materials characterisation.
This biocoal is a carbon neutral product, it burns clean and only takes few hours to process.

Newton-Ungku Omar Fund (NUOF) Grand Challenge 2019. NUOF Grand Challenge provides a platform for UK, Malaysian businesses and academic institution to collaborate on finding solutions to the challenges of urban mobility and waste to wealth in Malaysia.

Malaysians generate 38,000 tonnes of waste per day and out of that 15,000 tonnes is food waste. The country relies largely on land refill sites but these generate huge amounts of methane (a greenhouse gas) and heavy metal and toxic leechates that are not environmental friendly.
CPL Ltd has expertise in producing cleaner, greener, more efficient, smokeless solid fuels.
The Malaysian partner of this project, Eureka Synergy Sdn Bhd will manage the feasibility study, while SWCorp Malaysia will be carrying out a survey on consumer perceptions of the biocoal product.

Professor Lee Chew Ging, Dean of NUBS Malaysia, co-opened the Conference on 'The Malaysian Economy Towards 2020: Issues and Challenges' at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore.
The conference was jointly organised by the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore, and The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus.
The conference took place on 22-23 March 2016 and was supported by Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung (KAS).

The conference discussed Malaysia's trade, manufacturing, services, Government-Linked Companies (GLCs) and State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs), education, labour market, poverty, inequality, well-being, infrastructure, regional development, agricultural and resource-based industries, SMEs, healthcare, development planning, banking and finance, and fiscal sustainability.
Professor Lee was the Moderator for a session on the first day of the Conference.
The session included presentations on issues and challenges related to services and GLCs by Professor Rokiah Alavi and Ms Wan Khatina Wan Mohd Nawawi, respectively.

20 students from Dong Eui Institute of Technology, South Korea participated in a 4-week English Winter Programme at University of Nottingham Malaysia in Semenyih.

The aim of the programme was to enhance participants’ oral communication and study skills, focusing on discussion and listening strategies, academic presentation techniques, and inter-cultural communicative competence.

The programme included team building exercises, grammar revisions, improving professional skills and attitudes, discussion and presentation techniques, leadership, team communication, creativity, and critical thinking.
The final week of the programme involved assessments and exams covering listening, discussing, presenting, and other skills.

Participants had the opportunity to experience the local lifestyle and culture of Malaysia through trips around Semenyih town, Kuala Lumpur, and Malacca, including culinary adventures, sight-seeing, shopping trips, and other activities.
Participants were delighted to experience student life at a British university setting in the tropical climate of Southeast Asia.
Feedback from participants highlighted the excellent quality of teaching and learning, state-of-the-art campus facilities, warm reception, and mentoring sessions provided by UNM students.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia will be implementing electronic invoicing (e-Invoice) starting from August 1, 2024, in compliance with the Inland Revenue Board (IRBM) mandate.
An e-Invoice is a digital representation of a transaction between the University of Nottingham Malaysia and students. It contains transaction data for daily business operations.
The benefits of e-Invoice implementation include streamlining operational efficiency, enhancing record-keeping and tax compliance, and digitalizing tax and financial reporting.
Students will receive digital invoices for tuition and other university fees through the e-Invoice system starting from August 1, 2024.
Students have 72 hours from receipt to request rejection of an e-Invoice in case of inaccurate information, and the university will issue a new e-Invoice based on the updated information.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia collects essential student information for e-Invoicing purposes and ensures secure data processing in compliance with data protection regulations.
For payment-related inquiries or refund requests, students can contact the finance office at Finance.eInvoice@nottingham.edu.my.
To inquire about tuition fees as a transferring undergraduate student from Nottingham Malaysia to Nottingham UK, students can contact the Nottingham UK Finance office at tuitionfees@nottingham.ac.uk.

For semester due dates, late penalty charges, payment methods for miscellaneous fees, financial aid information, installment plans, and other finance-related queries, students can refer to the provided information pages or contact the finance department.

The United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG) is the largest association of local governments in the world and the officially recognized voice of local government by the United Nations.
UCLG ASPAC is one of the eight Regional Sections UCLG in which its Secretariat is located in Jakarta and hosted by the Provincial Government of Jakarta.
UCLG ASPAC represents local governments politically within the international community, and with the United Nations and its agencies.
UCLG ASPAC is accepting the expression of interests for an internship opportunity from the university students of all over the world including Indonesia.
Interns will be placed at the UCLG ASPAC regional office in Jakarta and provide support to the ongoing operations of UCLG ASPAC Secretariat.

Requirements for the internship include being a student of the 6th semester of undergraduate program or postgraduate program in fields like development, urban/regional planning, business administration, public administration, international relations, environmental, computer science, or related areas, having a minimal GPA of 2.75, excellent English skills, actively participating in extracurricular activities, being proactive and determined, having computer software skills, and being willing to relocate to Jakarta at own expense.
The duration of internships is a minimum of 3 months.
Students are expected to submit an updated CV and motivation letter to the Operation Management Division of UCLG ASPAC at info@uclg-aspac.org with the subject 'Internship'.

The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) Regional Centre for East Asia and the Pacific provides internship opportunities in various fields related to drugs and crime.

The eligibility criteria for the internship program include graduate studies in political and social sciences, economics, public health, psychology, public and business administration, law studies, or other relevant programs.
Selected internship candidates must have excellent English language skills, with fluency in speaking, reading, and writing. Knowledge of another UN language is considered an asset.
Interns at the UNODC Regional Centre in Bangkok, Thailand, are required to work full-time during office hours for a duration of 2 to 6 months.

To apply for the UNODC internship, interested students should submit a brief application letter, proof of continuing studies, a Curriculum Vitae (CV), and a short essay outlining their reasons for pursuing the internship.
Application emails for the UNODC internship should follow the format: 'Recruitment - Internship - [AREA of INTEREST] [Current field of study] [Internship period]'.
Only successful applicants for the UNODC internship will be contacted due to the high volume of applications received.
Dr Kah Mun completed her PhD in Finance at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM), focusing on behavioural finance.

Dr Kah Mun is engaged in both undergraduate and postgraduate levels at Nottingham University Business School.

Dr Kah Mun is studying psychological factors, cultural and societal factors that shape how investors make decisions, unusual market patterns, and how behavioural biases affect financial markets.

The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Electrical and Electronic Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) prepares students for dynamic careers at the forefront of technology and innovation. Accredited by the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) and the Engineering Accreditation Council (EAC) Malaysia.

The curriculum integrates core engineering principles with innovative topics such as VLSI Design, Embedded Systems, Power Systems, Electrical Machines, Robotics, Drones, Autonomous Vehicles, Renewable Energy, Artificial Intelligence, Digital Signal Processing, and Software Programming.
To further enhance employability, the programme includes professional studies workshops led by experienced engineers and a mandatory industrial training module.

Graduates emerge with advanced technical skills, project management expertise, and leadership capabilities, making them highly sought after by employers in sectors such as semiconductors, embedded systems, IoT, power generation, robotics, autonomous systems, renewable energy, telecommunications, and advanced technology.

Accredited Excellence: Accredited by the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) and Engineering Accreditation Council (EAC) Malaysia, meeting academic requirements for Chartered Engineer status.

Comprehensive Curriculum: Covers advanced topics such as power systems, renewable energy, artificial intelligence, and digital signal processing, preparing students for diverse engineering challenges.
Practical Focus: Gain hands-on experience through construction projects, group designs, and a final-year individual project, developing real-world problem-solving skills.
Cutting-Edge Tools: Offers training in modern tools, programming, and simulation software, ensuring proficiency with the latest technologies in engineering.

Career-Ready Graduates: Combines technical expertise with project management and leadership training, equipping graduates for impactful roles in energy, telecommunications, and electronics industries.

The Print Service is available in all computer rooms and the library.
The Print Service uses Multifunctional Devices (MFDs) for printing, copying, and scanning.
To use the service, you will need your University Card or your University username and password along with credit in your Print Service account.
A document sent to print from any computer room/public access PC is stored in your personal queue for up to 24 hours and can be released for printing from any MFD once you have logged in.
Items can be photocopied as long as they are within the copyright restrictions. The default setting is Single-sided A4 paper in black and white (mono).
Items can be scanned at any MFD and sent directly to your University email address. Scanning is free and saves paper.
Charges for printing and copying: Black & White (print and copy) - A4: RM 0.075 (per side) for double-sided, RM 0.10 (per page) for single-sided.
Charges for printing and copying: Colour (print only) - A4: RM 0.90 (per side) for double-sided, RM 1.00 (per page) for single-sided.
No cost is incurred for scanning.
Every act of printing or copying reduces the amount of credit in your Print Service account. Unused credit is not refundable or transferable.
You can check your print credit balance and top up your print credit online via the Print Service portal using your University username.
The University of Nottingham Malaysia hosted the AirAsia Hackathon from 1 to 3 March 2019, attracting around 300 participants.
The participants in the AirAsia Hackathon were required to work in teams of five and present a concept to a panel of aviation and technology experts.
The top five teams from the AirAsia Hackathon will qualify to compete at the Aviatar 2019 Grand Finale at the Langkawi International Maritime and Aerospace Exhibition (LIMA).

At the AirAsia Hackathon, the launch of the competition was attended by various dignitaries including Deputy Director General of Higher Education Dr Mohd Nor Azman Hassan, AirAsia Deputy Group CEO Aireen Omar, and others.

Internship opportunities available at the Institute for Democracy and Economic Affairs (IDEAS) Malaysia for Malaysian citizens or those with permission to work in Malaysia.
Interns at IDEAS will work in areas such as Political Governance, Education, Outreach, and Southeast Asia Network of Development.
Applicants for internships at IDEAS need to provide a CV, answer specific questions, and send their availability to admin@ideas.org.my.
IDEAS is a not-for-profit, cross-partisan think-tank that promotes the principles of rule of law, limited government, free market, and individual liberty and responsibility.
In January 2013, IDEAS was ranked as the 5th best new think tank globally and the best new think tank in Asia by the University of Pennsylvania.
IDEAS aims to encourage the subscription to classical liberal principles and their application in public policy.

IDEAS aligns with the vision of Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj, the first Prime Minister of Malaysia, emphasizing liberty, justice, the welfare and happiness of Malaysians, and the maintenance of peace among nations.
IDEAS provides opportunities for professional growth through partnerships with various national and global organizations in government, corporate, and political sectors.

The AI Nusantara program aims to equip participants with knowledge and strategies to navigate the AI-driven future, transforming their organizations into innovative, efficient, and sustainable entities.
Dr. Simon Lau conducted a 1.5-hour session on 'What is AI?' for 30 senior executives and management of KLSCCCI members, organized by AI Nusantara.
The session on 'Demystifying AI, Understanding Risks, and Shaping the Future' discussed the benefits of AI for businesses and how it can benefit participants' organizations.

The first session of the AI Nusantara program, co-created by The Hive Southeast Asia and SIDEC, was held on July 11th at Selangor Information Technology & Digital Economy Corporation (SIDEC) office in Shah Alam.
Participants in the program learned to identify areas of their businesses suitable for automation and digital transformation, unlocking new opportunities for increased productivity and cost savings.

The program also addressed potential pitfalls and ethical considerations related to AI implementation, helping participants harness AI benefits while mitigating risks and upholding responsible practices.
By the end of the program, participants will be well-equipped to lead their organizations into the digital age, leveraging AI for sustainable growth and competitive advantage.

The project will focus on immediate and mid-term behavioral responses of elephants to translocation, developing a long-term strategy to protect the endangered elephant population in Malaysia.
MEME will purchase high-sensitivity GPS satellite collars, VHF receivers, antenna, and additional camera traps to study elephant movements and behavior in the Malaysian rainforest.
Scholarships will be provided to Malaysian students for PhD studies on various aspects of elephant conservation, including stress levels, genetic tools, and human-elephant conflict.

The Asian elephant population in the Malay Peninsula has declined significantly due to habitat loss, human encroachment, and conflict, leading to their endangered status as listed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia offers an English MPhil/PhD program.
The program offers full-time options of MPhil (1-2 years) and PhD (3-4 years), as well as part-time options of MPhil (2-4 years) and PhD (6-8 years).
The start dates for the program are in February and September 2025.
The Malaysian fee for the program is RM50,000 per year, while the international fee is RM56,000 per year.
Applicants for the English MPhil/PhD program must have a good master's degree (usually merit or higher) and an upper second-class honours degree (2:1) in a relevant discipline for the PhD option.
For the MPhil option, applicants need an upper second-class honours degree (2:1) in a relevant discipline.
Applicants must demonstrate English proficiency with a minimum IELTS score of 7.0 or equivalent.

Siti Khadijah Zainal Badri is an associate professor in Applied Psychology and Wellbeing at the University of Nottingham, Malaysia.
Siti obtained her Doctor Philosophy (PhD) and degree in Psychology from the Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Johor.
Siti's teaching covers modules such as Person and Society, Psychology of Individual Differences, Occupational Health Psychology, and Contemporary Issues in Applied Psychology.
Siti has publications on topics like work-life balance, toxic work environments, emotional intelligence, and spirituality's effects on mental health.
In the future, Siti aims to understand health, wellbeing, and work-life balance across different generations and occupations in Malaysia.

In rankings just published by The Economist, Nottingham University Business School has been placed in the top 100 along with prestigious institutions such as Dartmouth College, Harvard, Stanford, and INSEAD business schools.

Professor Martin Binks, Dean of Nottingham University Business School, mentioned that the MBA program can be taken in a flexible, part-time Executive format, which includes delegates from major businesses and organizations across the region.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM), in partnership with Practera, presented awards to 76 distinguished students in recognition of their outstanding performance and successful completion of the Malaysia Industry Experience Project.

The Malaysia Industry Experience Project is a collaborative initiative established by Teaching and Learning (T&L) and the Careers Advisory Service (CAS), designed to provide UNM students with practical work experience and in-depth insights into industry operations.

In collaboration with Practera, the programme offers students the unique opportunity to engage in real-world industry projects across the Australia-Pacific region, requiring a minimum commitment of 25 hours over the course of two weeks.
By focusing on experiential learning, Practera aims to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge gained in academic settings and the practical expertise required in professional environments.

Matthew Ashfold is an Associate Professor and Head of the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences at the University of Nottingham Malaysia.

Matthew Ashfold joined the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) in 2013, was promoted to Associate Professor in 2017, and became Head of the School of Environmental and Geographical Sciences in 2020.
Before joining UNM, Matthew Ashfold completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Leeds from 2003-2006.
Matthew Ashfold completed his PhD at the University of Cambridge from 2008-2012 and had a short post-doctoral appointment there from 2012-2013.
Matthew Ashfold's teaching areas include Tutorials in Environmental Science, Global Environmental Change, and Environmental Modelling within the BSc Environmental Science program at UNM.
Matthew Ashfold received a Lord Dearing Award in 2022 for enhancing the student learning experience at UNM.
Matthew Ashfold is interested in atmospheric and climate science, with a focus on tropical Asia and Malaysia.
Matthew Ashfold is a Fellow of the Higher Education Academy and is involved in climate action projects at UNM, such as the Nottingham Advantage Award module Climate Action in Malaysia.

A student team from the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) won the second prize of the Premiere UK-Wide Case Competition 2022, organised by ASEAN-UK Business Forum (AUBF).

The team named Blueprint comprised of undergraduate students from the School of Economics Loh Nicole (team leader) and Matthew Ong Shen Wei along with Hiew Tzy Hwan and Dini Amirah Binti Mohd Desa from the Nottingham University Business School, as well as post-graduate student Chong Zhi Zheng (alumnus of School of Economics) from the London School of Economics.

The team walked away with a cash prize of GBP 400. They will also receive fast-track opportunities with McKinsey & Company (APAC) and PwC (Malaysia) as well as an invitation to an exclusive high tea networking session at the House of Lords, London with ASEAN ambassadors.

On 20 December 2022, they presented a proposal to answer the final problem statement of 'How can you help ASEAN countries and corporations to accelerate energy transition through digital levers?' at the London School of Economics.

The panel of judges include Michele Pani (Partner at McKinsey & Co, London), Dr Kanes K. Rajah (Executive Director of Centre for Executive and Professional Development London), Dr Kogila Balakrishnan (Director of Client & Business Development at Warwick Manufacturing Group), and Paul Aron Thomas (Co-Founder of Horízōn, and Co-Founder and CEO of Ziraf).
The case competition was organised as part of the ASEAN-UK Business Forum.

The competition was jointly organised by ASEAN-UK Business Forum (AUBF), Warwick ASEAN Conference, LSESU ASEAN Society, with McKinsey & Company as the knowledge partner, and supported by Ms Merlene Emerson MBE.

These are privately owned properties comprising primarily of apartments, houses and individual rooms in houses available for rent.
Students are advised to liaise directly with the property owners or operators regarding off-campus accommodation.
It is advisable to gather the correct information and clarify details before deciding.
Note that you are likely to sign a one-year contract.
Although the University may assist in initiating the contact, It is ultimately a contract between the student and the landlord/operator.
Some options for off-campus accommodation include Taman Tasik Semenyih, UniVillage Management Sdn. Bhd., and Tetris Apartments.
Taman Tasik Semenyih is a housing estate located behind the university with terrace and bungalow houses available for rent.
UniVillage Management Sdn. Bhd. is located opposite the University's main entrance and offers furnished rooms, food and retail outlets, gym facilities, and study areas.
Tetris Apartments are located about 1.5 kilometres from the campus and include three blocks of walk-up flats within the Semenyih Lake Country Club.
Students are advised to liaise directly with the off-campus accommodation providers.
Off-campus accommodation is considered a private arrangement between the student and the property operators, and the university is not obligated or liable in any way.

The Setting and Achieving Goals workshop was held on 18 January 2020 at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Teaching Centre in Kuala Lumpur.
The workshop was designed to help alumni clearly define their goals and to set their purpose and direction of life.
The workshop used a range of learning tools and methods, including instructor-led training, role-play activities, props, and open learning.
The workshop included four sessions that required participants to write their goals, break them down into details, simplify them, and develop action plans.
By the end of the workshop, participants learned a SMART way to define their goals using GPS.
Participants took part in the Yee Sang tossing ceremony, in-conjunction with the Chinese New Year celebration.
The alumni found this workshop informative, worthwhile, and a good start for the new year.

The Inaugural Benefactors Evening was held on 9 May 2016 to raise funds for the pathways programme, to raise aspirations and provide education opportunities for local communities.

The UNMC Foundation was the brainchild of our Provost, Prof. Christine Ennew in her passion to provide education opportunities to those from disadvantaged backgrounds, as well as to enhance the quality of life of the community around us.

The UNMC is funding the education of two students from the indigenous Penan, Wanna and Amelia, in Sarawak. The two students shared their story of how education of the indigenous communities is very often overlooked in society’s fast paced growth and progress.

The Tropical Conservation Ecology Lab at UNMC focuses on the ecology and conservation of Asian megafauna. Their main project is studying the behavior and ecology of Malaysian elephants to aid the Malaysian government in making better-informed management decisions.

Current projects at the lab include The Management & Ecology of Malaysian Elephants (MEME), Impact of traditional agriculture on forest structure, and Terrestrial Ecosystem Assessment & Monitoring Network (TEAM) among others. The lab also focuses on urgent issues such as human-wildlife conflicts and assessing the effectiveness of mitigation strategies like elephant translocation and electric fencing.
Salman Saaban, the Director of Protected Areas in the Department of Wildlife and National Parks Peninsular Malaysia (PERHILITAN), emphasized the significance of the initiative.
The project centers around studying elephants' roaming behavior, habitat needs, and the impact of linear infrastructure on the elephants.

After the great apes, elephants are considered to be the world’s most intelligent land mammal.
Elephants are known to have remarkable memories and can make and use tools like using leafy branches as fly swatters.
Wild elephants help to maintain the forest’s ecosystem dynamics by playing a vital role in seed dispersal and nutrient cycling, known as mega-gardeners of the forest.

Asian elephants can grow up to 2.7 meters in height with a weight of between 3,000 and 6,000 kilograms, while African elephants can grow up to 3 meters in height and weigh between 4,000 and 7,500 kilograms.
GPS collars were used by MEME and PERHILITAN to track the movement of over 50 wild elephants to understand their range and how infrastructures like roads impact their movement.

Roads that cut across wildlife habitats can become barriers for elephants, hindering their movement from one side to the other. The presence of oncoming traffic also increases the risk of elephant mortality.
To mitigate conflict and prevent further loss of elephant range, it's important to support farmers so they can co-exist with wild elephants in shared landscapes.

Dr Sumit Mandal, Associate Professor in the School of Politics, History and International Relations, is intrigued by the era of interconnectedness between Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore. He situates the Malay world against the broader backdrop of the Indian Ocean to observe patterns of trade, migration, and cultural exchange. Dr Mandal published the book 'Becoming Arab: Creole histories and modern identity in the Malay world' with Cambridge University Press in 2018. This book explores Arab communities in the Malay world in the 16-18th centuries, tracing their origins to Hadhrami Arabs migrating from Yemen. In 2020, 'Becoming Arab' was awarded the Harry J. Benda book prize by the US-based Association for Asian Studies for Dr Mandal's outstanding scholarship in Southeast Asian studies.

HSK (Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi) is an international standardised exam that tests and rates Chinese language proficiency. It consists of six levels, from 1 to 6, assessing different language proficiency skills.
The HSK Speaking Test (HSKK) assesses the test takers' oral Chinese abilities and has three levels: Primary, Intermediate, and Advanced.

Non-native Chinese speakers, including Chinese Malaysians, can take the HSK exam to evaluate their Chinese language proficiency. The HSK certificate is essential for educational decisions, employment recruitment, and improving Chinese language proficiency.
Preparation for the HSK exam involves self-study, language courses, and practice exams; resources like textbooks, online courses, and study guides are helpful.
The HSK certificate does not have an expiration date, but validity requirements may vary for different organisations and employers.
Candidates can retake the HSK exam to improve their scores and proficiency level; there are no restrictions on the number of retakes.

The University of Nottingham Malaysia is proud to announce the return of the UNAM-UNM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Award Essay Competition in 2025!

The competition is open to all students aged 17 to 23 years in Malaysia. Submissions must be by a single author and focus on the topic 'Meaningful Education for a Nation's Progress, Innovation, and Inclusiveness.' The submissions should be between 1,500 to 2,000 words and meet various criteria like originality, understanding of education issues, and a persuasive call to action.

The prizes include RM 2,000.00 for the first prize, RM 1,500.00 for the second prize, and RM 1,000.00 for the third prize. The winning submissions will be chosen by a panel of judges from the University of Nottingham and the United Nations Association of Malaysia.

Entries to the competition must be unique and original in content. They should not be published elsewhere or submitted to other essay competitions. Plagiarized entries will be disqualified. A bibliography acknowledging references is necessary.
The deadline for submission is 02 April 2025, which falls on a Wednesday.

The challenges to food security in the region include rapid population growth, urbanization, climate change disasters, and breakdowns in traditional social safety nets. The FSSIDS network emphasizes South-South Learning and Cooperation, stressing the importance of SDG 17 for sustainable development in food systems. It aims to connect stakeholders, facilitate discussions, establish new opportunities, and encourage interdisciplinary collaborations in food systems in South-East Asia and South Pacific Islands.

Countries such as Australia, Fiji, Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Samoa, Singapore, Thailand, United Kingdom, and Vietnam are part of the FSSIDS community. The FSSIDS Working Group includes members like Chin Chiew Foan, Christina Supramaniam, Pau Loke Show, Ee Von Goh, Andrew Clarke, Peter Noy, and Lexi Earl.

One of the main methods is through anonymised Student Evaluation. They use a tool called Evaluate to capture Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) and Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) data.

Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) evaluates an individual lecturer, usually focusing on a specific teaching session. The scores are considered when the lecturer applies for promotion or confirmation in their employment.
The open-ended comments from SET remain confidential to the staff member being evaluated, ensuring privacy.

Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) assesses the overall learning experience for an entire module, focusing on learning resources and outcomes. Feedback from SEM is considered during the module review process to improve the module for future delivery.

Nottingham's first civic college was opened in the city centre in 1881, four years after the foundation stone was laid by former Prime Minister, W E Gladstone.
An anonymous benefactor offered £10,000 for a college on condition that a suitable building be erected by the Council and that the college should be provided with £4,000 a year.

After the First World War, the college outgrew its original building. A generous gift by Sir Jesse Boot of 35 acres of land at Highfields presented the solution, and in 1928, the College moved to what is now the main campus, University Park.

Dr Stephanie Evers is known for campaigning to dispel the myth that palm oil and other drainage-based agriculture can be developed on tropical peat soils.

The winners of the YM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen bin Tengku Ismail Essay Writing Competition 2017 were announced at the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus. The essay competition was a collaboration between the School of Politics, History, and International Relations (PHIR) of the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus and the United Nations Association of Malaysia (UNAM). The chosen topic for the essay competition was on Gender Equality, focusing on 'What Can be Done to Overcome Prejudice towards Gender Equality'.

The first prize winner was Govind Nair from Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak Campus. The second prize winner was Bavani Ponnurangam Chinnathambi from The University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus. The third prize winner was Emily Chen Sue Mei from UNMC. The Master of Engineering (Hons) in Electrical and Electronic Engineering at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) prepares students for dynamic careers at the forefront of technology and innovation. Accredited by the Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) and the Engineering Accreditation Council (EAC) Malaysia.

The curriculum integrates core engineering principles with innovative topics such as VLSI Design, Embedded Systems, Power Systems, Electrical Machines, Robotics, Drones, Autonomous Vehicles, Renewable Energy, Artificial Intelligence, Digital Signal Processing, and Software Programming.

To further enhance employability, the programme includes professional studies workshops led by experienced engineers and a mandatory industrial training module. Graduates emerge with advanced technical skills, project management expertise, and leadership capabilities, making them highly sought after by employers in sectors such as semiconductors, embedded systems, IoT, power generation, robotics, autonomous systems, renewable energy, telecommunications, and advanced technology.
This year's theme is 'Limitless: Education Beyond the Ordinary', focusing on students' limitless artistries through creativity and innovation.
